HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
A Return to Amherst and the Pioneer Valley

BYLINE: By SUSAN SPANO

 BODY:
SPRING in the Pioneer Valley of central Massachusetts is a glorious affair; almost all the trees bear lacy pink and white flowers, and you cannot step out of doors without smelling their perfumes. Or so I recalled, having spent my student years at Mount Holyoke, one of the colleges - Amherst, Smith, Hampshire, and the University of Massachusetts are the others - situated around the town of Amherst, a veritable New England Oxford. I had often contemplated returning is the valley to sample the season's pleasures, but had been deferred by the price. Renting a car from New York for three days costs almost $200, and even if you take the train to Springfield for a mere $51 round trip, you need to rent a car to reach the Five College Area. Amtrak offers service to Amherst as well, but the train, on its way to Montreal, stops in town at 2:40 A.M., and leaves for New York at 1:15 A.M.
 
 Last month, though, I called the Peter Pan bus company and learned that the round-trip fare between New York and Amherst is $37.95, with about 10 departures a day. The Amherst Chamber of Commerce helped me find a small local concern called North Amherst Motors where I reserved a car for $29.95 a day, and provided me with a list of lodging options, including the venerable Lord Jeffery Inn right on the town common, with 50 handsomely appointed rooms that rent for $80 to $120. As I was looking for something less expensive, I called several bed and breakfasts in the area and booked three nights in three different private homes for $40 to $65. Then I packed jeans, turtlenecks and clogs - if I could no longer be mistaken for a student, I could at least try to blend in - and boarded the bus at the Port Authority Terminal.
 It was pouring rain, and the trip north via New Haven, Hartford and Springfield was a boring four and a half hours long; but the bus driver treated his passengers like a brood of dizzy chicks, making sure everyone made the right connections. I spent much of the trip remembering how, as a very green freshman, I approached the area for the first time, also on a Peter Pan bus. As we neared Northampton (our first stop in the Five College Area), I saw fingers of dingy snow on the flanks of Mount Tom, crocuses in the mud at the bus stop and yellow-green coronas around the budding trees. Clearly, high spring was several weeks away; still, the interseasonal sogginess seemed a sign of life and raised another memory from my freshman year, that star of English Lit !, Cheucer, and a professor who delighted in reading aloud from "The Canterbury Tales."
 I was trying to remember what comes after "When that April with his shoures soote" as the bus stopped alongside Amherst Common. The gently sloping greensward is bordered by the gracious edifices of Amherst College, which was founded in 1821 by, among others, Noah Webster and Samuel Fowler Dickinson, grandfather of Emily.
 Both the town and the college were named for Lord Jeffrey Amherst, as his first name is usually spelled in reference books.
 A British Army general, he is said by some accounts to have devised a plan to decimate the Indian tribes of New England by infecting them with smallpox.
 Lord Amherst never visited the town and is hardly dearly beloved.
 Standing in a puddle, gazing at the mist-shrouded campus on the hill, I felt gratified to see that little had changed since the days when, with a heart full of trepidation, I used to come to Amherst for mixers. After a 10-minute walk through a neighborhood of lovely turn-of-the-century homes northwest of the campus where the poets Eugene Field and Robert Frost once lived, I arrived at the door of the Lincoln Avenue Bed and Breakfast, a capacious yellow Victorian with a broad front porch. There was no sign out front, and no one at home except a cat, though I had been told the owner would be there. The door, however, was unlocked, so I entered, a little like Goldilocks. Inside I found spotless polished wood floors, two front rooms almost completely devoid of furniture and a stack of business cards indicating that besides running a B & B, the mistress of the house taught yoga and practiced acupressure, presumably in the empty rooms.
 Hoping that there was more furniture in a bedroom upstairs, I left my bag and ventured back into the rain.
 I had a cappuccino and a slice of pumpkin bread for about $2.50 at a college hangout on the common called Bonducci's Cafe, noting that the students still favored the Lands' End look with holes. Then I cut a damp swath across the common, stopping at the Robert Frost Library, 750,000 volumes strong and one of the few modern buildings on campus, where I collected a Five College Calendar of Events and studied it. It was never too late to avail myself of the valley's cultural riches, I decided.
The Mead Art Museum, 200 paces beyond the library, came at the right price - free. It lies beside mighty Stearns Steeple, bereft of the church it pinnacked when it was built in 1873 (the church was demolished to make way for the museum); at intervals no one seems to be able to predict, chimes still resound from the steeple in memory of the college's Civil War dead. The museum is notable for its early American painting, for a protrait of a rather wan Lord Jeffery Amherst, by Sir Joshua Reynolds and the gorgeously paneled Rotherwas Room, built in 1611 in Herefordshire, England, and carted across the Atlantic for the Long Island Jacbean-style mansion of Herbert Lee Pratt, an Amherst benefactor.
 THE college's Museum of Natural History just to the south of the gallery (admission free) also bears the Pratt name, and is a pleasantly old-fashioned place, with glass-topped wooden display cases, two aquariums humming in the background and not a soul around when I visited. There I found three petrified dinosaur eggs and a topographical model of the valley, showing the low Holyoke Range to the south of Amherst, the great oxbow of the Connecticut River near Northampton, and a bit of the hill country stetching up toward New Hampshire and Vermont.
 As darkness fell, I returned to my B & B and met the people who lived there, Bonnie Novakov-Lawlor, barefoot and wearing a floor-length dress, her husband, Larry, a set designer and painter, and their young son, Josh. Bonnie showed me to my pretty room at the front of the house on the third floor, with a single sleigh bed, rocking chair, small desk and lace-curtained window. The large, immaculate bathroom, which I shared with two other guests, was several steps away, and had a clawfoot tub (with shower) and skylight: a terrycloth robe was provided to ease my passage down the hall. The place was homey - I could smell dinner cooking and hear the family at the table - and made me feel ike a grad student who had rented a room for the semester.
 I had dinner at Boltwood's Tavern in the Lord Jeffery Inn, less expensive than the hotel's formal dining room. A nicely presented grilled tuna steak and glass of California Merlot cost $19 with tip. However, I found better and more economical fare later at several of Amherst's cafes and ethnic restaurant, like Paradise of India on Main Street, where a heaping lunchtime portion of chicken biryani cost $5.25. Several doors down is the Black Sheep Cafe, a casual, woody place, with old Joni Mitchell songs piped in, delicious hazelnut coffee and a begulling pastry case. And at Bell's Pizza, near the University of Massachusetts, I was happy to learn that the tuna grinders (submarine sandwiches) are just as good as they used to be, not to mention just as cheap (about $3).
 That night I attended a concert called Women's Singing Traditions of New England in Buckley Recital Hall at Amherst for $12. It was nicely done, and the product of considerable ethnographic research, as the program explained, with female singers performing traditional music brought to this country by immigrants from French Canada, Bulgaria, Ireland, Greece, Portugal and Africa. But during the concert my eyelids drooped, and later I wished I had caught the "Five by Scorsese" film program across campus instead.
 The next day was devoted to touring, beginning with a job past Emily Dickinson's handsome brick homestead on Main Street (open by appointment), where I peeped in the window sacrilegiously, but caught no sight of the reclusive poet's ghost. After a nondescript breakfast at my B & B, Larry was kind enough to give me a lift to North Amherst. Motors, where I collected my ear, drove back to campus and took a tour of the college, led by an exuberant sophomore named Amanda, with wire-rimmed spectacles. The rest of the group consisted of a serious-looking young woman who had just been accepted by Amherst and her parents. As we traipsed across campus, I noted the new computer center and the bike path that leads all the way to Northampton, and learned that Amherst, which went coed in 1976, has a student body of 1,600, now about equality divided between the sexes.
 After the tour I browsed through the shops in the center of town, including the Jeffrey Amherst Bookstore, with a whole floor-to-ceiling shelf of volumes on Emily Dickinson, and stopped in at the Allen House Victorian Bed and Breakfast on Main Street, a B & B in a Stick-style Victorian home built in 1886. The Allen House, which has five bedrooms, all with private baths, was full when I called earlier in search of a room, which I really regretted once I saw the inn's hand silk-screened wallpaper, cherrywood maniels and glorious late 18th-century antiques, among them an Eastlake bed in which I yeared to sleep.
 And I ended the day with a visit to my alma mater, Mount Holyoke, in the hamlet of South Hadley, about 10 miles south of Amherst. Founded in 1837, it is the oldest women's college in the country, with a handsome campus designed by Fredrick Law Olmsted. There I paused by the grave of the founder, Mary Lyon, and thought about tender scenes from my past.
 I spent the night at the Northfield Country House, about 20 miles north of Amherst along Route 63, an idyllic country road perfect for biking. The B & B is a fieldstone and brown-shingle manor house secluded on a hilltop above the peaceful little town of Northfield. It has seven bedrooms that share four baths, a yawning stone fireplace in the living room and massive chestnut beams. My room had a double bed with a quilt spread and white wicker furniture, and the proprietor was graciousness itself, serving me a full breakfast the next morning and telling me about the hill towns' love affair with contra dancing, traditional line dances.
 After leaving, I toured two of the 13 restored Colonial-era homes in Old Deerfield Village, bought a pair of shoes in Northampton, took in the Monets, Picassos and Seurats at the Smith College Museum of Art, and strolled among the luxuriant greenery at Smith's Lyman Plant house. Exhausted, I bedded down in another B & B, called The Knoll, in the little town of Florence, just west of Northampton. Surrounded by 16 acres of farmland and forest, it was a peaceful spot, and my doubled-bedded room was comfortable, but I liked the tub in the bathroom down the hall best - it was so long I could stretch out in it fully. During my 13 hours at the Knoll, I took two baths.
 Really, though, I should have stayed in Amherst all three days of my visit, preferably at the Allen House; that way, I could have avoided renting a car by taking the free Five College bus that runs around the valley during the academic year. My lodging bill would have been roughly the same, about $175 for three nights, as would meals and entertainment, which cost me under $100 for three very full days; but my transportation expenses would have been $37.95 rather than $113. And I should have gone in May, just to smell that thickly perfumed air.
 But I'm not complaining: I still have my memories.
 
The bottom line in Amherst
 
Getting There
 Peter Pan, a member of the National Trailways Bus System, (800)237-8747, offers a round-trip rate between New York and Amherst of $37.95.
 Amtrak, (212)582-6875, has train service to Amherst from New York for $52 round trip, and to Springfield from New York for $51 round trip.
 
Getting Around
 The Five College Bus System operates during the academic year along four different routes between Mount Holyoke in South Hadley; Hampshire College, the University of Massachusetts, Amherst and Smith College in Northampton. No fare is charged and anyone can use it. For schedules, call (413)588-5806.
 Free, student-led tours of the Amherst College campus begin at the Office of Admissions, (413)542-2328. From May 31 to Sept. 2 they will be offered from Monday to Friday at 10 A.M., noon, 2 and 4 P.M.
 North Amherst Meters, 78 Old Sunderland Road, North Amherst, (413)549-2880, has a fleet of rental cars that include compact models renting for $29.95 a day, not including tax or insurance. The first 100 miles a day are free, with a charge of 20 cents a mile for each additional mile.
 Valley Bicycles, 319 Main Street, Amherst, (413)256-0880, rents bikes by the half day ($10), day ($18), weekend ($35) and week ($60).
 
Where to Stay
 The Amherst Area Chamber of Commerce, 11 Spring Street, Amherst, Mass. 01002, (413)253-0700, is open Monday to Friday from 9 A.M. to 3:30 P.M.
 I can supply information on accommodations as well as area attractions and restaurants.
 The Alien House Victorian Bed and Breakfast, 599 Main Street, Amherst, Mass. 01002, (413)253-5000, has five rooms with private baths. Full breakfast and afternoon tea. Rates from $45 to $105.
 Lincoln Avenue Bed and Breakfast, 242 Lincoln Avenue, Amherst, Mass. 01002, (413)549-0517, has three bedrooms with a shared bath. The room rate is $65, with breakfast.
 Northfield Country House, 181 School Street, Northfield, Mass. 01360, (413)498-2692, has seven bedrooms that share four baths.
 Rates from $50 to $80, with a full breakfast.
 The Knoll Bed and Breakfast, 230 North Main Street, Florence, Mass. 01060, (413)584-8164, has three rooms that share two baths. Single $45, double $55 and $60.
 Berkshire Bed & Breakfast Homes, (413)268-7244, is a reservation service that offers B & B style accommodations in private homes in western Massachusetts.
 Rates vary from $45 to $185 a night. It charges an $8 booking fee. S.S.

HEADLINE: Tyson Foods Behaved Properly With Clintons

 BODY:
To the Editor:
With regard to "Mrs. Clinton Steps Forward" (editorial, April 24):
(1) The poultry industry is heavily regulated, but it is regulated primarily by the Federal Government, not by individual states. 
 (2) The tax credits you refer to were earned, not given, to Tyson Foods by Bill Clinton or the State of Arkansas. A few important points:
* These credits were received pursuant to legislation passed by the Arkansas General Assembly to foster economic development in the state.
* None of these programs targeted the poultry industry. They were, and are, available to any industry that spends money in the state to build new or improve old facilities or create jobs. One of the pieces of legislation passed in 1985 was enacted primarily to benefit the timber industry and International Paper Company specifically.
* Tyson Foods is only the fourth largest user of these credits, behind International Paper, Georgia Pacific and Nucor Steel.
* In Arkansas since 1985, Tyson has invested more than $300 million and created approximately 4,000 jobs to earn the credits.
* These programs are not substantially different from similar programs available in all the 49 other states. We are seeking sites for three new poultry complexes, and have received proposals from 150 communities in 25 states, all of them offering some form of economic development incentive. Many of them offer much more than Arkansas does. Yesterday, we announced a new plant to be constructed in Portland, Ind.
The relationship of Jim Blair, a Tyson lawyer, with Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton, and Mrs. Clinton's commodities trading, had absolutely nothing to do with Tyson Foods.
The tax credits that we received were earned by the company's commitment to doing business in Arkansas, and they were certainly not the result of some sort of insidious activity or "Arkansas mores," as you imply.
 
ARCHIE R. SCHAFFER 3D
Director of Media, Public and
Governmental Affairs, Tyson Foods
Springdale, Ark., April 26, 1994

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT NAMES BLACK DEMOCRAT ADVISER ON HAITI

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
After a six-week review of an Administration policy that he said is no longer "sustainable," President Clinton appointed a well-known black Democrat today as his new special adviser on Haiti. The President also announced plans to allow Haitian refugees hearings at sea to determine whether they should be granted asylum.
Mr. Clinton said that the evidence of mounting political violence in Haiti made the new asylum policy necessary and asserted that the United States also considered it necessary for domestic and foreign policy reasons to use sanctions to force a return to democracy. 
 "The United States has clear interests at stake in ending this crisis," he said.
The new adviser on Haiti is William H. Gray 3d, the president of the United Negro College Fund and a former Congressman who served 12 years in the House of Representatives. Mr. Gray will replace Lawrence A. Pezzullo, the veteran diplomat and former Ambassador to Nicaragua who was forced to leave his post after efforts to oust the Haitian military Government failed.
By enlisting a prominent black political figure, the Administration hopes to ease domestic pressure and position itself to combat charges raised by Haiti's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, and members of the Congressional Black Caucus that United States policy toward Haiti has been racist in outcome, if not intent.
Much of the detail for implementing the policy changes will now fall to Mr. Gray. It is unclear what his specific duties will be, or how he will work with Ambassador William L. Swing in Port-au-Prince.
Father Aristide pronounced the change in refugee policy "a step in the right direction." And Randall Robinson, the executive director of the TransAfrica Forum, whose 27-day fast to force a policy change had become a focal point for critics, ended the fast in response. [Page A7.]
Under current policy, Haitians are able to apply for asylum only in Port-au-Prince. Haitians caught on the high seas are returned to Haiti by Coast Guard vessels.
But today's action also highlighted the continuing problems with United States policy toward Haiti. Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, the military leader who led the coup that ousted Father Aristide in 1991, signaled in a televised interview that he would not resign to prevent the imposition of new United Nations sanctions set to take effect on May 21.
"The superior interests of the nation order me to favor always dialogue to reach a solution to this crisis," General Cedras said on the NBC News program "Meet the Press."
"Of course, he's going to say that," Mr. Clinton responded later in the day. "That's what he told us when he abrogated the Governors Island accord." Under the accord, reached last summer, the military agreed to hand over power to Father Aristide.
 
Using Larger Ships
 The United States has attempted shipboard processing of Haitians seeking asylum before, but officials rescinded that policy after the small Coast Guard cutters quickly became overrun with dehydrated passengers who spoke no English and were unprepared for the interviews.
Mr. Clinton said the new policy would address those logistical concerns by providing larger ships for the processing and seeking cooperation from friendly countries who would allow processing to be conducted on shore.
"We think we can do them fairly quickly, in a matter of a few days," Mr. Clinton said, "and then return those who should be returned and take those who should be taken into the United States."
Mr. Clinton appealed to a domestic and an international audience today as he declared that the United States had clear interests at stake in ending the Haitian crisis.
"We have an interest in bolstering the cause of democracy in the Americas," Mr. Clinton said. "We have an interest in insuring the security of our citizens living and working in Haiti. We have an interest in stopping the gross human rights violations and abuses of the military and their accomplices. And we clearly have a humanitarian interest in preventing a massive and dangerous exodus of Haitians by sea."
Father Aristide said the revised immigration policy did not go far enough. "It will not protect the millions of Haitian citizens who continue to face increased violence in Haiti," he said in a statement.
Mr. Clinton said today that the policy of returning refugees to Haiti, which he continued after initially denouncing it during the 1992 campaign, had worked well last year but had been outpaced by events. "I do not believe that is a sustainable policy, either practically or morally, given the level of indiscriminate violence," he said.
A White House official said the United States was still searching for countries to take part in the new plan. Putting it into effect will take at least two weeks, the official said.
Until then, Mr. Clinton said, all Haitians retrieved from boats by United States Coast Guard cutters would be returned to Haiti.
Mr. Clinton defended the United Nations decision to impose a full embargo on trade with Haiti, even though his advisers conceded that it would also create considerable hardship for many ordinary Haitians.
"While these stronger sanctions will cause more hardships for innocent Haitians, we must be clear," Mr. Clinton said. "The military leaders bear full responsibility for this action. They can stop the suffering of their people by giving up power, as they themselves agreed to do, and allowing the restoration of democracy and the return of President Aristide."
White House officials said that Mr. Gray, who will continue as president of the United Negro College Fund, would serve for 130 days as a unpaid temporary Government employee.
The 52-year-old Mr. Gray earned a reputation as a coalition-builder before he left Congress in 1991 to head the United Negro College Fund.
Mr. Gray left for South Africa today as part of the official United States delegation to the inauguration of Nelson Mandela as President.

International A2-7
 
DETAILS ON NEW HAITI POLICY
President Clinton named a new envoy to Haiti, a well-known black Democrat, and discussed details of the new policy of allowing asylum hearings for Haitian refugees. A1
HAITI ABUSES QUESTIONED
President Clinton reaffirmed his support for the exiled President of Haiti, but a cable from the American Ambassador there has charged that the President's supporters exaggerated human rights abuses. A7
A fast over Haiti policy was worth it, an activist said. A7
THE TOLL OF WAR IN ANGOLA
In Angola's rebel stronghold, life is a struggle, with no electricity or running water and little food or medicine, but the potential wealth of the country allows one of Africa's longest civil wars to continue. A1
IMPATIENCE IN JERICHO
The Israeli occupation is supposed to end in Jericho, but so far little has changed. The first contingent of the Palestinian police force was just six miles away, though, awaiting the signal to enter the area. A1
An international force went to Hebron to keep order. A3
SOUTH AFRICA'S CHALLENGE
Two men with very different backgrounds have responsibility in South Africa's new Cabinet for a complex task: improving the lives of the new electorate while protecting the stability of the economy. A6
THE BASIC ISSUE IN BOSNIA
News Analysis: the town of Brcko, seen as the next flash point of Bosnian conflict, is also a sign of why the war is unlikely to end soon: Muslims are fighting to go home to areas cleared by the Serbs. A2
HEADING FOR BRAZIL
American business people are flocking to Brazil in a new display of confidence that economic ties between the two nations will revolve around trade and investment. D1
 
Ex-Communists were ahead in Hungary's elections. A5
A businessman was winning Panama's presidential elections. A5
Seoul Journal: In North's shadow, picnics, not panic. A4
 
National A8-14
 
PRESSURE ON THE FED
The Federal Reserve is preparing to raise short-term rates for the fourth time in four months, but it is under pressure to act more quickly and more sharply this time. A1

HEADLINE: Pressure Grows On Fed to Raise Rate Yet Again

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
For the fourth time in four months, the Federal Reserve is preparing to raise short-term interest rates. But its orderly plan to contain inflation might be disrupted by turbulence in the bond and currency markets, which is putting great pressure on the central bank to act more quickly and raise rates more sharply this time, economists said this weekend.
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has signaled for a year, in appearances before Congress, an intention to raise interest rates before inflation begins to creep up again. But a spectacular rise in long-term interest rates on Friday and the sagging value of the dollar in international trading have shown a broad lack of confidence by many investors in the Fed's ability to control inflation, economists said. 
 As a result, they see the issue before the central bank as no longer whether to increase the short-term rates that banks pay to borrow money, but how early and how high.
Raising these short-term rates would dampen the potentially inflationary growth this spring of bank loans, and of the overall economy, since banks tend to make fewer loans and charge higher interest when they have to pay more to borrow money. Without low-interest loans, many companies could no longer afford to build factories and fewer individuals could afford to buy cars, slowing economic growth and inflation.
Higher rates could reassure bond investors, who worry that inflation will make their fixed, semiannual interest payments worth less over the years. Yet higher short-term rates are also likely to mean that consumers pay more interest on adjustable-rate mortgages, car loans and credit cards. While the Clinton Administration has reluctantly come to accept the need for some further increase in rates, Democratic members of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress warned on Tuesday that higher rates might not just restrain economic growth but stop it.
Higher rates for short-term loans, like the overnight borrowing by banks that the Federal Reserve most closely controls, also tend to produce temporary increases in long-term interest rates for mortgages and 30-year Treasury bonds. But in the longer run, which may mean months or years, higher short-term rates tend to hold down long-term rates by preventing banks from making so many loans that they fuel inflation.
The most common view among economists and former governors of the Federal Reserve who were interviewed this weekend was that the central bank would wait until the regularly scheduled meeting of its interest-rate policy committee on May 17 to raise rates again, partly because new figures on inflation in producer and consumer prices will be available by then.
"If they were going to raise rates on the basis of Friday's news, they would have done so on Friday," Lyle E. Gramley, a former governor of the Federal Reserve, said today.
 
Larger Rate Rise Expected
 Mr. Gramley and other economists said the next increase in short-term rates was likely to be half a percentage point, compared with just a quarter-percentage point in each of the previous three moves.
An increase could come in the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other, or in the key discount rate, which the Fed charges banks for overnight loans and which has remained at 3 percent, or in both rates.
The economists said that a further slump in the value of the dollar against other currencies could force the Federal Reserve to act sooner.
Some traders have suggested that investors could panic if the Federal Reserve does not move immediately to raise rates, but Wall Street economists tend to play down this worry. "If the Fed doesn't raise rates, there might be a few apoplectic analysts but the market will only erode a little bit," said Robert Giordano, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Steep rises in long-term interest rates clearly worry top Federal Reserve officials. J. Alfred Broaddus Jr., the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond and one of the 10 current members of the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee, said in an interview on April 29 that the level and stability of long-term interest rates were good measures of the central bank's effectiveness and credibility.
Mr. Broaddus and other members of the Open Market Committee have declined to comment in the last few days on financial markets.
The yield on 30-year Treasury bonds soared on Friday to 7.54 percent from 7.33 percent, the biggest one-day rise since just after Iraq invaded Kuwait in August 1990. Rates rose after the Labor Department said the economy created 267,000 more jobs in April, a sign of strength economists had not expected.
 
Predicting Impact on Dollar
 If the Open Market Committee raises short-term interest rates, this might prop up the sagging dollar by encouraging foreign investors to buy dollars so as to invest in American bonds. If the committee waits and the dollar drops through key psychological barriers, like trading at less than 100 Japanese yen for the first time since World War II, then subsequent increases in rates might not succeed in pushing the dollar back up again.
A collapse of the dollar would feed inflation by making foreign goods more expensive in the United States. A lower dollar would also make it easier for American manufacturers to raise prices for goods that they sell in competition with imports.
But this analysis, which relies heavily on economic theory, has its critics. Some analysts have suggested that the anticipated effect on the dollar may be outweighed by the extent to which potential investors in the dollar have borrowed huge sums to bet on low interest rates. Another rise in rates could hurt these investors and leave them unable to continue to buy dollars, these analysts contend, causing the American currency to fall farther.
Federal Reserve officials generally pay less attention to the dollar's strength against other currencies than to long-term interest rates. The dollar can sometimes fall not because investors dislike the United States as a place to invest but because other countries may have made themselves temporarily more attractive through high interest rates or shrinking government budget deficits.
When it comes to monetary policy, "you ought to set your policy for what is right for you," leaving aside other countries' policies, Robert D. Laurent, a senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, said.
Three times this year, the Federal Reserve has raised its target for the interest rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans. The first two increases, each of a quarter-percentage point, came at the last two meetings, on Feb. 4 and March 22. The most recent increase, another quarter-point, raising the rate to 3.75 percent, came halfway between meetings, on April 18.
 
Possibly, a Slow Period
 Financial markets may do the Federal Reserve a favor by quieting down in the next several days simply for lack of economic news. No Government agencies have scheduled the release of any economic indicators for Monday, Tuesday or Wednesday. According to a calendar prepared by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, no other such lulls of equal length have occurred or will occur this year.
If the Federal Reserve does raise rates, the odds seem excellent that the Fed will announce it, because of strong support for the idea among the Fed's top officials. Breaking with 80 years of tradition, the Fed has announced all three of its rate increases so far this year and is considering a permanent policy of doing so.
Mr. Broaddus said in Richmond that the announcements had not roiled financial markets excessively and showed that the Fed is more open than its critics have suggested. "There seems to me to be advantages to announcing our decisions more promptly," he said.
Alan S. Blinder, President Clinton's nominee to become the Fed's next vice chairman, said at his Senate confirmation hearing on Friday that he also favored prompt disclosure.

HEADLINE: Casinos Became Big Players In the Overhaul of Welfare

SERIES: Special Pleaders: A periodic look at lobbying.

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
Earlier this spring, Senator Harry Reid, a Nevada Democrat, stood on the White House lawn and issued a threat. If President Clinton went forward with part of his contemplated welfare plan, he said, "I will become the most negative, the most irresponsible, the most obnoxious person of anyone in the Senate."
Nevada politicians are not known for being passionate about welfare. But Mr. Reid was incensed that the Administration was considering a gambling tax to pay for part of the plan, and he and other allies of the gambling industry around the country set out to do something about it. 
 Viewing the idea as an economic death threat, Gov. Bob Miller of Nevada, also a Democrat, flew to Washington in a panic; the Nevada delegation implored Congressional colleagues, and casinos hired prominent lobbyists at fees of up to $70,000 a month.
Two weeks ago, Mr. Clinton put the Governor's mind to rest with a call to say he had abandoned the idea of the tax. The move was a turning point in the Administration's yearlong attempt to craft a welfare bill: officials said it meant that Mr. Clinton had decided to propose a smaller plan than some of his aides wanted, with about $3 billion less for new child-care programs.
White House aides play down the importance of the lobbying campaign, saying Mr. Clinton based his decision less on the merits of a gambling tax than on a desire to avoid any tax. "He ultimately made the decisions because he did not want a tax proposal of any kind," said Marcia Hale, the White House director of intergovernmental affairs.
Still, the potential alienation of four Senate Democrats, from Nevada and New Jersey, on this and other issues could not have been absent from the calculations. And the underlying story, at once quirky and commonplace, illustrates the way the capital is patrolled by vigilant, organized interests.
This may be the first time that casinos have helped shape welfare policy, but virtually every Government attempt to raise money or cut spending sets into motion similar campaigns from business or advocacy groups eager to protect their stakes. Often, as in the gambling debate, the efforts are led by former government officials, now earning lucrative livings as lobbyists. Just in the last few weeks, the White House has also been worked over by groups representing insurance companies and a coalition of nonprofit groups seeking to protect the rights of immigrants. The groups fear the welfare plan may be financed at their expense.
In the case of gambling, word leaked in March that the White House was seriously considering a possible 4 percent tax on gross gambling receipts. That is the amount casinos or horse tracks take in after paying winners but before paying other expenses, like salaries, rent or utilities. The Administration estimated the tax would raise about $3 billion over five years.
"I immediately flew back to D.C.," said Governor Miller in a telephone interview last week. As one of the first governors to endorse Mr. Clinton and the chairman of his Nevada campaign, Mr. Miller had a few political cards to play.
At a March 24 meeting, Mr. Miller and the state's two Democratic senators told Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the White House chief of staff, that the tax would devastate Nevada's most important industry.
They said the move could close 57 of the state's 189 gaming operations at a cost of 30,000 jobs -- with small gambling houses the most imperiled.
They followed up with a similar letter the following day, also signed by Democratic Senators Barbara A. Mikulski of Maryland, Wendell H. Ford of Kentucky and Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey, all of whom count race tracks or casinos among their constituents.
But the Nevada group also made a broader argument, intended to appeal to other states and to Mr. Clinton's sensibility as a former governor. They told Mr. McLarty that the taxation of gambling had traditionally been a state prerogative and that a Federal tax might bring similar encroachments into other state areas.
 
Lobbyists Join Fight
 The officials' efforts were followed by those of private lobbyists. At Senator Reid's suggestion, the Nevada Resort Association hired Paul Laxalt, a former Republican Senator. The group is paying Mr. Laxalt $40,000 a month to lobby Senate Republicans.
The association also hired Lloyd Hand, a former aide in the Johnson White House, for about $70,000 a month to lobby Senate Democrats.
Mr. Miller said that when he had returned to Nevada, he had called all 49 other governors, urging them to sign a letter to Mr. Clinton opposing the tax. Thirty-three of them did.
On April 25, before the letter was officially delivered, Mr. Clinton called Governor Miller and said the tax was dead.
"He said, 'You've made a very persuasive argument,' " Mr. Miller said of his talk with the President.
The Governor, who is up for re-election this year, convened a news conference within 15 minutes to share what most Nevadans regard as extremely good news.
Other lobbies embroiled in similar battles are hoping for similar results. Richard S. Schweiker, the president of the American Council of Life Insurance, has issued a statement threatening "a firestorm of protest" if the White House pursues a contemplated change in the tax on annuities. Mr. Schweiker is a former Republican Senator from Pennsylvania.
A coalition of nonprofit groups is fighting a possible White House proposal that would cut the amount of aid available to indigent immigrants.
The coalition has been highlighting the proposal's effect on Jewish immigrants from Russia, rather than Hispanics immigrants, who are thought to have less political power.
"It lets them go directly at Jewish members of Congress," said someone who has been lobbied.
For the casinos, the immediate threat is over, but the lobbying campaign is not. A publicist for Mr. Hand said this week that the coalition has hired Rudolph G. Penner, a former director of the Congressional Budget Office, to do a state-by-state analysis of the impact of a tax, in case anyone else proposes one.
Asked how long he thinks this lobbying effort will last, Mr. Laxalt laughed and said, "We could be doing this for 15 or 20 years."

HEADLINE: Giuliani's Policy Point Man Is a Quiet No. 2

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
In the days after he was elected, Rudolph W. Giuliani scratched the title of First Deputy Mayor out of the government organization chart. But he clearly has not eliminated the job.
To the contrary, Peter J. Powers, the shy, self-effacing Deputy Mayor for operations, has emerged over the last four months as the strongest second-in-command seen at City Hall in years, despite a profile so low that a police officer recently asked him for identification when he tried to enter the building. 
 He is the point man for Mr. Giuliani on both policy execution and on politics, roles that were traditionally split up in the Koch and Dinkins administrations, sometimes creating warring fiefs. And his 35-year friendship with Mr. Giuliani, dating back to their days in Catholic school, gives him an unrivaled authority rare in politics.
"He's not officially the First Deputy Mayor, but because of the nature of his relationship with the Mayor, in fact he is the first friend," said John S. Dyson, the Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development. "And we all treat him with greater deference than anyone else."
It is as if the two men are alter egos, Mr. Giuliani the public persona, Mr. Powers the private one; one man setting policy the other carrying it out; one man constantly storming the talk-show circuit, the other so contained that he can seem to be rationing words. And the symbiosis has won praise from such unexpected quarters as Representative Charles E. Schumer, the Brooklyn Democrat, who said he knows that a message delivered to Mr. Powers gets directly to Mr. Giuliani, without a separate agenda or ego interfering.
It was not what the insiders had predicted.
On the December day when Mr. Powers was named to office, his hands clutching a prepared statement to read before a bank of television cameras, political savants predicted that the tax lawyer would be a rank amateur in the rough-and-tumble politics of City Hall. They also said the job would strain the relationship between him and the Mayor as surely as the Clintons have become estranged from the Arkansas friends who followed them to Washington.
But Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Powers both say Mr. Giuliani's two pressure-filled campaigns for Mayor, with Mr. Powers as his campaign manager, had already taught them that their friendship would not wane. "In '89 that was my biggest concern -- would it affect our personal relationship?" Mr. Powers said. "We both felt it had not."
And so far, though Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Powers share a level of combativeness jarring to other civic leaders accustomed to more civility and compromise in governance, their missteps have not been grave. And it is too early to tell whether the style, over time, will cow potential adversaries into submission to Mr. Giuliani's policies or leave enough political wounds and quiet enemies to come back and haunt the Mayor.
 
Dodging the Limelight
 There is nothing flamboyant about Mr. Powers, a lifelong Republican whom Mr. Giuliani describes as an "old-fashioned conservative" who believes in fiscal constraint. Though he is usually watching nearby whenever the Mayor is publicly coping with crisis or stage-managing success, he stays out of the limelight, standing as if he would simply prefer to blend into the wall.
He has City Hall's premier power office and a commanding view down the building's main corridor, where one can watch the milling of lobbyists, journalists, City Council members and all the seekers of government's special favors. But he keeps his door closed and unlike Norman Steisel, his predecessor in the Dinkins administration, rarely stands surveying his kingdom.
Inside the office, his computer is programmed to carry a large rotating message in blue, like a personal Times Square electronic billboard, endlessly blinking "Power on Loan," to remind him, he says, that his power and position are temporary, subject to the voters' approval.
His voice is low and his style is discreet to the point of being secretive when he is questioned about the inner councils of the Giuliani administration. Press him for an example of a moment when he has disagreed with the Mayor and he will demur that there are "a few examples but I just never like to talk about them publicly." Ask him what is the most wrenching budget cut the administration has decided on to close the city's $2.3 billion deficit, and he declines again to answer. Ask him if it is true that he is more conservative than Mr. Giuliani and he laughs and replies: "I don't know. I can't answer that."
 
'I Would Not Deny That'
 Even when he does give away information, he does so with phrases like "I would not deny that," as if he cannot quite bring himself to confirm a detail of the inner workings of government.
But inside the administration, he is such a force that the one recurring criticism of him is that he is too controlling. He is the adviser the Mayor counts on as a sounding board in times of crisis, relying on his instincts on matters like the recent unrest on Staten Island after the death of 22-year-old Ernest Sayon in police custody.
"When I was figuring out what to do about Staten Island, I made sure to talk to him four or five times," Mr. Giuliani said. "And when we went out there, I made sure he was there. He gave me an independent assessment of who are the people you can rely on, and who are the people you couldn't rely on." Mr. Giuliani is a hands-on Mayor, intimately involved in decision-making and setting his administration's policies. But much of the Mayor's job is to meet the public, stopping at schools and ribbon cuttings, giving luncheon addresses, and making the rounds of political dinners. And Mr. Giuliani trusts Mr. Powers to be the one left behind at City Hall to see his policies are being carried out.
 
Court of First and Last Resort
 And so it was Mr. Powers who was the first and last level of appeal for many of the commissioners seeking relief from the job reduction targets imposed on them by Mr. Giuliani's budget director, aides said. Only highly sensitive debates, like those concerning the Human Resources Administration, went on to the Mayor, though Mr. Powers said he also brought each one of his decisions to Mr. Giuliani "so he could bless it."
Mr. Powers was the Mayor's chief negotiator the weekend a feud with Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines was patched up, with Mr. Powers almost turning up late that Saturday for his own 50th birthday party. He personally lobbied City Council members recently in a futile effort to stop a bill that would give the Council the right to hold hearings on the administration's privatization initiatives. And he is the one the state's Republican and Liberal Party leaders reach out to when they want Mr. Giuliani to appear at a political event like the state Republican convention later this month in New York City.
Administration officials say Mr. Powers has also emerged as a troubleshooter, the one to carry problems to Mr. Giuliani, the one to try to argue him out of a position the staff feels is wrong, and the one to lighten meetings with humor when they become too intense. "Peter can be blunt with the Mayor," said Cristyne F. Lategano, Mr. Giuliani's press secretary. "He's the closest person to him other than Donna," she said, referring to Mr. Giuliani's wife.
For his part, Mr. Powers said simply: "I'm not afraid of losing my job if I give him bad news. I don't know if anybody else is, but I know that I'm not."
 
A Zealot to Some
 Though some City Council members and their aides see Mr. Powers as a zealot, unable to handle dissent, Giuliani advisers describe him as flexible, open to ideas, and sometimes more willing than the Mayor to reach out to a rival.
Aides say Mr. Powers recently tried to get Mr. Giuliani to invite Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President and a potential mayoral challenger, to a news conference on domestic-violence initiatives that borrowed heavily from a report by Ms. Messinger and another Democrat, City Councilwoman Ronnie Eldridge. Three times Mr. Powers went back at the Mayor, finally smiling and saying "At the risk of offending you, I'd really urge you to reconsider."
"Anyone else in the Cabinet might have tried two times," said one aide, explaining Mr. Powers's self-assurance in dealing with Mr. Giuliani. "Peter tried three times." The Mayor, however, refused.
Mr. Powers has also moved to shield administration members from blame, when he thinks it is unwarranted, as he did last month when Mr. Dyson came under siege by editorial writers who criticized a $50 million offer the city made to prod the Metropolitan Transportation Authority into completing the deal to sell the New York Coliseum to the developer Mortimer B. Zuckerman.
Since Mr. Zuckerman also owns The Daily News, which endorsed Mr. Giuliani in his campaign last November, the critics suggested that his administration was providing special favors for the developer.
Although Mr. Giuliani scuttled the offer and told reporters it was Mr. Dyson's idea, Mr. Powers quickly told the Mayor that the idea was his.
"I didn't want anybody taking heat for my mistakes," Mr. Powers explained. "I went and said, 'Look, this was mine. John and I were kind of batting ideas around. I came up with this idea and we both liked it, but this was mine.' "
 
'Laying Down the Law'
 But he is not always magnanimous. Mr. Powers can be tough when needed, said administration officials and aides who worked with him as campaign manager, adding that to cross him is to risk losing access to Mr. Giuliani. "I've heard him laying down the law to commissioners -- you will do this -- with the clearly implicit tone that there are other people available," said one Giuliani administration official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
When Mr. Powers wanted balky Council Republicans to defy the Speaker and vote against the City Council's operations budget as too high, he sent Jack Lynn, the administration's lobbyist, to the lawmakers with a crude anatomical suggestion, according to one Republican who was there. The gentle Mr. Lynn has since been told he is being shifted to another position, and Council members say he told them that he and Mr. Powers had a stylistic difference.
Though an outsider to government until now, Mr. Powers already sounds much like one of the policy wonks who held his job in administrations past, as he speaks of the intricacies of government and the management challenges. Asked to tell of the greatest risk he had taken, he points not to any of the administration's bruising battles over budget or policy, but to a decision to move a prison cooking operation from Rockland County back to New York City. He volunteers that what he is most proud of is his work immediately after a plane ran off a runway at LaGuardia Airport to get the Parks Department to drop its opposition to a long-planned runway extension.
"If I had any doubts, it is very governable, the city of New York," Mr. Powers said recently, his first four months behind him. "I'm convinced of that. It's very governable."

HEADLINE: Businessman Appears to Oust 'Old Guard' in Panama Election

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PANAMA, May 8

 BODY:
A left-of-center businessman who remade the image of his party after its disgrace under Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega has won Panama's first democratic elections in more than a quarter of a century, according to exit polls and early official results this evening.
The expected victor, Ernesto Perez Balladares, 48, an American-educated banker and former Government minister, overcame the stigma attached to General Noriega by recalling the image of another former dictator, Gen. Omar Torrijos. 
 With nearly half of the vote counted by midnight Eastern time, Mr. Balladares had more than 33 percent and declared victory. "The elections are over now, the campaign is over now," he said in a brief declaration, adding that he would seek to assure that Panama is "a free country, an independent country, a sovereign country."
Mireya Moscoso de Gruber, the widow of the former President, Arnulfo Arias, who was elected in the last open election in 1968 before being overthrown by the military, was projected to come in second with 28 percent.
Placing a distant third was Ruben Blades, a salsa singer and Hollywood star.
The election comes just five years after General Noriega's ouster in a United States military invasion and is a stinging defeat for Panama's traditional elite, which was handed power after the invasion.
Mr. Balladares has promised a growing economy with more jobs and a greater role in public life for Panama's middle and lower classes.
Most of the early returns were from rural areas, where Miss Moscoso was strongest, and exit polls indicated that nationwide, Mr. Blades and his party, Papa Egoro, or Mother Earth Party, would win nearly a quarter of the vote.
Mr. Blades offered many Panamanians the promise of an end to racial and economic elitism in a country that is ethnically diverse but starkly stratified.
In helping to rebuild General Noriega's political base, the Revolutionary Democratic Party, Mr. Balladares carefully distanced himself from the former dictator, recently calling him the worst leader since Panama's independence from Colombia in 1903. General Noriega is serving a 40-year prison sentence in Florida for drug trafficking.
Mr. Balladares achieved success by taking up the mantle of the late General Torrijos, the party's founder and a former military ruler, who remains a national hero.
Among those voicing hope in Mr. Balladares was Pedro Garcia, a 38-year-old voter in San Miguelito, a hilly neighborhood that was the scene of intense strafing by United States forces in the 1989 invasion.
"There is runaway unemployment and runaway corruption here, and Toro is the only one who can stop that," Mr. Garcia said, referring to Mr. Balladares by his nickname, Bull, for his imposing build. "Toro bore no responsibility for the Noriega era."
After decades of deep involvement in Panamanian affairs, the United States seemed to have no clear favorite in the vote.
"For 150 years, for the United States, the result was more important than the process here," said Richard Millet, an expert in Panamanian history at the University of Southern Illinois, who came to Panama as an election observer. "Now it is the process that matters, because if the process works right, it gives results we can live with."
With recent elections marred by wholesale fraud or by bitter and tense campaigning, today's vote seemed remarkably settled. Panamanians turned out in large numbers early in the day and the process was widely reported to have been orderly.
Among 1,200 international and Panamanian observers was a team of about 30 led by former President Jimmy Carter. "Reports from the various observers and officials all suggest that everything is going well," Mr. Carter said.

HEADLINE: Stocks Lower in Japan

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, May 9

 BODY:
Japanese stock prices were modestly lower here today. Well into the afternoon trading session, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 71.31 points, or 0.36 percent, to stand at 19,791.16. On Friday, the index rose 1.49 percent. Today, stocks fell at the opening, propelled by Friday's news, according to traders, of stronger than expected job growth in the United States and fear of inflation. But the traders cited optimism that the dollar had stopped falling against the yen, as the result of support from many nations' central banks, saying they expected this to help stabilize stock prices.

HEADLINE: Freshman Withstands Volley of Calls on Guns

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LONG BEACH, Calif., May 7

 BODY:
Connie Szeibl was having fun. The threats from opponents of gun control, the invective, the words she had to lower her voice to repeat: she typed them up faithfully -- "you jackass" and all -- and passed them on to her boss, Representative Steve Horn.
"You don't know the threats we received," said Mrs. Szeibl, who is the the Congressman's district director and who rarely hears such colorful language in the normal course of business. "For four days we did nothing but answer phone calls, one after another after another." 
 The House's vote on Thursday to join the Senate in banning 19 assault weapons was a baptism in political hysteria for the freshman Republican, who remained uncommitted on the ban until the last day.
In the end, Mr. Horn was one of 2 of the state's 22 Republican representatives to vote for the ban. He said his decision reflected the views of a constituency deeply worried about guns in the hands of criminals.
 
Gun Lobby Seemed Far Away
 A vote for the bill risked the retribution of the gun lobby, but in fielding all the phone calls, his staff drew the conclusion that the muscle of the National Rifle Association often seemed far removed from the concerns of his constituents.
Calls did pour in from other parts of the state. Mrs. Szeibl's office here in the 38th District received 781 of them in three days, most of them heatedly against the ban.
"Most of the threats are, 'Go find another job, dear,' " Mrs. Szeibl said."They say: 'He'd better watch out when he comes into the district. We're all coming down and make sure that he doesn't get re-elected. He's not going to get any money from the Republican Party.' "
The Congressman recounted in an interview today: "One person said, 'I'm 83 years old and I'm going to go into every precinct in your constituency and campaign against you.' That's what a lot of my colleagues are afraid of."
What makes the National Rifle Association threats more frightening, he said, is that the group may attack a candidate not simply on gun control issues, but also on issues of more immediate concern to most voters.
But the callers from within this ethnically and economically diverse, mostly Democratic district, where rising crime has become an obsession, were 80 percent in support of the ban, Mrs. Szeibl said.
And when Mr. Horn returned home for the weekend for informal meetings with constituents, the issue was hardly raised.
At the home of John Simons, a Hungarian immigrant who is a retired machinist, the Congressman stood by the fireplace and fielded questions from about 20 people on health care, the deficit, budgetary controls, crime, the recession, military base conversion and illegal aliens.
Mr. Horn, who was president of California State University at Long Beach for 18 years before entering politics, answered with the careful precision of a professor.
 
No One Asked About Vote
 Afterward, Marsha Moode, a guest who has a political affairs program on a local cable television channel, said: "I think it's fascinating that they just took the vote on guns and no one in this room has asked about it.
"Anyone who says a word against the vote almost seems to be advocating violence in the streets. We are talking California politics here. Californians feel such a terrible sense of crime. Everyone's putting a double lock on their doors. When I parked my car outside here, I looked around to see that everything was all right."
Another guest, Bob Collins, a retired machinist, said he owned several rifles and shotguns and enjoyed trap shooting.
"I believe in the right to keep 'em and bear 'em and this and that, but not the assault weapons," said Mr. Collins, who said that as a retiree he could no longer afford his membership in the National Rifle Association.
The only guest who approached the Congressman on the issue was Harry Kemmerer, a retired engineer. "I thanked him for his vote," he said later.
Mr. Horn's second visit was to the home of Patrick G. O'Healy, a commercial real estate developer, in an affluent, gated community where guests could wander between the swimming pool and the table of hors d'oeuvres.
None of the people here, mostly Republicans, seemed unduly concerned over the Congressman's vote on assault weapons.
The host, Mr. O'Healy, was a case in point.
"Right after the riot I bought a little teeny gun, a Beretta 22-caliber pistol, kind of like a self-protection gun," he said. "I've never used it. I've never even carried it. It's still in its original grease. I'm not sure I would have the ability to shoot somebody. It's the Rambo fantasy."
Then, he led a reporter up the carpeted stairs to his comfortable bedroom, where he took from their hiding place two other loaded pistols, a .357 magnum and a Glock nine-millimeter. "I'm not sure why I really bought them," he said, feeling their heft in his hand and laying them gently on his four-poster bed.
"Quite frankly, I think this country would do well to eliminate all handguns," he said. "If it weren't for the fear of someone coming in with a handgun, if it weren't for the protection, I would never have bought a pistol."
Looking back at the week, Mrs. Szeibl talked of her strategy for handling the passionate phone calls.
"It is so emotional for these individuals," Mrs. Szeibl said, "that if we contradict them in any way it only inflames them. We let them vent their emotion and their anger.
"Many from out of the area were upset that they would not have their guns to shoot in the desert and in the woods. I asked them, 'But what do you shoot at?' They said, 'We shoot at trees.' I said, 'Why?' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: The offices of Representative Steve Horn, Republican of California, received hundreds of calls, pro and con, before last week's House vote to ban some assault weapons. But when he returned to his district to meet with constituents, as he did in a home in Downey, the subject hardly came up. (Ed Carreon for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Embassy in Haiti Doubts Aristide's Rights Reports

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
Although President Clinton reaffirmed his support of Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide today, the United States Embassy in Haiti asserted in a cablegram in April that the exiled Haitian President and his supporters were exaggerating and even fabricating reports of human rights abuses.
The cablegram, signed by Ambassador William L. Swing and sent to Secretary of State Warren Christopher on April 12, acknowledges that violence by criminal elements in the Haitian police has sharply increased in recent months. But it suggests that the situation is not as bad as reported by Father Aristide, his followers, non-governmental organizations, an international monitoring mission in Haiti and the news media. 
 "The Haitian left, including President Aristide and his supporters in Washington and here, consistently manipulate or even fabricate human rights abuses as a propaganda tool," says the cablegram, which consisted of 11 pages and was drafted by Ellen Cosgrove, the human rights official at the embassy.
 
Undermining U.S. Credibility
 It adds that they are "wittingly or unwittingly assisted in this effort" by non-governmental human rights organizations and by international civilian monitors with a joint mission of the United Nations and the Organization of American States.
At the same time, the embassy expressed deep frustration with the Administration's handling of the effort to restore Father Aristide to power, complaining that the decision to pull back a United States troop ship last fall emboldened the military and undermined Washington's credibility.
"Opting for an easier ride early on has led to a very rough ride in the here and now," the cablegram said.
The cablegram, which was made available by people who believe that the embassy has played down the extent of human rights violations, also reflects the deeply held view in the Administration that most of those seeking political asylum are economic migrants posing as victims of persecution.
 
Distrust of Aristide
 Since the cablegram was sent, the Administration has moved toward a tougher position against the Haitian military and criticized its human rights record more strongly. But the cablegram reflects a dislike and distrust of Father Aristide that has been widely felt in the Administration -- though voiced only privately -- and has complicated efforts to formulate a new Haiti policy.
Asked whether the cablegram reflects the Administration's policy, Sondra McCarty, a State Department spokeswoman, said it represented one in a series of cablegrams "intended to give a balanced treatment of a complex human rights situation."
"As in some documents," she said "certain portions taken out of context could be read by some as biased or misinterpreted."
But to Kenneth Roth, executive director of Human Rights Watch, "it shows that at least in the embassy there is an extreme antipathy for Aristide and a willingness to play down human rights abuses to prevent a political momentum to build for his return."

HEADLINE: Texas Capital Ends Benefits For Partners

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., May 8

 BODY:
By nearly 2 to 1, voters here have repealed a policy providing health insurance benefits to the live-in partners of homosexual and other unmarried city employees. With the vote on Saturday, Austin, one of roughly 20 cities with such benefits, became the first to repeal its policy.
The passage of Proposition 22, an amendment to the city charter, means that health insurance will again be offered only to employees' legal family members. Christian groups that backed the measure said they would push repeal efforts in other cities with similar policies. 
 The chief group that sponsored the proposition here, Concerned Texans, said the benefits represented a perversion of traditional family values. Spokesmen for homosexual rights groups called the repeal vivid proof of anti-gay bias in a city known as the most liberal in Texas.
Austin provided the benefits for 98 unmarried companions of city workers after the City Council approved the policy in September. The benefits will be canceled as of Monday.
Many voters said support of the measure did not mean that they were condemning homosexuals. With a recent property-tax increase on their minds, they said the vote was simply a way to save $104,000, the city's estimate of the annual cost of providing the extra insurance.
"I don't believe it's gay bashing at all," said Marty Guarino, a retired printer. "I don't care how some people want to live, but I just don't want to pay for it."
 
Dispute With Apple Computer
 The vote in Austin comes on the heels of a controversy late last year in neighboring Williamson County, where commissioners initially voted to deny tax breaks to Apple Computer because the company had extended benefits to unmarried partners of its employees. The decision was reversed after Gov. Ann W. Richards pressured the commissioners to reconsider.
A slowly growing number of cities and companies have been providing domestic partner benefits.
But the Rev. Charles Bullock, pastor of the Christ Memorial Baptist Church and the founder and president of Concerned Texans, said the Austin vote demonstrated a strong if not always vocal majority opposed to what he called irresponsible spending and morals.
"The grass roots are bypassing their leaders and saying we're going to vote and we're going to vote conservative," he said.
Just how much of a push Austin's vote will give to other groups remains to be seen. Repeal efforts for such policies in Seattle and San Francisco have failed in recent years. New York City's program, which was negotiated by the Dinkins administration and municipal unions and took effect in January, has never been put to the voters.
In Austin, some voters said they were less concerned about benefits going to homosexuals than they were about heterosexuals who were nothing more than friends taking advantage of the program: of the 98 employees who have registered their partners, 29 have listed same-sex partners, according to the city's Human Resources Department.
 
'Let Them Get Married'
 "Why should I have to pay for them to live like that?" said Rebecca Kunz, a 29-year-old homemaker who voted for Proposition 22. "Let them pay for it or else let them get married."
But Hugh Strange, a spokesman for the Mainstream Austin Coalition, which opposed Proposition 22, said that arguments that casual friends of city employees had been taking advantage of the benefits were false.
"It takes more information to register as a domestic partner than it does to apply for a marriage license," he said. People could be prosecuted for perjury or lose their city jobs if they lied about their partners.
Still, the final margin on Proposition 22 certainly seemed definitive: 51,475, or 62 percent, in favor, to 31,082 votes, or 38 percent, against.
In the bitter fight before the vote, each side accused the other of getting large amounts of money from out-of-state organizations.
In an interview today, Mr. Bullock played down any assistance his group might have received from the Christian Coalition or the American Family Association, two national Christian groups that Mr. Strange said had been active in the battle.
While proponents of the measure said the benefits program was an unnecessary expense for taxpayers, others cited the controversy in Williamson County and said the local economy might be threatened if Austin acquired an aura as a place unfriendly to homosexuals.
"Austin is known as an open city and it should stay that way," said Bruce Salzer, director of finance for the State Land Commissioner's Office. "Companies like Apple Computer won't do business here if we try to dictate to their employees how to live."

HEADLINE: Can Both Wealth and Justice Flourish in a New South Africa? Two Old Foes Think So.

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CAPE TOWN, South Africa, May 8

 BODY:
A fiery-eyed union leader with a Trotsky beard, Jay Naidoo is the chief proponent of Nelson Mandela's plan to ease the misery of South Africa's black majority by transforming the apartheid bureaucracy into an engine of houses, jobs and decent schools.
Derek Keys, a heavy-lidded boardroom wizard who has spent the last two years as President F. W. de Klerk's Finance Minister, is the country's ranking apostle of low-spending, business-friendly Government. 
 At a glance, the two men hardly seem meant for the same planet. But in a few days they will be members of the same Cabinet, sharing the new Government's trickiest assignment: to lift the lives of the newly enfranchised electorate without bringing down Africa's richest economy.
 
Housing, Jobs and Education
 In interviews as Mr. Mandela prepared to assume the presidency in a celebrity-studded inauguration on Tuesday, the two men agreed on the general goals of the "reconstruction and development program" that Mr. Mandela says is his minimum promise to the poor.
The program, scaled down after wide consultation with the business establishment but still ambitious, calls for building 1 million homes and creating 2.5 million public service jobs before the next elections, in 1999, and for providing 10 years of decent, free education for all children.
The men agreed, too, on the danger of bleeding the affluent whites who run the economy and of scaring away investors.
But as they talked, it was possible to hear the first strains of a debate that may soon test the unity of this unity Government.
"I have no difficulty with the program insofar as it represents a direction," said Mr. Keys, whom Mr. Mandela has invited to keep the job of Finance Minister in the new Government. "The biggest thing that has to happen is that it still has to be fitted into what can be done. In the course of that you're going to sacrifice fair parts of it. You can't do everything." The African National Congress that assumes the balance of power this week is no longer the collection of Marxists and economic populists, nationalizers and redistributors that once terrified white business.
Mr. Naidoo, who is to be Minister Without Portfolio in charge of the reconstruction plan, speaks with apparent conviction about "sustainable growth" and the "disincentive effect" of high taxes. He and other economic ministers in the Cabinet listen to an eclectic chorus of advisers, but seem most influenced by market-oriented mentors here and in the United States and Europe. They have signed international trade and borrowing commitments that bind them to honor free markets. They have retained Mr. Keys.
But many wonder how long the congress's new-found market faith -- and the spirit of consensus Government -- will survive when the demands of business and the poor begin to conflict.
"One doesn't know what the reaction will be to failure," said Mr. Keys when asked if he trusts Mr. Mandela's pro-business conversion.
Mr. Naidoo, in turn, does not want the new Government to be taken for African Reaganites. "To think that we are going to solve our problems in South Africa on a sustainable basis through economic populism is a fairy tale," he said.
"We have learned from the experiences of the rest of the world," he said. "But at the same time, there's no way you are going to have economic growth here that continues to benefit just a small minority of people.
"Unbridled free-market systems have failed under Reagan and Thatcher. A Government has got to intervene to create an environment where people's basic needs are met."
There is also a stress on restitution in the new Government that does not sit easily with the capitalists Mr. Keys represents.
In South Africa, said a Stellenbosch University economist, Sampie Terreblanche, 5 percent of the population, mostly white, owns 88 percent of the wealth. That is nearly double the concentration of wealth in the 10 richest Western countries.
Mr. Naidoo rejects, for now, the proposal some of his allies were floating last year to narrow the economic gulf by taxing the accumulated assets of the rich.
But Mr. Naidoo makes clear his sufferance of what he calls the "selfishness" of the rich could end if they resist the new Government.
"The rich need to look at what is their contribution going to be," he said. "We would prefer to do things by agreement rather than being prescriptive."
 
Economy Long in Decline
 The economy the African National Congress inherits is just emerging from 20 years of decline, battered by sanctions, drought and recession. Productivity is low, investment has been neglected, unemployment -- mainly among blacks -- is more than 40 percent. The Government has been bloated and wasteful, and the isolated, cartel-dominated economy has lost the habit of competition.
On the other hand, the country is developed beyond any other in Africa, and its economic system is, as Mr. Keys observes, "as tough as old boots." It has weathered the economic equivalent of the Biblical plagues, yet economic activity and business confidence are higher than before.
"That's not a drifting economic wreck," Mr. Keys said.
The problem, everyone agrees, is how to make the economy grow faster and create jobs. Mr. Keys estimates 4.5 percent annual growth of the economy is needed to stand in place, without even reducing the unemployment rate. This year, growth is expected to be about 2.5 percent.
"We don't have low wages to offer," Mr. Keys said. "The Congress of South African Trade Unions" -- which Mr. Naidoo has run since 1985 -- "set its face against that. The market in southern Africa is likely to grow slowly. You have to get investment up. That means you have to attract entrepreneurs. How do you attract entrepreneurs if you can't offer them low wage costs?
 
'It All Costs Money'
 "You can devise Government programs, incentives, to create conditions for investment. But it all costs money, in competition with your social policies. So that's the nub of the difficulty."
Mr. Naidoo said the main focus would be to educate and enrich the disadvantaged majority, thus offering investors a skilled work force and a great market of new consumers.
Mr. Naidoo insists that the social programs outlined in the reconstruction manifesto can be squeezed from the existing budget.
"We put this forward not as an add-on expenditure," he said. "It's really a growth and development strategy."
The new Government will get some money, he said, from an "apartheid dividend" -- streamlining the redundant bureaucracies that served the different races under apartheid. Segregated school systems and housing programs will be consolidated.
Military spending, he estimated, would be cut by a third over two years, and the defense force's hospital system and youth training ability would be turned to civilian uses.
Mr. Keys questions whether the savings will be as abundant as Mr. Mandela's advisers think. Part of the bargain that brought the congress to power is a promise to protect the jobs of white civil servants and soldiers.
"Well over half of Government spending is the salaries of civil servants," he said. "All of those civil servants' positions and remuneration and so on are guaranteed in terms of the interim constitution. You can't go in and fire half the staff. You have to turn people from doing one set of tasks to doing a different set of tasks. And the inertia involved in that process is quite substantial."
Mr. Keys favors business incentives like tax-free, union-free "export processing zones" where companies could produce goods for sale to Europe and North America.
Mr. Naidoo strongly disagrees, seeing such zones as sanctuaries for "fly-by-night speculators."
"That's not consistent with the democracy that we've just achieved in our country," he said. "We must never reduce ourselves to the type of one-dollar-a-day environment that exists in the south of China."
 
An Issue in Next Election
 Disputes over the economy could strain the unity of the Cabinet, especially as the parties begin to position themselves for the next election.
"If one is a minister then one will be following the Cabinet's policy," Mr. Keys said. "But at a certain point before 1999 it will certainly be necessary for the party that has put one in Parliament to define a different position, so that the voters will have a choice. That seems to me a pretty tricky operation."
Against that, Mr. Naidoo and Mr. Keys point out that the Mandela Government starts out with a flourishing culture of negotiation, including several national forums where unions, business leaders and politicians pursue compromises on economic policies and social programs.
Mr. Naidoo added: "Derek Keys is an ex-businessman. I'm an ex-unionist. We know how to negotiate."
