HEADLINE: Mississippi's University System Going on Trial

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ITTA BENA, Miss., May 5

 BODY:
With its flat-roofed, spartan buildings shimmering under the harsh Delta sun, Mississippi Valley State University, established 44 years ago "to train Negro teachers and provide vocational training for Negroes," looks like a no-frills military installation.
Less than 50 miles away in Cleveland is Delta State University, where stately pin oaks shade manicured quadrangles and gabled buildings. The university was founded 70 years ago to educate whites. 
 The sharp contrasts between the two state universities and indeed their continued existence are at the heart of a Federal trial, scheduled to begin on Monday in Oxford, Miss., on just how far Mississippi should go in desegregating its higher education system. Students at Mississippi Valley State, which has 7 whites in its enrollment of 2,300, and the Justice Department are challenging a state plan to close the university and merge it with Delta State.
The plan stems from a 1992 Supreme Court decision, which held that the state's higher education system was still segregated some 30 years after the flagship University of Mississippi was ordered to accept its first black student. The ruling, based on a 1975 lawsuit by a black student named Jake Ayers challenging the disparity in financing black universities and white ones, left it to the Federal courts to work out what a desegregated system of higher education would look like.
 
Effects for 18 Other States
 For the opponents of the closing of Mississippi Valley State, Mississippi's compliance with the law is a cruelly paradoxical twist to what was an effort to upgrade the state's historically black public colleges. But the state said it had no choice.
The outcome here is likely to affect 18 other states that maintained segregated colleges, in some instances well into the 1960's. To date, none of the 38 historically black state colleges and universities in the 19 states that had dual systems have been closed or merged, said Mark Musick, president of the Southern Regional Education Board.
A critical issue is just how the historically black institutions will be treated in an era when their formerly all-white counterparts often attract the cream of black students and when the competition in state legislatures for scarce dollars is intense.
The 1992 Mississippi decision, legal experts said, was to higher education what the 1955 Brown v. Board of Education case was to elementary and secondary education.
"After Brown and in the 60's we as a nation had some consensus about integration at the elementary and secondary school level," said Gary Orfield, a professor of education and social policy at Harvard University. "But we have never had any such consensus until now when it comes to higher education."
 
'Justify or Eliminate'
 The Supreme Court said that Mississippi, and by extension other states, had to do more than cease discrimination by race in admissions to its five historically white and three historically black universities. It had to examine its 60,000-student state-financed system and "educationally justify or eliminate" all traces of its old dual system to make sure it was not continuing to foster segregation.
This meant questioning the rigid reliance on standardized test scores for admission, the duplication of programs and the establishment of "mission assignments" for the various institutions. And the Court even challenged the continued existence of identifiably white and black colleges, even if black students preferred to attend historically black institutions.
Years ago, legislatures in Florida, Louisiana, North Carolina, Tennessee and most of the other 19 states tried to address the historical segregation first by aggressively seeking black applicants for the all-white colleges and universities and then by increasing the financing of historically black institutions. Most of the 19 states broadened the undergraduate and graduate programs in the black institutions in an effort to attract white students, but with only modest success.
In February, however, the Federal Department of Education warned the other 18 states that their progress toward desegregation was now subject to review on the same basis being applied in the coming Mississippi case. That standard would be used, the Federal officials said, regardless of what past court-ordered or federally approved desegregation plans required of the state in integrating both its white and black colleges and universities.
 
'A Tough Sell' to Whites
 Amid court pressure to re-examine the continued existence of any racially identifiable colleges, there is a powerful constituency that believes that the historically black institutions have earned the right to exist for their own sake and continue to serve thousands of black students with potential who would be passed over by other colleges. And in the competition with formerly all-white institutions to stay afloat by attracting a diverse student body, Mississippi Valley State is at a disadvantage, Mr. Musick said.
"It's rural and isolated, and even if you pick the most idyllic campus you can imagine and transplant it to Itta Bena, it's still a tough sell to attract white students," he said.
"Our history says we are the cotton-patch college but we have managed to survive fiscal neglect over the years out of sheer determination and to educate leaders for the state," said Dr. Roy Hudson, the university's vice president and himself a graduate of Mississippi Valley State. "We are in the unfortunate position of having to ask the courts to make us a legitimate part of this educational enterprise in which we have succeeded in spite of barriers."
Officials at Delta State are not enthusiastic about absorbing their neighbor. They argue that with a 25 percent black enrollment among its 4,000 students, the university is the state's most racially mixed institution of higher learning. Administrators and students say that a merger would harm both colleges.
 
Negotiations Collapse
 Last-minute negotiations for an out-of-court settlement collapsed last week..
Representative Bennie Thompson, a Democrat who represents much of the Delta, said students at black colleges feared that they would bear the heaviest burden in this desegregation, just as they did with the integration efforts in elementary and secondary schools. In those efforts, he said, it was largely black institutions that were closed and black teachers and administrators who lost jobs in the competition with white counterparts.
In addition to the closing of Mississippi Valley State, the state proposes maintaining the historically black Alcorn State University campus in Lorman while moving its administration to Mississippi State University in Starkville and the upgrading of programs and buildings at nearly all-black Jackson State University. The University of Mississippi would see little or no change.
W. Ray Cleere, the state's Commissioner of Higher Education, said Mississippi was having to take the heat for the Justice Department's failure over the years to address segregation at black colleges and universities while it aggressively pressed for the integration of formerly all-white colleges. Part of the result was the recruitment by those colleges of the top black students, leaving the historically black institutions with those black students in need of the most financial and academic help.
"Mississippi Valley is a weak institution," Mr. Cleere said, "but not because of any lack of devotion or drive on the part of everyone there. It has survived and done a good job when history has limited the resources it had available." But, he added, "that should not stand in the way of making higher education more efficient."
 
Story of Survival
 There have been previous efforts to close Mississippi Valley State, mainly to cut costs. But even that argument has lost some power as the state has gained revenue from an improved economy and from newly legalized riverboat gambling.
In recent years, because of tight budgets, Mississippi Valley State has not been able to fix its leaking roofs. A laundry building sat empty for four years because money was not appropriated for washers and dryers. Only now is an air conditioning plant being built to cool dormitories.
The university also suffered academically. Its degree programs were cut to 17 from 31. Enrollment plunged in the mid-1980's, but then rose. Only in the last five years, Mr. Hudson said, has the university begun to get some of the additional money it needs.
Faculty salaries, which average $35,000 for full professors, are below Delta State's $40,000 average. And Mississippi Valley State is limping along with a graduation rate of about 28 percent, compared with about 50 percent for Delta State and most other formerly all-white colleges.
But the Mississippi Valley State students insist that the encouragement that they get could not be duplicated at at a largely white college. Gwen Granderson, a senior who transferred to the mostly white Mississippi University for Women only to return to Mississippi Valley State, said that although the institutions were about the same size there was a big difference in the atmosphere.
"Here it is a lot more personal and there you are just a Social Security number," she said. "I participate more here. My father went here and he knew then and I know now that with just a little more effort and help, this could be a really fine school."

HEADLINE: Ex-Communists Leading Ballot In Hungary

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, May 8

 BODY:
Hungary's former Communists, swept from power four years ago, appear likely to be the dominant partner in a new coalition government after voting today in the first round of parliamentary elections.
With more than 80 percent of the vote counted, the Socialists, as the former Communists have renamed themselves, led with 32.7 percent; their likely coalition partner, the Alliance of Free Democrats, stood at 19.8 percent. 
 The governing right-of-center party, the Hungarian Democratic Forum, led by Prime Minister Peter Boross, stood at 11.6 percent. The far right group, led by Istvan Csurka, which last year was seen as a threat to Hungary's stability, managed only 1.3 percent.
The sharp swing to the Socialists, who got only 11 percent of the vote in 1990, reflected disenchantment with economic conditions across a broad section of society. Hungary's gross domestic product has fallen 20 percent in the last four years as exports of agricultural and other goods collapsed and factories cut production.
 
The Communist Resurgence
 But while many Hungarians became poorer, a few became conspicuously richer, causing considerable resentment in a society that had become accustomed to a sort of egalitarianism under 40 years of Communism.
The composition of the Government will not be decided until a second round of voting on May 29, when there will be runoffs in districts where no candidate wins today.
By bringing the former Communists back to power, Hungary becomes the third country of the old Soviet bloc to throw out an anti-Communist Government. Poland voted last fall for former Communists and an agrarian party allied with the Communists; Lithuania is also now governed by former Communists.
Investors do not seem worried about the prospect. Some investors say they hope for more dynamic economic policies. Several diplomats, concerned about the increasingly nationalistic voice of the Hungarian Democratic Forum, said they expected a toning down of the stridency. They said they viewed Gyula Horn, 62, the leader of the former Communists, as a pragmatic politician.
 
Sanguine View From U.S.
 "Even though the road map and driver may change, the ultimate destination -- a democratic society, market economy and full integration with the West -- remains the same," said the United States Ambassador, Donald M. Blinken.
The early returns indicate that the character of the Government in Hungary will be slightly different than in Poland or Lithuania. In a coalition of the Socialists and the Free Democrats, the former Communists would be balanced by a party formed in 1990 by urban intellectuals active in the anti-Communist opposition.
In the last weeks of the campaign, the two parties tacitly accepted their likely partnership, with both sides apparently burying the animosity they held toward each other in the 1980's.
Even though the Socialists would be the senior member of the coalition, it is not certain that Mr. Horn would be Prime Minister. Mr. Horn did not run as the prime ministerial candidate of the Socialists, apparently because his background as a member of a Communist Party militia that helped suppress the 1956 uprising provided too much of a campaign target for his opponents.
 
The Next Prime Minister
 There has been speculation that the relatively unknown leader of the Free Democrats, Gabor Kuncze, 44, a former engineer and plant manager, would emerge as Prime Minister. Mr. Kuncze proved to be a popular campaigner, with ratings were far above those of Prime Minister Boross.
Mr. Horn was the last Foreign Minister of Hungary under the Communists and is considered to come from the reform wing of the party. He made the decision in 1989 to allow about 20,000 East Germans to cross from Hungary into Austria, a move that helped precipitate the fall of the Berlin wall. Mr. Horn, who was badly injured in a car crash on Thursday, was operated on today for a wrist fracture, and did not vote.
The economy seemed to be the dominant factor in the voting. But in interviews outside polling places, voters who cast ballots against the Hungarian Democratic Forum said they were also angered by the rightist nationalist ideology that the Forum increasingly emphasized.

HEADLINE: Hunger Strike on Haiti: Partial Victory at Least

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
Day 27 turned out to be the final day of tomato juice and water for Randall Robinson.
Mr. Robinson, the executive director of TransAfrica Forum, a research and lobbying group, had adopted the liquid diet to protest the Administration's policy of returning refugees to Haiti without hearings on asylum. In the last week, particularly after he was hospitalized for a day for dehydration, reporters increasingly asked whether the fast was worthwhile -- a question that irked him. 
 Today, 13 pounds lighter but triumphant, Mr. Robinson said the answer was clear.
"I never doubted that it was worth it," he said. "No matter what the outcome, it's worth it always to try. It's better when you're successful, but it's always worth it to try."
 
Call From Key Clinton Aide
 Anthony Lake, President Clinton's national security adviser, called late Saturday afternoon and told Mr. Robinson the Administration would interview Haitians fleeing their country to determine who were political refugees, and would not automatically send all of them back to Haiti. But Mr. Robinson said he would not end his fast until the Administration publicly announced its policy today.
This morning Mr. Robinson, 52, played down his fast as pivotal to the Administration's policy shift.
"I expressed my own opinion, but obviously if it was a lone opinion it wouldn't have done much," he said. "I think it dramatized and facilitated the concerns of many across the nation, people who came to learn of this cruel policy through coverage of the hunger strike. If the Administration reacted, I don't think it was so much from me, but Americans who reacted."
Some, including former Vice President Dan Quayle, felt otherwise. In an interview on the ABC News program "This Week," Mr. Quayle said, "This is foreign policy by a hunger strike, and that is not the way to conduct foreign policy."
 
'Terrifying,' Family Says
 Friends and family said Mr. Robinson would have continued his liquid diet if there had been no action on the refugees. His wife, Hazel Ross-Robinson, said the fast had been "emotionally traumatic and terrifying" for the family. She said that she did not tell the couple's 4-year-old daughter, Khalea, when her father was hospitalized last week. Mr. Robinson also has a daughter, Anike, 22, and son, Jabari, 19, from a previous marriage.
Friends and acquaintainces say Mr. Robinson, though occasionally discouraged, always believed that Mr. Clinton would remember his campaign promise to help Haitian refugees and change his initial policy, which was largely adopted from the Bush Administration.
Last Friday, Mr. Robinson said he never dwelt on what would happen if that faith was unfounded. He said that when he was growing up in Richmond, his parents told him, "You don't do things because they're successful, but because they're right."
For a man who fasted nearly a month, the 6-foot-5-inch Mr. Robinson, whose normal weight is 195 pounds, looked surprisingly well.
 
No Burger Yet
 During his fast, in his basement room, Mr. Robinson could be funny, joking about tips from people who undertake fasts for their health and his new obsession with an advertisement for a hamburger with mushrooms, bacon and cheese. For his first meal, however, he chose dinner with his wife, a staff member of the House Armed Services Committee, at their favorite Chinese restaurant.
Mr. Robinson said he would spend the coming week focused on the logistics of the new asylum policy.
"The last time the Bush Administration tried this, and it was a cursory, farcical undertaking," he said. "We have to look at this process closely this time, to make sure that it meets minimal standards for fair hearings."
 
Beware Emotionalism
 Few Washington officials doubt Mr. Robinson's commitment to foreign policy issues. Aside from his work at the TransAfrica Forum, he is a private man who eschews the limelight. In a city of compromises, his is an unusual personality.
"I respect any man who puts his life on the line, but it's an issue that can easily become very emotional," said Lawrence A. Pezzullo, the former special envoy to Haiti, who was forced to resign last month. "It puts pressure on the Administration."
Mr. Robinson first came to national attention when he and few others began daily protests at the South African Embassy in 1984. The protests called for economic sanctions against the white Government and prompted other demonstrations. In 1986 Congress passed the Anti-Apartheid Act over President Reagan's veto.
In "High Noon in Southern Africa" (Norton, 1992), Chester A. Crocker, the Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs in the Reagan Administration, wrote of his frustrations with Mr. Robinson's opposition.
"He cherished the imagery of confrontation, both before and after the protest began," Mr. Crocker wrote. "He made a point of canceling, boycotting or walking out of meetings scheduled between concerned black Americans and Administration officials. He wanted attention and confrontation, not communication."
But the protests have also been cited as one of the actions that helped lead to international ostracism of South Africa and eventually to last month's open elections.
And Mr. Clinton said today that while his Administration's policy review began before the fast, he respected Mr. Robinson's "conviction and courage and his conscience."

HEADLINE: Seoul Journal;
Nuclear Fears? Korea's Noodle Sales Say No

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, May 8

 BODY:
Signs everywhere in this city proclaim that 1994 is "Visit Korea Year." Never mind that a North Korean official declared a while back that Seoul might be turned into a "sea of fire."
Even as the nuclear standoff with North Korea approaches its next showdown, people in Seoul are enjoying a warm spring and a reinvigorated economy. Many South Koreans say they do not believe that a war will come or that North Korea would ever use an atomic bomb, if it has one. 
 "People talk about it so I guess it's a dangerous situation, but I really don't feel it," said Bang Young Gyu, a 24-year-old who was visiting Yongsan Family Park here the other day.
Every few minutes, a military helicopter roared directly over the park, swooping in for a landing at the American military base just beyond a wall. But Mr. Bang and hundreds of others proceeded with their picnics and dodge ball despite the deafening noise. The scene was, in a sense, symbolic of the way South Koreans are going about their lives despite the military threat from the North.
In years past, people here say, even a hint of war sent consumers rushing to stock up on dried noodles. But this year, noodle sales did not shoot up even after the "sea of fire" comment in March when North Korean officials walked out of talks with South Korean delegates at Panmunjom, threatening war if Washington and Seoul mounted a pressure campaign.
Young people seem especially oblivious to the situation. Bae Soon Hoon, an electronics executive, said his 16-year-old daughter's high school English teacher had asked the class what the initials N.P.T. stood for. The teacher was shocked when not a single student could identify the nonproliferation treaty, which North Korea is suspected of violating with a nuclear weapons development program.
After being lectured about their ignorance, the students countered by stumping the teacher with some initials more important to them -- K.F.C., for Kentucky Fried Chicken.
A senior official says the South Korean Government has been trying to avoid alarming the public to prevent panic and the hoarding of food. The Government also does not want to scare away foreign investors or visitors as it pushes a campaign for tourism or to dampen celebrations marking the 600th anniversary of Seoul's designation as the nation's capital.
So far, South Korea seems to be surviving the scare. Some people have canceled their visits, a Government spokesman said, but the impact on tourism has not been devastating. The stock market weakened this year as foreign investors stayed away, but it has largely recovered.
Despite the calm in Seoul, political and military leaders here say the confrontation with North Korea could get worse. On Wednesday, President Kim Young Sam of South Korea, in perhaps his strongest warning to date, said his Government's patience with North Korea "has reached a limit." He said North Korea risked "self-destruction" if it continued its efforts to develop nuclear weapons.
On Saturday, Lee Hong Koo, South Korea's newly appointed minister in charge of North Korean issues, said action against North Korea by the United Nations Security Council would be "unavoidable" if the North Korean leadership failed to cooperate with international inspections of nuclear installations.
Mr. Lee said it was unclear whether North Korea had already started to change the fuel in the reactor at Yongbyon, 60 miles from Pyongyang, the North Korean capital.
Tensions have also been rising because North Korea declared its intention to annul the armistice agreement that ended the Korean War in 1953 and replace it with a peace treaty that it would negotiate directly with the United States. Washington and Seoul oppose this idea.
In what was viewed here as a show of its contempt for the armistice agreement, North Korea last week blatantly violated the pact by sending two platoons of heavily armed soldiers into a border zone for a few hours. It also withdrew its representative from a commission that oversees the truce. These actions prompted President Kim to order South Korean troops to increase their vigilance.
But details of the tactical back-and-forth between North and South were lost on many people at the park.
"When we look at the 9 o'clock news, it's really difficult for us to make a judgment about what's going on," Hwang Jae Ho, 41, said.
Mr. Hwang, who works for a heavy-machinery company, said it might not be all bad if North Korea did have the bomb because South Korea would inherit it after the inevitable reunification.
"It's sort of like having an older brother who's very good at fighting," he said.
Many of the people in the park, which once was the golf course of the main American base in Seoul, are happy to have the American troops around just in case, even if the helicopters do intrude on their picnics.
But many college students vigorously oppose the presence of the troops, saying the United States is contributing to tensions here.
"I really do think that we and the North Koreans are the same people," said Che Kyung Hui, a 22-year-old student at Kangnam College, who was visiting Yongsan park. "Even if North Korea had a mindset to start a nuclear war, the target would not be us but the Americans."

As children played, a United States military helicopter came in to land at an adjacent base. (Kasumi Wauke for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Tempest in Court: An Ousted Judge;
Metuchen Officials Want More Fines From Municipal Court

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: METUCHEN, N.J.

 BODY:
Metuchen calls itself the "brainy borough" of central New Jersey, a haven of petite streets, petite stores and grand self-esteem. It hardly seems like one of those fabled backwaters where out-of-towners are summarily ticketed to fatten the coffers of the local chieftains.
But that was the impression that lingered recently after some officials in Metuchen squashed the reappointment of their municipal judge because, they suggested, he had failed to wring enough fines from his part-time court on Main Street, which handles traffic violations, petty theft, zoning disputes and other offenses too trifling for the judicial big leagues. 
 Their apparent reasoning has roiled the legal waters across New Jersey, drawing a rare rebuke from the state's chief judge and kindling a debate over the relationship between justice and money in the state's localities.
"It's an attack on the basic fairness that we expect in our legal system," said James B. Smith, 51, the Metuchen judge whose eight-year tenure ended after he was likened to a vice president of marketing who had neglected the bottom line. "I couldn't believe why they did it and then I couldn't believe it when they actually came out and said it in public."
But the officials who ousted Mr. Smith said they had been badly misunderstood. They said they never tried to meddle with the court in this wealthy borough of nearly 13,000, which got its nickname decades ago because of the many residents who worked nearby at Princeton and Rutgers Universities. What they wanted, these officials said, was to cut the court's expenses so that it would operate as efficiently as some of its counterparts around the state.
At the root of the disagreement was a recent survey by The New Jersey Law Journal that contained some very enticing statistics for local officials hard pressed by the recession and cuts in state aid. The survey found that municipal courts can be wellsprings of money, sometimes yielding three or four times what it costs to run them.
The municipal court in Hoboken, for example, took in $2,895,209 in 1992 on only $636,855 in expenses, a 355 percent return. Over all, the 567 municipal courts in New Jersey took in $135 million and spent $70 million in 1992, The Law Journal said, for a rate of return of 93 percent.
 
Below Average Return
 The Democrats who control the Metuchen Borough Council seemed irritated to learn from the survey that their court was below average, earning a 31 percent return -- $152,501 in revenues on $116,483 in expenses. The nearby Borough of Middlesex, whose population is similar to Metuchen's, had a 102 percent return, taking in $196,256 on expenses of $97,332.
So in late March, when Metuchen's Mayor, Susan Marshall, a Republican, nominated Mr. Smith, a Democrat, for another three-year term, the Council balked. Thomas Sullivan, the Democratic Council President, compared the court to a poorly performing corporation, according to a tape of the meeting provided by Ms. Marshall, who was eager to pin the blame for the furor on the Democrats.
"I believe that it is possible for us to maximize and do a better job for our taxpayers with this court, and the place where you start usually is at the top," Mr. Sullivan said on the tape. "And I think it's time to bring in a new corporate vice president."
Another Democratic member, Barbara Buono, said, "It is incumbent upon the Council in these tough economic times to explore innovative ways to increase our revenues to stabilize property taxes." She later added that "the taxpayer is not getting the biggest bang for the buck."
 
An Unsuccessful Appeal
 About two weeks later, when Ms. Marshall was on vacation, the Democrats replaced Mr. Smith with their own candidate, Lydia Kuhn, a lawyer. Mr. Smith, who has a private law practice here, unsuccessfully appealed the move to the Middlesex County Superior Court.
But his removal did touch off protests from residents and lawyers around the state. William H. Gazi, a trustee of the New Jersey State Bar Association who is a municipal judge in Piscataway Township and Highland Park, resigned as a substitute judge in Metuchen. And the state's Chief Justice, Robert N. Wilentz, issued a statement calling Mr. Sullivan's comments "intolerable."
"It puts cash on the scales of justice," Mr. Wilentz said. "It encourages what amounts to judicial misconduct. It threatens judicial independence and undermines the public's confidence in municipal courts."
Mr. Sullivan, 34, a reporter for Dow Jones, the financial services company, said he regretted equating the court to a corporation. But he said his comments had been wildly misconstrued and he maintained that Ms. Marshall was keeping the fight alive to make the Democrats look bad.
"We take our responsibility to increase the efficiency of government very seriously," Mr. Sullivan said. "We felt to achieve those goals it was time for a change. We wanted somebody to take a fresh look at the situation and that required a fresh face. To say that we wanted to turn the entire town into a speed trap is ludicrous and loathsome."
Ms. Marshall, 37, an administrator at a Roman Catholic high school in Metuchen, said Mr. Sullivan was being disingenuous, pointing out that the Democrats had never indicated any problem with Mr. Smith before the journal's findings were publicized.
"For him to deny that he had any other spin on it is a lie," Ms. Marshall said. "The whole thing is horrible. We are being characterized as a town where justice is for sale."
Some legal experts said the criticism of Mr. Smith was unfair because municipal judges, who can rule on offenses with a possible punishment of less than six months, assess fines under guidelines set by the Legislature, the State Supreme Court and the localities. Aggressive policing tends to have a greater impact on fines than aggressive judges, they added.
And Mr. Smith, who was paid about $13,500 a year as judge in Metuchen, said the statistics in The Law Journal could be misleading because municipalities calculated their expenses differently. He noted that when he served as judge in nearby Dunellen in 1992, the court there took in revenues of $63,874 on expenses of $29,618, a 116 percent rate of return.
The legal experts were divided about the extent of inappropriate political influence on the municipal courts. One prominent trial lawyer active in the state bar association, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he was "floored" by The Law Journal's figures, as well as their ramifications.
"What took place out in the open in Metuchen happens every day elsewhere," he said. "Many municipal court judges do not get reappointed for reasons that are never talked about publicly. One is that they have not generated enough money. The other is that they do not back up the police."
In recent years, the Legislature has considered changing the system by giving municipal judges tenure, similar to that of judges on the county-level Superior Courts, who are named by the governor to a seven-year term and receive tenure if reappointed. But the proposal has faced stiff opposition from local officials who say it is their right to choose judges.
Ann Bartlett, chairwoman of the state bar association's judicial administration committee, said she believed that most municipal judges were able to resist pressure from those who select them. But she said she still favored tenure.
"The benefits of tenure far outweigh the interests of municipalities in maintaining their political autonomy because the political autonomy is what is invariably linked to influence-peddling," she said.
Such changes might soothe tempers in Metuchen, where residents like Daniel P. Spiegel said they were disgusted with both factions. Mr. Spiegel, 30, a mortgage banker who as a Republican served on the Borough Council in the late 1980's, said the other day that the Mayor and the Council should stop bickering and ask the county or the state to appoint a new municipal judge, even though Ms. Kuhn has said she is confident that she will be able to be fair and impartial.

"I couldn't believe why they did it and then I couldn't believe it when they actually came out and said it in public," he said. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)(pg. B5)

HEADLINE: U.S. Businesses Flocking to Brazilian Ventures

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, May 5

 BODY:
Business people from the United States are flocking to Brazil in a new display of confidence that economic ties between the two giants of the Americas will now revolve around trade and investment.
Even before Brazil's $49 billion commercial debt was rescheduled on April 15, Brazilian and foreign businessmen detected the thundering hoofs of United States investors and exporters. 
 Sao Paulo, a state with an economy larger than Argentina's, has seen a string of business announcements in recent weeks: Goldman, Sachs & Company, the investment bank, is to open an office here; J. C. Penney, the retailer, is to start a catalogue mail order business, and Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide, is opening an advertising agency. Later this year, Wal-Mart Stores is expected to open a discount store in Sao Paulo, its first in Brazil.
"It started last year -- then, all of a sudden, these guys are all over us," said Barry J. Gluck, a United States partner of the Brazilian office of Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu, referring to the estimated 300 business people from the United States who now visit Sao Paulo each day.
 
Symbol of New Interest
 Indeed, as bankers lined up in New York to sign Brazil's foreign-debt deal, United States exporters and investors in Sao Paulo were already exploring the new United States Trade Center, a freshly minted aluminum-and- glass building that symbolizes the new business relationship.
International business interest in Brazil is rising as investors increasingly look beyond the nation's two prominent drawbacks -- a 45 percent monthly inflation rate and a chronically weak central Government -- and see a Latin American economy the size of Russia's.
But while Russia is struggling to recover from the collapse of Communism, Brazil's economy is growing this year on the shoulders of a record grain harvest of 74 million tons, a forecast of an unprecedented output of 1.5 million automobiles, record foreign currency reserves of $37 billion, a healthy trade surplus and a growing appetite for United States imports.
"Russia should only hope to have Brazil's problems," said Paula Stern, an international economist based in Washington. "I'm sensing a new excitement about Brazil."
By relaxing rules and slashing taxes in the early 1990's on profits sent overseas, Brazil stimulated new investor interest, especially in franchising.
"Australia and metropolitan Sao Paulo have about the same population -- 18 million people," Michael K. Lorelli, president of Pizza Hut International, calculated during a visit here in early April. "In Australia, we have 434 Pizza Huts. In Sao Paulo, we have 38. I don't see any reason why we can't double here every two years."
In the last two years, franchising grew in Brazil by 30 percent a year. Economists predict that in 1994 and in 1995, United States franchises alone will expand by 20 percent a year in Brazil.
With United States companies swarming into a once-restricted market, Sao Paulo's fast-food consumers can now choose among Domino's Pizza, Arby's and Kentucky Fried Chicken. Within a year, Taco Bell and Pizza Inn are to enter the market and McDonald's is to open its Latin American training center here, Hamburger University South.
Brazilians, who drink 1.4 billion gallons of soft drinks a year, constitute the world's third-largest soft-drink market, after the United States and Mexico. Opening an aggressive new front in the cola wars, Pepsi-Cola plans to open a new $25 million bottling plant in Rio de Janeiro this year, part of $90 million in investments planned by Pepsi through the end of the decade.
Brazil was long a closed market but abolished its list of banned imports in 1990. Over the last decade, it has slashed average tariffs from 78 percent to 14 percent, near the regional average. In response, foreign imports jumped 25 percent last year, hitting $25 billion. This year, they are expected to jump 20 percent more.
 
Narrower Trade Gap
 For the United States, which is Brazil's largest trading partner, this means that the United States' trade deficit with Brazil is expected to drop by half this year, to less than $1 billion.
"It's a new ball game here," said Richard R. Ades, a Commerce Department official who heads the new United States Trade Center here. "The trade gap is narrowing. A lot of American companies are coming down here to appoint distributors."
The number of United States business executives using the services of his office is running at four times last year's level, Mr. Ades said. Last year, 12 official United States trade missions visited Brazil, four times the number in 1992.
United States exports to Brazil increased by 10 percent last year and are expected to rise another 15 percent this year. Underlining Brazil's new importance to United States exporters, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown will visit Sao Paulo late this month to dedicate the new trade center.
Analysts predict that United States-Brazilian trade will grow steadily in two areas -- computers and tourism. Brazil's imports of United States-made computers and peripherals appear likely to grow by 30 percent a year through 1995. And with more than 700,000 Brazilians expected to visit the United States this year, Brazil could become the fifth-largest source of foreign tourists, after Japan, Germany, Britain and France.
"Brazil has the most dynamic private sector in Latin America," said William R. Rhodes, the Citibank vice chairman who led the creditor banks in the renegotiation of Brazil's foreign debt.
 
A Government's Troubles
 The healthy Brazilian business sector contrasts with its sick public sector. Brazilian executives look to the Government with low expectations.
To beat inflation, which reached a record 2,500 percent last year, economists say that Brazil needs to close its budget deficit by cutting Government spending and by collecting more taxes.
Tax collection is up by one-third over last year's levels. But Congress has been reluctant to cut spending with elections looming on Oct. 3. Brazil's President, Itamar Franco, whose term winds up at the end of this year, recently signed a measure allowing for the return to work of 108,000 federal employees dismissed during the previous Government.
A privatization program cycles along at a modest pace. One state company has been sold so far this year. In May, auctions are to be held for a state shipping line and for the state aircraft manufacturer. In June, seven state petrochemical companies are to be auctioned to private bidders.
A new economic plan to reduce inflation before the presidential election was disclosed in March by Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who subsequently resigned as Economy Minister to run for president as Mr. Franco's successor.
"It's a plan of electoral opportunism," said Paulo Rabello de Castro, chairman of SR Rating, a new credit rating company in Rio de Janeiro. "Inflation could go down to 5 or 10 percentage points. But that is nothing new; Brazilian governments have already done that several times. But it won't be permanent."
If the plan is successful in the short term, it will probably set off a consumer spending boom, sending Brazil's growth rate back up to the 5 percent registered last year. But if Mr. Cardoso's plan fails, the election will probably be won by his foremost rival, Luis Inacio Lula da Silva, a socialist who has led opinion polls by a 2-to-1 margin over any challenger, including Mr. Cardoso.
When Mr. da Silva visits New York and Washington this week, he is expected to reassure United States investors that he supports foreign investment, free trade and the recent reworking of Brazil's foreign debt.
 
Beyond Politics
 Yet the flow of investment suggests that many Brazilian and foreign business people are gambling that there is limited damage a new president can do, whatever his ideological stripe. While few Brazilian business executives back Mr. da Silva, Brazilian and foreign companies here are going ahead with investment plans totaling $45 billion for this year, the highest level in five years.
"Even with its mind-boggling inflation last year, the economy grew by 5 percent in real terms and the manufacturing was up 9 percent," said Jeffrey E. Garten, the United States Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, who visited Sao Paulo last month.
"The business community is optimistic that Brazil is about to turn the corner," said Mr. Garten, a former New York investment banker. "Business is booming. Foreign investors are clamoring to get in."

HEADLINE: This Week's U.S. Sales Include Notes

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to the bills and notes markets, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. The Government will sell three-year notes tomorrow, followed by an auction on Thursday of 10-year notes.
According to traders, by the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.15 percent, and the rate on thesix-month bill was 4.61 percent. In when-issued trading, the 3-year note and 10-year note were being offered at prices to yield 6.53 percent and 7.31 percent, respectively.

HEADLINE: Essay;
For a Haitian Legion

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Here is my secret plan to avert a flood of Haitian refugees seeking political asylum, to reassert the credibility of American power in our sphere of influence, and to bring parliamentary democracy to the hemisphere's most oppressed nation -- all without the use of U.S. ground troops.
Can't be done, you say? Certainly it will not be done by following the increased-asylum plan President Clinton announced yesterday. 
 Concocted to lessen criticism from black leaders in the U.S., his plan is to (a) impose an economic blockade to make civilian Haitians miserable enough to rebel against the army; (b) pick up refugees at sea for interviews aboard U.S. ships, thereby encouraging more to seek political asylum, but turning back the majority as economic migrants; and (c) make veiled military threats with no intention of, or support for, carrying them out.
That last element of the Clinton approach -- pretending to flex military muscle -- was expressed last week in the most nail-nibbling, pusillanimous "threat" ever uttered by a President of the United States: "We are doing our best to avoid dealing with the military option."
Mr. Clinton's entreaties to the Haitian general and police chief fall on deaf ears because no real military threat exists; expending U.S. lives to save Haiti ranks low on the poll ratings that drive Clinton foreign policy. Needed is a counterforce that does not now exist.
My plan is known as "the Bay of Pigs option." Three decades ago, that place became synonymous with the word "fiasco." The C.I.A. secretly trained a military force of Cuban refugees in Florida and transported them to a Cuban beach to help topple Fidel Castro.
But when the decision came to provide the invading force the close support of air cover, President Kennedy flinched; local uprisings never materialized; and the anti-Castro Cuban patriots were killed or captured. Worse than a tragedy, it was an embarrassment.
Just because the intervention spawned in the Eisenhower Administration failed dismally then, however, does not mean that the notion of retaking an island by arming a force of its refugees can never work. We can learn from past tactical mistakes.
Where the Bay of Pigs was a secret enterprise, run by C.I.A. covert operatives who knew little about military operations, the Haitian Legion should be widely publicized, its training and equipment a challenge to the Department of Defense.
Of the nearly 200,000 Haitian refugees already in the U.S., could not a few thousand able-bodied young men be found to volunteer to fight for their country? I suspect there are more than that many patriots among them, and that -- given the training and equipment -- a serious, substantial force could be assembled.
Every American who went from soft draftee to soldier in three months of basic training knows the transformation possible. Add to that three months for development of natural leaders into noncommissioned officers, with simultaneous indoctrination of democratic procedures, and by year's end offshore Haitians would have a proud, fierce, battle-ready unit -- better equipped and trained than Haiti's.
Then you put them on U.S. warships, backed up by an aircraft carrier loaded with helicopter gunships, sail into Port-au-Prince -- and see what effect all that has on the band of hoodlums on the dock who chased us away before.
Even if the Haitian junta shows up with a larger armed force, the sight of oncoming landing craft backed up by an overwhelming show of tactical air power would contribute to a new willingness by the tinhorn generals to restore democracy and hold new, O.A.S.-supervised elections.
The object is to avoid a bloodletting with a credible show of force -- and not a Yankee force in front, but a Haitian Legion ready to fight and equally trained to form a disciplined post-crisis constabulary.
This plan will stress the Pentagon and is not foolproof: care must be taken to see that the legionnaires do not become a new junta. But it would instill pride and self-reliance, reverse the refugee flow, and generate popular bipartisan support.
What's the Clinton alternative? Ever more refugees -- a fiasco.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Lord Sharp, 77, A British Leader In Communications

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Lord Sharp of Grimsdyke, former chairman and chief executive of Cable and Wireless P.L.C., the British-based international telecommunications company, died last Monday in London. He was 77.
The cause was a heart attack, The Times of London reported. 
 Born Eric Sharp, he was made a life peer in 1989. He was chairman of Cable and Wireless from 1980 until his retirement in 1990 and chief executive from 1981 to 1990.
Cable and Wireless was founded in 1929 and languished after it was nationalized by the Labor Government after World War II. It was privatized in 1981, one of a group of enterprises privatized while Margaret Thatcher was Prime Minister, from 1979 to 1990.
Under his leadership, the concern's total revenues grew more than fifteenfold a year, and its profits increased more than tenfold. When he retired, it had operations in more than 55 countries.
Mr. Sharp pushed for the establishment of a fiber-optic cable "highway" operated by Cable and Wireless, linking Europe to Asia via the United States. The "highway" linked major financial centers and offered business customers such features as high-definition television and video-conferencing, high-speed data transmission and faxes.
In the early 1980's Cable and Wireless, with a group of investors, set up Mercury Communications, the first competitor to British Telecommunications, the Government-owned phone company. Mercury later became wholly owned by Cable and Wireless.
Eric Sharp was born in London. He earned a bachelor's degree in economics and statistics at the London School of Economics, became a British Army captain in World War II, joined Britain's Ministry of Power in 1948 and remained a civil servant until 1956.
He entered private industry in 1957 and rose high in the international operations of Monsanto, the American chemicals concern, before joining Cable and Wireless.
Lord Sharp is survived by his wife, the former Marion Freeman, whom he married in 1950; a son and a daughter.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 12, 1994, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An obituary on Monday about Lord Sharp of Grimsdyke, former chairman and chief executive of Cable and Wireless P.L.C., the British-based telecommunications company, misstated the increase in the company's revenues under his leadership. The increase was about tenfold from the 1980-81 fiscal year to the 1990-91 fiscal year, not "more than fifteenfold a year."

HEADLINE: Dow Corning Had Conflicting Findings on Silicone

BYLINE: By SANDRA BLAKESLEE 

 BODY:
Twenty years ago, the world's largest maker of silicone products made a fateful decision. Two scientific teams for the company had worked side by side for a decade on the nature of silicones, had talked to each other frequently and had come up with very different conclusions.
One group found that some forms of silicone -- including a type used in the manufacture of breast implants -- are biologically active and alter the immune system. The other group determined that silicones were inert and could be used safely in implants. 
 Based on the conclusions of the second group, the Dow Corning Corporation in Midland, Mich., decided to pursue a commercial breast implant business, former and present employees say.
The employees said the company decided to halt research into the immunological activity of silicone in 1975. Dow Corning's first implants went on the market in 1964. Eventually the company's products and those of others were sold to an estimated one million American women, accounting for approximately 1 percent of the Dow Corning's revenues over the years, according to a company spokesman.
Since the early 1980's, nearly 20,000 women who got these implants have sued Dow Corning, a joint venture of Dow Chemical Corporation and Corning Inc., and other implant manufacturers. They say the silicone gel in the implants leaked into their bodies and caused chronic pain, autoimmune disease, disfigurement, fatigue syndromes and other incurable conditions.
 
Maintaining Implants Are Safe
 Dow Corning, in spite of agreeing to be part of a $4.3 billion settlement of these claims, continues to reject their validity. "We've had 30 years of good results with implants," said Dr. Richard Mast, director of toxicology and bioscience research at Dow Corning. "We've done a tremendous amount of epidemiology. No definite connection between our products and disease" has been proved.
Dow Corning scientists have continued to study the safety of silicone materials in animals, Dr. Mast said. But he acknowledged that the company's research had in the past focused on observing the localized response to silicone exposure and not on the deeper questions of basic immunology. The company is now financing at least two laboratories that are researching the immunological effects of silicone.
Details of Dow Corning's early research into the biological activity of silicone came to light two weeks ago when lawyers representing implant patients obtained copies of a former Dow Corning scientist's papers and memorandums. The scientist, Dr. Robert S. Lake, turned the original documents over to a Federal grand jury in Baltimore on April 25, said his lawyer, Wayland Cooke. Dr. Lake is now a research scientist at the Lorillard Tobacco Company in Greensboro, N.C.
Dow Corning says that its biological research was never a secret. "The fact that we were evaluating silicones for biological activity was openly reported within Dow Corning and outside the company through published articles" in the 1970's, said Barbara Carmichael, a company spokeswoman. "We never tried to hide it."
Dow Corning executives and many of the company's top scientists maintain that the research gave proof that silicones are safe. The biological effects were "weak" and confined to materials not present in breast implants in significant amounts, said Gary Anderson, executive vice president of Dow Corning, who has been with the company since 1967.
 
'Decision Based on Profits'
 But Frederic Ellis of Gilman, McLaughlin & Hanrahan in Boston, a lawyer for the plaintiffs in the class action suit, says the existence of this research is a smoking gun: "It establishes that Dow Corning was well aware of the immunological effects of certain silicone compounds. They can say what they want 20 years later, but they made a decision based on profits, and not on the safety of the materials."
Interviews with Mr. Anderson and others who were at Dow Corning in the 1960's and 1970's help explain how the same evidence could be interpreted so differently.
In the early 60's, Dow Corning scientists were screening a variety of silicone compounds, Mr. Anderson said. Most proved to be inert, he said, but one complex silicone liquid shrank the testicles of mice. Intrigued, company scientists spent three years isolating the active ingredient, which was similar in action to natural estrogen hormones. It was licensed to Kabi Pharmaceuticals in Sweden and later used in clinical trials to treat prostate disease, but it eventually proved no better than existing compounds and was not commercialized.
Nevertheless, Dow Corning was encouraged by this find to move ahead with pharmaceutical research. In 1965, the company hired Don Bennett, an expert in drug metabolism, to head a newly formed research group called the Bioscience Research Laboratory. It was housed down the road at Dow Chemical.
 
Hoping to Cure Common Cold
 Dr. Bennett, who is now director of the division of drugs and toxicology at the American Medical Association in Chicago, recalled those days in a telephone interview. The research "was very exciting, very special," he said. "It was fun to get up in the morning and go to work. We set out to understand the absorption, distribution, biotransformation, elimination and metabolism" of silicones.
According to an article at the time in Dow Corning News, a company publication, researchers in the new laboratory sprayed silicone on plant leaves to retard evaporation, mixed silicone with herbicides to make the poisons go further and looked to see what effects silicone had on plant hormones. They used silicone compounds to kill bacteria, fungi and algae; one formulation that came out of their research is used today to reduce shoe odors.
"We were looking for chemical molecules that would be anti-virals," Dr. Bennett said. There were clues that silicone compounds might kill influenza. Dow Corning researchers hoped they might even come up with a cure for the common cold.
One of the most exciting findings, Dr. Bennett and others said, was that low molecular weight silicones are excellent adjuvants, materials that stimulate the immune system. Adjuvants are used to increase the efficacy of vaccines, he said, and this seemed a potentially lucrative market.
Controlled stimulation of the immune system is a benefit in a vaccine, but chronic uncontrolled stimulation could lead to autoimmune problems. Researchers do not know what the link is but are investigating it.
 
Need for More Research?
 Dr. Lake, an expert on viruses, was one of those researching low molecular weight silicones. In a series of experiments, he found that these could impair a critical component of the mouse immune system. But the reasons for the effects were not clear. These were the silicones later used in the manufacture of breast implants.
Dr. Bennett said recently that his group regarded the findings as indicating the need for more research. "If anything is absorbed or leached to the body systemically, further studies would be required," he said. "That was our position. We were certain that some of the smaller materials moved" and had metabolic effects.
"We never differentiated between implants or drugs," he said.
At about that time, because the group had not developed any commercial products, company executives decided to close the program, Dr. Mast said. "The program started as a scientific decision," he said. "But then you must make a logical business decision, to stop wasting your money."
Meanwhile, a second group had been working on what they believed to be inert forms of silicone for medical uses, including breast implants. This unit, composed primarily of chemists and toxicologists, was also housed at Dow Chemical, just down the hall from Dr. Bennett's group. Based on toxicology studies that looked at the local effects of implants in animals, they found no obvious reactions associated with silicone. They knew about the other group's finding of weak immune reactions, but they took this to mean that silicones are not biologically very active, and therefore were good material for use in breast implants.
 
'Almost an Embarrassment
 Dr. Bennett's group came up with a very different conclusion. "We learned there was a lot of biological activity with silicone compounds," he said. The chemists and toxicologists, on the other hand, were "sold on the concept of inertness."
"Inert did not fit with our work," Dr. Bennett said. "We were looking for active materials and we had them. We were almost an embarrassment" to the company.
One explanation of the contradictory interpretations, Dr. Bennett said, might be that compounds that are chemically inert, like silicone, are not necessarily biologically inert. And Dow Corning, the chemical company, paid more heed to its chemists than to its biologists. "Chemists typically think that biology will take care of itself," Dr. Bennett said.
To understand Dow Corning's decision, one has to recall the climate of the mid-1970's, Dr. Bennett said. Those were the days of artificial hearts and kidneys, heart valves and other mechanical medical devices, mostly made from silicone, that were going to revolutionize medicine. The term "biocompatibility" -- suggesting that materials like silicone were compatible with the human body -- was widely accepted by scientists, and doctors, he said.
Moreover, Dr. Bennett said, the nation was in a recession and this affected the business decisions at Dow Corning.
For all these reasons, the work done by Dr. Bennett's group did not raise red flags at Dow Corning.
Dr. Bennett, Dr. Lake and others in the group left the company in 1974 and 1975. Dr. Lake's research was never published.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 2, 1994, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on May 9 about research on silicones at the Dow Corning Corporation that led the company to manufacture silicone breast implants misattributed the statement that documents about the research had been turned over to a Federal grand jury by a scientist, Dr. Robert S. Lake. It was made by a lawyer for the plaintiffs in a class action lawsuit against implant makers, not by Dr. Lake's lawyer, A. Wayland Cooke.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Radio Stations Reduce Coverage of Local News

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 8

 BODY:
The percentage of commercial radio stations with no employees devoted to gathering local news increased last year to 16.9 percent, according to a survey by a radio industry trade group. The survey also showed that television news staffing has continued to grow modestly since 1987 even as radio news staffs declined at the steepest rate in more than a decade.
Opponents of broadcast deregulation cite the findings as evidence that radio listeners are being poorly served by station owners, who since 1981 have no longer been required to broadcast news and public-interest programming to obtain operating licenses. But the survey did not address how much news is broadcast by these stations, since many of them use syndicated news reports. 
 "It is efficiency at the cost of diversity," said Andy Schwartzman, director of the Media Access Project in Washington. He said the trend would most hurt those with the least access to information and cut off a career training ground that is particularly valuable to women and minorities.
 
Fewer Radio Newsrooms
 Last year, about 230 of the nation's 5,500 radio newsrooms went dark, said Vernon A. Stone, a professor emeritus at the University of Missouri, who conducted the research for the Radio-Television News Directors Association. He based his estimate on survey responses from 307 stations.
He estimated that 1,100 radio news operations had ceased since 1981, when rules were lifted on nonentertainment programming. The radio news work force now stands at 15,000, the same as in 1972, he said. The typical station news staff has one full-time employee, who may both compile and read the news, and one part-time employee.
 The findings, however, come as news-talk stations are attracting a record number of listeners. And industry executives said a decline in some local news operations was not a sign that news had been forgotten.
"That news operations are being reduced does not necessarily mean radio is abdicating its responsibilities," said William L. Stakelin, chief executive of Apollo Radio Ltd. of New York, which owns seven stations.
Industry executives say the recession accelerated a move by stations to forgo producing their own news. The industry increasingly relies on syndicated material -- news, music and talk shows -- transmitted by satellite and offered by networks on a barter basis in exchange for commercial time.
The decline in local news programming is also an outgrowth of radio's move to specialized formats ranging from bluegrass to polka; station owners have turned to narrow formats as a way to attract a specific audience desired by advertisers.
 
Consolidation of Operations
 In 1992, the Federal Communications Commission permitted owners to buy more than a single AM and FM station in the same market, and acquire up to 18 of each type of property. The previous limit had been 12 of each. Consolidation of operations, including news staff, has followed, said Bill Clark, chairman of Shamrock Broadcasting Inc. in Burbank, Calif., which owns 19 stations.
The consolidation has come as the news-talk format has soared in popularity, helping to stabilize the numbers listening on the AM band.
Last fall, news-talk stations pulled in 15.7 percent of total listeners, the highest level since 1989, when Arbitron and Billboard magazine began a national survey. "The reality is there are stations specializing in news, which lessens the viability of news for others," Mr. Stakelin said.
Neal J. Conan, a correspondent for National Public Radio, a noncommercial network, contends that the decline in local radio news staffs does not mean that listeners are less informed or or that there is less diversity among the people who present the news. "I'm not sure a three-minute newscast was vastly informative," he said. "It's not a tremendous loss."

HEADLINE: Budget Waiver To Be Sought

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said today he would urge Congress to waive its strict budget rules and avoid a $40 billion bottleneck that could kill the landmark GATT trade deal.
Some Republicans fear that such a move -- a tricky maneuver that needs the backing of 60 senators -- will unravel Washington's avowed new budgetary discipline and lead to calls for more one-time waivers that could boost the deficit. 
 But officials say the White House simply could not come up with any way to find $40 billion and had no choice but to opt for the controversial waiver in an effort to gain Congressional approval for the deal.
The General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs, which was signed last month in Morocco, will cost billions in lost tariff collections, even though economists believe the deal will spur economy growth by increasing trade. But the Federal government's budget rules require a detailed plan for raising new revenues. In effect, the rules mandate that any program which lowers Federal revenues be countered by matching spending cuts or tax hikes.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Fashion Post Is Filled At Barneys

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
Barneys New York said yesterday that it had hired Michele Smith, a top merchant at I. Magnin, as its senior vice president and general merchandise manager in charge of women's fashion.
Effective next week, she will replace Connie Darrow, who left the company in December to join Prada, the Italian leather goods house. 
 Ms. Smith will report to Bonnie L. Pressman, who runs the entire women's division and is a member of the family that owns Barneys.
 
'Lives and Breathes Fashion'
 Ms. Smith, who is 48 and has worked at I. Magnin for 28 years, is highly respected in the garment industry. "She has fabulous taste and is the kind of person who lives and breathes fashion," said Susan Sokol, the president of the designer Calvin Klein's women's collection. "She's got a terrific eye and wonderful people skills, too."
Ms. Smith's appointment comes as Barneys tries to put last fall's furor over delinquent payments behind it. Shortly before Ms. Darrow left the company, several small vendors complained that Barneys was late in paying them, giving rise to speculation that it was in financial straits.
As an outsider with no previous affiliation with Barneys, Ms. Smith may help to heal the rifts between the company and its smaller suppliers, whose cutting-edge fashions are critical to the retailer's identity as a place to find the latest styles and trends. She was responsible for European designer merchandise at I. Magnin.
She leaves I. Magnin, a unit of R. H. Macy & Company, at a critical juncture in the West Coast chain's history. I. Magnin has struggled in the last decade, closing stores as it suffered mightily in the weak California economy and lost business to rivals like Neiman Marcus. Many in the industry believe that the chain will be sold if Federated Department Stores Inc. succeeds in its bid to merge with Macy, which is in negotiations to emerge from bankruptcy protection.
Ms. Smith lives in San Francisco with her husband, David Ledesma, and daughter, Gabrielle. The family plans to move to New York.

HEADLINE: U.S. Sees New Policy on Haitian Refugees as Buying Time

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
Administration officials said today that their new policy on Haitian refugees might buy time for economic efforts to squeeze Haiti's military leaders from power, but they acknowledged that they still faced the fundamental question of what to do if that plan failed.
Even as officials from Florida began to warn about a new flood of refugees, aides to President Clinton said the most important effect of his decision to provide asylum hearings at sea to those fleeing Haiti might be to quiet American dissent. 
 Randall Robinson, a human rights campaigner, has ended his hunger strike protesting the earlier Administration policy, and other critics offered praise for Mr. Clinton's weekend announcement. These changes in attitude led some White House officials to express relief at having wriggled out of a corner.
"What this gives is time to see if the sanctions are going to work," a senior White House official said.
 
Only a Temporary Solution
 But there was no illusion at the White House that the new policy represented more than a temporary solution. Public hopefulness there was mixed with private skepticism that tighter sanctions, to be imposed on May 21, will work in time to unburden Mr. Clinton from having to decide whether restoring democracy to Haiti is worth using military force.
The new measures will impose a near-total embargo on Haiti, and Administration officials said the misery they cause might become so widespread that Mr. Clinton might not be able to wait much more than a month before resorting to blunter options to oust Haiti's military leaders.
A top aide to Mr. Clinton said, "We know that we're on a course toward bringing this to a head."
The officials also said the choice of William H. Gray 3d, a prominent black, to be Mr. Clinton's new adviser on Haiti had been intended in large part to blunt criticism from those who had characterized Washington's policy as racist.
 
Talks With Latin Governments
 In one indication of the new attention being directed at Haiti, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today that the United States was talking to Latin American governments about establishing a United Nations peacekeeping force in Haiti once the military is forced from power.
Administration officials had said previously that the United States would probably join such a force to help secure the return to power of the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Haiti's democratically elected President, whom the military ousted 30 months ago. But Mr. Christopher's remarks, during a visit to Mexico, made it clear that Washington was looking to Latin America to reinforce the message to Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras and his military colleagues that it was time for them to go.
Along with diplomacy, the focus remained on the refugees.
 
Fear of Refugee Increase
 Officials from Florida said Mr. Clinton's decision to stop summarily returning refugees intercepted at sea would result in a major increase in the flow from Haiti.
Senator Bob Graham, a Democrat, predicted that 5,000 to 10,000 people would leave Haiti each month to seek asylum, far more than the 1,300 who have been intercepted at sea so far this year. Mr. Graham said he feared that the new policy would "amount to a very substantial green light for people to leave Haiti."
But Administration officials insisted that they did not expect the increase to be overwhelming. Even though Mr. Clinton said his decision to allow processing at sea was motivated by worsening violence in Haiti, the officials said they did not expect that many more than the current 5 percent of refugees would be judged to be motivated by political reasons, and thereby allowed to enter the United States.
"Most people who are trying to leave the country are still doing so because of the economic situation," a senior official said. "There may be some increase, but I don't think it will be a substantial one."
The complaints from Mr. Graham and other Floridians, including Gov. Lawton Chiles, a Democrat, underscored the potential peril of a decision to open the door to more refugees. Even today, Administration officials said they hoped to persuade other nations, including Venezuela and Honduras, to accept some refugees.
With Mr. Clinton vowing with increasing fervor to end what he has called the Haitian military's "brutal misrule," Administration officials are portraying the stiffer sanctions as their final attempt at economic coercion.
 
May 21 Deadline Set
 Along with an immediate ban on granting visas to 600 of Haiti's top military and police officers, the measure gives the military until midnight May 21 to hand over power to Father Aristide or face virtual economic strangulation, with exceptions allowed only for food, medicine and certain supplies like books.
In a television interview this weekend, Samuel R. Berger, Mr. Clinton's deputy national security adviser, said the sanctions could cause such resentment among Haitian business and union leaders and others that General Cedras would recognize that he was in a "dead end" and would step down.
But other officials said they were far from confident that sanctions could have that effect during the limited time the White House is willing to maintain them. Michael D. Barnes, a former Congressman who is an adviser to Father Aristide, expressed similar doubts.
"Clearly the Haitian military no longer believes that the international community is serious about restoring Aristide," Mr. Barnes said. "They don't believe that the sanctions will really bite, and they certainly don't believe that they face any threat of ending up like Manuel Noriega, so the international community is going to have to demonstrate some clear resolve." The reference was to the Panamanian leader, removed by United States military intervention.

HEADLINE: Jawboning's Limits;
Some Say It's Time That the Administration Rethought Its Trade Policy Toward Japan

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
After almost a year of jawboning and negotiating, the Clinton Administration has little to show for its trade policy toward Japan, and some Administration officials and analysts are beginning to wonder aloud whether it is time for the United States to rethink its strategy.
The combination of the weak new coalition Government in Tokyo and the turmoil in world currency markets has seriously weakened the Clinton Administration's ability to get Japan to open certain of its closed markets and reduce its huge trade surplus with the rest of the world. 
 Japan's Finance Ministry announced today that its huge trade imbalance with the rest of the world had widened again, soaring to a record $130.04 billion in the fiscal year which just ended March 31. That is up 3.3 percent from last year's $125.9 billion, although there are indications that the stronger yen and weaker dollar are beginning to cut away at that surplus.
While senior American economic officials put a brave face on such figures and are counseling patience, several policy makers and lawmakers are saying privately that the Clinton strategy toward Japan is moribund, unlikely to produce the expected results and probably going to have to be redesigned.
These officials note that after a year of trying to negotiate a market-opening deal with Tokyo, the Clinton Administration finds itself without either a Japanese Government strong enough to deliver the trade initiatives Washington wants or the alternative currency weapons it was relying on to achieve the same results.
Since last July, the Clinton Administration has tried, but failed, to get the Japanese Government to agree through negotiations to certain "numerical indicators" that would show over time whether or not Japan was really opening its markets in insurance, autos and auto parts, telecommunications and medical equipment.
"We finally find ourselves face to face with a long-hidden truth, which is that the only people who can deliver in Japan are not the politicians but the bureaucrats and business cartels, who have not been the focus of our policy," said Clyde V. Prestowitz, head of the Economic Strategy Institute, which advocates a tough line against Japan on trade.
"The issue that the Clinton Administration now faces is how do you create a situation in which the bureaucrats and business cartels in Japan see it in their interest to strike a deal," he added. "It is clear the political leaders cannot deliver. And it is clear that there are limits to what we can do through the currency."
When it first became apparent in February that the Japanese Government could not or would not deliver what the American side wanted, the Clinton Administration began tacitly supporting a weak dollar and strong yen to pressure the Japanese Cabinet and bureaucrats to open their markets. A strong yen makes it harder for Japan to sell abroad and a weak dollar makes it easier for American products to penetrate Japan's markets.
But this has come at a price which has become unacceptable to Washington. Currency traders reacted dramatically to what they thought was a green light from the White House for the dollar to go way down, pushing the dollar to levels that were intolerable to the Clinton Administration, which had to intervene in the markets to prop up the American currency.
 
 
Pressure on Fed
 The falling dollar increased pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates to keep attracting foreign investors to buy American Treasury notes and bonds needed to finance the deficit. While Japanese investors bought a net total of $6.5 billion in American Treasury securities in the fourth quarter of last year, the falling dollar resulted in their selling a net $3.75 billion in the first two months of this year -- contributing to a widening of the current account imbalance and higher overall interest rates.
"The data suggests that the risks of continuing to maintain an image of policy conflict with Japan will be to discourage Japanese from investing in our markets," John P. Lipsky, chief economist for Solomon Brothers, said.
The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, has been told by Japan's Prime Minister, Tutsomo Hata, that Tokyo is eager to try to resolve the trade conflict between the two countries and that he will be forwarding some fresh proposals shortly. President Clinton wants to give Mr. Hata a chance to deliver and spoke with the Japanese Prime Minister by telephone over the weekend about resuming the negotiations, officials said.
 
 
Lacks Political Muscle
 But many Clinton Administration economic officials and analysts are skeptical about what Japan will come up with. The Hata Government does not even have a majority in the Parliament and hardly appears to have the political muscle to take on the Japanese bureaucracy and force through the sort of fundamental changes in Japanese trade policy demanded by Washington.
Some analysts believe that the Administration really now has only two choices. The first is to acknowledge that the sort of far-reaching, market-opening devices it hoped to negotiate with Tokyo are not going to happen and they should take whatever they can get out of the Hata Government, declare a modest victory, and try other means to keep the pressure on Tokyo for long-term change. That would at least stabilize the financial markets and take some of the pressure off the dollar and the yen.
The other option is simply to maintain the status quo, of pressing Japan to meet American demands, but to focus less on opening specific sectors of the Japanese economy and more on the other main American objective: getting Tokyo to stimulate its overall growth and consumer spending through tax cuts and other fiscal and monetary measures so that it will import more of everything. Some officials believe this holds out the best hope of diminishing Japan's global trade surplus, without destabilizing either the fragile Japanese Government or the currency markets. But it may take a long time to show results.
