HEADLINE: Vietnam Revisited: A periodic report.;
Where Monuments Speak of a U.S. Defeat, the Talk Is of 'Peaceful Contacts'

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam

 BODY:
In Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City there are Vietnamese who wash down pizza with Coke, pay for things with American dollars, wear American flag patches on jackets and yell "hello!" at any "big nose" foreigner they see.
But the country still raises patriotic banners gloating over what the Communists regard as America's defeat in the Vietnam War. Beneath an outwardly friendly curiosity many Vietnamese display toward Americans, a predatory undertone tinged with bitter resentment is often detectable. There are many reminders for Americans visiting Vietnam of the lacerations left by a war that ended nearly two decades ago but that still colors Vietnamese attitudes. 
 Vietnam's political leaders face something of a quandary as they reshape national policy toward the United States.
On one hand, the 1975 victory over the South Vietnamese Government and its American ally, still fresh in the minds of many, is commemorated as a historic triumph comparable to America's victory over the British at Yorktown. America, to some, is still an enemy -- a fighting enemy to Communist military veterans, and a perfidious former friend to those Vietnamese who regard America's withdrawal from the war as a betrayal.
 
Much Is Needed And U.S. Can Help
 Moreover, there are some who resent the 19 years it took Washington to lift its trade embargo, and the attitude of American conservatives who continue to block diplomatic recognition of the Hanoi Government.
But eclipsing these irritants, Vietnamese leaders have come to believe that there is a pressing need for American investment, technical aid, tourist visits and many other kinds of contact with the United States. Hanoi is even trying to persuade thousands of overseas Vietnamese (known as Viet Kieu), including Vietnamese-American refugees, to return to their native land and help rebuild it. Many have come back for temporary visits, and a few, disillusioned with life in the United States, expect to remain.
The Government is celebrating a double anniversary -- the 19th of the fall of Saigon, renamed Ho Chi Minh City after the war, on April 30, 1975, and the 40th of the fall of the French bastion at Dien Bien Phu on May 7, 1954.
Anti-American sentiments adorned some of the red-and-gold celebratory banners flown over streets for the occasion, but as a sign of the times, Vietnamese authorities did not include English or French translations that might have offended foreign visitors. Aside from the Communist slogans, visiting Americans -- tourists, business executives, journalists and officials of the United States Missing in Action Mission -- are treated by officials in Vietnam with studied courtesy and conciliation.
On the anniversary of Saigon's surrender to the Communists, for example, this correspondent was received at the home of Gen. Vo Nguyen Giap for a brief chat. The 83-year-old general, who commanded the Vietnamese Communist forces against both the French and the Americans, has been rated by Western military analysts as one of the greatest generals of the 20th century. But "the victor of Dien Bien Phu," as he is often called, does not gloat.
 
Old Warrior Muses On Today's World
 One subject of the conversation was the fall of Saigon in 1975, which this correspondent covered for The New York Times.
Imposing in his olive-green uniform and general's shoulder tabs, General Giap was avuncular and cordial, and clearly reluctant to say anything he thought an American might find objectionable. Speaking in French, he deferred benignly to frequent interjections and corrections from his wife, Dang Bich Ha, who was once a soldier in the Communist forces herself.
At his comfortable villa a few hundred yards from the Lenin-style mausoleum of Ho Chi Minh, General Giap, the supreme commander of Hanoi's legions from 1952 until 1977, mused on the changing state of the world.
"In the traditional sense, the threat of colonialism and imperialism has disappeared," he said, "and we shall probably not need to confront such threats again. We Vietnamese are optimists. But even though we face no shooting war in Vietnam, the world is in a very uncertain state, and Vietnam must always be willing to sacrifice to protect its freedom."
He praised the "fairness" of American journalists, and said that after retiring from active command he had turned his attention increasingly to the war against pollution and the preservation of the environment -- causes he knew to be popular with the American press.
General Giap's masterly command of logistics and maneuver, and his deployment of artillery at the isolated Dien Bien Phu fortress in 1954, caught the French defenders by surprise and stunned world leaders; a peasant army had brought a well-armed European army to its knees.
General Giap's 1962 book "People's War, People's Army," which outlines the mixture of political warfare and military strategy that was his hallmark, became a textbook for guerrilla insurgents in many parts of the world, and was highly regarded even by such longtime battlefield foes as the late Gen. William E. DePuy of the United States Army.
Although General Giap spent much of the anniversary of the fall of Saigon receiving Vietnamese military well-wishers and admirers, he took care in the interview to avoid any suggestion of belligerency.
"We certainly have no fight with the American people," he said, "and we welcome peaceful contacts with your country."
But despite the diplomatic language Vietnamese leaders use with Americans, there remain many reminders of the war that most Americans would find galling.
On Hai Ba Trung Street in Ho Chi Minh City stands a tall, unkempt-looking building that was formerly the Brink Hotel -- a military billet erected for United States Army officers. On Christmas Eve 1964, Vietcong terrorists drove a jeep containing a huge bomb into the building's courtyard and set it off, killing two Americans and wounding 58.
Today a monument stands at the corner entrance of the building, adorned with a concrete relief sculpture depicting American dead and wounded scattered through the debris. In front of the marker is a single strip of barbed wire, symbolizing the huge thicket of barbed wire that surrounded the building in the war years.
 
A Forbidding Prison, Full of Memories
 There is no marker at the floating My Canh Restaurant in Ho Chi Minh City, but many Americans remember it as the place where Vietcong bombs set off in June 1965 killed 44 diners, including 12 Americans. One, Sgt. Al Combs of the Special Forces, was killed along with his Vietnamese wife and their children.
Hanoi is also filled with disagreeable reminders of the war. At the Army Museum on Dien Bien Phu Street, a large bin containing dozens of flight helmets taken from American fliers shot down over North Vietnam is displayed. Outside, a freshly painted MIG-21 has been mounted; a sign says the aircraft shot down a dozen American planes.
The looming yellow walls and electrified wire surrounding Hoa Lo Prison in Hanoi -- known to Americans as the "Hanoi Hilton" -- remind visitors of a time when many American servicemen were imprisoned there, undergoing privation and mistreatment.
In Ho Chi Minh City, the former Doc Lap Presidential Palace has been restored as a museum intended to show the wasteful extravagance of the old regime, as abetted by the United States. Guides at the palace, English-speaking girls who had not even been born at the time Saigon fell, shepherd visitors through "shamefully opulent" reception chambers, a ballroom, dining halls and private quarters where South Vietnam's last President, Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu, spent his last days before fleeing to the United States.
Adorning the walls of District People's Committee headquarters and other official offices in many parts of Vietnam are photographs of Nguyen Van Troi bound to a stake and facing a firing squad in Saigon on Oct. 15, 1964. Troi, now a national hero for whom one of Ho Chi Minh City's main streets has been renamed, was caught and shot after trying to kill Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara by planting a bomb under a bridge Mr. McNamara's limousine was scheduled to cross.
 
The War Is Over; English Classes Call
 At West Lake in Hanoi is a monument honoring city residents who helped to find and capture downed American airmen. At a small lake in the suburban Ngoc Ha ("Flower Village") district of Hanoi is a monument honoring the antiaircraft missile crews that shot down American bombers in the 1960's and 1970's. In the middle of the lake stand a large fuselage section and wheels from a B-52 that was shot down at the spot in 1972, and was left where it fell.
Although the relic could offend some Americans, Vietnamese passers-by seldom spare it a glance. Many are hurrying to attend evening English classes offered at a school facing the lake, and the few Americans who visit the lake are usually hailed by children eager to practice their English. "We all must learn English if we hope to become traders and make money," one said.
A recent American visitor to Hanoi was John Denver, the folk singer, who happened to arrive on the anniversary of the fall of Saigon to begin a series of concerts.
"We had a phone call from an American back home who was under the mistaken impression that our first concert would coincide with the anniversary, and the caller didn't like what that seemed to imply," Mr. Denver said, "but we reassured him our arrival on that day was just coincidence."
Mr. Denver, who said he was exempt from the draft in the Vietnam War years because of a medical disability, said his concerts here -- the first by any American folk singer since the end of the Vietnam War -- had no political significance.
 
The Nation's Poverty Is Breeding Crime
 The crime bred by Vietnam's poverty is not helping to heal Vietnamese-American relations. Gangs of street children envelop foreigners as they step out of their hotels, and theft is a constant threat. Believing that a recent American visitor could not understand Vietnamese, one gang leader was overheard instructing his scruffy lieutenants to obstruct her way in the next block so that confederates could grab her watch.
It seems to some American businessmen that many Vietnamese are determined to attract as much American investment as possible while giving as little as possible in return. "In their eyes, Americans lost the war and although we are rich, we are weak," a businessman said. "The idea seems to be to take us for all they can get."
A Vietnamese former employee of an American company that had an office in Saigon before the Communist victory expressed a common view of Vietnamese who remained after their American colleagues fled.
"We have had very difficult lives," he said. "Some of us spent years in prisons, re-education camps and 'new economic zones' -- Vietnam's Siberias -- because we worked for Americans. But despite all, we love our country. I am glad I stayed, and so is my family. Some Vietnamese who opposed the Communists still resent America's leaders for abandoning Vietnam, but I say, forgive and forget."
A Government official offered a more diplomatic view. "The war brought us victory and we are proud of that," he said, "but the hatred is past and we are getting on with the future. Part of that future means learning English and making American friends."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The walls of Hoa Lo Prison, the "Hanoi Hilton" where many American servicemen were imprisoned, still loom grimly in the Vietnamese capital. (Monica Almeida/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rates Continue to Rise; Traders Still Nervous

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Interest rates continued to surge yesterday, rising to their highest levels since shortly after President Clinton was elected.
The most obvious source of upset during yesterday's session seemed to be the Federal Reserve Board. 
 Expectations that the Fed would move immediately to raise short-term interest rates in the wake of the strong April employment data released Friday were unrealized, because the Fed gave no sign that it had raised the overnight rate on bank loans in the Federal funds market.
But given the sour tone that has been pervasive in the market since early February, when the Fed began to tighten monetary policy, it is unlikely a move by the central bank would have done much to calm nervous traders.
"I don't think I can ever remember when the market's psychology was this bad," said Joseph Liro, chief economist at S. G. Warburg & Company. "The gloom is pervasive, and deep."
By late in the day, the bellwether 6 1/4 percent bonds of 2023 were offered at a price of 83 7/8, down a full point, or $10 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 7.63 percent. Over the last two trading sessions, bond yields have risen by 30 basis points.
Meanwhile, the outstanding 5 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at a late price of 8831/32 , down 29/32 on the day, to yield 7.48 percent.
Traders expect the Fed to continue raising short-term interest rates because the economy appears to be steaming along at a pace that if left unchecked will push up inflation.
 
An Incremental Approach
 Although some analysts expect the Fed will continue its incremental approach to raising short-term rates, many said they expected a more dramatic move this time.
Rather than raise the funds rate by one-quarter point for the fourth straight month, at some point between now and May 17, when the Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee is scheduled to meet, these analysts contend the Fed will raise the funds rate by half a point, to 4.25 percent, and increase the discount rate.
"The market needs an exclamation point," said Mitchell Held, chief financial economist at Smith Barney Shearson.
The April employment data, and big upward revisions in previously reported numbers for February, reinforced that notion.
"During the first four months we have created almost one million new jobs, and are on a pace to create 2.5 million to 3 million this year," said Steven A. Wood, director of financial markets research at BA Securities Inc. in San Francisco. "In all of last year we only created 2 million."
The jobs report caused many analysts to ratchet up second-quarter growth forecasts.
Mr. Wood is projecting growth of between 4 percent and 5 percent this quarter, a pace that he said "continues to have the Fed and the market worried about how strong the economy is, and about inflation."
Economists say that if not reined in, growth in excess of about 2.5 percent will fuel inflationary pressures.
But so far, inflation remains under control. With inflation remaining low, Edward S. Hyman, president of International Strategy and Investment, a money management firm, noted in a weekly report to clients that the rise in interest rates that has taken place over the last three months has pushed real, inflation-adjusted bond yields to their highest level in nine years.
With the Treasury set to begin its quarterly refunding auctions today, professional traders seem to believe that yields will go even higher. But some analysts acknowledge that the increase in rates should begin to attract demand from small investors.
A good test of that view will come at today's three-year note auction.
 
Sale of New Securities
 The Treasury is scheduled to sell $17 billion of the new securities. By late yesterday, the notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 6.66 percent. Last October, yields on 30-year Treasury bonds got as low as 5.79 percent.
"It's an incredible value," Mr. Liro said, "because inflation is running at a 2.5 percent rate now, and over the next three years the worst case inflation rate is about 4.5 percent.
The surge in short-term and long-term interest rates was also manifested at yesterday's auction of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills, which were sold at their highest levels in about two and a half years.
The three-month bills were auctioned at an average discout rate of 4.32 percent, up 32 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, from the average yield on three-month bills at last week's auction. It is the highest yield on a three-month bill since the auction on Dec. 2, 1991, when the average yield was 4.39 percent.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: Jury Convicts Rifkin, Rejecting Insanity Plea

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., May 9

 BODY:
Joel Rifkin, the unemployed landscaper who led a secret life of killing prostitutes and keeping their corpses for days, was found to be legally sane today by a jury that took only two hours to convict him of murder.
Mr. Rifkin, 34, who stood expressionless as the jury read its verdict, had admitted killing 17 women, so the facts of the case were never at issue in the two-week trial. 
 The real question before the jury was whether Mr. Rifkin, described by the prosecution's expert witness as a sadist and necrophiliac who even as a child was fascinated by strangulation, was legally insane, as his lawyer maintained.
But the jurors, to their own surprise, voted unanimously on their first ballot that he was guilty of murder, agreeing that he did not meet the legal definition for insanity because he knew what he was doing when he strangled his victims, and knew it was wrong.
Mr. Rifkin was also convicted of charges of reckless endangerment stemming from the police chase. He faces a maximum sentence of 25 years to life in prison for the murder conviction and another 2 1/3 to 7 years for the endangerment conviction.
Mr. Rifkin's own words convicted him, jurors said after leaving the Nassau County Courthouse.
"When Rifkin was talking over the possibilities of a psychiatric defense with one of his psychiatrists and said, 'I'm not in the book,' that did it for me," said Joseph Cavaco, a business manager from Levittown.
"He knew from the start an insanity defense wasn't going to work, and we proved him right," Mr. Cavaco said. "Our first vote was unanimous, which surprised me. I thought for sure there would be some differences of opinion, but no one bought his insanity defense."
Mr. Cavaco, who has a 16-year-old daughter about the same height and weight as Mr. Rifkin's 17th victim, Tiffany Bresciani, 22, of Manhattan, said, "It didn't affect my verdict, but I couldn't help thinking about my daughter and all those young women he killed."
Another juror, Rita Cobian, a manager for Nynex, said that the prosecutor, Fred Klein, had been "very effective" in convincing the jury that Mr. Rifkin was not insane.
"He put all the pieces together for us, and reaching a verdict was no struggle at all," Ms. Cobian said.
On leaving the courthouse, Mr. Rifkin's lawyer, John Lawrence, said, "We gave it our best shot, presented the evidence and the issues, and the jury didn't see it that way."
He said that Mr. Rifkin, whom he had represented for no fee, "had no reaction whatever" to the verdict. "He just stood up and said, 'I'll see you.' He thanked me, and that was it."
Mr. Rifkin was on trial only for the killing of Ms. Bresciani, whom he picked up on the streets of lower Manhattan last June, paid $20 for sex, then strangled in the back seat of his mother's car.
He took her body to his home in East Meadow, where he stored it in the garage for three days, then loaded it in the back of his pickup truck. In the early hours of June 28, while looking for a place to dump her corpse, he was stopped by the state police for a traffic violation, and troopers found the body. After his arrest, he confessed to killing Ms. Bresciani and 16 other women.
Mr. Rifkin is to go on trial as early as next month in two killings in Suffolk County, and he faces other trials in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx.
Lawyers on both sides addressed the insanity issue head-on during their summations this morning. Mr. Lawrence insisted that his client did not know what he was doing and often drove around in a haze after strangling his victims, "talking to them as if they were still alive."
"Strange? Yes," he said. "Sick? Yes. Incomprehensible? Yes. But to Joel, it was a state of mind. He did not understand what he was doing. His was a mind that was unraveling."
But the prosecutor urged the jurors to reject that claim.
 
'He Wants to Fool You'
 "He knew he was a serial killer," Mr. Klein said. "He studied books on it; it was his bedtime reading. And he studied police procedures for tracing bodies so he could fool people. Now he wants to fool you."
Mr. Klein said that when the state police arrested him, Mr. Rifkin was planning to dismember Ms. Bresciani's body before dumping it near an airport in Suffolk County.
He showed the jury a knife that was found in the front seat of Mr. Rifkin's truck, along with a set of bolt cutters he said Mr. Rifkin planned to use to cut through Ms. Bresciani's joints.
In closing, Mr. Klein read off the names of Mr. Rifkin's known victims, and said there were probably at least one or two more that Mr. Rifkin, "for reasons of his own," would not talk about.
Mr. Klein, the last to speak to the jurors, completed his summation shortly after noon. Judge Ira H. Wexner spent the next hour charging the jury, explaining the vagaries of an insanity defense and the charges against Mr. Rifkin.
After the verdict was announced, Judge Wexner remanded Mr. Rifkin to Nassau County Jail until sentencing on June 8.
Mr. Klein said he was "gratified by the verdict" and "glad that the jury was able to resolve the issues in what seems like a fairly short amount of time for all the evidence they had to consider."
Mr. Klein said "the fact that the verdict was so quick should convince the other counties that they have good cases against Mr. Rifkin also."
Mr. Cavaco, the juror, said that he and other jurors were affected by two letters Mr. Rifkin wrote to Mr. Lawrence last December, when Mr. Rifkin was hiring a new psychiatrist to help in his defense.
Mr. Rifkin said he wanted to carefully determine what documents were given to the new doctor so that the doctor was not given anything "incriminating." Mr. Rifkin also talked in the letters of writing a book and marketing his story before it became a public record.
"This just said to me, 'Here's a smart clever man who knows just what he's doing and is trying to cash in on it,' " Mr. Cavaco said.
Another juror, who declined to give her name but said she works for a branch of Apple Bank in Bethpage, also said that it was Mr. Rifkin's comment "I'm not in the book" that "stands out most in my mind."
"He knew he wasn't crazy," she said. "He knew what he was doing was wrong."
The letters Mr. Rifkin wrote and all of his taped conversations with his own and prosecution psychiatrists and psychologists became a part of the court record because Mr. Rifkin pursued the insanity defense, which places the burden of proof on him.
Margarita Gonzalez of Brooklyn, whose 23-year-old sister, Jenny Soto, was one of Mr. Rifkin's victims, said she was praying for a guilty verdict and wanted to shout with joy when the jury announced its decision.
But she said the verdict did not bring an end to her pain. "I'm just going to keep going to the other trials, and maybe they'll get around to my sister's," she said. "Then I can go back to my own life."

HEADLINE: Christopher Presses Mexico To Insure Its Election Is Fair

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, May 9

 BODY:
In a sign of growing American concern that political strife could arise from Mexico's coming presidential election, Secretary of State Warren Christopher urged the Mexican Government today to take further steps to assure a credible outcome, officials of the two countries said.
Publicly, Mr. Christopher took the opportunity of a biannual meeting of senior United States and Mexican officials to praise the economic and political changes undertaken by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari and voice confidence that the Aug. 21 vote would be free and fair. 
 In private, however, American officials said Mr. Christopher departed from the agenda of the so-called Binational Commission to convey the Clinton Administration's belief that Mexico must leave behind the fraudulent practices and contested results of its electoral past if ties between the two countries are to be strengthened.
"Any kind of challenge to the legitimacy of the election will be a tremendous problem for our relationship," said one of several United States officials who discussed the American position on the condition they not be identified.
"There is a feeling that the general lines of the electoral reforms they have laid out are in the right direction," the official said of election-law changes that the Mexican Congress has approved in recent months or is now considering. "There's less confidence that these things are working out in the way they should."
For the most part, United States officials said they had merely pushed the Mexicans to approve and fully implement democratic reforms that the Government and its Institutional Revolutionary Party had already promised to adopt. Those include auditing the voter rolls, prohibiting the political use of Government funds, new limits on campaign spending and more equal access to the news media for opposition parties.
Yet the officials said their warnings also reflected a sense that some Mexican Cabinet officials are resisting the proposed changes and that despite the passage of other measures their success will still depend on how they are put into effect.
In particular, the officials said Mr. Christopher pressed the Mexican Foreign Minister, Manuel Tello Macias, to support the invitation of foreign election observers as a way of increasing the legitimacy of the result. Two officials said President Clinton also raised the issue in a conversation with the Mexican Ambassador to Washington, Jorge Montano, on May 5.
Three Mexican officials said that while Mr. Tello and some others did oppose the observers, Mr. Salinas supported their presence.
With his assent, they said, members of the United Nations Electoral Assistance Unit visited Mexico in late April. They added that the Government would soon respond to a memorandum from the unit suggesting that it could play a limited role in helping to organize the network of Mexican-born observers that has emerged over the last three years.
The stance taken by Mr. Christopher and other American officials represents a shift in United States policy toward Mexico after the peasant rebellion that began Jan. 1 in the southern state of Chiapas and the assassination on March 23 of the governing party's presidential candidate, Luis Donaldo Colosio. Both events have badly shaken the Government and its party.

HEADLINE: Executives Balking At Clinton Health Plan

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
As Congress moves toward a vote on health care, the great majority of the nation's top executives are lining up against President Clinton's plan -- particularly his insistence that companies insure all their workers and pay most of the cost, a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.
Business opposition to the Clinton plan, with its mandatory coverage, appears to have increased in recent months, some executives suggested in interviews after the poll. Some say they oppose the plan even though it might reduce their health insurance costs, because they are philosophically opposed to giving the Government a greater role in health care, as the President would do. 
 While there are some notable exceptions -- like the Ford Motor Company and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation -- opposition to big government has become the corporate rallying cry in the battle over health care legislation. When President Clinton first proposed his plan, many companies welcomed his ideas. Now, however, the broad corporate resistance presents a big obstacle to passage of the White House's proposal.
"The crowd I run in, there is clear opposition to the Clinton plan, and it is solidifying," said Richard K. Davidson, chief executive of the Union Pacific Railroad, who is among the opponents, although the Clinton plan would probably reduce Union Pacific's costs for insuring 28,000 employees. "People are thinking of the negatives, the big brother role for government, the hidden costs, the taxation, that sort of thing. They fear big-government solutions."
The poll of top officers at 484 companies, representing a cross section of corporate America, showed a preference for keeping the present basic payment system, with its heavy reliance on voluntary, rather than mandatory, company-sponsored insurance -- a practice that leaves gaps in coverage for millions of people.
While 60 percent of the executives agreed that the health insurance system should be changed, 75 percent balked at altering their own status. They suggested, in the interviews, changes aimed at achieving such goals as reducing malpractice claims or giving small companies easier access to private insurance. But, on the other hand, they insisted that companies should retain their right to decide whether to insure employees and at what cost. And that view showed up in large and small companies.
"The Clinton plan might save me money, but I am not for it anyway," said Melbern G. Glasscock, president of Texas Aromatics Inc., a Houston company that buys and sells petrochemicals and employs 21 people, most of them covered under a company health insurance policy. "I am against any government interference. The long-term effect is that it will end up costing us more in the long run, and we give up freedom."
 
Millions Are Left Out
 The current voluntary system leaves 48 million working Americans without health insurance from their employers, although many are covered through a spouse's policy or a parent's. Lack of coverage particularly affects part-timers and people who work for small companies. Also, some companies design their premiums to encourage workers or their families to go elsewhere for insurance -- a practice the Clinton plan would end.
The Lucas Dealership Group, a chain of auto dealerships in the San Francisco area and in Hawaii, follows this practice. Lucas pays the entire $250-a-month premium to insure each of its 711 workers, but only 50 percent of the additional amount for family members. Thus, while each employee gets full coverage free, those with a spouse and, say, two children pay $150 a month to cover them. "That encourages the spouse to sign up where he or she works, which keeps down our costs," said Donald Lucas, the company's chief executive.
The Clinton plan requires every employer to pay 80 percent of the premium for family coverage for all employees, up to a maximum of 7.9 percent of a company's payroll. (The Lucas Dealership spends 5 percent of its payroll.) If a husband and a wife work at separate companies, then each company pays for full family coverage for the same family, thus increasing the contributions to the pools for insuring all Americans.
Under the Clinton plan, the money is to be paid into regional alliances, supervised by state governments, that contract with private health groups to offer a variety of insurance plans from which employees and unemployed individuals can choose. The Federal Government would subsidize premium payments for the poor, the unemployed and low-wage workers. It is the subsidies and the bureaucracy required to administer the program that have become targets of corporate opposition.
In the poll, conducted in late April, 71 percent of the executives said that health care would "worsen" with Clinton's plan in place, a far higher degree of pessimism than among the public. Only 38 percent of 1,215 people questioned in a New York Times/CBS News Poll in April thought the Clinton proposal would cause health care to deteriorate. While 78 percent of the executives polled described themselves as Republicans or nearly so, only 45 percent of the people in the public opinion poll described themselves in the same way.
If American companies fail to get Congress to go along with their first choice -- retaining the right to control the health insurance they offer -- then 58 percent of the executives said they would accept a fallback law requiring them to offer health insurance to all their workers, but with the proviso that the employees could be charged the entire premium. Only 32 percent of the executives polled said companies should be required to pay most of the premium.
 
Small Retailer's View
 Harry Jensen, owner of two rural grocery stores near Cedar Rapids, Iowa, would accept a requirement that he offer health insurance to his 50 employees, as long as he can decide who pays the premium. Currently only 10 of his employees, all full-timers, are offered coverage. Ten other full-timers in the less profitable of his two stores are not, nor are any of the 30 part-timers in both stores.
"If you are working in a no-growth area like I am, where you can't get prices up, it is hard to pay for health insurance," said Mr. Jensen, who is president of Jensen Holiday Foods Inc. He pays half of the premium of $1,500 a month for all of his insured workers, up from $700 five years ago. "I would not mind making health insurance available to everyone, as long as I did not have to pay too much of the cost," he said. "If I did, I might have to lay people off or cut salaries."
Among the various bills before Congress, corporate America has concentrated on two principal alternatives to the Clinton approach, which is itself embodied in several bills, including one proposed yesterday by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts. One of the two alternatives is sponsored mainly by Representative Jim Cooper, Democrat of Tennessee. It would require employers to offer health insurance to all employees, but without making them pay for it. The other, whose principal sponsor is Representative J. Roy Rowland, Democrat of Georgia, requires employers to offer health insurance only to employees working more than 30 hours a week -- but also without making the companies pay for it.
The Rowland bill comes close to maintaining the status quo for nearly a decade. It does so by excluding part-timers -- people working fewer than 30 hours a week -- from coverage and by exempting until 2002 any company that was contributing to group health insurance on Sept. 1, 1993. That approach has won over many companies, including the J. C. Penney Company, with 190,000 employees in stores across the country.
 
Not All Are Covered
 Penney's 65,000 part-timers are excluded from the company's health insurance plan, which offers coverage comparable to that in the Clinton package. Of the 125,000 full-timers, each working 25 hours a week or more, 90,000 are covered. Many of the rest are covered under a relative's policy at another company -- a practice that Penney, like the Lucas car dealership, tends to encourage with differential premiums. The company pays 70 percent of the cost for each employee, but only 50 percent for a spouse and 60 percent for each child.
"We consider health insurance as a benefit freely provided to attract people to work for our company," said James Schwaninger, Penney's director of government relations. "When health insurance is mandated, it is no longer a benefit. Social Security is not a benefit."
Corporate support for the Clinton plan comes mainly from giant manufacturers like Ford or Bethlehem Steel. Under union contracts, these companies pay all the cost of rich health insurance policies that cover not only all their employees but also tens of thousands of retirees not yet old enough for Medicare.
The Clinton plan would subsidize insurance premiums for these early retirees. And by subsidizing coverage for poorer Americans, the Clinton plan would also relieve these companies of the burden of cost-shifting. That happens when an indigent person is treated at a hospital or by a doctor without charge. These providers then cover the cost by padding the bills for a Ford or a Bethlehem.
 
Some Expect Lower Costs
 "The Clinton plan would lower our costs over a number of years," said Benjamin C. Boylston, vice president of human resources at Bethlehem, which has 20,000 employees and 70,000 retirees. He added that "most companies, if they really looked at their numbers," would find that the Clinton plan lowered their costs.
The poll offered contradictory evidence on this point. At least two-thirds of the executives disagreed with Mr. Boylston, saying the Clinton plan would raise their costs. But more than half also said that they did not know yet what the impact might be on their businesses.
The Union Pacific Railroad, like Bethlehem, offers rich health care coverage, although it has fewer retirees. But like so many other executives, Mr. Davidson, the railroad's chief executive, opposes the Clinton plan on the ground that he is against big government. "We would end up with additional taxes and the costs of a government infrastructure that would offset any savings from less cost-shifting," he said.
While big companies like Union Pacific and Ford might cut their spending on health care under a Clinton plan, many small companies might end up having to pay more, among them Morey Mahoney Advertising, a Denver agency with 14 employees. It pays 80 percent of the premium for family coverage for its employees, and the Clinton plan would probably drive up the agency's costs, says Arthur Mahoney Jr., the president.
Nevertheless, he favors it. "I have a major problem with anything that is inefficient," Mr. Mahoney said. "But no one has been able to demonstrate that the insurance industry, with all its multiple forms of bureaucracy, is more efficient than the Government. And this is a problem that cannot be solved by taking a selfish view of one's self-interest."
 
 
 
HOW THE POLL WAS CONDUCTED
 The New York Times/CBS News Poll of business executives is based on telephone interviews, conducted from April 15 to April 29, with senior executives at companies throughout the United States.
The sample of companies and executives was randomly drawn by Dun & Bradstreet Information Services from those listed in its data base of privately held and publicly owned companies.
As with previous polls in this series, companies with $5 million or more in annual revenues were eligible for the survey. However, because the subject of the latest poll, health care, is especially relevant to small business, an additional sample of companies with less than $5 million in revenues was also drawn for comparative purposes.
At each company, one senior executive was interviewed. Titles eligible for the poll included owner, partner, chief executive, president, chairman, executive vice president and senior vice president, with first opportunity for an interview given to the most senior official.
The completed sample included 115 interviews in companies with annual revenues of $500 million or more, 121 interviews in companies with $100 million to $499 million, and 248 interviews in companies with $5 million to $99 million in annual revenue. This combined sample of 484 was then weighted by revenue size to reflect the actual distribution of all listed companies in the country, because smaller companies predominate.
The separate sample of very small businesses -- those with revenues of less than $5 million -- had an additional 191 interviews.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, results based on such samples will differ by no more than six percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out senior executives at all listed companies in the country with revenues exceeding $5 million.
The potential sampling error for groups with fewer cases is larger. For example, for the group of companies with less than $5 million in revenue, the potential error is plus or minus seven percentage points.

HEADLINE: AT&T Wins $4 Billion Saudi Project

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
After heavy lobbying by top officials of the Clinton Administration, Saudi Arabia selected the AT&T Corporation today to modernize its entire telecommunications system -- a deal the company said would be worth $4 billion over the next six years.
The decision marks another major example of the Administration's determination to campaign for American companies in winning big contracts from foreign governments. 
 Two months ago, after personal campaigning by President Clinton and other top officials, Saudi Arabia awarded a $6 billion contract for commercial aircraft to two big American companies, Boeing and McDonnell Douglas.
Over the last several months, President Clinton has written King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, urging him to give serious consideration to the American telephone giant. In addition, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown has made the case personally on two trips to Riyadh since September, and Secretary of State Warren Christopher spoke on AT&T's behalf during his own trip there a month ago.
Under the decision announced today, the Saudi Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications signed a letter of intent awarding AT&T the job of modernizing the entire telephone network with fiber optics, advanced switching systems and a nationwide cellular telephone system.
The job has been ardently sought by many of the world's biggest telecommunications companies. The losers in today's decision are believed to be Alcatel S.A. of France; Siemens A.G. of Germany; Northern Telecom of Canada, and an alliance between Ericsson of Sweden and the NEC Corporation of Japan.
Each company submitted detailed proposals last September, and each has been supported at least to some degree by its Government.
Prime Minister Edouard Balladur of France visited Saudi Arabia several months ago, and is believed to have pressed the case for Alcatel. Top Swedish officials pleaded on behalf of Ericsson. And Ottawa recently announced generous financing arrangements for countries buying telecommunications from Canada.
In today's action, the Saudi Government essentially decided that it would deal only with AT&T. Although the company must now negotiate a formal contract for the precise terms, the decision virtually assures AT&T that the business will belong to it.
The Saudis offered little detailed information today on why they had picked AT&T, though AT&T has been doing business in the country for 15 years.
In a statement, Telecommunications Minister Alawi Darwish Kayyal said simply that "after several months of intense and detailed analysis by our engineers of all the offers, AT&T was chosen as the best, both technically and in cost."
Executives of the company also cited those factors, and explicitly acknowledged the Administration's political assistance.
"We are extremely pleased with the strong support we got from Clinton Administration, particularly from Secretary Brown and Secretary Christopher," said Dan Hesse, president of AT&T Network Systems International.
 
U.S. Redeeming Back Credits
 Daniel F. Burton, president of the Council on Competitiveness, a nonprofit group in Washington supported by business and other groups, said the United States was undoubtedly calling in foreign policy chits that it earned from orchestrating the Persian Gulf war against Iraq.
"I think it's highly appropriate," Mr. Burton said. "The Administration is saying, 'We've helped you in terms of your foreign policy needs, and now our foreign policy objectives have changed to place greater emphasis on economic issues and we'd like you to help us.' "
Mr. Hesse said that AT&T had offered the Saudis a financing package for the project, but that the United States Government would not play a financing role, as it did in the aircraft deal. In that case, the United States Export-Import Bank offered $6.2 billion in loan guarantees.
Ann Frye, a spokeswoman for the Export-Import Bank, said it had offered financial assistance, though far less than the deal's total value of $4 billion. She said the Saudi Government had not so far taken up the offer.
Even in its current state, Saudi Arabia's communications system is considered relatively advanced in the region, with satellite transmission and international direct dialing from urban areas. AT&T will extend that process and further modernize the system.
Under the terms of today's deal, AT&T will build a digital phone network with 1.5 million lines, and supply the extensive switching equipment, network management systems and training projects that the network will require. At least 200 sites are involved, many in remote rural areas.
The company will also build a cellular telephone system capable of serving 200,000 customers across the country. The entire project is scheduled to be completed by the year 2000.
The deal was announced after the stock market closed. In Big Board trading, shares of AT&T closed down 25 cents at $51.75.

HEADLINE: In Wave of Anticrime Fervor, States Rush to Adopt Laws

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.

 BODY:
The Florida Legislature has voted to increase the size of the state's prison system by nearly one third and to try juvenile criminals, regardless of their age, as adults when they commit three felonies. Texas has approved "no bail" provisions for sex offenders and other violent criminals, and proposals known as "three strikes and you're out" and "truth in sentencing" are finding support in state legislatures from coast to coast.
While much of the nation's attention has been focused on the Federal anticrime package to be negotiated by the House and the Senate, state legislatures have been moving even more quickly and aggressively to address the issue. Responding to what they describe as a state of alarm among their constitutents, lawmakers are writing tough new bills and supporting ballot initiatives intended to punish criminals more severely while they are in prison and make it more difficult for them to get out. 
 The single most popular legislation is the "three strikes and you're out" policy of life in prison without parole for criminals convicted of a third serious felony. Variants of this idea have been introduced in more than 30 states since voters in Washington State approved such a law last November and legislators in California and New Mexico did the same this year.
But legislatures are also moving toward treating both juvenile and adult offenders more harshly, as well as weighing stricter controls on guns and imposing "truth in sentencing" rules that would preclude early release for prisoners.
"It's almost impossible to keep up with what's passing in the 50 states, much less what is pending," said Donna Hunzeker, a criminal justice analyst at the National Council of State Legislatures, a nonpartisan research group with headquarters in Denver. On gun control alone, the organization calculates, more than 2,000 bills have been introduced this year, an increase of more than 100 percent over last year's record figure.
The rush by states to enact tough new anticrime legislation is exemplified by Florida, which has the nation's highest crime rate. Galvanized by the widely publicized killings of 10 foreign tourists in less than a year, the Florida Legislature convened last fall for a special session on crime, during which it made it illegal for juveniles to possess handguns. Almost simultaneously, legislators in Colorado, responding to a spate of drive-by shootings, took the same step in a special session of their own.
The crime issue also dominated the Florida Legislature's regular session, which ended April 15. Though lawmakers here balked at a "three strikes" proposal endorsed by Gov. Lawton Chiles, a Democrat seeking re-election, saying it would be too costly, and though they defeated a proposal for the "chemical castration" of rapists, they did approve measures that would hold parents legally accountable for crimes committed by their children, and they authorized localities to impose curfews on teen-agers.
Some of the burst of activity around the country has come as elections draw near; talking tough on crime clearly has political appeal. But public sentiment has been deeply stirred by a succession of brutal incidents like the tourist killings in Florida, the kidnapping and murder of 12-year-old Polly Klaas in California, the slaying of Michael Jordan's father in North Carolina, a carjacking death in suburban Washington, and the shooting rampage on the Long Island Rail Road.
 
'Politically Irresistible'
 "People are just fed up," said Bret Kinsella, a staff member for the North Carolina Senate President Pro Tem, Marc Basnight. The Legislature there earlier this month concluded a seven-week special session, the first extended extra session in state history, to grapple with the problem. "There was crime before, but you don't see the types of crime we have now," Mr. Kinsella said. "It's sociopathic, and that's the difference."
The aggressiveness of the states on the issue also reflects the reality of where and how crimes are committed and prosecuted. About 95 percent of all criminal cases are handled at the state or local level, a figure not expected to change much even with the expansion of Federal jurisdictions under the anticrime package in Congress.
But the punitive tone of much of the state legislation already approved or pending worries many experts. They say that building more prisons and imposing longer sentences is a strategy that has already failed to halt crime. They call for more support of alternatives to incarceration, especially for young, first-time offenders.
Getting tough "is a politically irresistible response to crime," said Beth Carter, national coordinator of the Campaign for an Effective Crime Policy, a coalition of state law-enforcement and elected officials that seeks more crime prevention efforts. Legislatures around the country appear to be acting on the principle that "if the response to crime is not lock 'em up, people will think you're doing nothing about crime," she added.
 
A Call for Discretion
 Research shows, however, that "acting on the crime after the crime has taken place will only help so far," Ms. Carter said.
"It is necessary, but not sufficient," and must be accompanied by efforts to keep young offenders out of prisons that have become "schools for crime," she said.
A few states have, in fact, taken a more balanced approach. Minnesota has approved legislation that will impose stiffer penalties for a variety of crimes, but the state is also alloting more money for crime prevention programs. Lawmakers there have rejected an automatic "three strkes and you're out" policy in favor of discretion in sentencing.
"Why would you want to put a third-time barroom brawler in prison and run the risk of letting out a first-time rapist?" asked Marcia Greenfield, administrative assistant for the Crime Prevention Committee of the Minnesota State Senate. "We want to have the flexibility to toughen penalties as we see fit, depending on the record of the offender."
By and large, though, states have chosen punishment over prevention, even when juveniles are involved. During its special session, North Carolina approved a measure that allows youths as young as 13 to be tried as adults, and makes an adult trial mandatory if a 13-year-old is charged with first-degree murder.
 
Three Strikes or One?
 Other states have had to contend with measures so Draconian as to be whimsical. "One legislator wants three strikes and you're dead," said Thomas R. Caltagirone, the Democratic chairman of the Judiciary Committee of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives. "It's Fantasyland up here. I'm trying to get cooler heads to prevail. Whether I'll succeed or not, I don't know."
Inevitably, some states are now arguing that the "three strikes" policy is too generous. Georgia recently approved legislation that would provide for life-without-parole sentences to offenders who have been convicted twice of violent crimes like murder, armed robbery, kidnapping, rape or other sex crimes.
"If you want three strikes in Georgia, you'd better join a baseball team," Gov. Zell Miller, a Democrat seeking re-election, said last month when he signed a bill putting a proposed constitutional amendment to that effect on the November ballot. In addition, California is considering "one strike" legislation that would apply to rapists and child molesters.
As the Georgia constitutional amendment effort makes clear, though, both voters and politicians increasingly see ballot initiatives as an alternative to a legislative process that is slow and full of compromises. Florida appears likely to vote on a "truth in sentencing" amendment that would require criminals to serve 85 percent of their sentences before becoming eligible for parole, while "victims' rights" proposals will be on the ballots in six states from Alaska to Maryland.
 
'The Grand Slam'
 In Washington, the two men who led the drive for last year's "three strikes" initiative are sponsoring a new ballot measure they call "hard time for armed crime." Their plan would increase sentences for crimes committed with guns, make the theft of a firearm a more serious crime than the theft of other property, and require stiffer sentences in cases of drive-by shootings.
Neighboring Oregon, alarmed that "three strikes" laws in Washington and California may send criminals its way, is now witnessing a drive to get a package called "the grand slam" on the ballot. Those proposals would require all able-bodied state prisoners to work or study, prohibit the reduction of criminal sentences without a two-thirds vote by the Legislature, make it more difficult to sentence criminals to probation or community service, and impose mandatory minimum sentences for all offenders older than 15 who are convicted of violent felonies.
"I have been frustrated by the lack of political will to take some tough steps on crime," said Kevin Mannix, a Democratic state representative who is sponsoring the initiatives. "I think the people are way ahead of the politicians."

HEADLINE: Stocks Fall Over Fears Of Inflation

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Inflation fears hit the financial markets hard for a second straight session yesterday. As long-term interest rates soared to a 19-month high in the bond market, stock prices declined sharply. Blue chips like Caterpillar, interest rate-sensitive utilities like Duke Power and high-technology stocks like Intel all were hurt.
For traders, yesterday was a replay of Friday's market, only worse. Then, stronger-than-expected data from the Government on job creation led to renewed inflation fears, a rout in bond prices and a 26-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average. 
 Some traders had hoped for an inflation-fighting increase in short-term interest rates on Friday and didn't get it. More, however, had expected a rate increase yesterday. High inflation cuts the value of current bonds and raises corporate borrowing costs, thus hurting stocks.
But when the Fed move did not materialize around 11:30 A.M., the typical time for such action, the Dow began to fall steadily, dropping 40.46 points for the day to close at 3,629.04.
 
Now, 'a Waiting Game'
 Now, traders forecast volatile markets until the Fed acts between now and its policy-setting meeting next Tuesday.
"It's going to be a waiting game now," said Kathleen M. Camilli, chief fixed-income economist for Maria Fiorini Ramirez, an economic consultant. "The longer it takes the Fed to act, the higher bond yields will rise."
Yields on the benchmark 30-year bond have risen faster than any time in recent memory, bond watchers said, a mark of traders' anxiety about inflation. [Page D19.]
If the Fed does not act quickly, Ms. Camilli said, the central bank may be trying to prove that "the Fed is not hostage to the markets" or that it may want interest rates to rise sharply to help cool an overheating economy.
Since April 27, just nine trading sessions ago, the long bond has added more than half a percentage point. It settled yesterday at 7.63 percent, up 9 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
At this rate, the long bond could hit 8 percent by the end of the week, further adding to stock-market volatility. "I don't think I've seen anything like this since early 1987," Frederic T. Leiner, fixed-income market strategist at Continental Bank in Chicago, said. "The magnitude astonishes me."
 
Nasdaq Index Falls 9.90 Points
 The Standard & Poor's 500 fell 5.50 points, to 442.32, and the smaller-company Nasdaq composite index dropped 9.90 points, to 722.96. The New York Stock Exchange composite index declined 3.14 points, to 245.33, with declining stocks outnumbering advancing stocks, 1,756 to 509. The American Stock Exchange market value index dropped 4.31 points, to 435.42.
The number of shares changing hands on the New York Stock Exchange was light at about 251 million shares, about 17 percent below this year's daily average of about 303 million shares.
Of the 30 component stocks in the Dow industrials, 24 fell, led by Caterpillar, which fell 2 1/2, to 105 5/8, on no discernible news. Philip Morris, another Dow stock, fell 2, to 50, after news reports that a rival, Brown & Williamson, had kept silent about cigarette hazards while the United States Surgeon General was preparing his landmark 1964 report on smoking.
Of 500 component stocks in the S.& P. 500, 375 stocks fell, led in declines not only by Philip Morris, but also Exxon, General Electric, AT&T and the FPL Group, the parent of Florida Power and Light. Exxon fell 5/8, to 61 3/8, on no discernible news. General Electric fell 1 3/4, to 94 7/8, after increasing its bid on Sunday for the Kemper Corporation, which put itself on the auction block to the highest bidder.
When interest rates rise, income stocks like utilities are often hurt. AT&T fell 1/4, to 51 3/4, despite announcing that it had won a contract valued at $4 billion to supply telecommunicatinos to Saudi Arabia. Duke Power fell 1 5/8, to 34. And FPL Group, which like other electric utilities pays high dividends, dropped 4 3/8, to 27 1/2. It announced a cut in its dividend, its first in 48 years, after determining that its payout was too high.
Symptomatic of the stock selloff in many high-technology companies, Intel, the maker of computer microprocessors, fell 11/16 , to 58 5/8, in Nasadaq trading.
Shares of Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream Inc. fell 20 percent, dropping 5 5/8, to 22 3/8, in Nasdaq trading, after investors rebelled against the company's five-year plan to increase market share at the expense of near-term profits.
McKesson's shares jumped 5 5/8, or 8 percent, to 77 7/8, after The Sunday Times of London said Glaxo Holdings was negotiating a multibillion-dollar deal with the company.
Interneuron Pharmaceuticals saw its shares plunge 1 1/4, or 17 percent, to 6, in Nasdaq trading, after the company issued a statement disputing a study that criticized its prescription anti-obesity drug.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mixed as Traders Await an Interest-Rate Rise

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar ended lower against leading European currencies yesterday as a much-anticipated increase in American short-term interest rates did not materialize.
But the dollar rose against the Japanese yen as President Clinton and Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata of Japan said they wanted to find a way to revive trade negotiations soon, before the July meeting of the Group of Seven industrialized nations.
 
 
Dollar at 102.80 Yen in New York
 The dollar, which recently neared its post-World War II low against the yen, has been under pressure because of a soaring American trade deficit with Japan. 
 The dollar fell to 1.6539 German marks in late New York trading from 1.6621 marks on Friday. But it edged up to 102.80 yen, from 102.53 yen on Friday.
Many market players had hoped that the Federal Reserve would respond to the latest signs of economic strength by pushing up the Federal funds rate on overnight bank loans ahead of Treasury's quarterly "mini" refunding, a major offering of three-year and 10-year notes scheduled for today and tomorrow.
But as the day wore on and it became clear that the Fed would not act, the 30-year Treasury bond fell to an 18-month low, extending steep losses suffered on Friday. The dollar was dragged down as well.
Traders said this was another example that European debt markets are increasingly luring funds away from the United States market.
Donald Maude, the chief United States fixed-income strategist at Scotia-McLeod, said the absence of an immediate Fed move seemed to indicate that the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, had not yet managed to get all members of the Federal Open Market Committee -- the Fed's monetary policy-making arm -- to agree on the magnitude of the next funds rate increase.
Meanwhile, the British pound rose in New York to $1.4985 from late Friday's $1.4935. The dollar also fell to 1.4110 Swiss francs, from 1.4125; 5.6665 French francs, from 5.6935 on Friday, and 1,587 Italian lire, from 1,596. The Canadian dollar was little changed, at 72.35 United States cents.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Price of Copper Advances On Signs of Faster Growth

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Copper prices jumped to a 13-month high yesterday amid new indications that the American and European economies are growing faster, increasing the likely industrial demand for the metal.
Copper for July delivery rose 2.10 cents, to 97.55 cents a pound, its highest price since March 1993, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. 
 "You have a lot of things working in its favor," said David Rinehimer, director of futures research at Lehman Brothers, including "indications that European demand is picking up" and "the data that came out Friday as far as growth prospects here."
The Labor Department reported on Friday that 267,000 jobs were added to the economy in April, a number that exceeded economists' expectations and pointed to strong growth.
 
 
German Export Orders
 Europe's economy also is growing again. Export orders in Germany rose by 5.8 percent in April. Although European copper consumption fell by 10 percent in 1993, analysts said demand should increase by about 2 percent there this year.
Steep declines in stockpiles are also encouraging traders to push prices higher. Last week, stockpiles held in London Metal Exchange warehouses fell by 3.5 percent, the 15th consecutive week of declines. Stockpiles in New York have fallen 59 percent so far this year.
"What's happening in Europe is some supply is moving to the U.S." Mr. Rinehimer said, as U.S. copper prices have risen above Europe's. Also, copper demand is rising in Korea and Taiwan, encouraging shipments from South America to be diverted there instead of sent to the United States or Europe.
The rally in copper did not extend to other metals. June gold fell $2.20, to $382.30 an ounce, on the Comex, while July silver lost 3 cents, to $5.445 an ounce.
On other commodity markets, gasoline and crude oil prices advanced after the Chevron Corporation said a fire yesterday forced it to shut a 63,000-barrel-a-day catalytic converter at a Mississippi refinery.
Unleaded gasoline for June delivery gained 0.97 cent, to 51.07 cents a gallon, on the New York Mercantile Exchange, while crude oil rose 3 cents, to $17.73 a barrel. Heating oil rose 0.24 cent, to 48.34 cents a gallon.
 
 
Coffee Prices Jump
 Elsewhere, coffee prices soared, rising to their highest level since June 1989, after coffee exporters said they would release only half the coffee that they have held off the market.
July coffee soared 4.7 cents, to $1.089 a pound, on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.
The Association of Coffee Producing Countries, which represents about 80 percent of the world's coffee exports, decided yesterday to release 50 percent of the coffee held in warehouses since October as part of a plan to lift prices. The plan called for the group, which holds about 525 million pounds of coffee, to sell its stocks once the average price exceeded 85 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: Russia Seeks Help to Fix Its Phones

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
Boris Y. Nemtsov, the Governor of the Nizhny Novgorod region 250 miles east of here, introduced a novel program recently: selling, for up to $450, a certificate that promises purchasers they will get telephones installed in their homes within six months instead of the years they would normally wait. Officials said residents were snapping up the certificates.
The money raised will be spent improving the region's decrepit telephone system. By paying interest at 1 percent a day for any delay beyond six months, the plan provides considerable incentive for the local telephone company to speed its work. Though the method may be unorthodox and the scale relatively small, the plan indicates the huge demand for improved communications in a country where getting a dial tone can be a triumph of will, and of the lengths Russia is going to in addressing the problem. 
 If there is a consensus within Russia on anything, it is that the telephone system must be upgraded, to provide Russians with greater access to service and to make it possible for business to be conducted more easily with the rest of the world and within a country that spans 11 time zones.
"It's hard to speak seriously of economic and business development in Russia without the development of modern telecommunications systems," said Dmitri B. Garamov, the director general of Westelcom, which operates the nation's main international telephone service.
Modernizing the telecommunications system is so high a priority that it is one of the few businesses in which the Russian Government, local and regional authorities and the domestic industry have all made a determined effort to welcome foreign investors like U S West and AT&T -- or at least the cash, technology and operating skills they bring.
"It's next to impossible to develop a high-quality telecommunications infrastructure without Western investment," said Vyacheslav F. Gurkin, a former first deputy communications minister who now runs Moscow Cellular Communications, a joint venture with U S West, the regional telephone company based in Denver.
Indeed, U S West and other foreign companies have established sizable operations here, and are cautiously optimistic that the upgrading of the national and local phone systems will prove to be a huge business opportunity.
"In a place this size, communications in the long run is going to be a big deal," said Viktor V. Pavlenko, the president of U S West International's division in Russia.
Right now, however, communications in Russia is a big headache. By various counts, Russia has 11 to 15 phone lines for every 100 people. In Spain there are 35 lines for 100 people, and in the United States, 70 lines for 100 people.
In Moscow and St. Petersburg, callers can usually count on getting a dial tone, but not much more. Calls are often not completed, or are plagued by static and other mysterious noises, or are abruptly cut off. In outlying areas, service is much worse -- if it exists at all.
Even in Moscow, which has 4 million of the country's 23 million phone lines, hundreds of thousands of people have been waiting years for service.
The centerpiece of the nation's telecommunications strategy now is a multibillion-dollar plan, in which U S West will play a key role, to install 31,000 miles of new intercity long-distance lines and 50 new switching centers across the country. After a number of fits and false starts, there is cautious optimism all around that the plan -- the biggest telecommunications project on the boards anywhere -- will come to fruition, wiring the country reliably together for the first time.
For foreign companies seeking business here, an even bigger prize lies just over the horizon: the tens of billions of dollars -- some estimates run as high as $120 billion -- that it would take over several decades to add 20 million or more new local lines and bring Russia's phone service up to the level of, say, Spain's.
While both Russian and Western executives here said they were hopeful about the opportunities, the prospects for the modernization programs remain clouded by the very scale and the cost of the task in a nation that is struggling just to keep its economy functioning.
 
Regionals Take Action
 Moreover, it is unclear that the Ministry of Communications can exert sufficient control over local and regional telephone authorities to pull off what some Russian telephone executives consider one last gigantic central planning project. They said the local phone companies were increasingly setting up their own expansion projects and responding more to local pressure for more lines and better service than to plans hatched far away in Moscow.
Then there is the continuing question of political stability. When Mr. Pavlenko of U S West assembled a group of institutional investors from the United States and Europe in Moscow last Oct. 25 to ask for $40 million to help finance the American company's expansion here, he hardly needed to point out the risks. Clearly visible through the conference room window was the charred hulk of the White House, the parliamentary building where a political uprising had been violently squashed by President Boris N. Yeltsin a few weeks earlier.
Despite the risks, nearly every big American and European telecommunications-equipment supplier and telephone network operator has a presence here, including AT&T, Alcatel of France and Siemens of Germany. Cable and Wireless of Britain recently bought a stake in an international long-distance carrier in St. Petersburg.
U S West, France Telecom and Deutsche Bundespost Telekom have been named as the foreign partners in the domestic long-distance upgrading project, which is known as "50-50" after the 50 switching centers and 50,000 kilometers of long-distance lines involved. The foreign companies are seeking ways to minimize their risk without giving up the potential rewards, and none has done so in more innovative ways than U S West.
 
Investors Brought In
 To raise more money without increasing its own financial exposure here, U S West eventually persuaded its group of institutional investors, including units of Morgan Stanley and Baring Securities, to put up $40 million. The investment, as well as all of U S West's operations in Russia, went into a newly formed entity called the Russian Telecommunications Development Corporation, which U S West will manage.
In addition, the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, a United States Government agency that helps finance private deals in emerging markets, agreed to provide $125 million in loan guarantees. Including all its borrowing capacity, the venture should have $400 million to $500 million to invest in telecommunications projects in Russia, Mr. Pavlenko of U S West said. All of the venture's profits will be reinvested in the business for some time, he said.
While the "50-50" project is the biggest single deal in the cards, the U S West venture is not concentrating all its energies or investment there.
It has already found considerable eagerness among local and regional governments and their telephone companies in pursuing their own modernization plans. It signed a joint venture deal in March with Rossvyazinform, the local phone company in Rostov, and Rostelcom, Russia's primary long-distance company, to provide long-distance digital switching equipment, cellular phone service, cable television and other services in the Rostov area, 400 miles south of Moscow.
In addition to Moscow Cellular, U S West and its investment partners also own stakes in cellular phone services in St. Petersburg and 10 other regions around the country, as well as 50 percent of Westelcom, which operates the three main international "gateways" for switching international calls.
"Clearly you're betting that this place is going forward and that this infrastructure is critical to the continued economic reforms of the country," Mr. Pavlenko said. "If the trends continue and you look at this over a one-to-two-decade period, this is a very interesting place to be."
