HEADLINE: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD;
Infectious Diseases on the Rebound in the U.S., a Report Says

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, M.D. 

 BODY:
DOZENS of healthy people become acutely short of breath and die from a new virus, which turns out to belong to a group of viruses known to cause kidney disease and bleeding. Why the new virus attacks the lung, not the kidneys, is a mystery.
A parasite rarely known to affect humans causes the largest outbreak of waterborne illness in this country. 
 A toxin produced by an intestinal bacterium contaminates undercooked hamburger, causing kidneys to fail and killing several children.
These are not the myths of science fiction.
All occurred in the United States last year, severely straining the resources of health departments and showing that vulnerability to new infections has never been greater. In addition, in a number of instances recently, bacteria have become resistant to antibiotics.
The lung disease was produced by a new hantavirus, and it has been fatal in more than half of the 72 cases that are known to have occurred since it was first detected in New Mexico last summer.
The parasite, cryptosporidium, contaminated the water supply of Milwaukee, producing prolonged diarrhea in 400,000 people and putting 4,400 in the hospital.
The toxin, produced by E. coli bacteria, infected not only people who ate the hamburgers but probably some who ate salad cut with the same utensils used on the meat, and some who came into contact with those who were infected. It made more than 500 people in the Seattle area sick and led to kidney failure in at least 29. Four died, all children.
Elsewhere, a new strain of cholera swept across India and Bangladesh, spread to Thailand and threatened other parts of Asia, infecting hundreds of thousands of people and killing thousands. Many experts believe cholera is likely to move from Latin America, where in 1991 it struck for the first time since 1895, into the Caribbean in the not-too-distant future.
Not so long ago, Government officials and medical leaders all but pronounced the end of infectious diseases as a major public health problem. These striking examples of new and emerging diseases prove that prediction wrong. They join a list that includes, among others, AIDS, legionnaire's disease, Lyme disease, Lassa fever and bleeding and fever from the Ebola and Marburg viruses. Some were unknown or minor hazards only a decade or two ago. Others increased significantly in incidence over the last 20 years. Still others threaten to become bigger hazards in the near future.
Some new and emerging infections are part of the poorly understood natural cycles of epidemics. Others reflect the rapidly changing spectrum of infections that has accompanied population growth, expanding poverty, urban migration, increasing international travel and rapidly changing technology.
Infectious diseases are the leading cause of death in the world. The toll is swelling as a result of H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, which is estimated to have infected 14 million people, mainly in Africa and Asia, since it was first recognized in 1981. By 2000, experts estimate, the number infected will be 40 million.
Yet overconfidence about infectious diseases has weakened public health systems in this country and elsewhere, jeopardizing their ability to detect and prevent new and old ones. What the United States needs now, a new Federal report says, is an infusion of up to $125 million a year to carry out a plan to provide the vigilance and rapid response needed to contain infections.
The single most important weapon in any country's defense against infections is its disease surveillance system. Surveillance is used to characterize disease patterns by time, place and person, to detect epidemics, to evaluate prevention and control programs and project future health care needs.
"Whatever shape health care reform takes in this country, surveillance will be the key to the meaningful evaluation of new programs," said the new Federal report, from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, a Federal agency in Atlanta.
The sudden, unexpected appearance of AIDS shocked health officials into a belated recognition of the need for improved surveillance and an awareness that such vigilance might serve as an early warning system to prevent new and emerging infections from becoming public health disasters. But the report said, "The ability to detect what is new or emerging depends on the capacity to identify and track the routine as well as the unusual."
Successful surveillance hinges on the accuracy of statistical analyses, and they hinge on the accuracy of reports that doctors and hospitals are supposed to mail to local health departments about specified infections. But many diseases are notoriously underreported in the United States.
Surveillance also relies on an effective laboratory system. Microbiologists can be the first to detect genetic changes in organisms that could signal an impending outbreak of antibiotic-resistant infections. Microbiologists can also be the first to detect known diseases that have spread to new geographic areas and populations. Laboratories can be vital for the early detection of exotic microbial agents that might be used for biological warfare or terrorist activities.
Surprisingly, the report said, no Federal resources are provided to state and local health departments to support the national disease reporting system. And other parts of surveillance systems have been weakened by budget cuts.
Although widespread misuse of antibiotic drugs has led to the emergence of resistant bacteria, the magnitude of the problem is unknown because no national system exists to monitor it.
Many outbreaks from infections that are transmitted through contaminated food and water go unrecognized or are detected late because current disease monitoring systems are inadequate to confront the present and future challenges. Twelve states have no monitoring system at all for surveying foodborne or waterborne diseases, the report said.
One of the most astonishing discoveries in recent years is that a bacterium, Helicobacter pylori, can cause ulcers and other stomach ailments including possibly some forms of stomach cancer. (The same bacterium was noted in the stomach in the early part of the century but was widely ignored.) Last February, the bacterium's causative role for ulcers was given widespread acceptance by a Government-appointed panel of experts that made antibiotics a required component of ulcer treatment.
Few had suspected that ulcers were caused by an infection. But H. pylori turns out to be just one of a small but growing list of microbes that have been found to produce what had previously been classified as noninfectious diseases.
Scientists have now determined that the hepatitis C virus, for instance, is a leading cause of chronic liver disease and cirrhosis. They are exploring a link between the papillomavirus and cervical cancer. And scientists in the United States and South Africa have reported evidence linking a microbe, Chlamydia pneumoniae, to coronary artery disease. C. pneumoniae, which is also known as TAWR, is a common cause of pneumonia, bronchitis and sinusitis. The findings suggest but do not prove a link between C. pneumoniae infections and atherosclerosis, the underlying cause of heart attacks.
Scientists are also exploring the role of microbes in multiple sclerosis, Sjogren syndrome, Alzheimer's disease, Kawasaki disease and insulin-dependent diabetes.
But such searches can be disappointing. From time to time, scientists have reported hints that one or another microbe causes coronary artery disease and rheumatoid arthritis. But proof is lacking for any microbial cause of heart attacks and arthritis.
Saying that the concept of separating domestic from international health is outdated, the report suggested a number of measures to guard public health, including these:
*Improving communications between health officials in countries throughout the world so they can share more information about trends in infections.
*Creating a global network of scientific centers.
*Improving surveillance by strengthening and creating long-term collaborations and partnerships with practicing doctors, microbiologists, public agencies, universities, private industry and communities.
*Organizing a network of doctors, emergency rooms, laboratories, medical examiners, travel medicine clinics, veterinarians and others to report certain problems like influenza and drug-resistant infections as sentinel surveillance systems.
*Using modern computing techniques to speed reporting of diseases from a doctor's office to a health department.
*Using aerial photography and satellite imaging techniques to investigate environmental sources of infection and formulate effective control measures.
*Seeking to discover the role of insects or other vectors in transmitting diseases that are not yet known to be spread in such fashion.
*Teaching more about public health and the basic principles of surveillance to medical students and young doctors.
Surveillance is hampered by the lack of rapid and accurate diagnostic tests for microbes like Mycoplasma, which causes respiratory illness, and by the lack of technicians who are proficient in applying the many tests that are available.
In both the Seattle and Milwaukee outbreaks, lack of training in the testing necessary for detection resulted in delayed recognition of outbreaks, the centers' report said.
At a time when most budgets are being cut, some see appeals for more money for infectious disease surveillance as self-serving. Yet, expensive as it is, prevention is often the cheapest medicine. Penny-pinching could be enormously costly in human suffering and dollars.

HEADLINE: American Box Turtles Decline, Perishing Cruelly in Foreign Lands

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
WHILE not exactly the American eagle or the Bengal tiger, the common box turtle, one of the most familiar and benign animals in the United States, may have a stronger hold on the memories and affections of millions of Americans. Now its very appeal has subjected it to a savage assault that threatens the future of the breed.
Box turtles by the thousands are being killed each year as the result of a booming wildlife trade that sends them to Europe as pets, say scientists, conservationists and officials on both sides of the Atlantic. Many die or are greatly weakened when jam-packed together without food or water for shipping, and many more succumb to an unsuitable European climate and to mistreatment by pet sellers and owners ignorant of the turtles' needs, they say. 
 Of the many kinds of wild animals being traded internationally, box turtles are attracting special attention because of the great numbers in which they are being exported -- 25,000 to 30,000 a year, according to the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. Since a female box turtle typically takes half a century or more to produce just two offspring that survive to reproductive age, this rate of capture and export is unsustainable and will eventually call the future of the breed into question if continued, scientists say.
Even before the surge in exports, box turtle populations, generally found east of the Rockies, were declining in many parts of the country because of human encroachment on the wild. That squeeze continues, and the added pressure of the international wildlife trade "is just disastrous," said Dr. Michael W. Klemens, a herpetologist with the Wildlife Conservation Society, formerly the New York Zoological Society. The trade is not going to drive box turtles extinct any time soon, he said, but if it continues at the present rate, "it is not sustainable."
The disastrous situation has been largely unnoticed, says Suzanne Dohm, the president of the New York Turtle and Tortoise Society, which has made preservation of the turtles its top priority. In focusing on conserving more exotic and charismatic animals, she said, "we have a tendency to forget about our local species; by the time we notice what's going on in our own backyard, it's too late."
Both the society and Dr. Klemens are campaigning to persuade parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, or Cites, which will meet in November in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to require permits for and the monitoring of trade in box turtles. If that were to happen, the Fish and Wildlife Service, which exercises Cites authority in the United States, would be able to enforce humane practices in the trade and to assess the magnitude of the problem better. If the turtles eventually became endangered, the participants in Cites (pronounced SITE-eez) could prohibit trade altogether, as it has done for a number of other animals.
The Fish and Wildlife Service is to decide by June 10 whether to propose a listing for the turtles under the treaty, and "most likely" will do so, said Dr. Susan Lieberman, a herpetologist who heads the branch of the agency responsible for Cites activities.
For many Americans, the black and yellow or black and orange domed shell of the box turtle is one of the earliest memories of a wild creature up close. Abundant in the past, easily found on the edges of woodlands and in fields, they have long been favored as pets. They flourish in warm conditions, hibernating in the winter (they have just come out of their sleep in the Northeast), snuggling down in dense vegetation, mud or humus during summer drought, and emerging after a good rain. That is when they are most catchable.
 
Not Fussy Eaters
 What many who capture them may not know is that these turtles' ability and willingness to eat almost anything gives them an important role in the food web of many an ecosystem, and therefore in maintaining ecological integrity. Nor, presumably, do many of the captors realize that longevity has been the key to the turtles' survival as a genus for millions of years.
"The only thing turtles have going for them, ecologically, is that they live for a long time and that they reproduce pretty much right to the end," Dr. Klemens said. In the case of the box turtle, that means a reproductive life of 50 years or more. They can easily live as long as humans, and one is said to have died at 138.
But unlike humans, turtles do not protect and nurture their young. They typically lay three or four eggs at a time, and the young are left to fend for themselves. Few reach adolescence, and fewer still become adults. This means that every adult turtle -- and especially every long-lived one -- is important to the survival of the genus.
Habitat destruction, road kills and mowing accidents have steadily reduced populations of both adults and juveniles in many parts of the country. A Texas study in the 1970's found that the local population of box turtles turned over completely within 32 years, indicating that adults were living out only part of their reproductive lives. Studies in Maryland revealed that the population in one area was cut in half between 1965 and 1975. A study from 1977 to 1987 in Wisconsin found that too few hatchlings were being born for each adult death to prevent population decline.
The decline has tended to go unnoticed because, to the casual observer, there still appear to be plenty of turtles around. Although this is true, Dr. Klemens said, many of the turtles are members of doomed populations -- the "living dead."
Into this already gloomy picture has burst the international wildlife trade.
For years, Mediterranean tortoises were favored as garden pets in northern Europe. But in 1984, trade in these tortoises was banned within the European Community on conservation grounds. Wildlife dealers looked elsewhere, and their eyes fixed on box turtles.
Though not strictly land tortoises at all (they are closely related to terrapins, and like other terrapins can swim), the box turtles resemble tortoises. In Britain, where box turtles have become especially popular, the distinction is blurred further because the British tend to refer to all species except sea turtles as tortoises.
As it became apparent that the trade in box turtles was increasing, Fish and Wildlife agents at American ports of exit began keeping detailed track of it. They counted 28,583 turtles exported in 1992 and 26,411 in 1993. Since the turtles have only recently emerged from hibernation, the 1994 season is just beginning. Dr. Lieberman said that data from Britain suggest that the exports are even higher.
 
About $1 Apiece
 Wholesalers and professional collectors typically place box-turtle orders by word of mouth to various people, including farmers and children, and pay them perhaps a dollar apiece for the animals, said Joe Ventura, a supervisory inspector for the Fish and Wildlife Service at Kennedy International Airport.
"What we've been seeing is very large numbers in shipments, 1,000 or more, sometimes 2,000 box turtles going to Europe," he said. "Initially, the animals are in horrible condition," kept in wet burlap sacks and cardboard boxes, in their own excrement, with no food or water.
Once in the hands of traders, no binding rules govern the turtles' treatment. Moral suasion has moved some shippers to treat them humanely, Mr. Ventura said, but "until they're listed under Cites, they can basically ship them any way they like."
The turtles' export value is generally declared at $5 or $6 apiece, he said. They bring 10 times that much and more on the European pet market, according to studies by British conservationists.
"There's a very long delay between the animals' being captured and gathering enough together to make it economic," said Andy C. Highfield, the director of the Tortoise Trust, a British conservation organization. "They are stressed, overcrowded, and quite frankly, half dead by the time they arrive in Europe. We are seeing the result here and it's not a pretty sight."
Mr. Highfield, who has made extensive studies of the turtles' fate, said that once the turtles arrive in Britain, their rate of illness and death is high. Some conservationists estimate that 90 percent perish prematurely after capture.
 
Inhospitable Climate
 Herpetologists say the northern European climate, with longer winters and shorter, cooler summers, is inhospitable to box turtles, just as it was to Mediterranean tortoises before them. To insure their survival there, said Dr. Klemens, would require that they live in elaborately devised environments with controlled humidity and ultraviolet light.
"You can't just take them and throw them in the garden, which is what people do," he said. There, most of them slowly die, he said, over months and months during which they do not display suffering in any obvious way.
Ignorance is a big part of the problem, said Dr. Clifford Warwick, the director of the Institute of Herpetology, an independent British scientific and conservation organization, who explained that both pet dealers and pet owners frequently do not even know what kind of turtle they have.
"You've got the blind leading the blind, literally," he said. "Owners don't know what they're doing, and the pet shop owners don't know what they're doing." Owners of turtles have told Mr. Highfield, in surveys he has taken, that if they had known the animals' true identity and survival requirements they would never have bought them.
A number of American states regulate the capture, killing and sale of box turtles, but in others, mainly in the Middle West and South, they remain unregulated. Since there is no evidence yet that they are endangered, they are not protected by the Endangered Species Act.
Dr. Klemens said that seeking separate Federal legislation would probably be more complicated than seeking a Cites listing, which, he said, seems the most appropriate course given that the convention's main purpose is to regulate trade.
Ms. Dohm sums up the situation this way:
"That foreign market is absolutely draining us. You can't buy a box turtle legally in New York State, but you can ship thousands of them out of Kennedy Airport. We cry about saving animals, and yet we let situations like this go on. Something's not quite right."

HEADLINE: GOLF;
Finchem Selected as P.G.A. Commissioner

BYLINE: By LARRY DORMAN 

 BODY:
Opting for continuity over change, the Tournament Policy Board of the PGA Tour named Timothy W. Finchem yesterday to succeed Deane Beman as the commissioner of the multimillion-dollar organization that oversees touring professionals.
Finchem, 47, the deputy commissioner and chief operating officer of the PGA Tour, had been rumored to be the frontrunner for the job ever since Feb. 28, when Beman announced his intention to step down. 
 Although the other candidates for the job were formidable, and included prominent golf names like Jack Frazee, former chairman of Centel Corporation; Charles Mechem, commissioner of the L.P.G.A. Tour, and Vincent Giles, president of Pros, the board never tipped its hand.
Until late yesterday morning, when Finchem went through another interview with board members in Dallas, he was still uncertain which way the board was leaning.
"I think the word would be relieved more than surprised," Finchem said of his reaction.
In the end, they were leaning close to home. Known to golf insiders as a tough, straightforward negotiator and an indefatigable worker, Finchem was always Beman's No. 1 choice for the job. A University of Richmond graduate who received his law degree from the University of Virginia, Finchem is similar to Beman in substance and probably will differ only slightly in style.
"He would have been my choice if I'd had one," said Beman, 56, who will officially end 20 years on the job when he steps down June 1. "I didn't have a vote and didn't attend any of the board meetings."
Finchem, who joined the PGA Tour in 1987 as the vice president for business affairs, came to golf from National Strategies and Marketing Group, a Washington consulting and marketing firm that he co-founded in 1984. A former deputy adviser for economic affairs to President Jimmy Carter and the national staff director for the Carter-Mondale presidential campaign in 1980, Finchem is regarded as a Washington insider.
Finchem takes over an organization that has very few pressing problems. He will have to overcome some opposition from a group of players who wanted Beman's successor to come from the ranks of touring pros. Finchem, a four-handicap at the TPC at Sawgrass, is the equivalent of a scratch player when it comes to negotiating.
"I think we'll just handle that head-on," he said. "What I really want to do is sit down and talk to every single player, particularly players who might have some misgivings, look them in the eye and tell them about what my approach will be to the job."
The main style point on which Finchem could differ from Beman is flexibility. Beman, for all his accomplishments, was viewed as a dogmatic and combative man who did not yield willingly once he had established an opinion. This was particularly true on matters such as the 15-tournament minimum for PGA Tour members, a requirement that kept many foreign players from participating more often in PGA Tour events.
His first order of business, once he smooths over any ruffled feathers, will be to forge some long-range plans for maintaining and expanding the Tour's sponsorship base, a base largely responsible for the growth of purses from $8 million when Beman took over in 1974 to their current level of more than $100 million on the three tours overseen by the PGA Tour.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Haitian Mirror

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Haiti holds up a mirror to Americans and tens of millions should look away in shame.
They live in freedom and safety because their parents or grandparents had the strength to flee pogroms or travel thousands of hard miles in search of work and bread. 
 But for years now, when Haitians have come seeking refuge, their need deep, their oppression relentless and their danger acute, they have been turned away. Children and grandchildren of earlier immigrants say nothing, mumble excuses or icily approve.
After his election, President Clinton went back on his word to allow Haitians a decent chance at entry into the promised land, instead of capturing them at sea and sending them back, as President Bush did. Now he has found the courage to recognize his error, and try to rectify it.
For giving at least a hearing, at last, to black refugees he deserves respect, not the warnings of approaching calamity that he is getting.
Black. White Americans at least should acknowledge what they see in the Haitian mirror. The Haitians have been turned back because of the color of their skin.
It is cowardly to pretend otherwise. Haitian refugees are poor, most are unschooled and some are ill. So were many of the European refugees without whom this country would now be less educated, less wealthy and less healthy than it is now.
Sons and daughters of European immigrants are among those who warn us against Haitians. They turn out studies that are supposed to show that immigrants are a hideous economic threat. In America, you can pick your study -- and on immigration I pick those like the one from the Alexis de Tocqueville Institution in Washington. Ten states with the lowest concentrations of immigrants in 1980 had an unemployment rate one-third higher than the states with relatively high immigration.
"Hordes" -- the word has not been used much about immigrants since the early 20th century, when it was a favorite of anti-Semites and Catholic-haters. Now it just hangs there in the talk and writing of anti-immigration groups -- Haitians and Chinese moving toward us, over the horizon, millions and millions of foreigners, in mass, not a one of them what you could call white.
But if we have any sense we will let the nation-building record of American immigration guide us. If we decide some day that the U.S. just cannot handle any new brains or more muscles, we can abandon American self-interest in immigration then, but for heaven's sake not now.
If ever there was a country whose people deserve warmth when they seek U.S. refuge it is Haiti. It is part of the Americas, a neighbor. The thug "police" and "army" officers who rule the country with machete and gun are direct descendants of the Duvalier dictatorships so long supported and armed by the U.S. And they overturned a President who may not be to American tastes but who was democratically elected.
Somehow, we have managed to think of only one plan to help Haitians: strangle them ever tighter in sanctions. Sanctions against enemy governments like Iraq's, or as pressure for a specific political purpose against a South Africa or North Korea -- that's one thing. But sanctions that can starve out a friendly neighboring people -- how long can the Haitians stand that? How long can we?
The Haitian mirror shows more than an American double standard just against black refugees. American politicians and commentators who scream for heavy bombing of Serbia, with all its risks of a wider European war, seem petrified at the thought of any military action against a mob of Haitian killers who have only fought unarmed civilians.
I cannot understand why the Latin American republics are not volunteering to share military action against the Haitian thugs. But then I could never understand why Western Europe could not handle Bosnian intervention, if it was so hot for it, without calling for America.
U.S. intervention in Bosnia could prolong and widen war. But it is hard to believe that U.S. armed forces could not handle the Haitian cops in a few days, if they don't pack up and get out first.
So, a final thought for mirror-gazing. If Canadians were taken over by marauding gangsters, surely we would offer them something better than the simple two-part plan so many Americans think is entirely good enough for Haitians: they just stay home, and we just starve them.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: To End Welfare, Create Real Jobs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The prospect of eliminating welfare, discussed in your April 22 article on Charles Murray of the American Enterprise Institute and his decadelong campaign to let poor women and children fend for themselves, sounds exciting. But history has proved that the recommendations offered by Mr. Murray and others are misdirected and will not work. 
 In the past, poorhouses and orphanages provided government assistance to the poor. Because "outdoor relief," or government subsidies, was not given, poor parents were forced to watch their children starve or give them up to institutions. Eliminating welfare today and reinstituting orphanages would not reduce out-of-wedlock births by much; it would break up families into unemployed parents and parentless children.
The value of welfare benefits has decreased continuously since the 1970's while the rate of out-of-wedlock births has risen. According to Mr. Murray's theory, these births should have decreased when benefits went down. Since they did not, welfare must not be a major factor in the rise.
We do not spend large proportions of our budgets on welfare. The amount of social spending on the children of poor single mothers (aid to families with dependent children, food stamps and Medicaid) is a small fraction of a total that includes Social Security, education, Medicare, unemployment insurance and disability insurance. An attack on welfare for its costs seems misplaced since other programs receive so much more.
Studies have shown that, realistically, only 15 percent of out-of-wedlock births can be linked to welfare benefits. Most unmarried women do not decide to have children because they know they can rely on welfare. Charles Murray's supposed statistics are proved wrong repeatedly by history and other researchers.
Democrats have listened to the experts selectively on eliminating welfare. David Ellwood and others have recommended a two-year limit, providing that child care, national health insurance, training, child support assurance and, most important, jobs are in place for those leaving welfare. The Government would create "last resort" jobs for those unable to find work in the private sector. Without these other programs, eliminating welfare will not reduce poverty or single motherhood, crime, or any other target for social change.
A set of answers offered in the studies of Mr. Ellwood and others emphasize that the availability of jobs for the mothers and fathers of poor children is the key to self-sufficiency. When there are jobs, people work. If more attention was paid to creating decent-wage jobs and instituting programs to make work pay, welfare could become obsolete by assuring that everyone who can work has a job.
 
MICHELLE C. BILLIES
Brooklyn, April 27, 1994
 
The writer is a graduate student at the Columbia University School of Social Work.

HEADLINE: A to Z Plan Spells Fiscal Responsibility

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The A to Z spending-cut plan, which would allow the House of Representatives to vote separately on any amendments proposed for the budget bill from A to Z, has been endorsed by a majority of the members. Yet it fails to win your endorsement in "Foolishness, From A to Z" (editorial, May 2) because the plan represents a radical departure from business as usual in the House. This is the point. Our bill compels Congress to do what state and local governments, businesses and families throughout the country have had to do -- go through each item in their budget and decide if they can afford it. 
 The "sane deliberation" you refer to has saddled our nation with $4.5 trillion of public debt. The status quo effectively ropes off three-quarters of the Federal budget from discussion and debate. As a result, our economy hobbles between periods of recession and modest recovery.
Under the A-to-Z process, members with meritorious ideas for reducing spending can have their own ideas voted on. The plan will open the agenda of the House and let the American people see how their representatives stand on spending priorities. The decisions that representatives must make will not be easy. Our deficit problem cannot be solved merely by eliminating pork-barrel projects or $500 wrenches. Denying this course, however, is opting for a far more damaging path.
If we do not force the Government to change how it operates, our economy will continue to suffer, and we will continue to burden future generations with our irresponsible fiscal policies.
 
ROBERT E. ANDREWS
Member of Congress, 1st Dist., N.J.
Washington, May 4, 1994

HEADLINE: Giuliani Plans License Sale Of WNYC

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that his administration planned to sell the license for WNYC-FM, the New York City-owned classical-music station, to help close the budget deficit for the next fiscal year.
But Mr. Giuliani said the city would strive to keep the station -- one of only two that still broadcasts classical music -- on the air by buying a less expensive license from a nonprofit station. 
 Although WNYC is a publicly supported nonprofit station, it has a commercial license -- a valuable commodity in a city whose radio band is filled to capacity. Administration officials believe that by selling WNYC's commercial license, and by buying a less valuable nonprofit license, the city could reap about $60 million, without changing the content of the station's programming.
But it was unclear last night how the administration intended to obtain a new noncommercial license for the station, since Federal officials say there are no spots left on the FM dial for a new station. And an independent analyst suggested that the sale would produce much less money than the administration was estimating.
 
Trying to Bridge Shortfall
 The sale of the license is one of dozens of cost-cutting proposals Mr. Giuliani will unveil today as he presents his formal budget for the fiscal year that begins on July 1. The cuts are intended to fill a $2.3 billion gap between revenues and expenses, the lingering effects of a deep recession in which slow increases in tax revenues have not kept up with sharp increases in spending on welfare, Medicaid, homeless shelters and other city services.
To bridge the shortfall, Mr. Giuliani is expected to propose nearly $1.3 billion in spending cuts to city agencies. The remainder will be made up with $400 million in additional state and Federal aid, a $200 million bond-refinancing scheme and other measures aimed at increasing revenues.
But the sale of WNYC's license is an emotional proposal that goes beyond a question of dollars and cents. Supported by a nonprofit foundation, the 50-year-old station is one of the few outlets of National Public Radio programming and counts about 600,000 listeners.
 
WNYE Seen as Option
 A senior Mayoral aide said one option the city was considering was moving WNYC's classical programming over to WNYE, another FM station operated by the Board of Education. WNYE broadcasts educational programs.
WNYE was established in 1938 and broadcasts an eclectic mix of educational and instructional programming. The lineup includes also sports, jazz, political programs, and programs tailored to black and Caribbean audiences.
Although no concrete proposal has been negotiated with the Board of Education or any other radio station, Mr. Giuliani has assured board members of the station's foundation that WNYC would continue to reach the same listeners in any event.
"This is really the best possible result for the city and the listeners of WNYC-FM," he said. "At a time when the city is facing a very difficult financial situation the sale of WNYC-FM will bring in very badly needed revenues."
Irwin Schneiderman, chairman of the WNYC Foundation, called the proposal "an elegant solution." He said that even if the city has to spend money to upgrade a noncommercial station, the administration would come out ahead because the station's commercial license is so valuable. "As long as we've got a facility that's comparable to what we've got, we're happy," Mr. Schneiderman said.
Steven Bauman, the president of the WNYC Communications Group, said the Mayor had promised him that none of the station's classical programming would be lost. "If we switch to a noncommercial band, all we will have done is to have sold the commercial license, which is of no use to us," he said.
Still, selling assets is not generally viewed with favor by bond-rating agencies and fiscal monitors, who prefer to see the city reduce its long-term expenses, rather than turning to one-time ways to raise cash.
The WNYC Communications Group, which also owns a television station and an AM radio station, receives 90 percent of its $18 million annual budget from private donations. In the current fiscal year, the city provided about $1.7 million in tax dollars as well, although Mr. Giuliani has declined to say whether he would continue that subsidy.
Finding a new home for the station may be easier said than done. By last night, the Board of Education had held only "preliminary conversations" with Giuliani aides about either selling the city the license for WNYE or melding WNYC and WNYE into one, said John Beckman, a spokesman for the board, said.
"The Chancellor has emphasized instructional programming for WNYE," Mr. Beckman said. "That does not preclude in any way listening to proposals the city might have."
Stuart Bedell, a lawyer for the Mass Media Bureau of the Federal Communications Commission, said that there is no vacant frequency in New York City and that it would be highly unlikely that the F.C.C. would approve a proposal to drop a new channel into the crowded field.
 
Turning to Colleges
 So the city would have to buy a license from one of the other non-commercial stations in the city, most of which are far less powerful than WNYC-FM and are operated by colleges and universities which are unlikely to part with them.
WNYE is the most powerful of the noncommercial stations in the city limits with a broadcasting strength of 20 kilowatts. But because its transmitter is on Tillary Street in downtown Brooklyn at 430 feet above sea level, the signal does not reach outside the city.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 13, 1994, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about plans by the city to sell the operating license of WNYC-FM referred incorrectly to the signal strength of another FM station, WNYE, owned by the Board of Education. WBAI and WNYC -- not WNYE -- have the strongest FM signals and the widest listening areas in the city among noncommercial stations. Both have transmitters atop some of the city's tallest buildings. WNYE's 430-foot antenna is in downtown Brooklyn, and the reach of its signal is limited by Manhattan's towers.

HEADLINE: Nice Drive to the Ballot Box

BYLINE: By Jordan Moss; Jordan Moss, a writer, has worked for Human Serve, a national voter registration advocacy group.

 BODY:
When President Clinton signed the National Voter Registration Act, or "motor voter" bill, into law a year ago next week, it was the final achievement of the 1960's voting rights revolution. Yet today, resistance from individual states is threatening the law's promise of universal enfranchisement.
Blatant obstructions to the ballot box have been outlawed since 1965, when the Voting Rights Act was passed. "Motor voter" addresses more subtle obstacles, eliminating the maze of regulations that hamper voter registration in almost every state. With 40 percent of eligible voters unregistered, the change was long overdue. 
 Properly carried out, the new law will let Americans register to vote when they apply for driver's licenses, welfare or unemployment benefits or use other government services. But a disturbing pattern of resistance is taking shape around the country. In drafting state laws to carry out the Federal law, which will take effect Jan. 1, legislatures are treating social service agencies differently from motor vehicle bureaus.
Registering will be virtually automatic in motor vehicle offices; typically, driver's license applications and voter registration will be combined on the same form. But some states -- for example, Georgia, Massachusetts, Florida and California -- are planning to require that welfare recipients ask to register, then fill out a separate form: a sure-fire deterrent, since welfare agencies are already notorious for long, complicated applications.
Even worse, many states haven't begun to draft plans for voter registration in welfare offices, a provision that was included specifically to insure that the bill didn't leave anyone behind. In major cities like New York, Chicago and Atlanta, where many poor people don't have driver's licenses, this preference for motor vehicle bureaus will worsen the very inequities that "motor voter" was supposed to eradicate.
President Clinton can rescue the National Voter Registration Act by instructing the Secretaries of Health and Human Services and of Agriculture, who have jurisdiction over welfare and food stamps, to issue guidelines on voter registration and to provide technical assistance to state agencies. And the Justice Department should make it known that it will be aggressive in monitoring the law's success.
Voter advocates have been urging the Administration to take these steps, but to no avail. Mr. Clinton, who rightly invokes the bill as one of his important achievements in office, must intervene soon to prevent the perverse possibility that it could mean even greater injustice at the ballot box.

HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICA'S NEW ERA: THE OVERVIEW;
SOUTH AFRICANS HAIL PRESIDENT MANDELA; FIRST BLACK LEADER PLEDGES RACIAL UNITY

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PRETORIA, South Africa, May 10

 BODY:
With the commanding dignity that has carried him through more than half a century of defiance, captivity and conciliation, Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela became the first black President of South Africa today.
He stood before a crowd of world leaders who shunned this capital during its decades of infamy, and in a husky, resolute voice swore the oath to become the 10th leader of South Africa since its union in 1910, but the first elected with the participation of the black majority. 
 Then the 75-year-old leader opened his presidency with an intimate speech of shared patriotism, speaking of South Africans' common exhilaration in the seasons and the soil, their common pain for their country's humiliation before the world and their shared relief at being readmitted to the company of civilized nations.
"Never, never, and never again shall it be that this beautiful land will again experience the oppression of one by another and suffer the indignity of being the skunk of the world," he said. [Transcript, page A8.]
As a token of renewal, Mr. Mandela promised that an amnesty would soon be announced for "various categories" of prisoners.
He lavished praise on F. W. de Klerk, the President who collaborated with him in negotiating the end of white rule and who today took the oath as one of Mr. Mandela's two Vice Presidents in a unity Government.
In a post-inaugural visit to the 50,000 ordinary citizens celebrating on the lawn far below the Government buildings, Mr. Mandela held Mr. de Klerk's hand aloft and hailed his predecessor as "one of the greatest reformers, one of the greatest sons of our soil."
For the day, at least, blacks and whites were united by the mutual strain of taking in the recently unimaginable:
There was Fidel Castro on his first visit to the country that tried to pulverize his army in Angola, the only one among the scores of dignitaries singled out by the crowd for lusty shouts of "Viva!"
And Muslim and Hindu prayers broadcast into the air of what has been the most rigidly, officially Christian of capitals.
And the Navy band in dress whites entertaining the inaugural dignitaries with a Zulu migrant labor song.
And finally President Nelson Mandela, now Commander in Chief, reviewing the defense force that was built, in large part, to prevent someone like him from taking power.
When nine Mirage jet fighters streaked overhead as part of an aerial salute, the citizens assembled on the grass sent up a roar, it seemed, out of a new feeling of custody rather than at the thrill of high-speed machinery.
Mr. Mandela's ascent has been virtually inevitable, at least since last July when negotiators cinched the dates for the first elections open to all races.
In the elections that finished on April 29, the African National Congress won more than 62 percent of the vote, earning 252 of the 400 seats in the National Assembly that elected Mr. Mandela on Monday without opposition.
Mr. Mandela, whose Xhosa name, Rolihlahla, means "someone who brings trouble on himself," knows well enough the difficulties he has taken on in maintaining the richest economy in Africa while satisfying the promises inherent in his triumph.
Still, today was a last occasion to contemplate the distance the country has traversed before it looks ahead.
Four years and three months ago -- just midway through the Bush Administration -- Nelson Mandela was serving a life sentence for trying to overthrow the Government. Today he heads it.
He became President on a stage erected in the reddish sandstone crescent of the Government building that overlooks Pretoria and, beyond, the hulking monument to the great inland trek of the Afrikaner Voortrekkers.
Mr. Mandela is a President who comes to power preceded by a myth, already embodied in liberation songs that swelled spontaneously in the waiting amphitheater: "Nel-son Man-DEL-a! Nel-son Man-DEL-a!"
He arrived, an hour behind schedule, between two of his daughters, and listened to the swearing-in of his two Vice Presidents, Thabo Mbeki and Mr. de Klerk.
When his own turn came, he eagerly began his oath before the Chief Justice prompted him.
 
Salute by Guns and Aircraft
 After he spoke, the cannons thundered a 21-gun salute and buzzing formations of helicopters and aged warplanes passed overhead.
The guests arrayed in the autumnal sun included 45 heads of state, plus an American delegation headed by Vice President Al Gore and including Hillary Rodham Clinton. Prince Philip, the husband of Queen Elizabeth II of England, attended, as did Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali of the United Nations.
So did James Gregory. Mr. Gregory was Mr. Mandela's warden for two decades, first at the Robben Island Prison and later at Victor Verster Prison, and they became so close that after Mr. Mandela was released the jailer retired out of boredom. "Life had become empty for me," Mr. Gregory told a Johannesburg newspaper.
 
Castro and Arafat Welcomed
 World figures long shunned here as Communists and sponsors of guerrilla insurgency, like Mr. Castro and Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, arrived today to more enthusiastic welcomes than the Americans received.
At an inaugural lunch in the residence called the Presidency, Mr. Mandela introduced the Cuban leader to Mr. de Klerk and then to the military chief of staff.
"Welcome to South Africa," Mr. de Klerk said.
"I hope you are successful," Mr. Castro replied.
It was a day for conciliatory gestures.
Joe Modise, a former guerrilla leader and now Mr. Mandela's Defense Minister-designate, noticed a delegation led by Chief Mangosuthu G. Buthelezi, of the rival Inkatha Freedom Party, and the Zulu king, Goodwill Zwelethini, languishing in the B-list seats and moved them to the front row.
Someone likewise rescued Winnie Mandela, the estranged wife of the new President, and led her from her chair behind a low sandstone wall to the covered stage where family and invited guests were seated.
 
A Victory in Soccer
 Tonight the new President dropped in at the packed soccer stadium where the South African national team defeated Zambia in an inaugural special. He frowned when the 60,000 spectators failed to raise their voices in the two anthems of the new South Africa -- the old Afrikaans poem, The Call of South Africa, and the liberation anthem, God Bless Africa.
"You have to learn the words to both anthems," he scolded the crowd. "If you don't know Afrikaans, you must learn it. If you don't know Zulu or Xhosa, you must learn those."
"It's nice that he came, but I think this is the last time we'll come together like this," said one fan, a resident of the Phola Park squatter camp who declined to give her name. Wrapped in a huge A.N.C. flag but already feeling the seep of disillusionment, she wondered, "What are we going to do now? There's nothing to protest against."

(Associated Press)(pg. A8); Nelson Mandela takes the oath of office as President from Chief Justice Michael Corbett in Pretoria. (Reuters)(pg. A1)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
BBC Plans International Expansion

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LONDON, May 10

 BODY:
In an effort to take a bigger share of rapidly growing television markets around the world, the British Broadcasting Corporation said today that it planned to create news and entertainment channels in Europe, Asia and the United States.
The BBC said its international expansion, which would put it in more direct competition with the likes of Ted Turner, Rupert Murdoch and the American broadcasting networks, would take place through a partnership with Pearson P.L.C., one of Britain's largest communications companies. 
 The partnership's first venture, in which Pearson will invest as much as $45 million, will be two satellite-delivered channels in Europe. One will be an all-news network and the other an entertainment network. They are scheduled to go on the air by the end of the year.
 
Other Plans in Works
 Although no firm plans have yet been set, the BBC and Pearson are also considering a wide range of other opportunities around the world for news and entertainment channels, children's programming and educational and documentary networks, executives said.
"In commercial terms, the BBC as a brand is respected around the globe," said Bob Phillis, the BBC's deputy director general. "Britain has an unrivaled reputation for high-quality program making. Production levels are the highest outside Japan and the U.S., and the BBC's archives are extensive and renowned."
The move comes at a time when deregulation of broadcasting by national governments and the rapid development of satellite and cable technology have set off a global stampede by program makers and broadcasters to establish new networks.
Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation has invested heavily in satellite-delivered services such as BSkyB in Britain and Star TV in Asia. Mr. Turner's Turner Broadcasting Company is making a big push to establish Cable News Network around the world, and is trying to become a competitor in entertainment television with its Cartoon Network and TNT movie channel in Europe. NBC has purchased a pan-European broadcaster, now called NBC Super Channel, and Capital Cities/ABC has acquired a string of European program producers and cable networks.
The BBC, although state-owned and advertising-free in its home market, is under increasing pressure from the British Government to develop additional revenue to help finance its operations. It has long had international radio and television broadcasts, but in television the BBC has increasingly found itself scrambling to keep up with better-financed rivals. The BBC's World Service Television, for example, can no longer be seen in much of Asia even as Mr. Murdoch is building a big presence there through Star TV.
 
A Way to Speed Growth
 For Pearson, which owns The Financial Times and other publishing and broadcasting properties, the deal with the BBC provides an opportunity to speed its growth.
"By adding our commercial skills and program assets to the formidable program-making and library resources of the BBC, we have created a strong British combination that should prove very attractive to regional partners wishing to develop satellite television within their markets," said Michael Blakenham, Pearson's chairman.
The executives said the companies would draw on the BBC's worldwide news network and huge library of programming. They will also draw on programming owned by Thames Television, a British programming producer owned by Pearson. Pearson also owns 50 percent of The Economist magazine and 17.5 percent of BSkyB, the British satellite-television system controlled by Mr. Murdoch.
The two companies said they were also negotiating with additional potential partners in each of the geographic markets they move into.
The BBC-Pearson venture will encompass the BBC's previously announced plan to start a version of its World Television news service in the United States by the first quarter of 1995. A BBC executive said the broadcaster expected the 24-hour-a-day service to generate "a substantial niche following" in the United States but not to make significant inroads against Cable News Network and other all-news networks.
The BBC and Pearson consider the United States one of the most attractive markets for other types of networks, executives said, but have not decided on details of any further expansion into the market.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Orange Juice Prices Drop As Brazil Sees Bigger Crop

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Orange juice prices fell yesterday to their lowest in more than a year amid reports that Brazil's crop would be larger than expected.
Orange juice for July delivery fell 3.30 cents, to 93.40 cents a pound, on the New York Cotton Exchange. Orange juice futures have tumbled 18 percent in the last two months. 
 The Brazilian Association of Citrus Exporters estimated that its crop would total 295 million boxes in the 1994-95 season, compared with the previous crop of 302 million boxes.
"It's not positive," said Robert Barber, economist with Florida Citrus Mutual, a farmers cooperative. "Up until yesterday, they had been talking about 285 million boxes."
Brazil is the world's largest producer of frozen concentrate orange juice, accounting for about 70 percent of world output, the United States Agriculture Department said.
The larger-than-expected crop in Brazil comes as Florida's crop has grown sharply in recent years, Mr. Barber said. Florida's crop was estimated last month by the Agriculture Department to be 174.3 million boxes.
"It's smaller than last year, but it's still a lot larger than what we had been having in the early 1990's and late 1980's," he said.
On other commodity markets, wheat prices fell after the Agriculture Department said stockpiles would be higher next year than now, reflecting poor exports. July wheat fell 3.75 cents, to $3.2175 a bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat has fallen 3.8 percent this month.
This summer's crop is expected to push up wheat stockpiles by 10 percent, to 615 million bushels, the Agriculture Departent said. Stockpiles as of April totaled 559 million bushels.
The rising stockpiles come in the face of smaller crops. The department estimated the winter wheat harvest for this year at 1.66 billion bushels, down 6 percent from 1993, because of fewer acres planted and weather problems. And it forecast that total wheat production would drop by 2 percent, to 2.36 billion bushels.
But poor demand from China and Russia, two big buyers of American grain, have kept stockpiles high.

HEADLINE: THE GIULIANI BUDGET: AN ASSESSMENT;
Mayor's Bet: Safety Carries More Weight With Public

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
In proposing his budget for the next fiscal year, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani made a calculated political judgment: that the voters and their representatives are worried more about safe streets than clean streets and more about fighting fires than maintaining parks, and that ultimately, the City Council will not have the nerve to battle him on public safety issues.
In the $31.6 billion spending plan, two departments -- police and fire -- stood out like beacons as the only two major Mayoral agencies protected from a 7 percent reduction in the municipal work force that Mr. Giuliani imposed to reduce the $2.3 billion deficit. 
 And lawmakers quickly made it clear yesterday that a significant issue before them as they debated the Mayor's budget would be whether protecting those agencies was worth the pain in the schools, youth programs and hospitals.
"We believe there is administrative bloat and excess that can easily be knocked out without affecting the number of cops," said Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker. "We're not going to do anything to reduce the number of cops, but that doesn't mean in any way, shape or form that we are exempting the Police Department from cutting bloat, and if they can't find it, we'll help them."
Mr. Giuliani, a former prosecutor who ran on a platform of fighting crime, was already anticipating the debate, which has been percolating quietly since he first submitted a preliminary financial plan in February that proposed cutting a multitude of services while letting the budgets of the Police and Fire Departments grow to record levels.
And he vehemently maintained yesterday that police strength was crucial to the city's social fabric and quality of life.
"I believe that the single most important priority in this city is making the city safe, and this budget reflects that," Mr. Giuliani said. "That's the reason I believe I was elected. That's the reason I believe I'm Mayor of New York City. I believe that's the single most important thing that I can do for this city."
Economic development itself, Mr. Giuliani said, hinged on the perception of crime in the city, "because even compared to the massive tax burden presented by New York City, way out of proportion to any other city, the primary reason for the contraction in New York City is fear of crime and a declining quality of life."
He said the strategies he had announced in recent months to combat illegal guns, domestic violence and youth violence all required a substantial commitment of manpower.
And he said that even if he wanted to reduce the police force, he is bound by a memorandum of understanding that would have to be altered by the State Legislature. The chances of the Legislature reducing the force size in an election year, he said, "are between zero and none."
But many Democrats looked at the service reductions spread throughout the rest of the municipal government -- a loss of a quarter of the city's park workers, a large cut in youth services and jobs programs, a reduction in recycling pickups from weekly to biweekly, a 20 percent reduction in the staffing of the social service agencies -- and wondered whether Mr. Giuliani's view was too narrow.
"It's your definition of quality of life," said Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge, a Manhattan Democrat. "I don't think that somebody who wants to clean my windshields is as troublesome to me as a homeless person on my street or rats playing on my corner or in the basement of my house or walking into a park that's not maintained."
Many black and Hispanic lawmakers were also fuming at a budget that they saw as protecting a largely white police force and fire department -- whose unions rallied around Mr. Giuliani during the campaign -- at the expense of other municipal jobs held by members of minority groups and at the expense of services needed by the poor and by minorities.
"I think this is rising to the level of minority versus Giuliani politics," said Herbert E. Berman, the Brooklyn Democrat who is chairman of the Council's Finance Committee.
Councilwoman Una Clarke, a Brooklyn Democrat, echoed the thought. "The issue is equity," she said. "Right now the only people who think this budget is fair are millionaires who live on the Upper East Side."
To fend off the Council charges of inequity, Mr. Giuliani called for $11 million in productivity measures from the police, asking the force to assume functions that had been performed by lower-paid civilians from other city agencies.
His budget proposed that the police take over traffic enforcement in midtown Manhattan from the Transportation Department. The police would take over taxi enforcement from the Taxi and Limousine Commission's inspectors and some of the duties of parks workers.
"We're talking about arresting people who are engaged in assaults, in drug dealing and sometimes tragically engaged in murder," Mr. Giuliani said. "We need to have the flexibility to have police officers do this.
But the move reinforced perceptions among the Mayor's critics that he was going to lengths to safeguard the police, even if it means giving them duties that could be done at a lower cost by civilians. "Will we soon be having police officers ticket garbage or inspect restaurants for health violations?" asked Manhattan Borough President Ruth M. Messinger.
 
Next Move Is Unclear
 Where the Council moves from here is not clear. Earlier this year Mark J. Green, the Public Advocate proposed that the Mayor could save $11 million in the Police Department by contracting out such services as repair of police cars. The Citizens Budget Commission, an advocacy group financed by business, has said that the city could save at least $50 million a year and put more police officers on the street by changing police work schedules and replacing hundreds of officers in administrative positions with civilians.
But the proposal would require the city to change its memorandum of understanding with the state, which set a fixed number of officers in exchange for financing the Safe Streets, Safe City program.
Mr. Vallone seemed reluctant yesterday to reopen debate on the memorandum. And one Democrat close to the Council leadership predicted that ultimately the Council would not have the nerve to go that far in finding police savings without the Mayor leading the way. "It's like Nixon going to China," he said. "Rudy can cut the cops. We can't."

Here are some specific budget cuts proposed by Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani for the 1995 fiscal year.
 
Department of Sanitation
Reduction of 2,001 civilian and uniformed jobs. Reduction of recycling to bi-weekly pickups, mostly in boroughs outside of Manhattan. Closing Greenpoint incinerator.
Projected savings: $76.6 million
 
Department of Correction
Reduction of 1,221 civilian and uniformed jobs. Closing Brooklyn Correctional Facility and a portion of the Manhattan House of Detention.
Projected savings: $60.7 million
 
Department of Homeless Services
Reduce workforce by about 1,000 workers, about a third of the agency. Eliminate program to collect clothing for homeless. Reduce maintenance workers and aides in homeless shelters by 100, about 9%.
Projected savings: $17.6 million
 
Department of Social Services
Reduction of workforce by 4,658 positions. Reduce supervisor-to-counselor ratio in Child Welfare from 1-to-5, to 1-to-6.
Projected savings: $124 million
 
Department of Youth Services
Eliminate Youth Link program to identify youth for counseling. Eliminate Street Outreach Program to get young people to use recreational facilities. Eliminate Neighborhood Youth Alliance, a conflict resolution training program.
Projected savings: $15.7 million
 
Department of Health
Eliminate 42 beds in communicable disease ward on Rikers Island. Recue staff at Medical Examiners Office by 6%. Reduce staff in pest control unit by 6%.
Projected savings: $16 million
 
Department of Mental Health
Reduce staff by about 20%.
Projected savings: $6 million
 
Department of Transportation
Furlough of 300 street and highway maintenance workers during winter months. Elimination of traffic enforcement agent unit.
Projected savings: $33.5 million
 
Parks Department
Reduce personnel by 23%. Reduce frequency of maintenance work in the parks. Close Marionette Theater in Central Park.
Projected savings: $12.9 million
 
City University
Reduce class offering. Reduce library hours. Possible rejection of enrollment of 2,000 students.
Projected savings: $13.9 million

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Seeing a U.S. Policy Shift, Traders Push Dollar Higher

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The dollar moved sharply higher against the German mark, the Japanese yen and other leading currencies yesterday, as traders around the world began to conclude that recent signals from the Clinton Administration favoring a stronger dollar constitute a shift in exchange-rate policy.
In a rally that started overnight in Tokyo, the dollar gained momentum through the day. Its rise yesterday was widely seen as the catalyst that prompted a strong performance by world stock and bond markets. 
 By late in the day in New York, the dollar was trading at 104.42 Japanese yen, up from 102.80 yen on Monday. Against the mark, the dollar rose to 1.6731, from 1.6539 on Monday.
Interest rates fell as the dollar rallied, with the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond falling to 7.49 percent. [Page D16.] And stocks surged, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average up 27.37 points, to 3,656.41. [Page D8.]
The change in currency policy that traders sense is focused on the dollar's exchange value with the yen. Recent statements and actions by Administration officials and monetary authorities suggest that a period of almost total concentration on the yen-dollar relationship may be coming to an end.
Because the United States has been unable to persuade Japan to further stimulate its economy or to loosen trade barriers, driving down the value of the dollar against the yen in hopes of paring the huge Japanese trade surplus has been a main, if not always openly articulated, goal since Mr. Clinton took office.
But the sharp selloff in American financial markets since February, particularly in the bond market, seems to have forced a reassessment.
After enduring a period of renewed weakness against the yen, and a sudden drop against the mark, last Wednesday the Administration indicated that it was changing its tune,asking the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to join with foreign central banks in a large-scale round of dollar buying on currency markets.
That intervention, which was coupled with statements from Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen that the dollar had fallen to a level not justified by economic fundamentals, was followed by more strong statements on the dollar from officials yesterday.
Currency traders also said that an article in The New York Times yesterday helped to buttress sentiment for the dollar. The article, which cited unidentified senior American economic officials, said the United States was pondering a shift in its trade policy with Japan.
"Through yesterday, the market was skeptical" about the change, said Nicholas Sargen, chief investment officer at Global Advisers, which has a $5.5 billion foreign bond portfolio.
A currency trader who asked not to be identified, said: "The market has been concerned for some time that the U.S. has been following a single-minded policy of Japan trade bashing, and has ignored other markets, including our own. To the extent the Administration is now cognizant of the implications of that, it could help to stabilize markets."
Many involved in the financial markets said a shift in exchange-rate policy in favor of a stronger dollar tended to calm nervous foreign investors and stabilize markets.
But the apparent change has critics. "I think the Administration has changed its view because it has been spooked by the alleged link between the yen's strength, the dollar's weakness and the weakness in the American bond market," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington. "I see no evidence of that. I think what the Administration has done is a mistake, and unlikely to work, because it runs against the economic fundamentals. It is hard to say our currency is undervalued when we will probably run a record $170 billion trade deficit this year, and move toward $200 billion in 1995."
The change in attitude was helped by monetary authorities in Japan and Germany, who chose to ease short-term interest rates yesterday.
Those reductions, coupled with the widespread expectation that the Federal Reserve Board would soon push its short-term rate target higher, prompted a buying surge of Treasury securities in Tokyo. The rally continued when trading shifted to European markets, and finally to New York.
"This is the first time in some time where I have seen significant foreign buying" of American debt securities, Mr. Sargen said. "And it intensified as the yen softened."
John P. Lipsky, chief economist for Salomon Brothers, foresaw at least two challenges in buttressing the dollar. "The Administration," he said, "should refrain from criticism when the Fed moves to raise interest rates. The other potential test is whether or not they will intervene to support the dollar if it comes under renewed downward pressure."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Air Canada To Buy Jets From Airbus

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TORONTO, May 10

 BODY:
After intense trans-Atlantic competition among aircraft manufacturers, Air Canada announced today that it would replace its fleet of 35 aging American-made DC-9's with the A319 airplanes produced by Airbus Industrie, the European consortium.
Air Canada said it would acquire 25 of the A319's, which are twin-engine, 112-seat aircraft, and had taken an option on an additional 10 of the planes. The carrier, based in Montreal, did not announce a price, but the A319 is listed in the Airbus catalogue at $39 million, which would value the initial order at about $1 billion. 
 The deal gives Air Canada, which acquired 34 of the slightly larger A320's about five years ago, the second- largest fleet of Airbus planes in North America, after United Airlines. Counting all orders and options, United will be operating 100 various Airbus models, and Air Canada, 75.
A spokeswoman for Air Canada, Kym Robertson, said the acquisition "makes a tremendous amount of economic sense" for the airline, which is short of cash and she said was getting 100 percent financing from the manufacturer.
 
A Better Fit
 "The salesmanship was very aggressive," she said. "Our position was that any kind of proposal that we entertained had to be cash-neutral or better." She added that the A319 made a better fit than other planes because it had the same engine, cockpit and galley as the A320 Air Canada used. The common features allow parts to be interchanged, and can lower the costs of pilot training and maintenance.
Air Canada, hit hard by the latest recession and locked in a bitter competitive struggle with Canada's other national airline, Canadian Airlines International, has suffered two years of heavy losses.
But its loss of $32 million (Canadian), or about $23 million (United States), for the first quarter of this year was lower than expected, and the company predicted that it would break even in 1994. In the first quarter of last year, Air Canada lost $293 million (Canadian) after provisions for staff reductions and investments totaling $147 million (Canadian).
"They still have to deal with Canadian Airlines," said Philip Koven, airlines analyst for Richardson Greenshields of Canada Ltd. "But air traffic is picking up, and they've managed to increase market share and done a good job on costs."
 
U.S. Review Likely
 Canadian Airlines International, based in Calgary, recently concluded a life-saving deal with American Airlines, which has paid $246 million (Canadian) for a 25 percent voting interest in Canadian Airlines. In turn, Canadian Airlines will pay $115 million (Canadian) for computer technology services from American.
Still, Air Canada's deal with Airbus is likely to be reviewed closely by the United States Government, which has had a long dispute with the Europeans about subsidies granted to aircraft manufacturers to win markets abroad. Washington has an agreement with the European Union that limits direct and indirect subsidies.
Air Canada had earlier announced plans under which the McDonnell Douglas Corporation would have refurbished the carrier's 35 DC-9's. But as a result of new proposals from Airbus, the airline changed its plan.
"The bottom line is that the new aircraft would be cheaper than refurbishing the DC-9's," Ms. Robertson of Air Canada said.
A spokesman for McDonnell Douglas, John Thom, declined to comment on the Air Canada deal.

HEADLINE: Form of Insanity Defense Planned for the Next Rifkin Trial

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., May 10

 BODY:
Joel Rifkin's new lawyer says he expects to pursue another form of insanity defense when the convicted murderer goes on trial again this summer in the killing of two women he buried in Suffolk County.
The court-appointed lawyer, Martin Efman, said today that he planned to show that Mr. Rifkin suffered from an "adopted child syndrome" and a multiple-personality disorder and was therefore legally insane when he killed 17 women. 
Mr. Efman plans to argue that because Mr. Rifkin was rejected by his biological mother, whom he believed to be a prostitute, his peers and his father, he sought refuge in an underworld of prostitutes where he strangled women to ease his suffering.
On Monday, Mr. Rifkin was found guilty of murdering his 17th victim, Tiffany Bresciani. A Nassau County jury rejected the insanity defense that he was a paranoid schizophrenic, afflicted with delusions and hallucinations. That trial had included testimony on the adoption and Mr. Rifkin's belief that his mother was a prostitute too poor to abort him.
 
Confessed to Killings
 His second trial is to be held in Suffolk County, where Mr. Rifkin has confessed to dumping at least two of his victims, Leah Evens, 28, of Brooklyn, a mother of two children and the daughter of a former New York City judge, and Lauren Marquez, 28, of Sunnyside, Queens, a mother of two.
Ms. Evens's body was discovered in Southampton a year ago on Mother's Day, several weeks before Mr. Rifkin was arrested in Mineola on June 28 for a traffic violation by state troopers who found Ms. Bresciani's decomposing body in the back of his pickup truck. In a 12-page confession, Mr. Rifkin, a 34-year-old unemployed landscaper, said he killed Ms. Bresciani and 16 other women, including Ms. Evens and Ms. Marquez.
Judge John J. Jones of Suffolk County Court has scheduled a conference for next Monday with lawyers in the double-murder case.
Mr. Efman said the defense had retained Dr. David Kirschner, a psychologist and director of a psychotherapy clinic in Bellmore, as its main witness.
 
Pattern of Disturbed Behavior
 Dr. Kirschner, who has helped in the defense of 10 adoptees involved in killing people, said today in a telephone interview that he had spent many hours with Mr. Rifkin and that "there were many relevant facts that did not come to light in the first trial."
Dr. Kirschner is extensively quoted on the adopted-child syndrome in a book, "Journey of the Adopted Self" by Dr. Betty Jean Lifton, recently published by Basic Books. She writes that Dr. Kirschner gave the name "adopted child syndrome" to a pattern of disturbed behaviors among some adoptees, including pathological lying, learning problems, running away, sexual promiscuity, an absence of normal guilt and anxiety and extreme antisocial behavior.
Dr. Kirschner says a small subgroup of adoptees commit violent crimes, including serial killers like David Berkowitz and Mr. Rifkin. He says both vented their rage on women as if to get revenge.
But Dr. Thomas Gutheil, professor of psychiatry and law at Harvard University, said that the adopted child syndrome was "a clinical assessment, designed to help psychologists treat patients," and that the subject of multiple personalities was "a whole different discourse."
"Putting them together in a single sentence is meaningless noise," Dr. Gutheil said. "It may fascinate legal scholars, but let's face it, the jury tends to vote its gut anyway."
The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders does not list the adopted child syndrome, said Doug Fiezel, a spokesman for the American Psychological Association, and it is not officially recognized by most psychologists and psychiatrists as a mental disorder.
The Suffolk County District Attorney's office declined to comment on the case today except to say that it was prepared to go to trial.
Mr. Rifkin is scheduled to be sentenced on June 8 in Nassau County. He faces a maximum of 27 1/2 years to life in prison. He is also charged with three murders in Brooklyn, and one each in Queens and the Bronx.
