HEADLINE: U.S. Is Urged To Allow In More Haitians

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
Because of the new policy announced by President Clinton to grant hearings to all Haitian asylum seekers, the top United Nations official on refugee matters and numerous human rights groups are pressing the United States to let more Haitians in.
Sadako Ogata, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, said in an interview on Monday that in light of the recent surge of violent repression in Haiti, the Administration should admit a higher percentage of Haitian refugees than the 5 percent of applicants it has accepted so far. 
 Under its refugee laws, the United States admits emigrants with a well-founded fear of persecution but refuses so-called economic refugees who are fleeing poverty in search of a better life.
Mrs. Ogata and human rights groups are turning up the pressure on this issue because they see a contradiction in President Clinton's revised policy, which reverses the practice of summarily returning Haitians without individual hearings.
 
Admission Rate Called Low
 On one hand, Mr. Clinton said the bloodshed perpetrated by Haiti's military leaders and their supporters had reached alarming proportions, but on the other, Administration officials say they expect to continue allowing in only about 5 percent of Haitians seeking to flee.
"That rate is very low," said Mrs. Ogata, who is in Washington to discuss Haiti and other refugee matters with the Administration.
"The spread of violence and widespread suppression of human rights to the point that the United Nations is going to levy sanctions in a very serious way means the whole country is not in a normal situation," she said. "In these situations, people who flee should be given some kind of chance to stay outside of the country, at least until democracy is restored."
American officials say the overwhelming percentage of Haitians are fleeing for economic reasons rather than to escape political persecution. But Mrs. Ogata urged the Clinton Administration to take a broader view.
"Killings, disappearances and mutilations are increasing, while whole areas that favor President Aristide have been targeted by the military," she said. "Maybe these people aren't leaving exactly because of their political convictions, but because their security is in danger. We should make sure these people aren't just turned back."
 
Emigration Surge Predicted
 Rolande Dorancy, who works with Haitian refugees in Miami, estimated that 95 percent of the people in Haiti are subject to persecution. "If the hearings are done the right way, then the United States should find that at least 50 to 75 percent of Haitians have a well-founded fear of persecution," he said.
Officials from Florida predicted a surge in emigration from Haiti in response to President Clinton's decision not to return refugees summarily. Senator Bob Graham, a Florida Democrat, predicted that 5,000 to 10,000 Haitians would flee each month to seek asylum, far more than the 1,300 Haitians intercepted at sea so far this year. Mr. Graham said the United States Government, and not Florida, should absorb the cost of handling the refugees.
While welcoming the Administration's new policy on Haitian refugees, human rights and refugee groups assert that it is nearly impossible to provide full and fair hearings for Haitians who are intercepted on the high seas and interviewed aboard Coast Guard cutters.
Some Administration officials admit as much. They say that the Administration does not want to conduct hearings on cutters, and that the use of larger naval vessels, perhaps Navy amphibious vessels that are used to carry hundreds of troops, is being considered. Another option under consideration is renting commercial vessels.
 
A Request to Canada
 Recognizing the shortcomings of hearings at sea, an Administration official said, "We're most eager to seek third countries not only to resettle bona fide refugees but for the purpose of processing them."
Madeleine Albright, the United States representative at the United Nations, went to Ottawa on Monday to ask Canadian officials to accept Haitian refugees. She is scheduled to meet with officials from several Caribbean countries on Wednesday to ask them to set up processing centers on their shores for Haitian refugees.

HEADLINE: A Lack of Money and Edgy Dissent Delay the P.L.O.'s Assumption of Power

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, May 10

 BODY:
On Sunday night a distress cable from Nabil Shaath, the chief Palestinian negotiator in Cairo, landed on the desk of Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman in Tunis, detailing the trouble the organization faced as it tried to carry out a peace agreement with Israel after 46 years of conflict.
"I have just sent $60,000, all secured through personal guarantees and loans, to finance the entry of some of our troops into Gaza," Mr. Shaath's cable read. "I cannot do more. Please send money; otherwise the situation will become very difficult." 
 He said he had sent the money to the commander of the Palestinian police officers who were then on the Egyptian-Gaza border. Those funds made possible today's entry of 148 officers, a small fraction of the 9,000 agreed upon by Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization.
"I cannot perform miracles," Mr. Shaath's cable continued. "I cannot be responsible for any further delays if the money does not arrive. May God be my witness, for I have delivered the message."
 
Breakdown of Bureaucracy
 In the message, provided to The New York Times by a P.L.O. official, Mr. Shaath did not specify how much money he needed, but it is in the hundreds of thousands of dollars.
Gathering the police officers and their families, moving them to Egypt and Jordan for training, and outfitting them with weapons and uniforms have proved to be very expensive. One official calculates the cost at a minimum of $1,500 a soldier monthly, or $162 million a year -- money the P.L.O. does not have.
In addition to the severe lack of funds, the Palestinians are dogged by a host of other difficulties, including a serious and continuing collapse of the P.L.O.'s administrative structure.
For nearly 25 years -- first in Jordan, then in Lebanon, now in Tunisia -- the organization maintained a kind of civil service, with as many as 20,000 employees around the world. Until the Persian Gulf war in 1991, when Mr. Arafat angered the Saudis and other benefactors by siding with Iraq, the P.L.O. could count on about $500 million a year from other Arab countries. But that flow has become a trickle, although exactly how little is not known.
As a result, many in the bureaucracy have not been paid for months and have quit to make a living elsewhere. And of those who remain, many so thoroughly disapprove of the management style of Mr. Arafat that they are actively blocking orders.
 
Discord at the Top
 While the international community, represented by the World Bank, has pledged $2.2 billion to help the Palestinians, the money is tied to specific projects and can be released only after the P.L.O. undertakes its new authority.
A payment of $5 million from the United States and other donors to put the process into motion has yet to reach the P.L.O., a fact Mr. Shaath noted in his cable to Mr. Arafat. Washington's contributions "may be delayed by American bureaucracy," he said.
In addition to the cash flow problem, political discord at the top of the Palestinian command has made it impossible for Mr. Arafat to name the 24-member Palestinian authority that is supposed to rule Gaza and Jericho until elections are held four months from now.
"What is left at the Tunis headquarters now is a group of people inhabiting a complex of offices who report to no one and have no idea what's to become of them," said a middle-level executive, venting the anger of many other Palestinians. "People who have worked for the P.L.O. for 20 or 30 years are just milling about, stunned. The message is that Arafat wants us to just go away."
Israel and the Palestinians had agreed that the Palestinian authority would be formed by Wednesday; otherwise, Israel may delay the transfer of power, including the deployment of Palestinian police officers, until it has the names of the P.L.O. staff members who are to run things.
 
Who's in Charge?
 But in interviews today it appeared that Mr. Arafat, who is in South Africa for Nelson Mandela's inauguration, has yet to discuss the issue with his aides. Many are insisting they will not serve unless they are granted their own executive power, intead of just being Mr. Arafat's pawns.
"It does not matter if we are 5, 20 or 24," one senior official in Tunis said. "Arafat will, as usual, make every decision himself. That has been the problem all along."
Senior officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Mahmoud Abbas, for example, the P.L.O. executive committee member most responsible for fashioning the peace agreement with Israel, has refused to serve on the governing board. So has Farouk Kaddoumi, a sort of P.L.O. foreign minister.
According to one official, Mr. Abbas was "mortified" on May 4 in Cairo when Mr. Arafat staged a high-profile, last-minute refusal to sign the peace accord until some phraseology was changed. Mr. Arafat raised his objections in the presence of scores of dignitaries in Cairo for the signing.
"He swore that was the last time Arafat embarrasses him in this way," the official added.
Nearly 7,000 officers have been recruited for the police force from the remnants of the Palestine Liberation Army, a force that once numbered 20,000 guerrillas based in Lebanon. The army was largely disbanded after the Israeli invasion of Lebanon in 1982 and scattered around the Arab world, with units in Algeria, Libya, Egypt, Sudan, Yemen and Iraq.

HEADLINE: Camera Maker Signs Lease to Stay on L.I.

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., May 10

 BODY:
Spurned last year when it tried to build a new corporate headquarters on state-owned land in Melville, Olympus America said today that it had signed a six-year lease to occupy a former Grumman Corporation building in a nearby commercial area and that it would remain on Long Island.
The signing caps an intense effort by Suffolk County, New York State and the Town of Huntington to find an alternate site for the Japanese-owned manufacturer of cameras and medical equipment, and to provide incentives to keep the company, which employs more than 600 people on Long Island, from moving away. 
 It follows a recent decision by the Northrop Grumman Corporation to keep two divisions on Long Island, ending fears that the company, formed last month when the Los Angeles-based Northrop Corporation acquired Grumman, would cut hundreds of jobs in the area.
 
Competing Offers
 An Olympus official, Sidney Braginsky, said Olympus weighed offers from Westchester County, New Jersey, Virginia and North Carolina before deciding to lease and renovate the building, which is in Melville, a part of Huntington.
"There was consideration of moving off Long Island," Mr. Braginsky said, but he added that "the 600 employees who work for us here are our most important asset."
Olympus now leases offices in Lake Success and Woodbury in Nassau County, but the leases will expire by next March, and the company said it needed more space.
A plan devised by the State Urban Development Corporation for a new Olympus headquarters on the site of a former state developmental center in Melville was abandoned last year when officials in Huntington and a local civic group sued to block the project. Nearby residents said commercial development would destroy their neighborhoods.
Robert J. Gaffney, the Suffolk County Executive, said the company's decision marked "a successful battle in the war for economic development" that would spur activity in the commercial corridor along Route 110, where office vacancies soared in recent years.
Olympus will lease the 270,000-square-foot building, vacant since July, from the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, or MONY, for six years with two options to renew, for a total of 15 years. MONY said the value of the transaction ranged from $29 million to $73 million, depending on the length of occupancy and other options.

HEADLINE: Denver's New Airport Still a 'Field of Dreams'

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
When Denver officials started selling the idea in the early 1980's that the city needed a new airport, they built their pitch on some basic promises: build it and they will come; build it and it will work; build it and it will be completed on time and for the price we have projected.
But the biggest public works project in Colorado's history -- financed by investor bonds and $500 million in Federal grants -- is having trouble delivering on those promises. 
 Passenger traffic at Denver, while increasing, is still far short of projections made around 1989, when the new airport was approved by Denver residents. The project's cost has ballooned to about $3.2 billion, more than $1 billion more than the original price tag. On May 2, city officials announced that Denver International Airport would miss its fourth deadline for completion because its baggage system still did not work. As for a new scheduled opening, all that Mayor Wellington Webb was willing to say was, "I won't hazard a guess."
 
Cutthroat Competition
 That so large a project is off schedule and more costly than planned is not unusual. What angers critics is that as cutthroat competition forces airlines to slash budgets and jobs, Denver International -- with its high rent and landing fees -- will be a luxury that airlines can ill afford.
Airline executives are reluctant to criticize publicly a project that is the pride of the Transportation Secretary and former Denver Mayor, Federico F. Pena. But in an interview with Time magazine before the Clinton Administration took office, Robert L. Crandall, the outspoken chairman of American Airlines, called the new, 53-square-mile Denver International Airport a "field of dreams."
"A lot of money is being poured into building a great big new airport way out in the boonies" some 23 miles from downtown Denver, Mr. Crandall told the magazine in 1991. "There's no need for a new airport in Denver." A spokesman said last week that Mr. Crandall did not wish to discuss the airport at this time.
 
Rising the Cycles
 The new airport's proponents dismiss recent problems as minor in light of the airport's potential to attract companies to Denver and its ability to help relieve an overburdened national air-traffic system by reducing the ripple effect of chronic weather delays at Denver.
"This was a visionary project that was preparing the city and state for the next century," Mr. Pena, who was mayor of Denver from 1983 to 1991, said in an interview last week. "There are going to be changes in the cycles as you go along, but you've got to realize that these are 40- to 50- to 60-year investments."
Denver is subject to boom and bust cycles. It is currently enjoying growth, not like in the early 1980's, when the building crane was humorously referred to as the state bird, but steady growth nonetheless. Air traffic is returning to levels close to Denver's peak in 1986.
City officials decided early on that expanding Stapleton International Airport was not an option. The 65-year-old Stapleton, the nation's sixth-busiest airport, has a terrible record of delays -- industry surveys showed it was the third worst last year -- largely because its runways are so close together that bad weather can cut capacity by two-thirds, from about 80 flights an hour to about 25.
 
Promise of a New Airport
 In the early 1980's, city officials said the proposed site of a new runway for Stapleton, the nearby Rocky Mountain Arsenal, was too contaminated from military weapons and chemical testing to build on. And they noted that as part of a settlement in a suit over Stapleton's noise level Denver had agreed to close it by the year 2000 and build a new airport.
By the late 1980's, air traffic through Denver had dropped with the region's economic downturn. But by then the new airport was being touted as a way to create thousands of jobs and to attract new businesses.
It did create jobs, and without Denver taxpayers paying for it.
But while critics concede that Denver will eventually need a new airport, they argue that Denver International is too much too soon. It was conceived, they say, for short-term political and economic gain, using unrealistic predictions.
"It was sold to the voters and to the public based on promises that were clearly not kept and upon data that have been shown to be inaccurate," said Michael J. Boyd, president of the Aviation Systems Research Corporation, an airline consulting firm in Golden, Colo.
For example, passenger-traffic projections made by the Federal Aviation Administration in 1990 stated that 27.4 million people would board planes at Denver in 1995. In 1992 that estimate was lowered 37 percent, to 17.2 million passengers.
The original project approved by Denver voters in 1989 was a $1.9 billion airport with 12 more jetway gates than at Stapleton. The reality is a $3.2 billion facility with 88 gates, 20 fewer than at Stapleton.
City officials blame the rise in cost on changes demanded by the airlines, like the insistence of United Airlines, Denver's primary carrier, that a sophisticated system be installed.
The original estimate did not budget money for a baggage system because the airlines usually pay for that themselves. But in the name of efficiency the city demanded that all airlines at the airport use the same system. The result was a $193 million, computer-operated system that has thus far proved unworkable in tests.
Much of the friction is the result of a familiar conflict over airports generally: Cities want a striking foyer for visitors, which Denver International clearly is, with its tent-like roof mimicking the nearby Rocky Mountains, a four-story atrium and $7.2 million in art. But this is precisely the kind of Taj Mahal airport that airlines disdain because they, and their passengers, ultimately pay for it.
Airports are mainly financed by airlines, which pay rent and user fees. To finance construction of the Denver airport, the city sold bonds based on that projected revenue. The city and its taxpayers are not liable even if the airport defaults; the bondholders are.
The problem is that the high cost of building Denver International will add to the airlines' cost of using it at a time when travelers are seeking low air fares, and airlines are trying to accommodate them. The airlines' cost of using the new airport will be the highest in the nation, rising from $6 per passenger at Stapleton to $16 per passenger at Denver International, about twice the national average. Even the new airport's proponents agree that the expense will likely outweigh the savings generated by reductions in airport delays.
This higher cost will undoubtedly be passed on to passengers or airline shareholders. Southwest Airlines has already said that, given the choice, it may opt out of Denver completely. "We don't like passing on costs and raising fares," said a spokesman for Southwest, Ed Stewart.
To some degree, the airport's backers have history on their side. New or redeveloped airports, like Kennedy, Newark and Dulles, were once considered white elephants.
"We really did look at the world as it's going to be and take an action that prepares us for the next 40 years," said Tucker Hart Adams, president of a Denver economic research and forecasting company.
Besides, the airport will pay for itself, city officials say, pointing to estimates that revenue from the airlines and other sources will be $374 million a year, $32 million more than the airport's projected annual $342 million in expenses.
But for people who bought the airport bonds, the project is not risk-free. A 1991 report by Congress' investigative arm, the General Accounting Office, noted that the possibility for default would become more likely if several things, including delays in the airport's opening and traffic shortfalls, were to occur.
Moody's lowered its credit rating on the airport's revenue bonds last Wednesday, saying that though the airport's credit worthiness is strong an indefinite delay adds to its risks.
It also fuels doubts among Denver residents, who appear increasingly skeptical about assurances that no Denver taxes are being used for the project. A recent telephone survey found that 59 percent of respondents said they would vote against the project if they had the chance again.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Denver International Airport, above, which was to have cost $1.9 billion and have been operating by now, instead has cost $3.2 billion and will miss its fourth scheduled opening. Airlines are still using Denver's 65-year-old Stapleton International, which ranks third nationally in flight delays. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Pepsico expands its snack-food horizons by introducing corn chips to a crisp-loving nation.

BYLINE: By Richard W. Stevenson 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
THEY eat all kinds of strange snack foods on these shores, including the prawn-flavored crisp -- an acquired taste, to be sure. But they haven't acquired a taste for that American staple, the corn chip, a failing that the king of salty-snack marketers, Pepsico Inc., is now out to remedy.
Pepsi, the owner of Frito-Lay, will officially introduce Doritos to Britain today. It is spending $9 million on advertising and promotion to do so, more than half of it on a television campaign from BBDO New York that is scheduled to begin in the next few weeks, not to mention another $18 million it spent to build a state-of-the-art corn chip factory. 
 Pepsi and its British snack-food subsidiary, Walkers Smiths Snack Foods Ltd., have high hopes for Doritos in Britain, a nation whose per capita consumption of potato chips, or crisps as they are known here, almost matches that of the United States.
But Britain is merely a test-bed for Pepsi's real dream: transforming the snack food industry from a highly fragmented business dominated by local favorites into one dominated by global brands that can be packaged and advertised much the same way anywhere, just like, say, Coca-Cola or Pepsi-Cola, with all the economies of scale that would bring.
After Doritos could come global campaigns for Pepsi-owned products like Cheetos cheese puffs, Ruffles potato chips and 3D's, a snack product developed by Pepsi and General Mills in Europe.
Or, in the marketing jargon used by Christopher A. Sinclair, the president of Pepsico Foods and Beverages International, "If we can get three or four major global platforms on the brand front, that's where we can really build the franchise."
Pepsi's international sales of snack foods, he said, could triple over the next 5 to 10 years, to $13.5 billion annually from $4.5 billion currently.
Pepsi has invested heavily in its international snacks business, spending $1.5 billion in recent years to acquire local manufacturers and distributors, including $600 million for Walkers Smiths, the leading crisp maker in Britain.
Because local tastes and snacking habits vary so much, Pepsi has largely viewed each market as distinct and has done little to send its brands across borders. But now the company is taking the next step in the belief that adroit product development and marketing can create brands with international appeal.
Britain, for example, is potato-chip crazy. Consumers eat 5.28 pounds of potato chips per capita each year in Britain, and are the closest rivals on that front to Americans, who gobble 6.16 pounds of potato chips per person. Yet while Americans eat another 6.16 pounds each of corn chips every year, the British eat almost none.
Wondering if that void could be filled, Pepsi and Walkers Smiths spent several years testing corn chips. They found that the British liked corn chips just fine, as long as they were cut slightly thinner than Americans are accustomed to -- more like the potato chips the British are used to -- and as long as they were flavored to British tastes.
If Pepsi has learned a single important lesson from its experience with Doritos in Britain, in fact, it is that even global snack-food brands have to be adapted somewhat to local tastes.
"We could not simply copy the Doritos mix, we had to treat it as a new product opportunity," said Martin Glenn, the director of new product development for Walkers Smiths.
But Pepsi is betting that advertising and packaging will be transferable across borders. The BBDO New York campaign that will begin for Doritos in several weeks will also be seen soon in the United States. Mr. Sinclair declined to disclose details, other than to describe the theme as "cutting loose or letting loose" with Doritos.
The new packaging developed for British consumers is also expected to become the standard for the brand as it is gradually introduced in other markets around the world. Moreover, the packaging is being test-marketed in the United States, and Mr. Sinclair said it would probably be adopted there as well.

HEADLINE: Legislator Urges Diplomacy to Improve Rights in China

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
The chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee said today that he expects China to meet President Clinton's human rights demands as a condition to renewing Beijing's trade status. If it does, he said, the Administration should stop threatening China with sanctions and use other means to promote human rights.
The chairman, Representative Lee Hamilton, an influential foreign-policy voice, also urged President Clinton to lay the groundwork for a policy that will take account of United States trade, security and political interests. 
 "I believe the President has not always provided the personal articulation and justification that his policies need," Mr. Hamilton said in a speech at the American Enterprise Institute.
"On China, we need a broader understanding of our national interest. We need a skillful balancing of economic, security and human rights interests, rather than a single-minded emphasis on one objective."
Mr. Hamilton thus highlighted an intensifying debate, just three weeks before President Clinton must decide whether to renew China's trade benefits as a "most favored nation." Senior Administration officials said they are involved in an intense dialogue with China to try to get Beijing to demonstrate as much progress on human rights as possible in the next few weeks.
While no one at the White House will say so out loud, it is now widely assumed within the Administration and on Capitol Hill that Mr. Clinton will find a way to renew all or most of China's trade benefits, which allow it to export products to the United States at the lowest tariff rates.
The only real question is what political steps the President will take to get down from the tall tree he climbed a year ago, when he declared that he would not renew trade benefits without "overall significant progress" on human rights. While China has made some progress, and Administration officials hope for more, how "significant" it will be remains to be seen.
One option was endorsed by Mr. Hamilton today, when he said "I hope and I expect" that China will do enough by June 3 -- like accounting for political prisoners -- that the President will be able to declare that Beijing has met his conditions.
Mr. Hamilton said President Clinton should then renew China's trade status, and retire permanantly the threat of a revocation. Instead, he said, Mr. Clinton should try to influence China by fostering "change through personal diplomacy and our economic ties."
Under another option, some lawmakers and human rights organizations argue that, barring some dramatic move, China at best will only fulfill some of the President's human rights demands before the deadline.
They contend that the President, for his own political credibility, cannot renew China's trade benefits across the board, given the spotty progress Beijing has made on human rights. Instead, they advocate renewing the most-favored-nation status for China's private exports, but withholding it for selected exports from Government-owned or army-owned factories.
Like the White House, this school understands that the economic stakes are too great -- more than $40 billion a year in trade -- for Washington to totally revoke the trade benefits. But they want to keep up the pressure.
 
Describing the Targets
 "I honestly believe that if the Chinese do not make overall significant progress, the President will honor his executive order and have some revocation" of the trade benefits, Representative Nancy Pelosi, a California Democrat who has been a leader of the get-tough policy.
She said one possible target is China's state-owned military industries, which export everything from clothing to AK-47 assault weapons to the United States.
Senior officials say the final decision will come down to a political judgment for the President. If he gets just enough progress from Beijing, he could swallow hard, renew China's trade status and take the criticism from editorial writers and some members of Congress, who will inevitably point up the differences between his oratory and his actions.
Or he could choose the politically more attractive route of renewing trade benefits selectively, thus remaining true to his campaign promises while not aborting the trading relationship.
Not only the President has a political interest in such a compromise; so do many of the most outspoken Democratic lawmakers who have advocated a tough line on China since the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre. Although many Administration officials believe a selective approach is unworkable, given the difficulty of sorting out whether a company is privately owned or state-owned, it may turn out for political reasons to be the policy.

HEADLINE: China Allows a Prominent Dissident to Leave

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, May 10

 BODY:
A onetime Communist propaganda chief who became a vociferous advocate of democracy in China and whose case has been followed by the Clinton Administration will be allowed to leave the country this month to study and lecture at Columbia University, Western diplomats said today.
Ten previous petitions by the dissident, Yu Haocheng, to go abroad were refused by Communist authorities. 
 Mr. Yu, 66, the former chief editor of the Masses Publishing House, an organ of China's Public Security Bureau, this week received a Chinese passport allowing him to apply for a visa to enter the United States.
China's decision to grant Mr. Yu an exit permit is an important step in Beijing's efforts to comply with part of President Clinton's May 1993 executive order on human rights in China. Mr. Yu was first on the list of dissidents whose unsuccessful attempts to leave the country were raised by the State Department's top human rights official, John Shattuck, last fall.
 
Another Dissident Freed
 Mr. Yu was not available for comment, but he has reportedly purchased an airline ticket to leave the country on May 28.
[Mr. Yu will be a visiting scholar at Columbia starting later this month and is scheduled to take part in a project called "China and Constitutionalism" at Columbia's Law School and Center for the Study of Human Rights, Judith Leynse, associate director of public information at Columbia, said.]
The resolution of Mr. Yu's case follows the release last month of Wang Juntao, one of the leaders of the 1989 Tiananmen Square uprising who had received a 13-year prison sentence in 1991 and was suffering from hepatitis. He was put on a flight to New York to seek treatment on "medical parole."
Human rights organizations hailed Mr. Wang's release, but they also have stepped up their efforts to demonstrate that China's human rights record has been deteriorating in some important respects, including the continued detention without charges of Wei Jingsheng, China's best-known dissident; his secretary, Tong Yi, and thousands of other political and religious detainees.
Even as Mr. Yu was receiving the news about his passport in Beijing, security authorities in Shanghai appeared to be staging a new crackdown on a group of dissidents, with four reported arrests.
A Western diplomat who has followed Mr. Yu's efforts said the news of his freedom to travel was "very encouraging" because his case was "one of the more difficult ones" that the Clinton Administration had hoped to resolve this month. Mr. Clinton must decide by June 3 whether China has made "overall significant progress" in human rights, or Beijing will face cancellation of favorable tariff status for $30 billion in Chinese exports to the United States.
 
Clinton Remarks on Trade
 Mr. Clinton, in remarks last week, gave strong indication that he is not inclined to cancel the trade agreement because to do so " would be detrimental to the economic progress of China and to the standard of living which has come to so many millions."
Along with Fang Lizhi, an astrophysicist who lives in exile in the United States, Mr. Yu was the first of China's intellectuals to assert that human rights were not something to be granted by the Communist Party, but rather were inherent and inviolable rights of individuals.
As recently as last November, Mr. Yu challenged the assertion, widely made by China's leaders, that international pressure on China over human rights amounts to interference in China's internal affairs.
"If it is the sovereign government which infringes or tramples upon the human rights of its citizens" then "all the resolutions safeguarding human rights passed by the United Nations are but a mere scrap of paper," he wrote in an address, delivered in his absence, to a Hong Kong symposium on human rights.
Born in northeastern China, the son of a professor of Chinese literature, Mr. Yu joined the Communist Party in 1942. His fluency in Russian and English got him a job in the Ministry of Public Security in 1956, where he was given the task of setting up a publishing house to propagate the Communist Party line.
 
Imprisoned in Late 1960's
 During the Cultural Revolution in the late 1960's Mr. Yu landed in prison, apparently for incurring the wrath of Jiang Qing, the wife of Mao Zedong. He was tortured and spent three years in solitary confinement.
With the rise of Deng Xiaoping as China's leader in 1978, Mr. Yu was rehabilitated and named chief editor of the Masses Publishing House.
But his trenchant assaults on the Communist Party's power, often put him in opposition to Mr. Deng's attempts to balance the conservative and liberal elements of the party leadership.

HEADLINE: Stocks Rise on Dollar Rally; Dow Up 27.37

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
At last the volatility in the international currency markets has helped the domestic stock market. Yesterday, the dollar rallied to its highest level in more than two weeks, lifting bond prices and thus lifting stocks after four straight declining sessions.
Blue chips like AT&T and General Motors, pharmaceutical companies like Warner Lambert and Bristol Myers, and high-technology companies like Microsoft and Oracle all benefited. 
 But the lift in the dollar may be short-lived and so may the stock and bond rallies. A negative inflation surprise from the April producer and consumer price indexes due tomorrow and Friday could just as easily send dollar, bond and stock prices tumbling.
"I think it's a temporary rally for the dollar," said David F. DeRosa, director, foreign exchange trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York.
For the moment at least, currency speculators may be joining in the bond and stock markets' consensus that the Federal Reserve Board will, between now and its policy-setting meeting next Tuesday, decisively raise interest rates as an inflation-fighting action.
Or the United States and European central banks, according to a current market rumor, may be buying dollars at moderate rates of intervention in advance of today's $12 billion auction of 10-year Treasury bonds.
At the very least, the United States, Germany and Japan seemed to be coordinating their actions yesterday to benefit the dollar. The German and Japanese central banks cut money market interest rates, thus making the dollar more valuable, especially if the Fed raises rates soon. President Clinton said he was upbeat about trade talks with Japan.
Whatever the case, the dollar rose to 104.42 yen, up 1.62 yen. What has that got to do with stocks or bonds? A more valuable dollar makes American exports more expensive and less competitive, easing inflationary pressures and thus helping both stocks and bonds.
"It's in the mutual best interest of the U.S., Japan and Germany to see the dollar stronger," said Martin D. Sass, whose M. D. Sass Investors Services manages $2 billion, about 70 percent of which is in fixed-income investments and 30 percent in stocks.
The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell to 7.49 percent, down 14 basis points. Yields fall when prices of current bonds rise, because traders do not need to offer higher rates to entice buyers. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 27.37 points, to 3,656.41, after falling 69 points in the previous four sessions. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 3.69 points, to 446.01. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 2.04 points, to 725.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was normal at about 295.6 million shares changing hands.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index was up 1.61 points, to 246.94, while advancing stocks outnumbered declining stocks by 1,327 to 887. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 0.23 point, to 435.19.
Of 30 component stocks in the Dow industrials, 21 rose, led by AT&T and General Motors. AT&T rose 1 3/4, to 53, in reaction to a $4 billion telephone contract with Saudi Arabia announced after the closing bell Monday. General Motors rose 1 5/8, to 55 1/2, on no discernible news.
Of 500 stocks in the S.& P. 500, 296 stocks rose, led not only by AT&T and G.M., but also by Exxon and Procter & Gamble. Exxon rose 3/4, to 62 1/2, and P.&G. rose 1 1/8, to 54 5/8, both on no discernible news.
The most active stock yesterday at 15 million was the American depositary receipts of Ericsson, the Swedish maker of telecommunications equipment. Ericsson was one of several telecommunications manufacturers that lost out to AT&T on the huge Saudi Arabian contract.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Surge, Aided By Dollar and Auction

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities surged more than a point yesterday as a rebounding dollar and a well-received three-year note auction helped sentiment after two-days of sharp losses.
The buying came from both retail and institutional bond traders and allowed the market to recoup almost half of the losses sustained on Friday and Monday. 
 The average yield at the Treasury's three-year note auction was 6.54 percent. While the yield was far above the 4.83 percent rate at the February sale it was lower than many traders expected.
Traders were especially encouraged by the auction's noncompetitive bidding, which is a gauge of small investor sentiment. The noncompetitive bids totaled $1.45 billion -- the highest since the May 1990 auction, when they were $2.44 billion.
Traders said the large number might be an indication that small investors now thought Treasury securities were a good buy relative to other investments. For example, the yield on the new three-year note is higher than the yield was on the 30-year bond in February.
 
Lift for Market
 If that is the case, this buying could give a lift to a market that has sold off strongly since the Federal Reserve began raising short-term interest rates in February.
By late in the day the price of the 30-year bond was up 119/32 , to 8511/32 , while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 7.49 percent, from 7.63 percent on Monday. That was the biggest one-day drop in yield since April 5, when the bond yield dropped 17 basis points.
Jane Tedder, vice president and senior portfolio manager of the Security Management Company, said the surge in bond prices was welcome, although confounding. "Nothing makes a lot of sense, but with two days of price declines, the market to some extent is responding to being oversold," she said.
Also adding to the momentum, Ms. Tedder said, were reports of coordinated interest rate moves by the United States, Germany and Japan, which would help support the dollar.
Most of the recent trading, she said, has been psychological. "The market has been trading in anticipation of inflation, or of the perceived threat of inflation," Ms. Tedder said. The Fed, she said, has not done a good job of easing the market's concerns and in the last interest rate increase "should have come with a boulder, but instead chose to shoot pebbles and that is leading to market uncertainty."
With the Federal Open Market Committee meeting next week, Ms. Tedder said she thought the Government would have to increase both the Federal funds and discount rates by 50 basis points.
"One nagging thought," she said, "has been that the Fed is seeing something in the economy that the market can't, or they have already accomplished what they've set out to do. And if they have, than they are seeing things we are not seeing."
Traders said the strengthening of the dollar against the yen also stirred talk of greater Japanese participation in this week's Treasury auctions.
Market analysts said they were encouraged to see the market rallying ahead of the auction, suggesting that the market had reached an oversold condition.
 
New Debt Is Sold
 Municipal and corporate issuers took advantage of the drop in yields to sell new debt, with municipals selling about $1.8 billion, while the Ford Motor Company's finance unit sold $1 billion of certificates backed by car loans.
Puerto Rico sold $305 million in general obligation bonds with a maximum yield of 6.50 percent in 2023 through Smith Barney Shearson. The commonwealth's debt is rated A by Standard & Poor's and Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service.
Bond traders said investor demand was good enough so that yields were lowered by five basis points in some maturities after the initial pricing.
Shorter-maturity serial bonds were initially priced to yield from 3.75 percent in 1995 to 6.45 percent in 2010.
Ford sold the senior asset-backed certificates at a price of $999.49 for $1,000 of debt to yield 6.47 percent through Goldman, Sachs. The certificates, which have an average life of 1.59 years, were priced to yield about 54 basis points more than the 4.25 percent Treasury note due in 1995. they are rated triple-A by Moody's and S.& P.

HEADLINE: Report Links Growth And Natural Resources

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
The Commerce Department released a new report on the gross domestic product today that attempts to determine just how fast the economy is using up the nation's natural resources.
Government economists hope the annual report, known as the "Green G.D.P.," will help them determine whether the economy is using natural resources faster than it is finding new reserves or alternative resources. 
 Such depletion could mean that the economic growth rate does not reflect the price society will pay if there are not enough resources to meet future demand.
For example, today's report said the average annual rate of return on capital for the oil and mining industries would have been only 4 percent to 5 percent from 1958 to 1991 if depletion costs had been included. Existing economic growth figures estimated that the average annual rate of return for the oil and mining industries at 23 percent.
 
 
Practical Uses Unclear
 Economists say it is too soon to tell how the Green G.D.P. figures will be used and practically applied. Unlike most conventional economic indicators -- like the regular report on the gross domestic product, which measures the economy's output of goods and services -- the Green G.D.P. will not produce a single number that can be compared with previous totals.
For their part, Government analysts have been careful not to draw too many conclusions from their work, leaving that instead to politicians and academics.
"Our natural resources have real value and must be treated as important economic assets and part of our nation's wealth," the Commerce Secretary, Ronald H. Brown, said.
Initially, the new report will track oil, gas, coal and minerals and metals drilled and mined in the United States and its territories.
Over the next few years, the Commerce Department plans to add renewable commodities like lumber and farm crops to the report. Later, the Government hopes to quantify the cost of air and water pollution.
The new annual report, formally called the Integrated Economic and Environmental Satellite Accounts, also provided these details:
*Proven oil and mineral reserves would add 3 percent to 7 percent to the nation's business assets if included in existing economic growth statistics.
*The value of new reserves discovered over the last three decades has roughly offset the depletion of reserves.
*The value of proven oil and mineral reserves is two to four times greater than existing buildings, equipment and extracted inventories in the oil and mining industries.
In computing the results, Government analysts charge the value of the extracted products against the G.D.P. much in the same way a business depreciates its assets, such as plant and equipment.
 
 
Exploration and Development
 The prices of the commodities used take into account exploration and development costs, not just the current price of a barrel of oil or a shipment of coal, a Government analyst said.
In addition, discoveries of new reserves will be counted as additions to the economy's environmental account, much in the way construction of new structures is added to the G.D.P.
Critics contend that the Clinton Administration could be "prostituting Government statistics to advance a certain point of view," according to Daniel Mitchell, an economist at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research group. "Environmentalists want to use this so they can argue, 'We value clean air this much, we value clean water this much,' " Mr. Mitchell said.

HEADLINE: Review/Music;
Abbreviated Russian Fountainhead

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN 

 BODY:
It must take an unusually strong faith to start an opera company in Russia these days. Even the most established and renowned Russian companies, the Kirov and the Bolshoi, are reeling under economic pressures, and they can at least live on a back list of productions. Nevertheless, the New Opera of Moscow has been braving this harsh climate since 1991, offering alternative views of standard repertory works.
The company, conducted by its artistic director, Yevgeny Kolobov, made its American debut on Monday evening at Avery Fisher Hall. Its showpiece was an idiosyncratic reconsideration of Glinka's "Russlan and Ludmilla," a mammoth 1842 work that Richard Taruskin, writing in the New Grove Dictionary of Opera, describes as the fountainhead of the 19th-century Russian style. 
 This semi-staged, seriously truncated edition was not the production to prove Mr. Taruskin's point, although it did confirm that the score offers stretches of glorious choral writing, brilliant orchestral textures and inventively shaped arias. Full-length versions of the work are rare, even in Russia; the Kirov Opera's uncut version, which just opened in St. Petersburg, runs more than five hours. Mr. Kolobov, paring away a great many episodes, choral expansions, orchestral dances and even the overture (the only part of the work regularly heard in the United States) brought the work down to two and half hours.
The essentials of the story were retained. Based on a Pushkin poem, the opera begins at the wedding of Russlan and Ludmilla, from which the bride is abducted by Chernomor, an evil sorcerer. With help from Finn, a benign sorcerer, and hindrance from Naina, an evil sorceress, Russlan and two of Ludmilla's other suitors, Ratmir and Farlaf, set out to rescue Ludmilla, who is ultimately restored to Russlan.
Mr. Kolobov, besides telescoping the action, has decided, his program note says, that "the main criterion in producing the opera is to stress the importance of Baian, the narrator." Baian, actually, is a minstrel whose aria in the opening wedding scene foretells the trials Russlan and Ludmilla will face. Mr. Kolobov opens the work starkly with Baian's aria and has him give a reprise at the end of the work in place of the wedding festivities. The overture -- or a section of it -- makes its first appearance as a coda to the opera.
On Monday, the singers were costumed and given some space to mill around in at the left side of the stage. And if they were dramatically constricted, some of them did fabulous work vocally. As Russlan, Pavel Daniliuk had ample opportunity to show off a big, resounding voice with the rich, deep tone that is characteristic of the best Russian basses. Marina Zhukova had some pitch problems in the highest passages of Ludmilla's coloratura arias, but elsewhere her soprano was attractive and flexible. Yelena Zelenskaya's somewhat darker, more rounded and almost mezzolike soprano was heard to good effect in Gorislava's music.
There were also solid contributions by the cast's two mezzo-sopranos, Irina Chistyakova (Ratmir) and Yuliya Abakumovskaya (Naina), two lyric tenors, Marat Gareyev (Baian) and Sergei Khomov (Finn). Tigran Martirosian, a bass, made Farlaf into a comic character somewhat like Monostatos in "The Magic Flute." The silent role of Chernomor was played by Viktor Tsyplayev.
Mr. Kolobov elicited a shapely, warm-toned performance from his orchestra and chorus. It was a pity that so much of the music was deleted.

HEADLINE: Is It Art or Merely a Safety Hazard?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
Wherever art and commerce rub together, the potential for conflict lurks. At the old Macy's warehouse in Long Island City, Queens, the two are digging in for a head-to-head court fight that could test, for the first time, the Visual Artists' Rights Act, a Federal statute that went into effect in June 1991.
On one side are three artists who, over two and a half years, transformed an 18,000-square-foot lobby at 47-44 31st Street into an eye-popping sculptural installation made of recycled materials, scrap and abandoned appliances reconfigured into a huge silver fish, a moon that opens up to reveal an astronaut with a trash-can head, a bathtub sun and much more. 
 Testifying last week in Federal District Court in Manhattan, the art historian and critic Robert Rosenblum compared the work, which is unfinished and untitled, to the Watts Towers in Los Angeles and Antoni Gaudi's Church of the Holy Family in Barcelona, Spain.
 
Argument Against a Work
 Helmsley-Spear, the New York City real estate giant that owns the building, takes a different view. At a hearing to decide whether the artists should be granted a preliminary injunction that would bar the owners from disturbing the work until its fate can be decided at a trial, the lawyers for Helmsley-Spear are arguing that the sculpture presents a safety hazard to the tenants of the building and to members of the public who walk through the lobby. Many of the sculptural elements, some of which weigh hundreds of pounds, are suspended from the ceilings and walls. The work was commissioned by a partnership, which is now dissolved, that leased the building. Helmsley-Spear says it must go.
"The owner is caught in an unfortunate situation," said Adrian Zuckerman, a lawyer with Davidoff & Malito, which is representing Helmsley-Spear. "We are attempting to protect the health, safety and welfare of the tenants and the public. This has nothing to do with the quality or the esthetics of the piece."
But if the judge in the case, David N. Edelstein, accepts the argument of Richard A. Altman, the lawyer for John J. Veronis, John Swing and John Carter, the sculptors who created the work, Helmsley-Spear will have no choice but to begin talking about art, not safety.
 
Saving From 'Distortion'
 Mr. Altman contends that the work is protected by the Visual Artists' Rights Act. Signed into law by President George Bush in 1990 and effective six months later, the act is an amendment to Federal copyright law that seeks to protect certain categories of visual art commissioned or completed after June 1991 from intentional "distortion, mutilation or other modification" that would harm an artist's honor or reputation and to prevent the destruction of works "of recognized stature."
The law is much narrower than European laws that govern what are known as the moral rights of an artist. It does not deal with books or musical works, and it protects only certain categories of visual art: paintings, sculpture, drawings, prints (in editions of less than 200) and photographs produced for exhibition.
Motion pictures and other works of visual art produced in multiple copies, including photographs for magazine publication, are not protected. It is assumed that they are, as a matter of course, altered to suit the demands of different markets. In addition, in virtually every case they would be excluded by the act because they were produced for hire by salaried employees. The intent of the statute is to protect unique works of art that once mutilated or destroyed, could not be recreated.
"It started out being much more expansive, and ended up being whittled down to a statute that provides very little protection," said Marci A. Hamilton, an associate professor of law at the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law in New York City. "This is the way moral rights are going to work in this country, because they do not fit neatly in our economic system of copyright protection."
 
Safeguards and Precedents
 Other experts argue that despite its relatively narrow focus, the statute extends important legal safeguards and establishes potentially important legal precedents.
"It establishes that artists have rights that are different from copyright," said Robert A. Gorman, a professor of law at the University of Pennsylvania. "It also opens the door to the recognition of moral rights in this country. It's an acknowledgement that the law should protect certain rights that go beyond economic rights to affect an artist's reputation and the integrity of the artwork."
The Congressional report on the legislation cites the case of two Australian entrepreneurs who bought a Picasso print, "Trois Femmes," cut it into hundreds of pieces and sold them as "original Picasso pieces."
Although the act is deliberately narrow, legal experts say it could have been invoked to protect "Shinto," a 1,600-pound-metal sculpture by Isamu Noguchi, which once hung in the lobby of the Bank of Tokyo Trust Company at 100 Broadway, in the financial district. In 1980, without notifying the artist, the bank chopped the sculpture into pieces and put it into storage.
Under the 1991 act, the bank would have had to make a good-faith effort to notify the artist and give him 90 days to remove the sculpture, at his own expense, before it took action.
 
In Another Case
 It is unlikely that the act would have helped the sculptor Richard Serra in his fight to prevent the General Services Administration from removing his sculpture "Tilted Arc" from the plaza in front of a Federal building in lower Manhattan in 1989. It might even have hurt him.
Mr. Serra argued that because "Tilted Arc" was "site-specific" -- that is, created with a particular site in mind that is inseparable from the artwork -- the act of removal amounted to destruction of the work. Under the Federal statute, if the owner of a building and an artist agree that removal of a work would irreparably harm it, the owner has the right to destroy it.
"The artist would not do well to pursue the site-specific argument," said Jane C. Ginsburg, a professor of law at Columbia University. By calling as his witnesses Mr. Rosenblum and Kent Barwick, the president of the Municipal Art Society, Mr. Altman is trying to establish that the lobby installation is "a work of recognized stature," as required by the act. The meaning of this vague phrase remains to be tested in court.
Mr. Rosenblum, who called the installation "staggering in its lunatic invention," nevertheless puzzled over the question of stature. "A work of art that is unknown can't be of stature because nobody knows it," he said.
There are other confusing points. New York is among 11 states with their own visual arts law, the Artists' Authorship Rights Act. In fact, in 1984 Mr. Altman argued the first case under the state law, which involved an artist whose mural on the side of the Palladium, on East 14th Street in the East Village, was about to be painted over by the new tenant of the building, who argued that outright destruction, as opposed to alteration, was not barred by the law.
In the end, the tenant simply desisted, and the mural remains.
At the moment, is not clear when the Federal arts law supersedes state law.
 
Implications for Building Owners
 Thus far, the only legal light that has been shed on the statute comes from a 1991 Illinois case, in which a judge ruled that the act did not apply to a puppet theater.
The case has potentially far-reaching implications for the property rights of building owners. It is one thing to hold off for 90 days while a sculptor removes his work from a lobby. But the law also protects works, like murals, that cannot be removed without undergoing mutilation. In theory, if the three artists prevail, their work cannot be removed from the Macy's warehouse until the last of these artists has died.
"If the owner of the building has not secured a signed written agreement entitling him to dismantle the work, the statute does appear to say that he is stuck with the undesired work," said Mr. Gorman, law professor at the University of Pennsylvania.
The arguments continue this week. If Judge Edelstein grants the artists a preliminary injunction, their work will be protected until their case is heard. If not, Helmsley-Spear can begin dismantling the work, as it says it would like to do. A decision is expected within a few days, and Judge Edelstein has stated that he intends to set a trial date quickly.

Veronis, sculptors, have transformed the 18,000-square-foot lobby at the old Macy's warehouse in Long Island City, Queens, into a sculptural installation of recycled materials, scrap and used appliances. The building's owner wants it removed. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
JABULANI NTSHANGASE is not, from all outward appearances, an overly emotional man. But it was clear yesterday that some of the euphoria that gripped South Africans cheering their new president had rubbed off on him.
"This is truly a great day for us," said Mr. Ntshangase (pronounced chan-GAH-say). "We are finally free." He was born in Soweto, a black township near Johannesburg, and now lives in New York, where he sells South African wine. 
 Given the attitude of most Americans toward apartheid, his task has not been easy. Even after economic sanctions against his country were lifted in 1991, it was evident that little had changed in the lives of millions of South Africa's blacks. South African products, including its wines, found little support here.
"All that has changed overnight," Mr. Ntshangase said, shaking his head in disbelief. "I was out in Amagansett, on Long Island, yesterday," he said, "and the shop owners were pleading for every bottle I could give them.
"One fellow kept saying: 'Whatever you've got, I'll take two cases. Whatever you've got.' It's amazing."
Jabulani Ntshangase came to New York 14 years ago from London, where he, like so many other South Africans, had fled to make a life away from the oppression of apartheid. (Jabulani is a common name in South Africa; it is the name of a neighborhood in Soweto and of the stadium where President Mandela gave many of his political speeches.)
"I came on a United Nations scholarship," he said. "It was under something called the United Nations Educational Program for Southern Africa, which was open to students from Zimbabwe, then Rhodesia, Namibia, then Southwest Africa and South Africa.
"I started at Long Island University, but eventually got a degree in business at Baruch College here in Manhattan."
He has been involved in the wine business since shortly after he arrived in the United States. "I came in May," he said. "School didn't begin until October, and I was broke. A friend, another South African, told me about a job opening as a clerk at a liquor store on the Upper West Side, Acker, Merrall & Condit. I took it."
By chance, Acker, Merrall is one of the city's leading retail wine shops. Mr. Ntshangase, who had had little to do with wine at home, soon became a knowledgeable wine salesman.
When apartheid began to crumble in the late 1980's, it became evident to a few South African wine makers and to an even smaller number of importers here that one day there could be a respectable market for South African wines in this country.
South Africa is the world's ninth-largest wine-producing nation. Its wine-making history dates from the time of the first European settlers in the middle of the 17th century. The wines, mostly produced by French Huguenot colonists, were valued in Europe before many of the famous chateaux in Bordeaux existed.
South African wines had long been popular in the United Kingdom. Canada, too, was a major market, particularly for South African brandy. But it was mostly inexpensive stuff, shipped in bulk and bottled on arrival in some northern port.
One of the first to see a future, however modest, for South African wines in this country was Neal Rosenthal, a New York fine-wine importer. He hired Mr. Ntshangase to work with him on bringing in and selling Cape wines.
In 1992, Mr. Ntshangase, who is 44, joined forces with Andre Shearer, 32, a white South African who had worked in Europe for a decade and came to the United States to sell wines. His wines come through a business he and his brother run in South Africa called the Natural Company.
Last year, about 67,000 cases of South African wines were shipped to the United States. "How many were sold is another matter," Mr. Shearer said frankly. Both men -- they call their partnership Cape Classics Inc. -- are emphatic about bringing in only quality wines. "The U.K. market is floundering because the South African image is all cheap wines."
Mr. Ntshangase recalled with relish a roomful of Boston retailers who, in a blind tasting, overwhelmingly chose a $20 South African chardonnay over a $48 French meursault.
Mr. Shearer recounted with equal joy how some of New York's top retaurants were vying with each other to snap up as many bottles as he could supply of a sauvignon blanc from Mulderbosch Vineyards in Stellenbosch.
Together, they crowed about Lespinasse, the luxurious restaurant in the St. Regis Hotel, where six South African wines are featured on the wine list.
"The world is awash in wine," Mr. Shearer said. "There is no way we can compete with California on inexpensive wine. We have to put our best foot forward."
"In fact," he continued, "we're not just selling wines; we're selling a culture, a region, an exciting part of the world." Both men say their customers often express as much interest in visiting South Africa as they do in buying its wines.
Mr. Shearer, tall, blond and voluble, and Mr. Ntshangase, short, dark and more reserved, make a striking pair when they put on dinners and wine tastings for prospective distributors around the country. They share a sense of mission and a firm conviction that time is of the essence.
"Wine leads the way," Mr. Shearer said. "It opens the door to a wide variety of other South African products." Not that there has been excessive resistance to South African goods recently; last year, the United States became South Africa's principal export market.
As for time, Mr. Ntshangase and Mr. Shearer want to capitalize on their country's moment in the sun. "We have one shot at this," Mr. Shearer said. "We have 12 months ahead of us. Then the euphoria will die and South Africa will, we hope, become just another country."
 
TASTINGS
Louis M. Martini Barbera, 1989. About $6.25.
 
Italian-style wines have become chic in California. They even have a cute name: Cal-Italian. Most of the newer ones, made from the principal Chianti grape, sangiovese, are disappointing. They don't hold a candle to some of the older, traditional wines that sell for a third of the price. But this Martini barbera is a decidedly untrendy wine. It is even made from untrendy grapes like petite sirah, gamay beaujolais and the untrendiest of all, barbera itself. Some of the grapes actually come from the hot San Joaquin Valley. It's hard to get less trendy than that. It's a good wine. It is aged for about three years in large oak tanks and is just right for cookouts and hearty old-fashioned Italian meals. Back in the 1930's, Mr. Martini peddled his barbera to Italian places in the North Beach neighborhood of San Francisco. Those folks knew a good Italian-style wine when they tasted it. So will you.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sauvignon blanc from South Africa. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 509 words

HEADLINE: A Responsible Budget

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph Giuliani proposes to cut $1 billion from New York City programs next year without cutting the services that make life bearable for the city's most vulnerable. It takes an optimistic nature to believe his administration can raise the city bureaucracy's productivity enough to sustain services while reducing the number of employees. But, as the Mayor points out, he has already accomplished some things his critics claimed could not be done. Most notably, he has persuaded unions to accept a severance plan for city employees and to give him extraordinary authority to transfer employees between agencies.
The budget Mr. Giuliani submitted to the City Council yesterday was his formal plan for fiscal 1995, starting July 1. He faced an awesome $2.3 billion deficit -- the largest since the city's fiscal crisis in the mid-1970's. And closing the gap is made more difficult by the public's rebellion against further tax increases. In contrast to predecessors who raised taxes, the Mayor opts to cut them -- only $35 million next year, but $260 million the year after, and more after that. He includes long-overdue relief for apartment owners, who pay higher taxes than owners of houses. 
 Mr. Giuliani hopes to cover most of the $2.3 billion deficit with program cuts, more help from Albany and Washington, and city employees' contributions for their health insurance. In addition, he plans an intricate refinancing of city debt and sales of city assets -- an FM radio license, a hotel, gas stations and, later on, sewage plants. Such deals can bring in quick cash, but they are one-shots that offer no long-term relief.
None of those are sure things. Cost-free health insurance for most city workers is too generous, but they resist paying any share of it. The $45 million he hopes to get for the WNYC-FM license seems high. And, not least, Council members from poor neighborhoods are understandably unhappy with staffing cuts at social service agencies while the Mayor refuses to cut police and fire personnel -- key supporters of his mayoral candidacy.
Over all, the new budget seems more realistic than the Mayor's preliminary plan in February. For example, he now pledges not to cut the number of social workers and preserves the Department of AIDS Services. And, sensibly, he has adopted a slower plan for merging the city's police, housing police and transit police, an idea that has encountered resistance.
As before, Mr. Giuliani projects a slight reduction in total spending, to $31.6 billion from $31.7 billion, and stresses that this would be the first reduction in 16 years. If it happens, without further injury to services already maimed by earlier cuts, that would be a real accomplishment.
In yesterday's presentation, Mr. Giuliani demonstrated an impressive personal knowledge of the budget, although he provided few details on the specific impact of cutbacks. It now becomes the Council's responsibility to test his blueprint, to assure that the city fulfills its obligations to the needy and disadvantaged.

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
A Tale Of Two Women

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN 

 BODY:
Imagine that Anita Hill had come forward with her accusations against Clarence Thomas more than a year after he had been confirmed by the Senate.
Imagine that she had chosen to introduce herself to the American people at a press conference sponsored by the A.C.L.U. and NOW, accompanied by a sworn enemy of Justice Thomas who had made a cottage industry of digging up dirt. 
 Imagine that a friend of Justice Thomas was willing to swear under oath that he had been told by an attorney for Ms. Hill that she might be persuaded not to go public in exchange for a job.
Imagine that she then announced that the only way to get satisfaction was to bring a suit asking for $700,000 in damages.
Would Americans have responded to Anita Hill in a different fashion than they did three years ago?
You bet they would have.
And therein lies an essential difference between the cases of Professor Hill and Paula Jones, the woman who has gone to court to get the President to pay up for an alleged outrage in a hotel room.
The complaint by conservatives that feminists, who rallied round Professor Hill, have not done the same for Ms. Jones reminds me of sitting in a meeting next to the picture editor of The Times, the only other woman in the room.
When a clerk came in with the photographs for that day's paper, he gave them to me.
Because, of course, all women are the same woman. And, according to those who insist that feminists should embrace Ms. Jones unquestioningly, all women's stories are the same story.
That's ridiculous and condescending. Each instance of sexual harassment has to be judged on its own merits. Facts, timing, motives, credibility: all must be considered before we make up our minds what to believe.
On all those counts Ms. Jones sorely needed better advice and counsel. Her first public appearance, at the Conservative Political Action Conference, led to suspicions of political motivation or manipulation. The appearance with her of Cliff Jackson, who instead of a life has a vendetta against Mr. Clinton, smacks of a smear campaign. Bringing a suit for damages after an attorney first tried to negotiate a settlement in which she and her husband would get jobs if she kept mum makes the question of gain a very real one.
Above all, her timing is troublesome. Why did she not make these charges of sexual harassment in time to inform the choice of Americans at the polls in 1992?
Ms. Hill herself had made the atmosphere somewhat more hospitable for such charges by the time the Presidential election rolled around. And Gennifer Flowers had broken silence about Mr. Clinton's alleged womanizing. At a time when this country was deeply embroiled in discussions about Mr. Clinton's private behavior and how much it mattered in public life, why didn't Paula Corbin Jones come forward and say, "Wait until you hear what he did to me!"?
Time, they say, wounds all heels. Justice Thomas's tenure on the high court is shadowed not by Ms. Hill's charges but by his own lack of stature. The taxpayers could save on the salaries of his staff if Justice Scalia was simply given two votes.
The same may be true of Mr. Clinton. Many voters say they care about health care, crime and the economy, not his private life; some feminists are disheartened by his reputation and the seaminess of this alleged incident. In 1996, the first opportunity she has provided us to use the allegations she now proffers, both groups may decide Paula Jones's story of being solicited for oral sex pales beside the President's accomplishments -- or lack of same.
There's no doubt liberal ideology plays a clear role in all this, making feminists less eager to embrace the accuser of a pro-choice President than that of a conservative jurist. There's no doubt feminist ideology should make us demand that Ms. Jones not be crucified on the altar of rumor and sexual innuendo, as Ms. Hill was.
But that's no reason to let right-wing activists, no friends to either the President, women, or the issue of sexual harassment, shame us into foolish lock step. We feminists, of all people, know that all women are not the same woman, all stories not the same story. Accept, knee-jerk, each accusation without looking at how and why it came to be made? That's not feminism, it's credulity.
