HEADLINE: THE GIULIANI BUDGET: THE OVERVIEW;
Giuliani's Budget Proposes Cuts For Spending and Work Force

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed a $31.6 billion budget for New York City yesterday that would reduce spending slightly for the first time in 16 years and sharply cut the municipal work force in almost every major agency except the Police and Fire Departments.
Submitting his first executive budget to the City Council, Mr. Giuliani said the city "has been spending itself beyond its economy" for more than a decade, creating perennial gaps between what it spends and what its tax base can support. The Mayor said the city's overspending had drained the local economy, driving private industry from the city. 
 "The purpose of this budget is to redirect the economy of New York," Mr. Giuliani said. Saying the city was "hemorrhaging jobs" while the rest of the nation was recovering, Mr. Giuliani added, "We can't employ people through government alone."
In drafting his plan, Mr. Giuliani needed to close a $2.3 billion gap between projected spending and revenues for the fiscal year that begins on July 1. To do that, he has suggested about $1.2 billion in spending cuts from city agencies, mostly through cutting 15,000 workers, or 7 percent of the city-financed work force. Mr. Giuliani said those cuts could be made without serious damage to services if managers learned to run agencies more efficiently. Over all, spending would fall by $102 million.
He also proposed some modest tax cuts totaling about $35 million.
The extent of the service cuts is likely to figure in the debate over Mr. Giuliani's budget as it moves to the City Council, particularly since the budget makes no cuts in the Police or Fire Departments. Already some lawmakers are asking whether protecting those agencies is worth the pain for schools, youth programs and hospitals. [News analysis, page B5.]
Besides cutting jobs, the Mayor relied in his efforts to close the budget gap on some actions that will still require the cooperation of the State Legislature, the Federal Government or the municipal unions.
Those measures include about $400 million in increased aid from Albany and Washington, $200 million from persuading unions to pay for part of retirees' health benefits, $200 million from refinancing city bonds, $110 million from selling a city-owned radio station and the United Nations Plaza Hotel, and $51 million from changing payments on an outstanding debt to the city's pension funds.
Despite some signs of an economic recovery, the Mayor's plan assumed that tax revenues will remain flat next year, bringing in only $18 billion. The main reason is that property taxes are expected to continue to sink because the prolonged recession has driven real-estate prices down, Abraham M. Lackman, the city's Budget Director, said.
If a budget is a blueprint of a Mayor's priorities, then Mr. Giuliani's made clear that his highest priority is law enforcement, where he began his career as a prosecutor. The heaviest cuts fell on social programs and other services. The Mayor has proposed eliminating 1,400 jobs in the Transportation Department, 2,000 in the Sanitation Department, 4,600 from social services and nearly 2,500 administrators in the school system.
But the Police Department, whose uniformed officers are protected from reductions under a 1991 state anti-crime law, will not only grow slightly next year but also will absorb the missions of other agencies. Uniformed officers will take over some responsibilities for directing traffic, patrolling parks and enforcing taxi rules.
 
'Most Important Priority'
 "I believe the single most important priority in this city is to make this city safe, and this budget reflects that," Mr. Giuliani said. "That's why I believe I was elected."
Mr. Giuliani will now have to sell his proposal to the 51-member City Council, where some members yesterday objected strenuously to his plan to shield the police from spending cuts while cutting social services.
The Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, a Democrat, responded positively to most of Mr. Giuliani's budget proposals, praising the Republican Mayor for cutting taxes and for accepting a Council proposal to sell the city's waste-water treatment plants two years from now.
But Mr. Vallone said the Council would seek to restore nearly $28 million in cuts in youth programs and some of the $317 million cut for the Board of Education. He said he was also especially troubled by a $1 billion reduction in the construction budget for schools.
"Our priorities may not be the same when it comes to youth and education, but that could and should be negotiated out," Mr. Vallone said.
Several black and Hispanic Council members said the budget hurt minority neighborhoods disproportionately, especially the deep reductions for the Social Services, Youth and Parks Departments. Some pointed out that many of the jobs that were being cut were held by minorities, while the predominantly white Police and Fire Departments avoided the ax.
"We're getting a double whammy in that we lose jobs and plus we lose services," said Councilman Enoch Williams of Brooklyn.
Mr. Giuliani said his job reductions would come from the ranks of supervisors and support staff rather than front-line social workers or others who deal directly with the public. And he said the cuts would not necessarily reduce services, noting that he was challenging his managers to do more with less.
Nevertheless, under the Mayor's proposed budget, parks would be cleaned less often, sanitation workers would travel longer routes, lines would be longer at welfare offices and there would be fewer after-school programs for young people. Recyclable trash would be collected half as often and welfare recipients would be fingerprinted to reduce fraud.
In a departure from past practice, Mr. Giuliani's budget did not spell out in detail where jobs would be eliminated or what programs would be reduced, though budget aides had detailed documents listing the expected service cuts.
Mr. Giuliani said, however, that the majority of the jobs are to be eliminated through a severance program that has so far attracted 7,400 applicants. Since municipal unions agreed earlier this spring to allow the city to transfer employees from agency to agency, the city will be able to shore up vital services, the Mayor said.
"Because of the redeployment program, we can't tell you exactly where the service reductions are going to take place," he said. "I'm asking the people who manage this city where they have service cuts to try to do more with fewer people."
 
A Campaign Pledge
 The plan also reflected the Mayor's campaign pledge to create a leaner government that lives within its means and provides essential services while cutting taxes for the city's seven and a half million residents.
On taxes, Mr. Giuliani proposed a $28 million reduction in the commercial rent tax and a $7 million cut in the tax on hotel rooms next year. Over the next four years, he has proposed nearly $1 billion more in sundry tax cuts, including a $70 million reduction in property taxes for co-op and condominium owners in 1996 that was first suggested by Council leaders.
Mr. Giuliani's plan would also consolidate some agencies and introduce other efforts to "reinvent government" that he promised in his campaign. The plan calls for merging the city's Police Department with the Housing and Transit Police Departments, a proposal that has met stiff resistance from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. It also calls for moving the Parking Violations Bureau into the City Finance Department and dismantling the Taxi and Limousine Commission, handing its enforcement powers to the police.
In another controversial proposal, Mr. Giuliani has stuck by his earlier plan to save $7 million next year and $88 million each year after that by using an electronic device that fingerprints recipients of welfare payments.
 
Wall Street Reaction
 On Wall Street, the reaction was generally favorable. Richard P. Larkin of Standard and Poor's Corporation, a bond rating agency, said the plan was "one of the more positive budgets we've seen in the last five years in terms of trying to get spending in line with recurring revenue." But he added that "this budget still contains items for which the city has been criticized in the past."
Mr. Larkin said bond traders were troubled by the Mayor's plan to save $225 million by stretching out the city's debt and to raise $110 million by selling off some city assets, including WNYC-FM's license. He also criticized a plan to borrow $215 million against future tax revenues. None of those actions would help to reduce the city's long-range budget problems, he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 12, 1994, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article yesterday about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's budget plan misstated the total of the tax cuts he is proposing in some editions. It is $35 million, not $42 million.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
A New Owner of a Philadelphia Development Site Hopes to Build a Large Office Building

BYLINE: David J. Wallace 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
ONE of downtown Philadelphia's largest development sites has a new owner who envisions building the city's first large commercial office building in at least two years.
A development partnership, financed primarily by German banks and led by Aby Rosen and Michael Fuchs, bought the site, known as Penn Center West, from the former developer for $8 million. The price was approved by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which had acquired the mortgage in the takeover of a savings bank. 
 The land spans more than four blocks, a total of eight acres, several blocks northwest of Philadelphia's main business district, with the largest parcel along the riverfront. Under the city's zoning it could accommodate 7.5 million square feet of office, retail, residential or hotel development, Mr. Rosen said.
The former owner, H. Leonard Fruchter, bought the property in 1980 and has seen other buildings constructed in the central business district while his property went undeveloped. As a condition of the sale, Mr. Fruchter will take a portion of any future profits generated by the site.
The new owner, R.F.R. Holding, is the United States affiliate of a German real estate and development company, Rosen Development, which is based in Frankfurt.
The L-shaped property spans four narrow blocks from 20th Street and John F. Kennedy Boulevard west to the Schuylkill alongside the elevated tracks for the city's commuter rail lines. A five-acre riverfront parcel at 24th Street, now a parking lot, is considered to have the greatest potential for development. It lies directly across from the 30th Street railroad station, where Amtrak and commuter trains arrive, and is easily accessible by a bridge that crosses the river at Market Street a block away.
Although no development plans for Penn Center West are pending, Mr. Rosen predicted a build-to-suit corporate headquarters of up to 800,000 square feet might be the first project. Several local companies are known to be shopping for headquarters space.
Real estate brokers say that other uses besides offices may be appropriate for the Penn Center West site, a subject of development speculation in Philadelphia for many years.
"We are currently reviewing the plans that came with the property," Mr. Rosen said. "They were very ambitious proposals that might have worked in the 80's, but now we are downscaling and having an architect look at them."
Instead of the full 7.5 million square feet allowable, Mr. Rosen predicted long-term construction of four million to five million square feet.
Mr. Rosen said the cost of obtaining space at Penn Center West had given it a new competitive edge, however, because of a 75 percent write-down by the Resolution Trust Corporation of Mr. Fruchter's original loan. That has reduced the developer's land costs, which makes it possible to offer space at a lower price.
Mr. Rosen is not the only developer with a site, however. The Rubin Organization, JMB Realty and other companies have sites for office towers, some within blocks of R.F.R.'s property. Their large sites, envisioned for major office buildings, have remained parking lots, with developers unable to find tenants willing to pay their price or pre-lease enough space.
Many companies are consolidating their space rather than expanding or building now, however, dimming prospects for new construction.
"The utmost care is being taken in terms of capital allocations, decisions to lease and purchase, and the right to contract or sublease is as important as the right to expand," said Clive G. Mendelow, chief operating officer of the Binswanger Advisory Group, which does consulting work for corporations on real estate asset portfolios as part of the Binswanger Organization, a brokerage and advisory firm.
For example, Rosenbluth International, a corporate travel agency, gave up prestigious rental offices in One Liberty Place -- the city's tallest office building -- and four other locations, combining its operations in a 144,000-square-foot building it bought at 24th and Walnut Streets, at the edge of downtown's business hub, said a company spokeswoman, Diane Peters. It was an expansion, but the company chose to buy an existing building rather than go into a new one at higher cost.
Mr. Fruchter said he assembled the Penn Center West property in 1980 and, in 1985, sold one square block to Maguire Thomas Partners and I.B.M. for construction of twin office buildings called Commerce Square.
"The plans are fluid in the sense that we're flexible in responding to need as it arises," Mr. Fruchter said. "You could have different uses and they would have to interrelate. You just have to reconcile the architectural needs with the demands and social needs of the neighborhood."
R.F.R.'s portfolio includes rental apartments in Connecticut, office buildings in New York City -- the 65,000-square-foot building at 3 West 57th Street and the 145,000-square-foot building at 830 Third Avenue -- and a 10-acre commercial development site in Miami, Mr. Rosen said.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 16, 1994, Monday

The Real Estate column on Wednesday, about plans for a development site in Philadelphia, misidentified the agency that reduced the price on the land. It was the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, not the Resolution Trust Corporation.

HEADLINE: Right-Wing Lawmakers in Haiti Swear In a Provisional President

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
In a defiant step supported by Haiti's military leaders, a rump group of right-wing legislators in Port-au-Prince swore in an 80-year-old Supreme Court justice as Haiti's provisional President today, intensifying the country's confrontation with the United States.
The move came just as President Clinton has adopted a stern new posture toward Haiti's military rulers over their refusal to permit the return to power of the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the country's democratically elected President ousted in 1991. 
 Although the action was carried out by only a minority of Haiti's Parliament, the military's backing was seen as an effort by the ruling junta to make formal its ouster of Father Aristide.
With the step today, the army commander, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, and his military allies seem to be hardening their rejection of Mr. Clinton's appeals to step aside or face tougher economic sanctions and possibly military force.
In Washington, Clinton Administration officials and supporters of President Aristide said they would not accept the action as legitimate. The White House denounced the installation of the new President, Emil Jonassaint, as "cynical, unconstitutional and illegal."
Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary, said that Mr. Clinton remained committed to restoring Father Aristide to power and that he would seek to extend the punitive sanctions already imposed on 600 of Haiti's leaders to Mr. Jonassaint and other members of the newly declared Government.
The appointment of Mr. Jonassaint follows months of threats by General Cedras and his followers to install a successor to Father Aristide. Administration officials described the move today as a disturbing sign of intransigence by the Haitian officers in the face of new demands from Mr. Clinton and the United Nations that they relinquish power.
General Cedras and four other senior members of the army's high command attended the ceremony in Port-au-Prince at which Mr. Jonassaint took the oath of office, and the Legislative Palace where it took place was ringed by scores of heavily armed soldiers and armed civilians.
The 13 Haitian senators and 30 deputies who supported the move and attended the ceremony today contended that Father Aristide's long absence from Haiti left them with no option under Haiti's Constitution but to turn to the Supreme Court justice as his provisional successor.
Representing only a minority of each body, the group included eight senators elevated after irregular elections organized by the military in January 1993.
 
An Act of 'Open Defiance'
 Secretary of State Warren Christopher said the procedures used to replace Father Aristide "seem to us to be invalid." The Haitian Embassy in Washington, which supports Father Aristide, issued a statement denouncing the move as "just one more act in open defiance of the international community by the coup regime."
Michael Barnes, a top adviser to President Aristide, called the step "just another cynical, tragic piece of evidence that the military regime in Haiti has no intention of fulfilling the commitment it made last year to give up power and permit the restoration of democracy."
A United Nations Security Council resolution approved last week calls on General Cedras and his supporters to honor the accord they signed last summer at Governors Island in New York and step down by May 21 or face a near-total economic embargo.
Mr. Clinton, who pressed for that new ultimatum, has said only that it would not be wise to rule out the use of force if those sanctions fail. But his aides have made clear that sentiment within the White House is moving in favor of military action to oust Haiti's leaders if the sanctions do not force them to step down within several weeks or months.
American officials in Washington nevertheless acknowledged today that the move by the right-wing Haitian legislators appeared to serve notice that the army leaders would not easily be swayed. A senior official said it was being regarded by the Administration as an effort by General Cedras and his supporters "to demonstrate that they are in control, that they are going to call the shots, and that they are not intimidated by sanctions."
 
A 21-Gun Salute
 The honors showered by the Haitian military on Mr. Jonassaint in Port-au-Prince today included a 21-gun salute at the National Palace and a chance to review the Presidential Guard on the lawn of the gleaming white-domed building, whose gates were flung open for the first time in months. He was later ushered upstairs to a reception.
In his short acceptance speech, Mr. Jonassaint called on the United States and Haitians to allow his Government a chance to put its policies in action. "Let there be a truce to give the Government a chance to make decisions," he said. "We ask all citizens to show patience, to give us a chance."
But a radical right-wing Senator, Bernard Sansaricq, delivered a fiercely nationalistic speech in which he appealed to the United States to switch its backing from Father Aristide to Mr. Jonassaint.
Haiti has been without a day-to-day leader since the resignation in December of Prime Minister Robert Malval, who was appointed by Father Aristide as part of a procedure that was supposed to lead to his reinstatement. Father Aristide has refused to name a new Prime Minister until General Cedras steps down.
To reinforce its tough new stance, the Administration has sought to persuade other nations to agree to join in a United Nations force to keep peace in Haiti once its military leaders are gone.
While Canada has said it would take part, no Latin American countries have agreed. But officials of Mexico , which has long championed non-intervention in the internal affairs of other nations, passed up a chance to criticize the American threat of military force in Haiti while senior United States officials were in Mexico City for discussions this week.

HEADLINE: GERMANS REDUCE 2 INTEREST RATES

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BONN, May 11

 BODY:
The German central bank lowered its key interest rates by half a percentage point today to the lowest levels in five years, suggesting that Germany was again joining the United States and its allies to stop the recent slide in the dollar that has troubled American financial markets.
The larger than expected interest rate cuts by the Bundesbank in Frankfurt, which spurred hope for economic recovery in Europe, were accompanied by similar or smaller rate reductions in Italy, France, Belgium and Denmark. 
 The German rate cuts sent the value of the dollar higher in early trading in Europe. But by the end of trading in New York, the dollar was slightly lower against both the German mark and the Japanese yen, after a sharp jump on Tuesday.
The bank reduced its discount rate to 4.5 percent from 5 percent and the Lombard rate to 6 percent from 6.5 percent, lowering the band within which commercial short-term interest rates fluctuate in Germany.
In Frankfurt and in German Government offices here, there was a sense that now it was up to the Clinton Administration and the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates in the United States to halt the decline on world financial markets and stop the fall of the dollar against strong German and Japanese currencies. Lower German rates make it less attractive for currency speculators to hold German marks, and higher American ones would make the dollar more attractive.
Worries about world currency and financial markets played an important role in the decision, according to one of the Bundesbank officials involved. "We have to do something about the volatility we've seen on the markets since the Federal Reserve first raised U.S. rates in February," the official said. "If the Fed were to raise the Federal funds rate by 50 to 75 basis points next week, that would go a long way to calming the markets." A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The dollar's recent drop against the mark and the yen has signaled a decline in confidence in the Clinton Administration's policies, according to some traders and analysts, and sent financial markets in the United States and abroad tumbling. Long-term interest rates in the United States shot up today to 7.63 percent, the highest level since just after President Clinton was elected in November 1992.
 
Where Coordination Helped
 In the last two weeks, first Washington and then both the United States and 16 allies stepped into the currency markets to buy dollars and support the ailing currency. Today's larger-than-expected cut in German interest rates is likely to make currency traders think that a coordinated effort to prop up the dollar might be gaining steam.
German financial analysts welcomed the cuts in key lending rates there. "Neither in wage settlements nor on the demand side are there any signs of danger for domestic price stability, or of the value of the mark abroad," the Dresdner Bank said. "In these conditions the Bundesbank has every reason to continue siphoning down money market rates in coming months and more or less regularly lowering the key indicators."
Peter Pietsch of Commerzbank said the Bundesbank was trying to encourage investors to put their money into long-term instruments rather than parking it in bank accounts, which has the effect of inflating the money supply. "I do not believe there will be another big reduction before the summer," he said.
The last time Bundesbank rates were as low as the levels set today was early in 1989, well before the surge of inflation and the record high European interest rates that followed German reunification in 1990.
German politicians, facing a difficult election campaign this fall, sang a chorus of praise for the central bank for lowering rates and expressed hope that the step would accelerate the recovery and transform the gloomy German national mood.
 
Signs of Better Times
 Finance Minister Theo Waigel said that the change from shrinkage to growth in the economy was becoming "steadily clearer" and that spending cuts by the Government had given the Bundesbank leeway to make more dramatic reductions than the earlier quarter-point cuts.
The Economics Ministry, recently backed by several independent institutes, is forecasting growth of about 1.5 percent this year, after a decline of about 2 percent last year, though not fast enough to reduce unemployment much below 10 percent, or four million workers, before the elections.
The Bundesbank has insisted that its sole considerations are its mandate to defend the German currency, which has soared by more than 5 percent against the dollar in the last two months, and to keep down German inflation, now running at 3.1 percent and expected to fall to less than 3 percent for the year.
While the bank remained true to that mandate today, and said so in explaining that the outlook for low inflation had let it cut rates, it is now led by a president, Hans Tietmeyer, who is more able than his predecessor, Helmut Schlesinger, to do what other countries want and lower German rates instead of increasing them.
"Tietmeyer isn't exactly what you would call an internationalist, but he's certainly more internationally minded than Schlesinger was," a colleague said. "Lowering rates today was also easier because nobody could argue that doing so would weaken the mark on the currency markets. If the Fed were to raise U.S. rates, that would neutralize the effect of lower German ones on the value of the dollar."
 
Differing Circumstances
 Mr. Schlesinger presided over the Bundesbank from 1991 to 1993, a time when heavy private and Government borrowing to finance the unexpectedly high costs of reunification had sent inflation up and forced the bank to raise the discount rate to a record 8.75 percent in September 1992.
Mr. Tietmeyer, a former aide to Chancellor Helmut Kohl, succeeded Mr. Schlesinger on Oct. 1, after the high rates had done most of their work and brought inflation down, at the cost of a severe recession that sent most of the rest of Europe into the economic doldrums and helped wreck the system of tightly linked currencies that was supposed to evolve into a common European currency as early as 1997.
The links were loosened after the last European currency crisis, including an attack by speculators on the French franc last summer. European central banks are no longer required to intervene to prop up each other's currencies when they fall sharply in trading.
But because they are not obliged to intervene, buying or selling currencies on speculation that the central banks will step in is riskier. As a result there is less of it, and the French, Belgian and Dutch currencies have been more stable in relation to each other in recent months.
This has not been true of the dollar, which investors have been selling in recent weeks because of widespread speculation in Europe that the Clinton Administration wanted to use a weak dollar as a weapon in a trade war with the Japanese. A weak dollar would make it so easy for holders of Japanese yen to buy dollars that Japanese consumers could hardly resist buying American imports.
 
Effect in Europe
 The hesitation of the Federal Reserve to raise American interest rates, despite fears that the economic recovery would spur inflation, rattled traders in the European markets, who reacted by selling dollars and buying marks.
After the Bundesbank's move today, the dollar rose from 1.6740 marks, the level set on the Frankfurt exchange just before the announcement of lower rates. It briefly reached the 1.68 level before falling back to 1.6690 marks in late New York trading, down from 1.6731 marks on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Welfare Plan Seeks Limit On Benefits

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
Unwilling to wait for President Clinton to act, his Democratic allies in the House of Representatives today proposed a welfare bill similar to the one he has long promised but has yet to deliver.
The measure would place a two-year limit on welfare benefits and then require indigent mothers to join a community service program. To finance its provisions, the bill seeks deeper cuts in benefits to immigrants than legislation that White House aides say they are likely to propose. Indeed, those cuts alienated some potential co-sponsors in Congress. 
 The Congressional plan comes from the Mainstream Forum, a group of centrist and conservative House Democrats affiliated with the Democratic Leadership Council, the political organization that Mr. Clinton helped found and headed when he was Governor of Arkansas.
The forum's leaders have been urging Mr. Clinton for months to put his welfare plan on a faster track, and the move today reflected the allure the issue holds for both parties in an election year.
 
Stench in the Nostrils?
 "We believe that welfare reform should be at the top of his agenda," said Representative Dave McCurdy, the Oklahoma Democrat who is both the founder of the forum and the current chairman of the leadership council, a non-Congressional group that includes governors and other elected officials.
One representative after another stepped to the microphone at a news conference today to denounce the current system and urge fast change. Declaring welfare dead, Representative Nathan Deal, a Georgia Democrat, said, "The stench from its decaying carcass has filled the nostrils of every American."
With the White House still preparing its plan, it is probably too late for Congress to pass a bill before the November elections. But the likely outlines of an eventual law are starting to appear. Mr. Clinton and both parties in Congress are now advocating sweeping changes that would limit the time mothers could collect benefits and then enroll them in a work program.
Important differences include how to pay for the program and what to do about families who complete a community service program but still cannot find private employment.
The Administration issued a statement today praising Mr. McCurdy's plan as "further proof of the broad consensus in Congress."
The clamor for welfare changes owes much to Mr. Clinton's 1992 campaign, when he issued his promise to "end welfare as we know it" by imposing a time limit. But after the bold talk, Mr. Clinton has been accused of foot dragging on the issue.
He has been slowed in part by the difficulty of finding a politically viable way to pay for his plan, which is expected to cost close to $10 billion over five years, for expanded training, child care and work programs. To avoid a tax increase, the Administration is trying to raise that amount by cutting other programs; it has still not settled on a final list.
In addition, Mr. Clinton has been reluctant to put forward a welfare plan at the same time he is pushing health care, since both proposals must travel through the same Congressional committees. Mr. Clinton does not want to overwhelm the Congressional staffs or have to trade votes on one issue for votes on the other.
 
Problems of His Own
 Mr. McCurdy was having his own problems this week, when a number of important co-sponsors refused to back the bill because it would raise much of the approximately $18 billion it is expected to cost by denying Supplemental Security Income to many legal immigrants.
Mr. McCurdy argues that some legal immigrants are abusing the program, by bringing their parents to the United States and then signing them up for benefits, which are about $130 a month.
Among those refusing to co-sponsor the bill was Representative Jim Slattery, a Kansas Democrat, who was the chairman of the task force of the Mainstream Forum that drafted the proposal. Mr. Slattery argued it was unfair to pay for it by cutting assistance to legal immigrants.
While the Mainstream Forum contains about 90 members, it was unclear today how many would sign on as co-sponsors to the bill, which has not yet been officially introduced.
One aspect of Mr. McCurdy's bill that is likely to provoke fierce disputes is his plan to limit the community service program to three years, after which welfare recipients would be eligible for no cash at all.
House Republicans would allow states to impose the three-year limit; Mr. McCurdy would require it, but allow states to grant extensions to 10 percent of the caseload.
The provision raises several central questions: Are there really enough jobs in the economy for all five million families now on welfare? And do welfare recipients have the skills and emotional stability to hold the jobs?

HEADLINE: $10 Billion For G.M. Pensions

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 11

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation announced plans today to contribute $10 billion of stock and cash to finance the pensions of its retirees, in hopes of narrowing the nation's largest financing gap in a private pension fund.
In one of many wrinkles, the complex deal, which was worked out with one Federal agency but still requires the approval of another, would allow G.M. to more easily sell all or part of Electronic Data Systems. For months, rumors have circulated on Wall Street that G.M. is seeking to unload E.D.S., the information technology subsidiary it acquired in 1984. 
 At the end of 1993, G.M. estimated that it had set aside $22.3 billion less than required to pay the pensions for its future retirees. Since then, G.M. has set aside another $1.9 billion, and rising interest rates have further reduced the liability. G.M. has said it intends to finance its pensions fully by the end of the decade.
 The new proposal applies to G.M.'s most underfinanced pension plan, which covers more than 600,000 active and retired hourly workers.

 
 
Revision of Earlier Plan
 In November, G.M. announced a plan to contribute a vast chunk of one class of its common stock to pay for pensions, pending Government approval. But after negotiations with the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, the Federal agency that insures some private pension plans, G.M. arrived at the proposal announced today, which includes $4 billion of cash and a slightly smaller number of the shares, 177 million instead of 185 million.
The value of the G.M. class E shares is tied to the performance of Electronic Data Systems. The stock's closing price today was $33.75, down $1.50. Based on that price, the value of the contribution would be $5.97 billion.
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, who oversees the pension agency and who announced the agreement in Washington today, said it would be the largest private pension contribution in history. But Mr. Reich also called the extent of underfinancing by corporations nationally, which he said grew from $27 billion in 1987 to $53 billion in 1992, a "very dangerous trend."
While the plan has the support of one pension regulator, G.M. must still receive waivers from another arm of the Department of Labor, the Pension and Welfare Benefits Administration. Mr. Reich oversees that office, but officials there insisted that their approval was not a foregone conclusion. The approval process is likely to take months, the officials said.
"We've still got to wait for the important waiver," said Catherine J. Baker, an industry analyst in Boston who follows G.M.'s class E stock for Cowen & Company, a brokerage firm. She said that while she rated the stock a buy despite the pension contribution, "I would prefer as a holder of the G.M.E. stock that it didn't go through."
 
 
 
Stock Price Might Suffer
 G.M. announced that United States Trust would act as trustee for the stock once G.M. made the contribution, with responsibility for maximizing the shares' value. But, Ms. Baker said, the arrival of so many new shares on the market through the pension plan would inevitably put pressure on the price -- unless G.M. is planning to sell E.D.S., she said, in which case class E shareholders would benefit from the contribution.
According to the proposal, G.M. will contribute $2 billion in cash by the time it makes the stock contribution and will pay the remaining $2 billion by October 1995. G.M. will also continue to make its regularly required annual payments, which the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation estimated would total $8 billion by the end of 1996.
In return, G.M. sought and received from the Federal pension agency an important benefit: E.D.S. was freed from any liability for G.M.'s pensions, making the unit more attractive to buyers should G.M. decide to sell it.
"We wanted to have that flexibility with respect to E.D.S.," said Heidi Kunz, treasurer of G.M. Ms. Kunz would not comment on whether G.M. intended to sell the subsidiary.
 
 
 
Rumors of a Sale
 G.M. paid $2.5 billion for E.D.S. in 1984. Simply on the basis of the class E stock's value, the subsidiary is now worth more than $16 billion. Since the unit generates little cash for G.M. -- its gains go to dividends, or else back to E.D.S. -- selling all of it, or selling part of it to a strategic partner, would be a quick way to strengthen G.M.'s balance sheet. Various large telecommunications companies -- most recently AT&T and Sprint -- have been rumored to be interested.
Some industry analysts see the stock contribution as the first step in an elaborate plan to sell E.D.S. The problem G.M. faces is that the capital gains taxes on an outright sale would be prohibitive, industry analysts said. But if the pension fund sold the shares, the fund would apparently pay no capital gains taxes.
To make the pension fund contribution, G.M. requires waivers from at least two provisions of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act, the Federal law that governs pensions. Under that law, no more than 10 percent of a pension plan's assets may be in the employer's stock. Further, a pension plan may hold no more than 25 percent of any class of the employer's stock.
The 177 million shares represent 37 percent of all class E stock and would raise to 25 percent the amount of the plan's assets consisting of G.M. stock.
In addition to those waivers, G.M. is lobbying Congress for legislation that would free it from a 10 percent excise tax related to the stock contribution.

HEADLINE: In Twist, Consumer Group And F.C.C. Back Cable TV

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
So much for convergence the idea that the telephone, television and computer industries will work together to build futuristic information networks that offer everything from movies on demand to video games.
Less than two months after most cable television and telephone companies abandoned their mating frenzy, the cable industry has declared war and begun a major legal campaign to delay phone-company plans to enter the television business anytime soon. 
 In a surprising twist, moreover, cable operators are getting a sympathetic hearing from the Federal Communications Commission, the same regulatory agency that in February ordered cable systems to roll back prices by a total of 17 percent.
Perhaps even stranger, the cable industry's main lobbying group has teamed up with the Consumer Federation of America, the nonprofit organization that led the political campaign in Congress for strict regulation of cable rates.
In a barrage of legal challenges filed around the country, the cable industry is arguing that telephone companies should be blocked from building video networks until the F.C.C. imposes elaborate new rules. The coordinated effort is part of a strategy developed by the National Cable Television Association.
"The telephone industry is seeking the opportunity to finance their infrastructure investment on the backs of ratepayers," said Decker Anstrom, president of the cable association. "We have a very simple view of all this: rules first, and then applications."
Phone companies have filed nearly two dozen proposals with the F.C.C. to build video networks around the country, which would carry television and other new services in addition to regular telephone conversations. The cable industry argues that phone companies are trying to finance their ventures at the expense of ordinary phone customers, who may end up with higher bills and services they may not want.
On Tuesday, California cable operators petitioned the F.C.C. to investigate efforts by the Pacific Telesis Group to build an advanced video network in several California cities where Pacific Telesis provides phone service. In New Jersey, the National Cable Television Association has called for a Federal investigation of Bell Atlantic over what it describes as unauthorized efforts to lay optical fibers that are ultimately intended for use in a video network.
In the next few days, the New England Cable Television Association is expected to ask the F.C.C. to delay the Southern New England Telephone Company's plan to build a video network in Connecticut.
 
Want Some Regulation
 These efforts may not be successful. But they demonstrate that despite lip service throughout the communications industry for unfettered competition between different industries, the individual industries are still interested in preserving their traditional regulatory protections. Many cable companies are eager to enter the telephone business, an effort that phone companies have frequently delayed through their own maneuvering on regulation.
In fact, telephone executives are now arguing that the cable television industry is merely stalling for time. "The cable industry's agenda is to hold us off as long as they can so that they can continue to make money and prepare themselves for competition," said Ward White, vice president of the United States Telephone Association.
In any case, the chairman of the F.C.C., Reed E. Hundt, is listening to the cable industry's arguments. It was Mr. Hundt who infuriated the cable industry by getting the agency to approve rate cuts on Feb. 22, a move that helped derail some of the biggest proposed alliances between cable and telephone companies. But now he is raising some of the same concerns as the cable industry.
"These are not questions to be taken lightly," Mr. Hundt said in an interview on Tuesday. He said that he strongly supported fair competition between the cable and telephone industries, but that he remained concerned about the potential for the phone companies to use their monopoly position unfairly. "We want to make sure that telephone ratepayers are not subsidizing the telephone companies' entry into the video business," he said.
 
The Opposing Arguments
 The telephone companies argue that there are already rules in place to insure that they do not use money from their regulated phone rates to subsidize unregulated activities like Yellow Pages advertising or cellular telephone services. Those rules could simply be applied to the new video networks, the phone companies contend.
But lobbyists for the cable industry say they want to be sure the that telephone companies properly account for their costs. The biggest dispute is over whether telephone companies will treat most of their investment in video networks as simply a modernization of phone services. That might mean that the costs could be rolled into regulated phone rates, the cable companies fear.
In recent weeks, the F.C.C. has begun asking telephone companies to describe their plans in greater economic detail and offer further evidence that they would not be using ratepayers to subsidize their video efforts. In letters to Bell Atlantic and to Ameritech, the regional Bell company serving Midwestern states, the agency asked for information on their projections on revenue and on issues like the payback period the companies anticipated on their investments in video services.
Thus far, telephone companies around the country have filed 23 applications with the F.C.C. to deliver television programming under a regulatory framework that the agency adopted two years ago, known as video dial tone. Under those rules, a phone company can build a video network and sell its capacity to others, though it cannot own or even package its own programming.
But Congress is considering legislation that would lift the programming restriction, and most of the Bell companies are building video networks with that in mind.
In Chicago, for example, Ameritech has proposed hooking up 1.2 million homes by the end of 1995. Pacific Bell would link up nearly 1.3 million homes in four cities by the end of 1996. Bell Atlantic wants to hook up more than one million people in Maryland, Virginia and New Jersey. Nynex, which serves New York and New England, is conducting some limited trials but has not yet announced plans for new services.
Brad Stillman, legislative counsel for the Consumer Federation of America, said the F.C.C. must first adopt strict rules on how these networks would be financed. "We don't want telephone ratepayers to bear the cost of building out the network," he said. In some of the applications, he said, "they are giving hypothetical architectures, hypothetical costs, and we have no idea how much it's going to cost."
So far the F.C.C. has approved only five video-dial-tone applications, and those approvals are only for limited experiments. Virtually all the other applications call for permanent television operations, and it is these applications that the cable and consumer groups have opposed.
Mr. Hundt said he strongly supported the concept of head-to-head competition between telephone and cable companies and has organized a team of senior staff people to sort out the policy issues. But he also said that the commission needed new rules to regulate the way in which it allowed phone companies to proceed.

HEADLINE: In Vallone's Hands

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
With Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's $31.6 billion budget before the City Council, its fate now depends largely on the leadership skills of Speaker Peter F. Vallone and on how he positions himself in negotiations between a Republican Mayor, whose core values he shares, and the Democratic City Council.
Like Mr. Giuliani, Mr. Vallone, a Democrat from Astoria, Queens, has long appealed to middle-class constituents and championed quality-of-life services like police, schools and sanitation. The next two months of wrangling over the plan will test whether Mr. Vallone can deliver a budget similar to Mr. Giuliani's in the face of concerns among many minority lawmakers that the cuts Mr. Giuliani is proposing would fall particularly hard on their constituents. 
Mr. Vallone, with the good-humored adeptness of a practiced legislative leader, left all his options open yesterday. Sprawled in a red leather chair in his City Hall office, he signaled his basic agreement with the direction Mr. Giuliani had taken by speaking of how much the Mayor had adopted the Council's own priorities. He particularly singled out Mr. Giuliani's support for police strength.
 
Warning to Commissioners
 But then he added a warning -- possibly leaving an opening for a legislative revolt -- that Mr. Giuliani's budget is far too vague about how cutting the municipal work force by 15,000 would affect city services. The Council expects to get details from the Mayor's commissioners in hearings beginning tomorrow. "They are going to have to be very forthcoming with us," he said. "You can't come in and tell us everything is going to be rosy if it's not going to be rosy."
Even as he spoke, some lawmakers in the 22-member black and Hispanic caucus huddled to hammer out their own position on the budget to be delivered at a news conference today. Councilwoman Virginia C. Fields, who attended the session, said the lawmakers were concerned about the education budget, social services, the hospital system and the work force reductions.
The job cuts, she said, "are a major issue for us because they buy into a philosophy many of us do not support: that government has to be reduced for job growth and the economy to move forward."
Other members were trying to determine whether the balance of power in a Council that has been strongly controlled by Mr. Vallone had changed because of antagonism toward Mr. Giuliani among some black members on the Council. And they questioned whether those dynamics would drive Mr. Vallone to accommodate calls to find substantial savings in the Police Department to restore funds for social programs.
 
'It's a New Era'
 "While we think we understand the sense of the body, on an issue like this, I don't know," said Councilman Herbert E. Berman, the Finance Committee chairman. "It's a new era, a Republican Mayor, a Democratic legislature, a large segment of the Council that feels offended by the new Mayor. It's too early to see how that works out."
The Council has had control over the budget only since 1990, when a new City Charter eliminated the Board of Estimate. During a heated budget battle with Mayor David N. Dinkins in 1991, Mr. Vallone threatened to develop a Council budget from scratch. But in fact, over the past four years the Council has changed the executive budget only at the margins: normally altering about $100 million of the $30 billion budget each year.
But the minority caucus has enough votes in the 51-member Council to swing the budget debate and could force bolder action if it works in concert with the Council's five white liberals. "If the caucus holds together they could change the budget," said City Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge, a Manhattan Democrat.
While no one expects an open rupture among Council Democrats, lawmakers said that if the caucus held together as a bloc it could confront Mr. Vallone asking for restorations in social programs and cuts from the Police Department.
Others believed any confrontation was unlikely. Mr. Vallone traditionally exerts very tight control over the budget process, demanding the loyalty and votes of his members once he and his finance committee negotiate a deal with the Mayor.
Members who cross him know they will pay immediate consequences -- such as the disappearance of the funds each member is allotted for pet programs in their districts.
Mr. Vallone already has many members of the caucus in key leadership positions, and he has been moving quietly over the past few months to strengthen his influence over possible dissenters. In late March he announced the appointment of four caucus members to chairmanships of new subcommittees -- which come with extra money.
Further strengthening Mr. Vallone's hand in the budget battle is a Council vote scheduled for today on a bill that would allow Council hearings on any major effort by the Mayor to turn over government service to private contractors.
The Council is expected to pass the bill by a margin large enough to override a veto. The confrontation over the bill is expected to be heated and noisy enough, some Council aides said, that any black lawmakers who feel that it is good politics in their districts to oppose the Mayor can do it on the privatization bill instead of the budget.
Mr. Vallone said yesterday that, as ever, he expects lawmakers to pass a budget by the end of June, in time for the new fiscal year. "This is serious stuff and we understand we have to come together as a Council," he said. "Otherwise we have anarchy."

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Begins A State Visit To Germany

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BONN, May 11

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia began a three-day state visit to Germany today, pushing hard on several fronts with his friend Helmut Kohl for more respectful and dignified treatment of his battered but still great-power country.
"Dear Boris" and "my friend Helmut" hugged each other warmly in bright spring sunshine, but there was tough diplomatic bargaining nonetheless. 
 Mr. Yeltsin offered Russian support for a permanent seat for Germany in the United Nations Security Council, "if it is expanded."
In response, Chancellor Kohl gave German support for the full inclusion of Russia in the group of the world's most powerful industrial democracies after the economic summit meeting in Naples this summer.
Mr. Kohl, who insisted in 1985 that President Ronald Reagan visit a German military cemetery that included the graves of Waffen SS soldiers, diplomatically gave way to Mr. Yeltsin's objections to a ceremony for departing Russian troops this summer in the eastern German city of Weimar. The Russians felt that it would invite comparisons between their 49-year occupation of eastern Germany and the cruelty of the nearby Nazi concentration camp in Buchenwald.
 
New Invitation Planned
 "There will be one event, which will take place in Berlin," Mr. Kohl said at a news conference with the Russian leader this afternoon. It will take place in Mr. Yeltsin's presence on Aug. 31, the German leader said, "in a respectful, dignified way and a friendly atmosphere."
Deploring the fact that the Weimar proposal had somehow been misunderstood, Mr. Kohl said that all he had wanted was to invite the Russian leader to join him in paying tribute to the traditions symbolized by Weimar as a cultural and political capital, where the Constitution of the short-lived Weimar Republic was proclaimed after World War I, and that he would invite Mr. Yeltsin back later to do so.
At the news conference, Mr. Yeltsin did not bring up previous suggestions that Russian troops should be included in military parades for the British, French and American soldiers who defended West Berlin in the midst of Communist territory until unification in 1990. All allied troops will leave Berlin by the summer, and a separate ceremony will be held for them on Sept. 8.
Nor did Mr. Kohl yield today to his guest's insistence on special treatment as a condition of joining the "partnership for peace" offered by NATO leaders at their summit meeting in Brussels in January. Poland, the Czech Republic, Hungary and some other formerly Communist countries accepted the partnership reluctantly as a possible first step toward full membership in NATO for themselves, something Russia objects to strongly as a threat to its security.
 
Alliance 'Indispensable'
 "The Atlantic Alliance remains indispensable for us Germans as the guarantee of our security, but also as an anchor of stability for all Europe," the German Chancellor told Mr. Yeltsin at a state dinner in the Petersberg guest house. It sits on a hilltop across the Rhine where Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain of Britain and Hitler talked in the period leading up to the Munich Agreement of 1938, which led to the dismemberment of Czechoslovakia.
Because of American fears that excluding the Russians could encourage nationalist militancy and weaken Mr. Yeltsin in a time of economic and political fragility, the NATO offer was extended to all formerly Communist countries in Europe, including Russia, on an equal basis.
Perhaps acting under pressure from the nationalist bloc in the Russian Parliament headed by Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, the Russian Government has not yet accepted. Mr. Yeltsin said today that Russia should be treated differently because of its size and great military strength.
And in a brief interview, Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev said Defense Minister Pavel S. Grachev would explain Russia's proposals when he visited NATO headquarters in Brussels on May 25. They are thought to involve a bigger role for the 52-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which has neither the military might nor the decision-making ability of the alliance.
 
A Plea to Industrialists
 At the dinner tonight, Mr. Yeltsin said, "It is unbecoming to split Europe into zones of greater and lesser security."
During his visit here, accompanied by his wife, Naina Y. Yeltsina, the Russian leader will visit Mr. Kohl's home in Oggersheim, near Ludwigshafen, and see the Romanesque cathedral in Speyer, where some of the German Holy Roman Emperors are buried.
Mr. Yeltsin will also press German industrialists in Stuttgart on Friday to invest more money in helping Russia become a market economy. Last year, there was just $18 million of private German investment there, while Russian businesses pumped 10 times as much, $181.5 million, into Germany.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Poor Auction Demand Pushes Up Bond Yields

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond yields surged yesterday, as the second leg of the Treasury's quarterly refunding drew less demand than expected and the auction of the new 10-year note went poorly.
Expectations of another rise in short-term rates by the Federal Reserve and caution ahead of the release of two key inflation reports today and tomorrow also helped push prices lower and yields higher. 
 After a surprisingly successful three-year note auction on Tuesday, when retail interest caused many in the market to conclude that small investors were ready to do some serious buying, the results of the 10-year sale were sobering, leading some to believe that conclusions drawn on Tuesday may be premature.
Frank Sannella, an analyst with Technical Data, said yesterday's poor showing at the 10-year note auction hit the market hard.
After the results of the disappointing Treasury auction were released in the afternoon, the yield on the 30-year bond spiked 14 basis points, to 7.65 percent, before finishing down 13/32 of a point, to 848/32 for a yield of 7.60 percent. That was up from 7.49 percent on Tuesday.
In an effort to sell the new 10-year note, dealers had lowered the price by late in the day so much that the yield jumped to 7.40 percent. The 7.36 percent average yield at the auction was the highest since May 1992, when the yield was 7.53 percent.
 
 
Limited Upside
 "The upside to the market remains limited until there is a clearer picture of the economy and the Fed uncertainty is out of the way," Mr. Sannella said. "I expect the market's bias will continue down for the remainder of the week or until the Fed takes some action."
In early trading, the bond market showed little reaction to the German Bundesbank's cut of its discount and Lombard rates by 50 basis points, to 4.50 percent and 6 percent, respectively. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Price jumps in precious metals pushed the Commodity Research Bureau index up 1.84 points, to 226.78. The index, a closely watched basket of commodities, is viewed as a forward look at inflation pressures.
Traders said there was still uncertainty among Fed watchers over whether the Fed would raise its short-term interest rate target by 25 or 50 basis points. But they said the market prices seemed to have already discounted a half-point increase into the Federal funds rate over the near term and an end-of-year funds rate in the area of 5.25 percent to 5.50 percent.
 
 
Economists Are Divided
 A recent survey conducted by MMS International shows a split among economists on the outlook for what the Fed will do next. The Fed's policy making group meets next Tuesday.
According to the survey, only 57 percent are forecasting a half of a percentage point increase in the Federal funds rate, which is now 3.75 percent, while the while the other 43 percent expect a quarter of a point increase.
In the municipal market, the largest negotiated sale of the day was $176 million of park revenue bonds issued by the Los Angeles County Public Works Financing Authority through Lazard Freres & Company.
The issue, rated double-A by Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's, was initially priced to yield a maximum 6.439 percent for a bond due in 2015.
Elsewhere, S.& P. announced yesterday that it was dropping the debt rating on about $2.7 billion of Denver International Airport bonds by three grades, to BB, or junk bond status, from BBB.
The rating agency cited continuing difficulties with the baggage system that has made it impossible to predict when the airport would be able to open, a situation that could lead to inadequate capacity to meet timely interest and principal payments. Ernie Perez, an analyst with S.& P., said that "the airport debt is not in danger of imminent default."
 
 
'No Viable Backup System'
 He added: "That no viable backup system is in place while they try to de-bug the existing system is a main concern to us. They haven't even put together a team to work on it. And we don't know what the final cost will be in fixing it."
S.& P. said the developing outlook on the rating reflects the possibility that the rating could be raised or lowered in the next one to three years depending on the effects and duration of the delay, including the costs to correct the baggage system.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops as the Fed Fails To Increase Interest Rates

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most leading currencies yesterday after the Federal Reserve took no action to push up short-term American interest rates.
Traders sold dollars through the day as it became clear that the Fed would not act yesterday. Adding pressure to the dollar was an afternoon selloff in the bond market after weak demand in the auction of 10-year Treasury notes. 
 The steady selling of dollars erased gains made after the German central bank lowered both its key interest rates by half a percentage point, larger than the cuts expected.
"The Fed has been disappointing currency traders for days now," said Koichi Takenaka, assistant vice president at Industrial Bank of Japan in New York. "We keep expecting the Fed to do something with rates to support the dollar and bonds."
 
Rises, Then Falls
 In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.6690 German marks, down from 1.6731 marks on Tuesday. It rose as high as 1.6810 marks just after the Bundesbank cut its discount rate to 4.5 percent from 5 percent and lowered its Lombard rate to 6 percent from 6.5 percent.
The dollar also slipped to 104.29 Japanese yen from 104.42 yen. Its retreat followed strong gains on Tuesday, when traders focused on signs that recent support for the dollar by the Clinton Administration represented a shift in exchange-rate policy.
Many currency traders had expected the Fed to push up short-term interest rates after the Bundesbank lowered its key lending rates. A Fed move would have suggested a more strongly coordinated effort to lift the dollar from its recent slump. In one such move on May 4, the Fed, the Bundesbank and other central banks teamed up to buy dollars.
 
Focusing on the Fed
 Higher rates here and lower rates abroad buoy the dollar by making dollar-denominated assets more attractive.
"Any dollar benefit from coordinated interest-rate action depends far more on the Fed than on the Bundesbank," said Avinash Persaud, head of currency research at J. P. Morgan Europe in London.
The Fed is to hold a policy meeting on Tuesday, and many traders expect it to raise short-term interest rates for the fourth time this year.
"The dollar is facing a crisis of confidence," said David Gilmore, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics, a consulting firm. "There's a lot of reluctance to park money in U.S. assets right now."
The dollar has fallen as much as 6 percent against the mark and 10 percent against the yen this year as investors sold dollar-denominated assets, and speculators tired of waiting for the dollar to rally.

HEADLINE: G.M. Gives Mexico Its Own 'Chevy'

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, May 11

 BODY:
Passionate purple, nail-polish red and swimming pool aquamarine are colors that a growing number of Mexicans have begun to associate with the North American Free Trade Agreement.
As soon as the trade pact took effect on Jan. 1. General Motors de Mexico started importing a cuddly new subcompact car from Spain called Chevy in several psychedelic colors. Its arrival has brightened an otherwise dreary automotive sector. 
 The new car is called the Chevy here, though it is not a traditional Chevrolet and has been sold in Europe as the Opel Corsa. But General Motors decided to go with a familiar nickname to bring a new model to Mexico.
Importing the Chevy is just the first step. By the end of next year, General Motors plans to start producing the car in its Ramos Arizpe plant in the state of Coahuila, which borders Texas. While the company has not talked of exporting Chevys to the United States, that is considered a logical move.
With more than 5,500 sold in Mexico and nearly as many on order by customers, the Chevy may be the most visible symbol of the trade agreement, which lowers tariffs on goods crossing the borders of the United States, Canada and Mexico. G.M. officials said they would not have imported the Chevy into Mexico before the pact, which substantially reduced the restrictions on such imports.
The 5,500 Chevys sold here since January might not sound like a lot in a country of 90 million people, but it is impressive considering that General Motors de Mexico imported just 1,700 vehicles in all of 1993.
The little four-cylinder gas-saver is the most colorful in a wave of more than 10,000 imports that G.M. brought into Mexico during the first quarter of 1994. The other 4,500 or so were manufactured in the United States and Canada, and include Corvettes, Cadillacs, fire-breathing Firebird Trans Ams and bullet-shaped fiberglass Oldsmobile vans.
The influx of imports into Mexico is seen by the American auto makers as proof of what they said last fall: The trade pact would not cost American workers jobs because cars from the United States and Canada would be exported to Mexico while Mexican-made cars came north.
"What Nafta does is allow us to rationalize our production, which means that we'll support the Mexican market by producing the majority of our products here and importing the rest," said Gary L. Henson, president of General Motors de Mexico.
But Steve Beckman, an international economist with the United Automobile Workers union in Washington, said he disagreed. "Looking only at the import side doesn't give you the whole picture of whether or not jobs are being lost," he said.
Mr. Beckman said that while American exports to Mexico had risen, Mexican exports to the United States had grown as rapidly, canceling any benefit to American labor.
 
More Models Available
 Still, the impact of the trade agreement is clear at General Motors showrooms like the one at Chevrolet Aguinaco in Naucalpan, a suburb of Mexico City. The large American-style dealership is loaded with more models than Mexicans have ever seen in a G.M. showroom. Juan De Aguinaco, director general of the company, said imports accounted for almost two-thirds of the increase in sales from last year's first quarter.
"If we could have gotten all the cars we had orders for, we could have sold twice as many as we did." Mr. De Aguinaco said.
From January to the end of March, Mr. De Aguinaco's agency sold 180 Chevys, among the highest for any automobile dealer in Mexico.
With companies in Mexico no longer required to export more than they import, and with lower percentagesfor local manufacturing content, General Motors was able to import the Chevy and enter the lucrative market for first-time car buyers. Until now, the market had been dominated by Volkswagen, which still makes the old-fashioned Beetle here, and Nissan, which manufactures a no-frills sedan called the Tsuru.
 
Costs More Than a Beetle
 The Chevy comes in two models: the basic Joy and the better-equipped Swing. Both are available in two-door and four-door versions, with five-speed manual transmissions and 1.4-liter engines that get about 40 miles a gallon. The Joy costs about $11,000, which is $1,500 to $2,000 more than the Beetle.
Buyers like 27-year-old Cesar Borja of Mexico City are willing to pay the difference because the Chevy is much more powerful, maneuverable and stylish than the Beetle.
"It's modern," said Mr. Borja, who drove up in an old Volkswagen that he hoped to replace with a Chevy Swing. "And on this type of car, these wild colors are fun."
G.M.'s desire to enter the low end of the market with a car for young people is understandable. Sixty percent of Mexico's population is younger than 25. Until it introduced the Chevy, General Motors had not competed for that market segment, not only because Volkswagen was too strong but also because the Mexican Government had limited the number of models that a company could build.
 
More Export Activity
 Because the Chevy comes from Spain for the time being, it is subject to import limitations and a 20 percent Mexican tariff. Cars made in the United States and Canada encounter a smaller tariff of 10 percent that will disappear in 10 years.
The trade pact has prompted other American companies to step up exports. Last month, Ford introduced four models to Mexico, including the redesigned Mustang. Mexicans have long favored and lovingly cared for the older classic Mustangs. Chrysler is also bringing in new models, including the Dodge Intrepid and Jeep Cherokee Sport.
Even with the higher level of imports, the Mexican market for automobiles is still troubled. Domestic sales dropped by 14 percent in the first quarter of this year, even as export sales climbed by nearly 44 percent. The decrease is attributed to a lingering recession, uncertainty caused by several violent incidents in Mexico this year and interest rates as high as 35 percent caused by the defense of the peso by the central bank of Mexico.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Air Products' Charge Set

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: ALLENTOWN, Pa., May 11

 BODY:
Air Products and Chemicals Inc. said today that it would take an after-tax charge of $60 million, because of derivatives contracts it entered into with the Bankers Trust New York Corporation
The company, which produces industrial gases, entered into five interest-rate swaps with Bankers Trust between October and December last year. The swaps were bets that United States and European interest rates would remain stable and were "leveraged," meaning that profits, or losses, could multiply very quickly. 
 Air Products' loss on its swaps will reduce net income to $13 million, or 12 cents a share, the company said. Without the charge, earnings would have been 65 cents a share, it said.
The company's stock fell 75 cents today, to $39.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Air Products' loss is the latest in a series of setbacks companies have suffered in derivatives trades with Bankers Trust. Procter & Gamble said last month that it had lost $102 million after tax on a leveraged swap with Bankers Trust, the biggest loss on interest-rate swaps by a United States industrial company.
Gibson Greetings Inc. said it had lost $19.7 million and the Mead Corporation announced a $7.4 million loss on swaps last month.
The company "will absolutely not" do any more leveraged swaps, and senior managers will keep a closer watch on the types of trades carried out by treasury executives, said Kevin Ramundo, an Air Products spokesman.
Air Products, which employs 14,000 people, has used swaps for some years to guard against swings in interest rates that could raise the cost of servicing its $1.3 billion in debt, Mr. Wagner said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Looking ahead, an industry group rethinks its meeting venue.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
CHANGE is slow in coming to the advertising industry. But as the American Association of Advertising Agencies begins its annual meeting, there are palpable signs that there is indeed change.
For one thing, the Four A's, as the industry organization is known, is taking steps to modernize the meeting, which started yesterday at the Greenbrier resort in White Sulphur Springs, W. Va. 
 The agenda includes forward-looking sessions on reinventing and re-engineering the nation's agencies and the future of commercial communication. References to this being the 76th annual meeting are being played down in favor of the fresher-sounding phrase, "the 1994 annual meeting."
And the entertainment at the black-tie dinner tomorrow, which usually runs to performers of a certain era like the comedian Rich Little, will be the Capitol Steps, a group from Washington that fashions today's headlines into song parodies that mock high-profile figures like President Clinton and the conservative talk-show host Rush Limbaugh.
But perhaps the most notable indication of change is a declaration by O. Burtch Drake, who was named the president and chief executive of the association in January.
"The Greenbrier is no longer a sacred cow," Mr. Drake said in a telephone interview from his office in New York before the meeting.
The frequency at which the annual meetings are held there "is a subject that will be renewed after this meeting," he said, adding that it was "the most black-and-white issue" among the members of the Four A's.
The Greenbrier serves as the meeting site every third year; in between, there is a meeting in the South and one in the West. While it is "a first-class resort," Mr. Drake said of the Greenbrier, it is "always a difficult draw."
"It's very expensive and very hard to get to," he added. "We virtually can't get anybody from California to come to the Greenbrier because it's impossible to get there."
The Greenbrier is tucked away in the Allegheny Mountains of southeastern West Virgina, about 50 miles northwest of Roanoke, Va., the nearest large city. Its inaccessibility is typical of the grand resorts that executives once used as getaways.
About 400 people are expected to attend the meeting, which runs through Saturday, down from earlier estimates of 430. As recently as 1990, before the recession hit the industry, the annual meeting drew 627 people in Palm Desert, Calif.
To be sure, the issue of where to hold an annual meeting looms small compared with the industry's most pressing problems, ranging from the fraying ties between consumers and name-brand advertised products to the increasing difficulty agencies have in building long-lasting, stable relationships with clients.
Yet in a field in which perception is often reality, the selection of a meeting site can take on larger significance. That is particularly true when the disaffection with the genteel Greenbrier goes beyond issues like cost and location.
The remote resort has, in effect, become a symbol of a reluctance, even a resistance, to change among the industry's leading executives.
Part of that is attributable to the Greenbrier's old-fashioned atmosphere. The last time the Four A's met there, in 1991, signs were still posted in the hallways at night advising quiet because "it's sleepy time down South."
And part of that stems from the favor the Greenbrier finds among those who once dominated the industry, the older top executives of the big agencies based in New York. By extension, it has become synonymous with a time when those men ruled advertising, much to the dismay of women and members of minorities, as well as executives of smaller agencies and those from agencies in the Midwest, West and Northwest.
"There are people who love the Greenbrier and think it's the finest resort in America," Mr. Drake said. "But there are people who think it sends all the wrong signals, that we're a bunch of old stodgy guys in green pants standing around with drinks in our hands."
Mr. Drake said the 77th annual meeting of the Four A's, to be held next April, would be at the Hyatt Regency Grand Cypress in Orlando, Fla.
"We're going to Disney World," he added, laughing. "It's a sign of a change of the times."
At a business session yesterday, the Four A's board, in its annual election of officers, voted as expected for Edward L. Wax, chairman and chief executive of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide in New York, to become the chairman for 1994-95. Mr. Wax, who has been vice chairman for 1993-94, will succeed Roy Bostock, chairman and chief executive of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York, who has served as the chairman for 1993-94.
Mr. Wax, in brief remarks, said he would focus on three issues during his tenure: advocating the effectiveness of advertising, protecting "the right to commercial free speech," and promoting "the value of advertising agencies."
Burt Manning, chairman and chief executive of the J. Walter Thompson Company in New York, was elected vice chairman for 1994-95. That places him in line to succeed Mr. Wax and become the chairman for 1995-96.
The session ended on a light note when, as Eric Mower, chairman and chief executive of Eric Mower & Associates in Syracuse, delivered the treasurer's report, the Eastern Greenbrier Junior High School's wind ensemble marched through the room playing "We're in the Money."
