HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Things were fine until the Fed's foray, a Nobel laureate says.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
THE economy is perking right along, but growth is still modest by the benchmark of other recoveries. A handful of commodity prices are inching up, but there is no evidence that self-sustaining inflation driven by wages is in the works. The President is a Democrat, but on the critical issues of taxation, spending and regulation he is acting more like a deficit-fearing pre-Reagan conservative.
Why, then, have the bond markets reacted so perversely to what the Federal Reserve labeled a long range pre-emptive strike against inflation? And why have the big central banks had to intervene repeatedly to stabilize the dollar against the mark and yen, just when the interest-rate advantage to holding assets in dollars is rising?
Some would point to President Clinton's flat-footed policies toward Japan and China, which have unsettled major trade relationships. And some fear that the Democrats will revert to free-spending form, once they come to their liberal senses. But a more plausible explanation for the markets' jumpiness is offered by James Tobin, the Nobel laureate in economics who advised President John F. Kennedy. "The markets are fighting the last war," he argues, behaving as if the inflation of 1979 is just around the corner. 
 In the view of some very respectable economists Washington has already gone too far. The Fed's initial moves to raise short-term interest rates in February, Mr. Tobin insists, were at best premature and, arguably, based on spurious evidence of inflation in the making.
Commodity prices always edge up during economic recoveries, he points out, just as they go down during recessions. What would have been worrying (and is nowhere in sight) was a sign that wages were rising in response to the increased demand for labor, creating the conditions for cost-push inflation. And while it is true that the tighter the labor market, the greater the risk of bottlenecks that would generate cost pressures, Mr. Tobin insists that "Alan Greenspan doesn't know where this 'natural rate' of unemployment is, any more than I do."
Richard Cooper, an economist at Harvard who advised President Jimmy Carter, shares Mr. Tobin's skepticism about the Fed's stance. The pervasive sense that foreigners are ready and eager to take a chunk of America's markets, he notes, makes employers more resistant to wage demands and workers less militant than in past recoveries.
Just how much the slack product markets in Europe and Japan and the fierce competition from low-wage Mexicans, Brazilians and Chinese have reduced labor's moxie is a matter of conjecture. But Neal Soss, chief economist for CS First Boston, speculates that it is in the range of half a percentage point, leaving the economy with room to fill perhaps another million jobs before labor shortages become an issue.
The opinion that the Fed has overshot is also reportedly held by some members of the Administration. But their voices have been muted, perhaps because there is little expectation that tighter credit will actually choke off growth. Mr. Cooper wonders, though, whether the sanguine assumption that all the Fed has really done is to stretch out the recovery is correct. Some forecasts, he points out, suggest that a "growth recession" -- a period of positive growth but at a rate insufficient to absorb new entrants into the labor force -- will set in before the 1996 election.
To be sure, the majority view among economists is still that both the timing and the size of the Fed's increases in interest rates were prudent. "The main point is that the economy isn't very far from full employment," said Benjamin Friedman of Harvard. But whether the Fed's initiative was good policy or overkill, it remains a puzzle why the bond and currency markets have been behaving as if double-digit inflation is just around the corner.
Robert Gordon, an economist at Northwestern University, thinks that the problem is largely one of presentation rather than policy. "Short-term rates always go up in this stage of the business cycle," he said. "What's new is that the Fed is talking about it."
The Fed's idea, presumably, was to get the maximum anti-inflation bang from the minimum tightening of credit from its new show of openness. But the psychological spin apparently was reversed, with the markets assuming that the Fed's break with precedent was evidence the financial gnomes were concealing the really bad news.
Still to be seen is how the tempest over bond rates and the dollar will play out in economic growth and employment. It will not feed back to change the Government's behavior, Mr. Gordon argued, since the Fed has already gone about as far as it will go on interest rates and the White House is bound to a passive fiscal policy by the deficit reduction law.
Mr. Tobin is not-so-quietly worried, though, that what he sees as the Fed's bumbling foray against a remote threat of inflation will do great damage to businesses that need cheap capital to grow. "The markets just aren't sophisticated about economics," he laments.

HEADLINE: Stocks Fall in Computer-Driven Trading; Dow Drops 27.37

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market declined yesterday in computer-driven trading, following a sharp rise in long-term interest rates when the Government experienced more difficulty than stock or bond traders had expected in selling the new 10-year Treasury note.
Higher interest rates cut the value of current bonds, raise borrowing costs for corporations and thus hurt their stocks, as well as slow the overall rate of economic expansion. 
 Blue chips like Motorola and General Electric, widely held utilities like Ameritech, and oil companies like Exxon, all fell. High-technology stocks were especially hurt, including Microsoft and Novell. Computer disk-drive makers like Conner Peripherals and Seagate Technology fell over concern of an industry price war.
William R. Rothe, managing director for Nasdaq trading at Alex. Brown & Sons Inc., said high-technology stocks tended to rise or fall faster than the general market, and were known as "high beta" stocks. "They may be the first to go to when traders look for liquidity and want to cash out their stocks," he said.
Despite a normal volume of 277.4 million shares changing hands on the New York Stock Exchange, traders suspect that many Wall Street firms are still on the sidelines and that computer trading accounted for much of yesterday's action. Traders may be waiting for the Federal Reserve Board to raise interest rates as well as for the Government this morning to release the producer price index, a closely watched gauge of inflation.
"It was pretty quiet around here," said William Lord, vice president-trading for UBS Securities Inc. "I don't know how much of today's volume was machines and not humans, but there must have been a fair amount of machines."
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 27.37 points, to 3,629.04, and the broader Standard & Poor's 500 fell 4.52 points, to 441.49. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index, which has a heavy concentration of technology stocks, fell 8 points, to 717.
 
Decliners Outpace Advancers
 The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 2.43 points, to 244.51, while the number of declining stocks outnumbered advancing stocks by 1,550 to 672. The American Stock Exchange market value index declined 2.02 points, to 433.17.
Much of this week's stock market volatility is linked to the turmoil in the international currency markets. The dollar rose sharply Tuesday but ended a little lower in New York yesterday, despite a half of a percentage point cut in key German interest rates. The interest rate cut could make the the dollar a more attractive investment for many investors, especially if the Federal Reserve follows with another rate increase soon.
Bond traders yesterday had expected slight demand for the new 10-year Treasury notes and therefore a quite expensive average yield of 7.34 percent at the auction. But demand was even less, and the average yield was even pricier at 7.36 percent. Yield on the 30-year bond soared to 7.60 percent, up 11 basis points. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
As soon as the auction results were announced at 1:42 P.M., the stock market's high-speed computer-guided trading kicked into full force, selling hundreds of stocks. The Dow fell more than 20 points in 15 minutes, but at no time were the New York Stock Exchange's anti-program trading "circuit-breaker" rules required, because the Dow did not fall more than 50 points.
Of the 30 stocks of the Dow industrials, 20 fell, led by General Electric, which fell 1 7/8, to 93 1/8, on no discernible news, except for continuing legal troubles of Joseph Jett, the ousted bond trader at G.E.'s troubled Kidder, Peabody unit.
Of the 500 stocks of the S.& P. 500, 343 fell, led by G.E. and also Philip Morris, which fell 1 5/8, to 47 5/8, after a Wheat First Butcher & Singer analyst cut his assessment of seven tobacco stocks, including Philip Morris.
The most active stock yesterday was Perrigo, one of the most active stocks Tuesday, when management of the nonprescription pharmaceutical concern announced that fourth-quarter sales may not reach expectations. Perrigo's volume was 8.6 million shares.

HEADLINE: Review/Pop;
Streisand Opens American Tour With Optimism

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
Near the close of Barbra Streisand's frequently thrilling concert on Tuesday evening, she hit the opening notes of "Happy Days Are Here Again," the first song on the first album she recorded. In her famous 1962 interpretation, the bouncy little proclamation of good times was slowed down and interpreted as the hysterical cry of a woman who disbelieved every word she was forcing herself to sing.
This time, at the 14,000-seat USAir Arena in Landover, Md., the song was rehabilitated into an upbeat pop anthem accompanied by a slide show illustrating reasons for her optimism. Newspaper headlines with announcements like "Roe v. Wade Upheld" were interwoven with pictures of Ms. Streisand's heroes, from the Clintons to Nelson Mandela. The number was followed by Ms. Streisand's only speech of the evening, a defense of Hollywood that stressed the movie industry's importance to the economy and its sense of moral responsibility in turning out movies about the Holocaust and AIDS. 
 But music, thank goodness, not politics was the show's main order of business. And Ms. Streisand, who ended her long absence from public performance on New Year's Eve in Las Vegas, displayed a voice near the peak of its form.
It has been three decades since she made her reputation as a modern-day Fanny Brice with Judy Garland's wounded heart. Now, as then, she has simply to open her mouth, and out comes a sound that is beautiful, though edged with a whine, and that conveys a primal mixture of yearning and driving ambition. Interpretive ideas aren't what make the singing so compelling, but rather raw, needy emotion guided by a dramatic instinct that infuses everything with an operatic intensity.
But if Ms. Streisand's voice is as strong as it ever was, her perspective has changed. In evolving from an insecure teen-age diva into Hollywood royalty, she has exchanged her girlish hysteria and spontaneity for a measured regality. The hyperemotionalism remains palpable, but it is under control to the point that Ms. Streisand can look back with some affection and humor at the brash, stage-struck kook from Brooklyn she used to be.
Tuesday's concert, the first American date on a tour that will take her to Detroit, Los Angeles, San Jose, and New York (June 20, 23 and 26 at Madison Square Garden) over the next month and a half, was a lavish, rather formal retrospective in which the lighter moments had the feel of a playful therapy session.
During the first half of the show, moving about an elegant living-room set that she said was suggested by Monticello, Ms. Streisand conversed with three unseen "therapists." In one clever bit of film editing, Dr. Susan Lowenstein, the psychiatrist she portrayed in "The Prince of Tides," fielded complaints from several of the nuttier characters from her other films. The most charming interaction between stage and screen had her singing "I'll Know" with her teen-age idol, Marlon Brando, shown in a film clip from "Guys and Dolls." In the most sentimental interaction, she serenaded a series of growing-up pictures of her son, Jason Gould, with "Not While I'm Around," from "Sweeney Todd."
Musically, the concert was one long romantic symphony of ballads of varying hue, skillfully joined together and augmented with enough bright patter to keep things from dragging. A 64-piece orchestra, led by Marvin Hamlisch, accompanied her, playing handsomely enlarged versions of the original arrangements from her albums.
After a full-blown overture, Ms. Streisand made her entrance singing "As If We Never Said Goodbye," an imposing ballad from the musical "Sunset Boulevard," which established the show's semi-operatic tone. The most memorable vocal performances in the first half included a tender "Can't Help Lovin' Dat Man," which showed off Ms. Streisand's too-seldom-heard crooning voice, a soaring "He Touched Me," and a version of "The Man That Got Away" that stood beside the classic Judy Garland version in its sweep and depth of feeling. On the lighter side was "I'm Still Here," from "Follies," for which Stephen Sondheim supplied new custom-written lyrics. (Best line: "I kept my nose to spite my face.")
In the more musically forceful second act, most of the scenery disappeared, except for an overhead screen that flashed then-and-now pictures of the star. A dramatic peak was hit with a suite from the film "Yentl," which the singer belted with a ferocious conviction, at one point singing harmony with her own screen image. It was complemented by a soft, glowing "Lazy Afternoon," from the musical, "The Golden Apple." A slightly jazzy "For All We Know" and a stentorian "Somewhere" ended the show with flourishes that were grand but not overblown.
As Ms. Streisand's recent album "Back to Broadway" showed, she can be her own worst enemy by over- thinking songs, imposing rigid concepts and creating music that sounds so worked-over it becomes remote and frozen. Onstage, where retakes and retouching are impossible, the raw emotion runs free. Barbra in concert is Barbra at her best.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Barbra Streisand performing on Tuesday in Maryland. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Essay;
Nixon On 1996

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
"'94 will be a great year for non-incumbents," Richard Nixon opined a few months before his death. "People want change. Clinton asked for it; now the country is going to demand it."
But to a man who won four out of five national races, matching F.D.R.'s record, the focus had to be on the national ticket in 1996. 
 "Lamar Alexander would be an excellent President. It's early for him, though. Like Carroll Campbell or Tommy Thompson, he may be V.P."
Nixon then came up with a surprise: "In '96, we should have a woman on the ticket. It doesn't do anything for the Democrats, but would do plenty for Republicans. Not a senator, Hutchison or Kassebaum; has to be a governor. Executive experience."
He grinned at the thought of the New Jersey Governor as Vice President: "Christie Whitman would be a real sleeper on the ticket." He liked the way Governor Whitman, daughter of a Republican State Chairman, rose to a crisis: "She showed great presence during the Rollins flap."
What should she do? "Get to New Jersey's issues -- crime, welfare, drugs. Be progressive but conservative. Travel abroad to get New Jersey business; that's always a good excuse. Then come back and talk to the New York Economic Club."
To the top slot: Is Bob Dole the front-runner? "Yes, and if Dole keeps his voice and his sense of humor, he has a good shot." He thought about that and pointed to my notebook, to make sure I wrote it down: "Dole likes people, you know." I have an underlined note: Dole likes people.
"Kemp has the problem of a young star fading, but he has enthusiastic supporters and that's good. To get over the question about being heavy enough, he has to travel, make himself more of a world figure. No more Johnny-one-note on economics. He's an attractive candidate and has to win an early primary."
Nixon thought Dick Cheney, the Defense Secretary who won a war, was an homme serieux, but was "a beltway candidate"; the approval of the Washington Establishment was a negative.
Pat Buchanan, one of his former speechwriters? "Pat's a true believer. Third party, maybe." He thought Pat likely to split if the Republican Party backed away from its anti-abortion stand, as it must do to win: "On abortion," said Nixon, "the state should stay out of it. Don't subsidize and don't prohibit."
Which brought up William Weld, the conservative but pro-choice Governor of Massachusetts: "He'd win if nominated," said Nixon, perhaps thinking of Nelson Rockefeller in 1960, "but Weld would not be nominated for President at a Republican convention. It's a social thing."
James Baker he dismissed with a glare. Senator Phil Gramm: "Smarter than most, but weak on the tube." I did not ask about Dan Quayle, who had not yet begun his run, but my guess is that Nixon would advise him to forgo a '96 candidacy and make his loyalist mission the keeping of the Christian right behind a Republican centrist -- the mirror image of what centrist Nixon did for far-right Goldwater in '64.
Who's left? "If Pete Wilson survives in California in '94, he will be nominated in '96 and will be a strong candidate," Nixon, the survivor, unequivocally predicted. "He's very good on foreign and defense policy. Been everything -- Mayor, Senator, Governor. A moderate on domestic stuff, but not a mushy moderate."
Colin Powell? "Formidable. Intelligent, tough-minded, sound. But Republicans would want him for the wrong reason, because he's black. Blacks will keep voting liberal because they're poor."
A wild card? "Perot is the Democrats' secret weapon. Gore's victory in debate over Perot on Nafta was good short-term for the Democrats, bad long-term. They need Perot to stay in because two-thirds of his support are Republicans. This time, let him buy his own time, deny him debates."
Would Hillary be a campaign issue? "Leave her alone, she's effective." But Nixon recalled: "When we met, I told her about a ballplayer from Arkansas, 'Arky' Vaughan. But she never heard of him. Can you imagine? Hall of Famer, lifetime batting average .367."
I looked it up afterward; Arky Vaughan, Pittsburgh shortstop, had a lifetime average of .318. We often had to straighten out Nixon's statistics, but on political assessments he was pretty longheaded.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: Package Deal Is Offered to Lure Tourists to Big Apple

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Every New Yorker knows: avoid lines, never pay retail. But visitors stand in line at a lot of places, paying a lot more money. Acknowledging Big Apple sticker shock and the city's innate ability to intimidate, government officials and business and arts leaders have joined for the first time to offer a unified front on tourism.
Here's the deal: a package including two nights at a New York hotel with parking and breakfast, lunch at a high-priced restaurant like Lutece (sorry, no dinner), a ticket to a Broadway show, free admission to the Metropolitan Museum of Art and other major arts institutions, and a tour of New York by boat or double-decker bus. 
 All for $199.40 a person, double occupancy, tax included.
The package, which does not include a well-known bridge linking Manhattan and a borough to the east, is being announced today by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and a group of business leaders. The idea is to spur tourism, an industry worth more than $14 billion to the city, according to city officials.
The package deal, called NY 94 and available May 15 through Oct. 15, is intended as a first step in redressing what officials characterize as lackluster support for tourism. Sponsors say that cultural institutions like the Met and the Museum of Modern Art -- not to mention Broadway producers -- have never before offered tickets and admissions as part of a tourism promotion.
"This is the first time in my memory that the arts institutions and cultural organizations in the city have combined with the private sector to promote the city of New York," said Martin E. Segal, the former chairman of Lincoln Center, who organized the arts community's involvement.
Participants include 110 restaurants, 52 hotels, 49 cultural institutions and 13 retailers.
John S. Dyson, Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, said yesterday that the city's Convention and Visitors Bureau has been "asleep at the wheel." He said that the need for New York to promote itself as a destination has become more critical as the city loses some of its cultural exclusivity: New York is increasingly exporting its cultural offerings, and more and more Broadway shows are getting their starts outside the city.
"But there has been a kind of New York City hubris about tourism," Mr. Dyson said. "Our attractions are so obvious, it was thought you didn't need to sell it. But you need to sell everything more today."
One of the main selling points of the package, organizers say, is that it seeks to quell some of the confusion in a New York holiday by arranging two days of discounted activities and reservations through one toll-free phone number.
The organizing consortium, which consists of hospitality industry executives and state and city government officials, say the full-price value of the $199.40 deal would be $345.06 list price, for a saving of $145.66. There are to be four packages, rising in price to $459.40 a person. That price could include a room at the elegant Mark on the Upper East Side or at the Hilton in midtown, while the $199.40 package would offer one of seven hotels like the Ramada Milford Plaza near Times Square.
All choices depend on availability. If a restaurant or hotel is full, participants would be booked elsewhere at comparable places. Broadway producers have set aside blocks of orchestra seats for the promotion. By generating more business, hotels and restaurants are hoping to benefit from the promotion, which has a total budget of more than $3 million.
New York State has committed $2.2 million, including $1.7 million that would otherwise have been spent on national advertisements for New York City. The city will pay $125,000 to produce a guidebook, and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will donate $10,000 for general purposes.
In addition to offering the project discounted meals for $19.94 or free admissions, restaurants, hotels and cultural institutions are being asked to contribute $1 million for advertising and operations. Some $800,000 has so far been pledged, including $18,000 from cultural institutions.
 
Anyone Can Play
 An advertising campaign, to begin today, is focused on the Northeastern states and eastern Canada, partly to persuade day trippers to stay overnight, though anyone, including New Yorkers, can buy a package. Ads are being taken out in newspapers and magazines like Gourmet and People.
The city has considered such a campaign before. Officials at the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau said they had planned a similar promotion four years ago, but had to pull back when money expected from the city hotel tax was not forthcoming. As a result, efforts to promote tourism have centered on trade shows and larger groups.
"We basically have not had our act together," said Tim Zagat, a promotion organizer and publisher of the Zagat Survey of restaurants. "To get New Yorkers to even get down and talk to each other is very hard."
Companies have staged their own promotions revolving around New York with varying success. "Individual companies seldom have the clout to create enough noise to really get attention," said Jonathan Linen, vice chairman of American Express, which has contributed $250,000.
The new tourism effort grew out of the promotion effort for the 1992 Democratic National Convention, during which Broadway performers put on a free lunchtime show; restaurants offered $19.92 lunches, and a fashion show was staged in Bryant Park. The organization behind that campaign, the New York Host Committee, in effect decided to stay intact. The group expanded last year as cultural institutions became involved.
"New York is just vibrant," said Bill Fischer, owner of Fischer Travel Enterprises. "People want to be here. And the money that government commits to it is minimal compared to foreign governments."
 
Occupancy Is Up
 There is some evidence that visits to New York are picking up, as the city inches out of recession.
Hotel room occupancy started edging up last October and has increased each month since, said John A. Fox, senior vice president of PKF Consulting, which tracks the lodging industry. In March hotel occupancy was 69 percent, compared with 64 percent a year earlier.
"In general," Mr. Fox said, "we've seen a good resurgence, and I'm fairly bullish that we'll have a pretty good year."
Jonathan Tisch, president and chief executive officer of Loews Hotels, a participant, is confident there will be plenty of room to handle the hoped-for surge. "We will be able to provide additional rooms from those properties already involved, or from others who may also want to participate."
Organizers are also speaking of an even bigger promotion to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the United Nations next year. New York, Mr. Zagat says, could be pitched as the capital of the world, with each nation being honored on a separate day.
Rick Binford, senior vice president of the Convention and Visitors Bureau, foresees that his agency will work in similar directions as NY 94. "Everybody believes a strong, sustained, extended tourism effort is healthy for us," he said.
 
 
If You Go. . .
 NY 94, a package deal for New York sponsored by a consortium of businesses and cultural institutions, is offered May 15 to Oct. 15.
 
What You Get: Two nights, parking, breakfast, lunch at "one of New York's top restaurants"; admission to a Broadway or Off Broadway show, opera, dance, concert or other live performance; shopping assistance at a major retail store; a pass to major museums and attractions; a bus tour or boat tour.
 
What You Pay: $199.40, $279.40, $369.40 or $459.40.
 
For Brochure: (800) 9-NY-CITY.
 
To Reserve: (800) 554-8687.
 
Advice: Book early to insure choice of shows.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 13, 1994, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article and a chart yesterday about a new tourism promotion for New York City misstated the availability dates for a two-night package deal. It will be available Memorial Day to Labor Day (May 30 to Sept. 5), not May 15 to Oct. 15.

HEADLINE: The Making of a Fiasco

BYLINE: By Thomas Carothers; Thomas Carothers, senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, is author of "In the Name of Democracy: U.S. Policy Toward Latin America in the Reagan Years."

 BODY:
WASHINGTON
Scrambling to revive its moribund Haiti policy, the Clinton Administration has decided to rule out a compromise with the country's military leaders and to broaden economic sanctions. The one certain effect of this new policy will be to greatly increase the possibility of U.S. military intervention.
Faced with the tightened embargo, which will go into effect next week, Haiti's rulers will not just throw up their hands and go. They will engage in political maneuvering, like yesterday's installation of the 80-year-old Supreme Court Justice Emile Jonassaint as "provisional president." And they will continue their sickening game of chicken with the United States -- clinging to power as the suffering in Haiti goes from terrible to truly horrifying, betting that the U.S. will lose its stomach for the embargo before it forces them out. 
 As the stalemate intensifies, the choices facing the Clinton Administration will be increasingly stark and agonizing: to admit defeat and call for a lifting of the embargo, to hold tight and bear responsibility for enormous suffering in Haiti with an uncertain prospect of eventual "victory," or to invade. Faced with these choices, the Administration may well go the military route. U.S. Presidents can tolerate only so much defiance from tinpot strongmen before they send in the marines, as George Bush did in Panama in 1989.
Haiti has been a source of tremendous frustration for the Clinton Administration. That frustration inevitably combines with the aggravations in Bosnia, Somalia, North Korea and elsewhere to create a besieged mentality in which some unexpected spark -- a daytime massacre of dozens of Haitians or the killing of a group of foreign relief workers -- could push the President to order an invasion.
Military intervention in Haiti may look like a plausible way out of a perplexing policy dilemma. But a U.S. invasion -- and it would be a U.S. invasion, even if Secretary of State Warren Christopher proves successful in his recent efforts to persuade Latin governments to provide multilateral support afterward -- would be a serious mistake.
The political problem in Haiti is not simply that the military refuses to allow the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the country's first freely elected President, to return. It is that Haitian society is profoundly polarized between an entrenched business and military elite, some of whom are violently anti-democratic and some of whom are not, and the great mass of ordinary Haitians, who deeply hate the elite and in 1990 chose a leader who promised a fundamental redistribution of power.
A U.S. invasion to "restore democracy" in Haiti, therefore, could not simply aim to pacify the country. It would have to shatter the hold of the violent, anti-democratic members of the elite by eradicating the web of thuggish armed groups that have asserted control across the country. It would then have to be followed by a long-term occupation to check the extremists on both sides and slowly forge a moderate consensus, which has never existed in Haiti. And it would have to be complemented by an extensive and costly long-range assistance program.
These tasks are enormous. Yet if we invade Haiti we will almost certainly do so trying to minimize our mission. Mr. Clinton could persuade the extremely reluctant Joint Chiefs of Staff to move only by assuring them that it will be a short-term pacification action. And Americans are likely to support an invasion only if it is short and painless. Any military action would thus be designed as much to meet constraints at home as to confront the actual challenges in Haiti. Its underlying purpose would be to solve the public relations problem that Haiti has become for the Administration.
Even if the U.S. does invade with a commitment to overseeing a long-term restructuring of Haitian society, it is unclear that we could succeed. We can scarcely point to a track record of American invasions' leading to the transformation of highly underdeveloped countries with few democratic traditions into stable, functioning democracies. Foreign occupations rapidly wear on both the occupiers and the occupied. We might be hailed by Haitians on our way into Port-au-Prince, but we would soon be taking blame for the country's continuing troubles and looking for a way out.
Armed intervention poses problems of principle as well as practice. At root, we have no interest at stake in Haiti so compelling as to warrant unilateral military action. Some people argue that the U.S. should promote democracy abroad by force. But a U.S. invasion of Haiti would not be widely seen as upholding such a principle, and it would not convince the world that the United States would act decisively when elected leaders in other countries were overthrown.
We hardly blinked at the forcible negation of the elections in Algeria and the ouster of an elected leader in the former Soviet republic of Georgia in recent years. In this hemisphere, few Latin Americans would be persuaded that we would invade other countries, say Venezuela or Brazil, in response to a coup. Instead, the lesson the world would extract from an invasion would be that if a U.S. President is humiliated long enough by strongmen in a relatively powerless country with a history of American involvement in its internal affairs, he will send in the marines. This would not be an especially impressive lesson.
American military intervention in Haiti would violate international law, and would thereby contradict our efforts since the end of the cold war to promote an international order based on heightened respect for the law. Within the hemisphere it would set back our goal of moving beyond unilateralism and developing a regional approach to the promotion of human rights and democracy.
Finally, an invasion would set a dangerous example for other regions where our strategic interests are greater. Do we want to send a signal to Russia, for example, that it is acceptable for dominant regional powers to use force to solve their neighbors' internal political problems?
All of our options in Haiti are unsatisfying. Armed intervention is among the worst. The Clinton Administration must instead consider alternatives that don't depend on the immediate return of President Aristide, up to now a central part of U.S. policy. An option that should be considered is the formation of a multiparty interim government, fully backed by the legitimately elected members of the Haitian Parliament. This would be part of a U.N.-sanctioned negotiated accord that would permit a substantial U.N. force to oversee next year's elections and stay in place afterward to protect the results.
The paradox of Haiti policy is that the longer we hold out for the best of all possible worlds, the more likely we are to end up with the worst.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Senate Approves Bill To Jail 3-Time Criminals for Life

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 12

 BODY:
The State Senate today unanimously approved legislation that would require mandatory life imprisonment for a person convicted of violent crimes on three or more occasions.
The vote of 35 to 0 put New Jersey on the path toward enacting one of the nation's toughest versions of the "three strikes" concept. If this bill or one similar to it becomes law, as expected, a person convicted on three occasions of certain violent crimes in any jurisdiction would be sentenced to a mandatory term of life imprisonment with no eligibility for parole. The crimes the bill covers are murder, manslaughter, aggravated assault, kidnapping, sexual assault, robbery and possession of a firearm, explosive or destructive device for an unlawful purpose. 
 The bill already has the support of more than half the members of the Assembly, and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman campaigned in favor of such legislation, although she said today that she wanted to make sure the law applied only to the most violent crimes.
To face sentencing under the new law, criminals would have to commit three violent offenses after the date that the Governor signs it.
One of the few reservations expressed before today's vote concerned how cash-strapped governments will cover the cost of anticipated increases in already booming prison populations. But Senator Louis F. Kosco, the sponsor of the three strikes bill, a Republican from Paramus, said the costs were irrelevant.
"Each time they go through the revolving door, repeat offenders cost the state a great deal in legal and parole expenses," he said. "And we must take into account the economic and social costs society incurs with each new offense perpetrated by repeat offenders."
The New Jersey prison system is already operating at 135 percent of capacity, with about 25,000 inmates, said Patricia Mulcahy, a spokeswoman for the State Department of Corrections. The department's budget for the current fiscal year is $663 million, and the department has requested $730 million for the fiscal year beginning July 1.
It currently costs an average of $26,000 a year to house a state prison inmate in New Jersey.
Ms. Mulcahy said that 54 percent of the state's inmates are violent felons. Backers of the tougher sentencing statute said that current recidivism rates show that about 150 inmates a year are returned to prison in New Jersey after committing a third or more violent offense and they serve average sentences of 5 to 10 years.
The average age of the habitual criminal is 29, with a life expectancy of 69, meaning an average prison stay of 40 years for criminals convicted under a three strikes law.
Under current New Jersey law, inmates with multiple violent offenses generally serve a minimum of five years before being eligible for parole. But the majority of those inmates do not become eligible for parole for 10 years, correction officials said.
Based on the assumption that most repeat violent criminals already spend at least a decade behind bars, the Department of Corrections estimated that the financial impact of the three strikes bill would not begin to be felt until the 11th year.
 
Additional Costs
 The nonpartisan Office of Legislative Services said that the additional costs would hit the state in the sixth year, since some inmates are paroled after only five years.
"For every inmate who is not paroled as a result of this bill, an additional $80,000 in construction costs and $1 million in operating costs would be incurred over the lifetime of that inmate," the Office of Legislative Services said in a fiscal impact statement it released today.
That accounting breaks down to $25,000 per year per inmate for operating costs or an additional $3.75 million each year for 30 years, or $1.7 billion, assuming an increase of 150 inmates each year.
In a separate action, the Senate voted to allow greater public access to criminal records of juveniles. The legislation, proposed by Governor Whitman, was prompted by several recent cases involving suspects with juvenile crime records that were, by law, kept secret from law-enforcement and school officials.
Before either bill passed by the Senate today becomes law, the Assembly must give its approval and Governor Whitman must sign the legislation. But politics and the mood of New Jersey residents against crime make it highly unlikely that anything will prevent the bills from eventually becoming law.
The Assembly Speaker, Chuck Haytaian, is a candidate for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate, and a tough stance on crime is one of the major planks in his platform.
 
Cautious Support
 As early as last year, in the midst of a gubernatorial race, Mrs. Whitman was calling for three strikes legislation. But she gave only cautious support to the Senate's version of the legislation.
"I support and always have supported what I call three strikes and you are in," the Governor said. "My concern is the scope of this particular legislation. We are looking at it to insure it is tight enough and that we go after the appropriate offenses to insure that those who are the most egregious offenders are the ones."
Legislators in Connecticut in the last three weeks passed a bill giving prosecutors the discretion to seek life sentences against repeat violent criminals, rejecting the opportunity to make such sentencing mandatory. The bill was among about 250 pieces of legislation passed in the closing days of the session, and Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has not yet considered the bill or made his position on the issue public, his spokesman, Doug Quat, said today.
In New York, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has pushed for legislation to imprison third-time violent felons for life without parole. But it appears there is little chance of New York joining the rush toward such legislation since the Speaker of the State Assembly, Sheldon Silver, opposes the idea.

HEADLINE: In Alaska, a Yearning For a New Ice Curtain

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SOLDOTNA, Alaska

 BODY:
The Russian Far East and Alaska share the midnight sun, an affinity for fish and a common disdain for central governments that are more than 5,000 miles and many time zones away.
But with post-cold war business ventures floundering and some cultural exchanges turning into a horror movie ("The Guest Who Wouldn't Leave"), people on both sides of the Bering Sea are now wondering if it was easier to like each other when their governments hated each other. 
"People used to say, 'Gee, they look just like us, we share the same kind of environment, and wouldn't it be great if they got rid of Communism,' " said Rick Matiya, an Alaskan school administrator, who is fluent in Russian. "Now, you hear people say, 'They stink, they drink too much and they all want to buy guns.' Well, you can say the same thing about Alaskans."
Six years ago, when the Ice Curtain between Russia and Alaska came down, Mr. Matiya led an exchange between his Alaskan town of Soldotna and the Russian city of Magadan, a mining and industrial center on the northern shore of the Sea of Okhotsk. This year, his latest effort in diplomacy was telling a Russian guest that he had overstayed his welcome and would have to leave.
 
Guests Who Like to Linger
 "The problem is, you invite them for two weeks and they want to stay six months," Mr. Matiya said. "We tend to be workaholics. You go over there and life stops when you walk through their door."
Soldotna (pronounced sole-DOT-nuh), a three-hour drive southwest of Anchorage on the Kenai Peninsula, was one of the first communities in Alaska to welcome Russians into its homes and schools. To outsiders, it is known as a place where even the nicer hotels warn against bringing fish into the room at night.
But to people who have several generations of northern latitudes in their blood, the Kenai is the cradle of Russian America. In 1791, the Russians established their first settlement on the mainland of Alaska when they landed about 10 miles west of Soldotna and built a fort on Cook Inlet. And it is on the Kenai that Nikolaevsk, a new village of Russian exiles, was started in 1968.
Despite these links to the country across the Bering Sea, some Russians feel less than welcome on the Kenai and elsewhere in Alaska. The post-cold war glow has faded, replaced by a tenuous relationship, new stereotypes about drunks and leeches, and a wariness about business ventures.
 
'We All Have Much to Learn'
 "When I first came here, I felt myself to be a celebrity, all the time with people wanting to talk, to hug, to invite me to dinner," said Natasha Kokavrov, who came to Alaska three years ago and has now set up a guest house and a consulting business catering to Russians. "People are still very nice, but we all have much to learn. Russians too often say things like, 'Shut up, you jerk' in public."
More than any other state, Alaska has been trying to build business and cultural bridges to Russia, which can be seen on a clear day from the tip of the Seward Peninsula. Aeroflot and Alaska Airlines now fly between the countries. And native people, mostly Eskimos, can travel back and forth within a special zone without visas.
But even the biggest boosters of northern brotherhood are having some doubts now. They compare the relationship between Russians and Alaskans to marriage: after a nice honeymoon, things are getting rocky.
"There was this love-at-first-sight relationship," said Jim Stimpfle, a Nome realtor who has had Russian visitors to his house. "We welcomed them and their rubles at face value. Now, there isn't a merchant in town who will take rubles anymore. And the only Russians flying over here are bureaucrats and members of the Russian Mafia."
 
When Hosts Confront Guests
 The Federal authorities in Alaska, while reluctant to give out details, say they are investigating reports of a black market trade in walrus ivory and of drug and prostitution rings run by Russian-organized criminals who have come to Alaska.
But more commonly, the authorities have been called to Alaskan homes as mediators in problems where a Russian guest will not leave. "I get called out all the time on that; you've got a host family who can't tolerate their Russian guest anymore," said Kermit Liebel, an investigator with the Immigration and Naturalization Service in Anchorage.
Betty Obendorf, a Soldotna resident, told of having a boy as a guest who was supposed to stay for a month. "But he stayed for seven weeks, and I finally had to force him to leave," she said. Ms. Obendorf, who has had many Russian guests and has been a guest in Magadan, blames cultural stereotypes for the problems.
"When they see our homes, they think we are all rich Americans," Ms. Obendorf said. "I was so open because I was caught up in the emotion of it all. I was taught to hate these people because they had atomic bombs aimed at us. Now, some Russians are taking advantage of us. But some Alaskans are taking advantage of them as well."
 
High Expectations Blamed
 Mr. Matiya, the school administrator, said only a handful of the thousands of Russians who have come to Alaska since the end of the cold war -- and an equally small percentage of the Alaskans who have gone to Russia -- have created tension.
"I think part of the disappointment comes from this expectation that Alaskans are supposed to understand Russians better than anyone else in America," he said.
Dr. Ted Mala, a doctor in Anchorage of Russian-Eskimo heritage who helped initiate exchanges between the two countries, said the Soviet culture had left a legacy of dependence. "Russian-Soviet culture has taught them to be anything but independent," he said, "so when they come here they expect everyone to do everything for them."
While personal contacts have sometimes soured, formal tie-building efforts continue, with mixed results. The University of Alaska at Anchorage has become a center for Russian students. With grants from the United States Agency for International Development, the school brings budding Russian entrepreneurs to Anchorage for classes on how to run a business. They also send Alaskans to Russia for the same purpose.
 
Boon for Warehouse Stores
 "We know this is not going to restructure their economy," said Charles Neff, director of the university's American Russian Center. "But these are the pioneers. We have pretty much kept the scam artists out."
Perhaps the biggest beneficiary of the open borders has been the giant warehouse stores. When the Aeroflot flight from Magadan lands at Anchorage each Wednesday, there is a mad dash of cabs from the airport to Costco, the largest of the warehouse stores, where Gummi Bears are sold by the barrel.
"The only places they want to see are Costco and the Alaska Bush Company," a strip club, said Sheldon Harris, Costco's Russian coordinator.
In that sense, they may be little different from rural Alaskans who visit the city for the same reasons.
 
Looking at Other Shoes
 Here in Soldotna, a town of 4,000 people famous for its king salmon, some Russians have learned to laugh at things being said about their countrymen in Alaska.
"We all gasped when we first came here," said Grigorii Vaisenberg, who teaches Russian at Soldotna High School and has been in Alaska for three years on an extended work visa. "You know the old Russian comedian's line about our shoes being the best shoes in the world until we see other shoes. At first it was like that for most of us here. But now it's changing."
Mr. Vaisenberg, who lives in an apartment here with with his wife and two children, says he feels stuck between two cultures -- Russian and Alaskan. But last winter he started leaning one way.
"I hit a moose with my car," he said. "So now I am an Alaskan."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Russians were welcomed in Alaska when the so-called Ice Curtain came down six years go, but familiarity has bred, if not contempt, at least uneasiness in some quarters. Many Russian students, however, still cross the Bering Sea to attend business classes at the University of Alaska. (Anne Raup for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Interest Rates Don't Faze Companies

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 12

 BODY:
Who's afraid of the Federal Reserve? Not the chief executives of the nation's biggest companies -- at least not yet.
The nation's central bank has increased short-term interest rates three times this year and is expected to raise them again. But business leaders gathered here today for a semiannual conference with top Administration officials expressed no concerns. 
 A group of 16 big companies went so far as to declare that not one of them had experienced any noticeable loss of sales or orders thus far because of the higher rates and that none of them anticipated an appreciable loss of business during the rest of the year.
Lawrence A. Bossidy, the chairman and chief executive of Allied Signal Inc., a maker of automotive and automobile parts, was blithely unworried. "On my own company, it hasn't had any impact yet," he said.
Robert E. Allen, the chairman and chief executive of AT&T, was equally unconcerned. "I don't think the current move is going to make any significant difference."
 
 
'Euphoric State'
 And John F. Welch Jr., the chairman and chief executive of the General Electric Company, was downright effusive. "A lot of us were here six months ago and never would have predicted the euphoric state we're in today," he said.
Similar sentiments from business leaders have led the Fed to raise interest rates even higher in the past. But the mood here today at the conference of the Business Council was too cheery for anyone to fret about interest rates.
The chief executives basically supported the Fed's moves because they said they thought the increases would help control inflation and not hurt their sales. They said consumer confidence, which is high now, was as important -- or more important -- than the modest interest rate increases so far.
The chief economists from 16 of the 100 companies represented here forecast in a report that the United States economy would grow strongly this year, despite some slowing in the second half. The optimistic forecast, seemingly at odds with Government statistics released today, reflected the extent to which the recent economic expansion has helped blue-chip companies.
 
 
Strong Demand
 Demand for goods and services is so strong that companies have new freedom to raise prices, although some are not doing so for fear of damaging relations with long-term customers, according to the report. None of the 16 companies that drafted today's report said they had found any drop in sales or orders from the recent increases in interest rates, "and none thought that current levels of interest rates were high enough to affect business appreciably," the report said.
The report predicted that the Fed would push overnight interest rates up to 4.3 percent by the end of the year. But Dennis Weatherstone, the chairman and chief executive of J. P. Morgan & Company, said big companies did not expect such an increase to harm their sales.
The Fed's interest rate policy committee is scheduled to meet on Tuesday, and economists and former Federal Reserve governors have been predicting that it will raise short-term interest rates again.
The chief economists predicted that inflation in consumer prices would rise from 2.7 percent last year to 2.9 percent this year and 3.3 percent in 1995, and would peak in the current business cycle at up to 4.5 percent.
Top economists at the 16 big companies, which also included Ford Motor, Caterpillar and Bethlehem Steel, prepared today's estimate.
Chief executives here foresaw a gradual pickup in inflation, as some factories begin operating flat out and raise prices. Edgar S. Woolard Jr., the chairman and chief executive of Du Pont, said that some of his factories were operating at full capacity and that prices of some products were rising after three years of decline.
None of the companies involved in the 16-company report, and none of the 11 chief executives who addressed this evening's news conference, were active in the housing industry, which has begun to complain that higher interest rates will discourage Americans from buying new homes.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and Defense Secretary William J. Perry are scheduled to address the group on Friday, while Robert E. Rubin, the head of the President's National Economic Council, is scheduled to speak on Saturday.

HEADLINE: France Says It Won't Support Military Intervention in Haiti

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
The French Foreign Minister said today that France would be willing to take part in a United Nations force to keep watch in Haiti after democracy is restored, but would "certainly not" join an intervention intended to overthrow the military government.
Alain Juppe, who met with President Clinton at the White House, said, "We aren't going to play the conquerors all over the world." His Government has already contributed more troops to United Nations peacekeeping operations in Bosnia than any other country. 
 Instead, the Foreign Minister made plain France's view that the United States and its partners should rely, at least until the fall, on the strict new economic sanctions that take effect on May 21 to compel Haiti's military leaders to step down.
Mr. Clinton has said that he would consider using American force to overthrow Haiti's military leaders if the sanctions alone failed to do so. And in a television interview this morning, Anthony Lake, the national security adviser, said the United States would "preferably" be joined by troops from other nations in any such operation.
 
Haiti's 'Four Friends'
 Along with Canada, Venezuela and the United States, France has been among the so-called Four Friends who have played a central role in seeking to restore Father Aristide.
While making clear today that French soldiers would not join in an American military intervention, Mr. Juppe would not say whether his Government would approve of such an operation if it were ordered. But the Foreign Minister did say that the United States and others should wait "four months to allow the sanctions system to work," a time limit that suggests considerably more patience than aides to Mr. Clinton are willing to show. They have mentioned one month as a reasonable period to determine if tightened sanctions would drive the military leaders from power.
A senior Administration official said today that the United States had "absolutely not" committed itself to the four-month waiting period, adding, "This is a matter that is being viewed with some urgency."
A day after a rump group of parliamentarians in Haiti installed a provisional president, Emil Jonassaint, who is backed by the military, Mr. Juppe made clear that his Government remained committed to the return of Mr. Aristide. And his pledge of France's willingness to join in a United Nations force to help retrain the military in Haiti after its leaders step down represented a small victory for the Clinton Administration, which has been seeking ways to demonstrate that other countries are looking ahead to the ouster of the army.
 
An Expanded Mission
 The kind of United Nations operation that Mr. Juppe said France would participate in would be a revised and expanded version of the mission that was aborted last fall.
In weighing that approach again, White House officials have said a similar United Nations mission would not be dispatched until Haiti's leaders step down or are forced from power, a task that could require thousands of American soldiers.
While expressing willingness to take part in a renewed operation, Mr. Juppe used sarcasm today to express his criticism of the American decision to abandon the previous mission. "Unfortunately," he told reporters at a breakfast meeting, "the ship that was carrying the force did a U-turn because there were some people who were shouting rude remarks on the key side, on the wharfs."

HEADLINE: Auto Insurers Say Florio Aides Hid State Deficit

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 12

 BODY:
Lawyers for the insurance industry charged today that the Florio administration knew that the state-run auto insurance pool it had created was running at a deficit from its inception, but hid that reality from the public for political reasons.
That accusation, documented in a lawsuit by insurance companies against the state, emerged as the insurance industry and the Whitman administration appeared close to an agreement to pay off the $1.3 billion debt of the insurance pool, known as the Market Transition Facility. 
 That arrangement, which sold insurance only from Oct. 1, 1990 until Sept. 30, 1992, was created to succeed the deficit-ridden Joint Underwriting Association, an earlier state-run insurance system set up to hold down costs for drivers unable to buy insurance on the open market. At one point 53 percent of the drivers in New Jersey were relegated to the joint underwriting pool.
The Joint Underwriting Association was declared bankrupt three years ago, chiefly because of lax monitoring of claims by the private companies, which were paid to administer the pool but did not bear the costs. The state's Insurance Department has been assessing insurance companies a surcharge to pay off its debt.
Gov. Jim Florio was father to the transition pool. On the way to his landslide election victory in 1989, Mr. Florio promised to scrap the troubled and unpopular joint underwriting system and the $222 surcharge that all car owners were dunned to help finance it. He made good on his promise and New Jersey drivers saw their rates drop to $825 from $1,050, on average.
The new arrangement simply charged the old rates without the surcharges, a system that the companies strenuously but unsuccessfully protested as economic folly. They filed the current lawsuit to block the state from forcing them to pay $217 million on top of what they have already paid to settle the $1.3 billion debt. The Whitman administration appears ready to pay off about $700 million of that sum by issuing bonds if the industry will pay the rest.
According to briefs filed in court today, the Florio administration ignored warnings from its own experts that it had to increase customers' fees by 63 percent to keep the pool solvent. At a meeting on May 31, 1990, four months before the new pool had issued a single policy, Jasper J. Jackson, the deputy Insurance Commissioner, told the pool's advisory board that adjusting the rates to make the arrangement actuarially sound was "probably not possible politically," according to documents filed with the industry brief.
Samuel F. Fortunato, Mr. Florio's Insurance Commissioner, had said he intended to run the transition pool to break even, but the insurance companies argue that he rejected repeated calls by his own advisers for an immediate rise in auto insurance rates.
The Insurance Department documents show that in November 1990 two actuarial consultants, Milliman & Robertson Inc., which was hired by the department, and William M. Mercer Inc., which was engaged by the market transition pool's actuarial committee, independently concluded that rates should be increased immediately by at least 60 percent. Both companies predicted a deficit of more than $1 billion unless the "grossly inadequate" rates charged by the pool were increased.
 
State's Own Estimates
 A month later the actuarial committee again warned the Commissioner that a rate increase was "both urgent and long overdue." In January 1991, the Mercer company advised the pool of a projected first-year deficit of $396 million and a 15-month deficit of $509 million. The deficit was growing about $33 million a month, the report stated.
About this time the New Jersey Manufacturers Insurance Company released its own projections, showing the same $1 billion deficit as the department's own actuaries in their as-yet undisclosed reports.
A spokesman for the Insurance Department at that time, however, called the insurance company's projections "complete bunk," and added that department officials "absolutely refute that there's a deficit already."
The transition pool kept running up a deficit until December, when the department issued a "cash call" to auto insurers, requiring them to pay $217 million to let the pool continue paying claims and keep it afloat. The call came after Mr. Florio was defeated in his bid for re-election by Christine Todd Whitman.
The insurance companies went to court and won approval to keep the money in an escrow account instead of turning it over to the state until its challenge to the cash call is resolved. Mrs. Whitman was forced in March to declare a freeze on paying claims until the case is settled.
Marc Buro, the spokesman for the current Insurance Commissioner, Drew Karpinski, said the Commissioner would not comment on industry claims that Mr. Fortunato intentionally allowed the deficit to grow.
 
Democrat Doubts Motives
 William J. Pascrell Jr., Democrat of Paterson and the State Assembly's deputy minority leader, said today that he was worried that the Whitman administration's bonding plan was just part of a long-term strategy "to saddle everyone but the insurance companies with the M.T.F. debt."
Mr. Pascrell said the taxpayers could end up paying for most of the bonds, which could end up costing $2 billion when all the interest is paid.
But John K. Tiene, the spokesman for the New Jersey Insurance News Service, an industry group, said the bonds would be paid by surcharges on car owners with bad driving records. He said the insurance companies had already contributed $240 million toward the debt, and that when the $217 million in escrow is released, probably within a month, the industry will have lived up to its end of the bargain.
While the insurance agreement between the administration and the industry was being studied, more than 100 insurance brokers and agents staged a demonstration on the steps of the State House today to protest what they said was the refusal by some insurance companies to write car insurance for urban residents.
Murray Weber, president of the Insurance Brokers Association of New Jersey, said many agents feared that they would be dismissed in the coming year because of the practice.
But Mr. Tiene said that many insurance writers had been discharged for mismanaging customers' fees and collecting illegal service charges, and that drivers in urban areas were not being turned away.

HEADLINE: Nuclear Agency to Send a New Inspection Team to North Korea

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 12

 BODY:
The International Atomic Energy Agency said today that it will send a team of inspectors to North Korea this weekend in what appears to be a last-minute attempt to avoid imposing United Nations sanctions, Asian and American officials said.
The loose arrangement will permit the inspectors to finish most of the testing and sampling in North Korea's nuclear reprocessing center that they were prevented from carrying out in March. North Korea has also been warned that its hopes of diplomatic talks will disappear unless it freezes any action to remove spent fuel from its nuclear reactor. That fuel, once converted to weapons-grade plutonium, would give the North enough material for four or five nuclear weapons. 
 As in the past, the arrangement was reached in last-minute brinkmanship, amid threats of sanctions. But both the United States and South Korea have backed down in recent weeks on details of their demands, in an effort to create an atmosphere that could lead to long-delayed, high-level talks at which the United States planned to offer incentives for the North to give up its weapons project.
"There is no real deal, so it is a bit risky," said a senior South Korean official closely involved in the talks. "But our main objective is to keep the replacement of the fuel from happening, to keep new material out of their hands. I am not optimistic, but I haven't given up hope."
Because they have been burned so many times, American and South Korean officials stressed that they were far from declaring that the long-brewing crisis has eased. In the past, when the Government of Kim Il Sung reached similar agreements, inspectors ran into obstacles once they arrived at the complex at Yongbyon, near North Korea's capital. Just a week ago, the Administration's top official handling the dispute, Robert L. Gallucci, suggested that the policy may have hit a dead end, and expressed pessimism over whether a diplomatic solution could be reached.
North Korean officials have said publicly in recent days that no spent fuel rods have been removed. So far, however, they have adamantly refused demands from the I.A.E.A. to take samples from the rods.
The sample process would solve a mystery: Has North Korea secretly removed some fuel rods, obtaining a raw source of plutonium that might already have been converted into weapons. The Central Intelligence Agency has said that North Korea may possess one or two bombs.
Administration officials and their South Korean counterparts have said that they expect the next few weeks to be the critical test of whether North Korea is willing to give up its nuclear project for the right price by putting its new harvest of fuel rods under strict I.A.E.A. control.
"The whole idea is to test the proposition that the North Koreans are willing to deal," Mr. Gallucci said last week. If the current inspection fails, the Administration is likely to move toward sanctions.
South Korea has been veering from sharply-worded warnings to optimism. Its president, Kim Young Sam, told a group of retired military officers today that "I have confidence that North Korea's nuclear weapons development should be stopped and can be stopped."
Such assistance would require an agreement for much broader I.A.E.A. access, including permission to inspect two suspected nuclear waste sites. It was the effort to see those sites that touched off the standoff.
I.A.E.A. officials acknowledge that one reason they are visiting the North with only a vague agreement is to get another look at two vital sites: The reprocessing center and the reactor. If seals placed on equipment at either site have been broken since the failed March inspection, it would indicate that the weapons program is moving along fairly quickly. Moreover, in the course of replacing security cameras and film in the reactor, inspectors are likely to see whether the unloading of the fuel rods has actually begun.

HEADLINE: At the Bar;
'Come and get me': A Government lawyer takes up a sword -- er, pen -- against his employer.

BYLINE: By Linda Greenhouse 

DATELINE: BETHESDA, Md.

 BODY:
In the annals of American civil disobedience, simply receiving payment for writing an op-ed article sounds a bit tame. And Peter G. Crane, a soft-spoken lawyer for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission who holds a high security clearance and spends his spare time researching the final decades of czarist Russia, appears a most unlikely candidate even to think about defying the law.
But when Mr. Crane accepted a $150 payment from The Washington Post for an article entitled "Arrest Me, Officer, I'm Writing," he put himself in deliberate violation of a Federal law that prohibits Government employees from receiving pay for any "speech, article or appearance," whether or not connected in any way to their Government work. 
 Unless the Supreme Court finds the law unconstitutional in a case it accepted for review a few weeks ago, Mr. Crane's gentle act of defiance could cost him a $10,000 civil fine and possible suspension or dismissal from his job.
His 1991 article criticized the law and ended with an invitation to Government enforcers to "come and get me." They did. The next morning, two investigators from the inspector general's office at the Nuclear Regulatory Commission appeared at his door, advising him that for his own good he should ask The Post not to pay him, since the violation was not in the writing but in the payment. Mr. Crane replied that he was set in his course, and when The Post's check arrived he took it to the inspector general's office and endorsed it in the investigators' presence. He then donated the money to CARE.
Two more op-ed articles by Mr. Crane followed. One was another critique of the law entitled "Let My People Write"; the most recent, in March, was an essay on the 40th anniversary of the American hydrogen bomb test that vaporized two of the Bikini Islands and brought radiation-related disease to the surrounding Marshall chain. Mr. Crane spent a recent year in the Marshall Islands as a member of the Nuclear Claims Tribunal there.
The Post paid $200 for each of those articles. The Justice Department has brought an enforcement proceeding, which is on hold until the Court rules sometime next year on whether the law violates the First Amendment.
"It hadn't occurred to me to write for money -- and I probably never would have, had it not been for this nonsensical law," Mr. Crane said the other day at his home here in Bethesda, where his study, a converted porch, is crammed with the fruits of his research into the late Romanov period.
The law, a 1989 amendment to the Ethics in Government Act, was the product of one of those spasms of sanctimony that sweep periodically over Washington. Congress, eager for a pay raise and at the same time stung by scandals concerning members' outside earnings, linked a raise to the abolition of honorariums and then extended the honorarium ban -- minus the raise -- to the entire Federal civil service.
The law's passage coincided with Mr. Crane's deepening interest in Russian history, sparked by his desire to document for his two children some of the history of his family, German Jews who had a ringside seat on the events that swept Russia in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.
His grandmother's uncle, Adolph Rothstein, was the financial adviser to Sergei Witte, the finance minister under Czars Alexander III and Nicholas II. And Raphael Loewenfeld, Mr. Crane's great-grandfather, was Tolstoy's German translator and first biographer. Some Tolstoy material that Mr. Crane found among his grandmother's papers is of such interest that the Russian Ministry of Culture wants it for the national archives and has invited him to Moscow as an official guest. He will make the trip next month with his wife and children.
The 47-year-old Mr. Crane, who studied British history at Harvard before going on to Duke Law School, is diffident in telling his story. "I'm afraid it will sound like ancestor worship," he said. But he became so intrigued by what he was learning, particularly about an economic reform movement in the 1890's "that has tremendous parallels to what's happening in Russia today," that he decided to write some scholarly articles.
He was just about to try his hand when the new law took effect. Although the scholarly journals for which he was prepared to write do not typically pay for articles, he was so offended by the law that he joined one of several suits that groups of Federal employees were readying. Other plaintiffs include a freelance theater critic who works for the Department of Health and Human Services and a mail handler who writes and speaks about the Quaker religion.
Mr. Crane believes that if the law itself is bad, the interpretive regulations issued by the Office of Government Ethics are even worse. The regulations give examples of prohibited and permitted extracurricular activities: a Federal employee whose hobby is comedy may accept a fee "for performing a comedy routine at a dinner theater" but not for a speech that includes jokes "or otherwise amuses his audience."
To Mr. Crane, examples like this not only underscore the tortured distinctions that he believes the Government is now making in policing its employees' ethics but also raise the specter of Federal monitors sitting in the back row counting jokes to decide whether a performance is a comedy routine or simply a funny speech.
The legal challenges have been successful so far: both a Federal district court and the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit have declared the law unconstitutional. The courts ruled that the across-the-board ban on compensation was so unjustifiably broad as to burden the free-speech rights of even those employees whose extracurricular writing might relate to their jobs and so could properly be restricted.
After some internal hand-wringing, the Clinton Administration took an appeal to the Supreme Court. The case, now called U.S. v. National Treasury Employees Union, will be argued in the fall.
Mr. Crane, meanwhile, has submitted one article to a history journal and is working on other projects, including a proposal for a book about the experience of four Berlin classmates, all 15-year-old girls, who fled the Nazis in 1933 and found refuge in four different countries. One was his mother.
A Government lawyer since 1975, Mr. Crane appears a bit baffled by his new status as Government adversary. "I see myself not as a crusader for the First Amendment," he said, "but as someone speaking out for basic common sense."

HEADLINE: Stocks Rise as Data Ease Inflation Fears

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
As if they had never heard the news before, stock traders bid up prices yesterday after the Government offered still more evidence that the economy was expanding moderately without worrisome inflation.
But the stock market gave up much of its gain as the session wore on. The Dow Jones industrial average, up as much as 35 points by 2 P.M., closed with a gain of 23.80 points at 3,652.84. 
 The bond market helped lift stocks, as prices rose and yields retreated from an 18-month high, lowering borrowing costs for corporations and enhancing stock values. The yield on the benchmark 30-year bond dropped to 7.56 percent, down 4 basis points. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
The release today of the April Consumer Price Index "will be a key story in terms of whether this market is going to continue to rally," said Gene J. Seagle, who heads Tactics and Technics, a technical market consultant in Weston, Conn. "If the Consumer Price Index is favorable and the market is strong and goes above 3,700, then the market is turning."
By most of the technical indicators he watches, including a bottoming out of bearish sentiment, Mr. Seagle said the stock market was due for a sustained rally in two to three weeks.
 
Rate Increases Seen
 Still, traders continued to expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates soon as an inflation-fighting measure. Rao Chalasani, chief investment strategist for Kemper Securities Inc. in Chicago, said the Fed must raise interest rates by half a percentage point for both the Federal funds rate and the discount rate.
The Fed must take that step to reach a "neutral" monetary policy, Mr. Chalasani said, one that neither encourages nor discourages economic expansion.
But both the bond and stock markets have tumbled each of the three times the Fed has raised interest rates since February. Since then, the markets have tumbled even further whenever Government or private-sector data seemed to confirm inflation.
Still, traders have tended to ignore steadily accumulating data that disproved that inflation was a threat. But yesterday traders took notice. The Labor Department offered the most convincing data yet that the economy was not building up inflationary pressures in a month that was not distorted by severe winter weather.
Wholesale inflation fell. The April Producer Price Index, a closely watched inflation gauge, posted a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent, instead of the gain of two-tenths of 1 percent expected by private economists. The "core" rate, excluding volatile food and energy prices, posted a similar increase, again half of expectations.
 
A Rally Falters
 Moreover, consumers bought less. April retail sales, another index of inflationary pressures, showed a decline of eight-tenths of 1 percent, or $183.6 billion, instead of the expected gain of two-tenths of 1 percent.
Both the bond and stock markets rallied convincingly until midafternoon, then faltered. One reason might have been a speech in Arizona by Robert Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank in San Francisco, who said the Fed had "a way to go" before declaring victory over inflation. Mr. Parry is a member of the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee, which meets next week.
The broader Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 2.26 points, to 443.75. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 2.61 points, to 719.61. The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.04 points, to 245.55, on volume of more than 270 million shares. Advancing stocks outnumbered declining stocks by 1,207 to 977. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 0.18 point, to 433.35.
Of the 30 component stocks in the Dow industrials, 20 rose, led by Philip Morris, which rose 3, to 50 1/2, on speculation that it may be close to spinning off its food or tobacco businesses.
Of the 500 stocks in the S.& P. 500, 240 rose, led by Philip Morris and Exxon, which rose 5/8, to 62, on news that it was selling its Callaway Chemical business for an undisclosed price.
The most active stock yesterday was Cisco Systems, a computer networking company, which closed unchanged at 29, in advance of the release of its third-quarter earnings. After the market closed, the company reported a rise of 82 percent in its profit, to $84.3 million, or 32 cents a share, from the comparable period a year ago.
