HEADLINE: House Votes to Raise Threshold for the 'Nanny Tax' to $1,250

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
The House voted today to simplify the "nanny tax," the Social Security laws that may have turned thousands of household employers into tax cheaters, deprived many housekeepers of their retirement benefits and embarrassed several Clinton Administration nominees.
The House voted 420 to 0 to revise the tax made famous by the case of Zoe Baird, whose failure to submit Social Security payments for her household help cost her a chance to become Attorney General. 
 The bill would also ban Social Security payments to criminally insane people in a mental institution and infuses the Social Security Disability Insurance Trust Fund with enough cash to prevent it from going broke next year.
The Senate Finance Committee has approved a similar version. The full Senate has not taken up that bill.
 
44-Year-Old Law
 Enacted in 1950, the tax on household workers has never been changed. It requires household employers to pay Social Security and Medicare taxes for workers who earn more than $50 in a quarter or $200 a year.
"Congress never intended to make tax cheats out of law-abiding households who occasionally hire a teen-ager to baby sit their children," Representative Jim Bunning, Republican of Kentucky, said in a debate on Tuesday.
The Government has estimated that three-quarters of household employers ignore the law. Ms. Baird became the first of several candidates for top jobs in the Administration who were embarrassed by disclosures that they had failed to pay the tax.
If employers do not make the payments the workers will not have Social Security benefits when they retire.
Under the House legislation, the annual threshold would be raised to $1,250 next year and indexed to inflation in future years. Employers would be allowed to file those taxes once a year, instead of quarterly.
 
Added Protection Seen
 "This simplification, coupled with the updating of the threshold, should result in a significant increase in compliance with the law, and should therefore increase the number of people protected under Social Security," said Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois and chairman of the Ways and Means Committee.
But under the higher threshold thousands of domestic workers would actually lose benefits, according to a Social Security actuary. Fewer would lose coverage under the Senate Finance Committee version, which would set the threshold at $630 next year.
In a separate provision of the House bill, the legislation would reallocate a small percentage of the Social Security payroll tax from the Retirement Trust Fund to the Disability Insurance Trust fund to keep it from running out of money next year. The amounts of payroll taxes paid by workers and their employers would not be affected.
Mr. Bunning said the transfer of money was "just a temporary solution" to the serious problems in the disability program. Record numbers of ill and injured Americans are seeking benefits and wait months for decisions on their claims. Some have died, lost their homes or received welfare while seeking Social Security.
"The administration has to take a serious look at why the disability program is in trouble, and it has to act fast," said Mr. Bunning, the senior Republican on the Social Security subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee. He criticized the agency for giving employees $32 million in bonuses last year while it was pressing Congress for extra money for the backlog of disability claims.

HEADLINE: U.S. Data Suggest A Lull in Growth, With No Inflation

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
In reports suggesting a lull in economic expansion, which could ease some concerns about future inflation, Government figures showed today that retail sales fell in April while first-time claims for unemployment benefits climbed unexpectedly and substantially during the first week of May.
At the same time, the Labor Department said inflation at the producer level was nonexistent for both April and for the latest 12 months. 
 The combined reassurance that neither the economy nor inflation is overly rapid set off a rally in the bond and stock markets early in the day. But a warning about inflation by a senior Federal Reserve official later in the day made some investors turn more cautious. Stocks retreated from their highs and the yield on the 30-year bond ended at 7.56 percent, down from 7.60 percent on Wednesday. [Page D5]
Despite today's soft figures, analysts generally agreed that the Federal Reserve would not be dissuaded from a path of gradual but steady tightening of monetary policy and that it would likely raise short-term rates next week for the fourth time since early February.
"The reasons for their raising rates are still there," said Bernard M. Markstein 3d, economist at the Meridian Bancorp in Reading, Pa. "They're moving on a plan to shift policy to where the Fed considers it to be neither stimulating the economy nor holding it back.
Another quarter-point rise to 4 percent in the overnight lending rate among banks, which is the Federal Reserve's short-term interest rate target, would bring it into the lower range of what many regard as such a neutral position.
Some analysts called for the Federal Reserve to emphasize its determination not to allow inflation to break out in the future by hoisting the Federal funds rate by a half-point and raising the discount rate charged on Federal Reserve loans to banks sharply as well. Robert T. Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, indicated this afternoon that he favored such a course.
Yet there was little in today's figures other than an exceptionally large upward revision to retail sales for March to nudge the Fed in this direction.
 
Economy Limping
 The economy, which many had been expecting to speed up in the second quarter after severe weather held it to a 2.6 percent growth pace over the winter, has clearly begun to limp.
Pent-up demand has been satisfied, various analysts suggested, and no longer is refinancing of mortgages adding to consumer spending power. Moreover, companies continue to cut back, military activity is on the wane and taxes have been raised.
"Now there's a lull," said Brian Fabbri, a New York consultant.
Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at the Chemical Bank, noted that retail sales had risen only negligibly so far this year after adjusting for inflation and predicted that second-quarter growth would probably be shy of a 2 percent pace.
"From December to April there was no growth in one-third of the economy," Mr. Kellner said, referring to retail sales.
Today's report of an eight-tenths of 1 percent decline pushed April sales down to $183.6 billion, with almost every category lower. Nondurable goods fell 1.6 percent and nondurables fell two-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department's report showed.
The revisions raised the March advance to 1.7 percent from the four-tenths of 1 percent that was first estimated and raised the February advance to 1.9 percent from 1.6 percent.
Sales by merchants selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes slumped 2.5 percent, while automotive dealers posted a 1.7 decline and those selling furniture and other home equipment saw sales fall five-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Declines in Nondurables
 Among nondurables, the declines were 1.3 percent at clothing stores, 1.1 percent at drug and proprietary stores, nine-tenths of 1 percent at restaurants and bars and two-tenths of 1 percent at food stores. The only gains were 1.2 percent for gasoline service stations, which benefited from higher prices, and a one-tenth of 1 percent gain for department stores and other general merchandisers.
By contrast, seven of the nine major categories posted gains in March, six of them by more than 1 percent. The relatively early Easter and Passover holidays were thought to have helped March results at the expense of April even though the sales figures are adjusted for seasonal, holiday and trading differences but not for price changes.
The Labor Department's report on first-time jobless claims showed a jump of 26,000 in the week ended May 7, lifting the total to 378,000. The four-week moving average climbed to 358,000 from 351,000, the highest reading since mid-February.
The one-tenth of 1 percent decline in prices received by American producers for finished goods, which matched similar performances in December and October, reflected a five-tenths of 1 percent decline for food and one-tenth of 1 percent for energy. Excluding those often erratic components, the finished goods Producer Price Index edged up one-tenth of 1 percent.
 
No Intermediate Changes
 The Labor Department's report also showed no change in prices for goods at the intermediate stage of production and a five-tenths of 1 percent decline for raw materials.
One source of upward price pressure in intermediate goods was a 6.8 percent surge for organic chemicals but this was countered by a 7.3 percent drop for softwood lumber.
In still other gauges of business activity, the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation reported that optimism remained strong among executives in the construction industry but that expectations among manufacturers eased from the record levels of mid-February.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Allied Signal to Buy Textron's Lycoming Unit

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 12

 BODY:
In a significant consolidation of the small airplane engine business, Allied Signal Inc. said today that it had agreed to buy the Lycoming Turbine Engine division of Textron Inc. for $375 million in cash.
Allied Signal, a diversified manufacturing company based in Morristown, N.J., has been seeking to expand its aerospace business, which is based in Torrance, Calif. Its plant in Phoenix makes motors for regional transport planes containing 19 to 30 seats. 
 The acquisition of Textron's Lycoming division, which makes engines for planes with 70 to 115 seats, will make Allied Signal the nation's largest manufacturer of small airplane engines, eclipsing Pratt & Whitney and Allison.
 
 
Layoffs Expected
 The deal is expected to result in layoffs at the Stratford, Conn., plant of Lycoming, which employs more than 2,000 workers, and at its plants in Greer, S.C.; Dallas, and Luton, England, which combined have about 900 workers.
Regional air transport is considered the fastest-growing segment of the airline industry. Traffic in the regional segment grew by more than 10 percent in 1993 and is expected to double by 2003 as it becomes more economical for major airlines to turn over short-haul routes to regional carriers, Allied Signal said.
"Both companies have taken dramatic steps to improve productivity and overall performance," Daniel P. Burnham, president of Allied Signal Aerospace, said in a statement. "Combining them will generate significant savings which will help create a stronger, more cost-effective organization for today's intensely competitive market."
Wall Street liked the acquisition, with industry analysts agreeing that the combined businesses would result in significant cost savings by consolidating their manufacturing, engineering and marketing activities.
 
 
Share Prices Gain
 Shares of Allied Signal closed today at $35.75, up $1.50, in trading on The New York Stock Exchange. Textron's shares finished the day at $54.75, up $1.375.
The analysts said that $375 million was a fair price to pay for the Textron division but noted that Allied Signal would also assume Lycoming's liabilities, including $70 million in pension obligations.
"This one is clearly accretive to earnings because it will improve their market position, grow the business, and improve returns," Howard A. Rubel, an analyst for Goldman, Sachs & Company, said. "Allied is putting together a bunch of high-tech businesses that are stronger merged than they were as individual entities."
Allied Signal's engine business, which had sales of $1.3 billion last year, makes turbofan engines for business jets like the Falcon and Lear, turboprop engines for business and regional aircraft, and auxiliary power units for commercial and military aircraft.
Textron's Lycoming, which generated $620 million in revenue last year, manufactures turbofan engines for regional airlines; helicopter engines for commercial, military and utility aircraft; military tank engines, and marine propulsion engines.
 
 
Tank Engines
 Lycoming's engines are used in a variety of aircraft and tanks, including the British Aerospace BAE 146 and Avro RJ regional airliners, Bell AH-1s Cobra, Boeing CH-47 Chinook, the United States Navy's LCAC hovercraft and the Army's M1 series Abrams main battle tank.
Dennis Signorovitch, a spokesman for Allied Signal Aerospace, said that the merged airplane engine businesses would have headquarters in Arizona and that the company planned to maintain Lycoming's operations in Stratford and elsewhere. But Mr. Signorovitch said the company anticipated some reduction in staffing levels. He declined to be more specific.
James. F. Hardymon, Textron's chairman and chief executive, said that selling Lycoming was part of the strategy of the company to aggressively manage its systems and components businesses. Textron, based in Providence, R.I., is a $9.1 billion conglomerate with aircraft, automotive, industrial, systems, components, finance and business segments.
Mr. Hardymon said proceeds from the sale would be used for general corporate purposes, including reducing debt, repurchasing common shares and financing acquisitions.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Up Modestly On Bond-Friendly Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Government securities moved modestly higher yesterday after an unexpected drop in April wholesale prices and consumer spending.
The weaker-than-expected data eased investor fears of rising inflation pressures. So far this week the anxious market has not been able to put together two consecutive days of a similar trading pattern, its concerns shifting over interest rate increases, a weaker dollar, a quarterly refunding by the Treasury, inflation data and the the coming Federal Open Market Committee meeting. 
 The 30-year bond rose 14/32 , to 8422/32 , for a yield of 7.56 percent, down from 7.60 percent on Wednesday.
The Atlanta Federal Reserve's index of business activity added to the market's firm tone. The April index fell to 19.4 from 37.2 in March, while the prices-paid component of the index dropped to 22.1 from 23.1. Analysts at MMS International, an economic analysis firm, said declines in production, new orders and shipments pulled the index down.
 
Rally Is Tempered
 Bonds prices initially rallied, with the yield on the 30-year bond dropping as low as 7.48 percent after the Labor Department released data showing April prices down one-tenth of a percent, compared with expectations of a two-tenths of a percent rise. Wholesale prices for the 12 months ended April fell four-tenths of a percent, the Labor Department reported, the first drop in two years in the 12-month period.
The bond gains were slowed though, by comments of Robert T. Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco. Mr. Parry said the Fed still had "a way to go" before inflation was contained. While the evidence so far shows little inflation, the Fed has to "anticipate problems and pay attention to warning signs," he added.
One trader said, "He took the wind out of the market's sails."
Maureen Allyn, the chief economist at Scudder Stevens & Clark, who has been saying all along that growth will slow in the first half of this year because of a downturn in consumer and Government spending, said yesterday's data confirmed some of those expectations. The Government reported a decline in retail sales for April.
"Underpinning that forecast is consumer spending, and unlike January through March where spending was brisk, we may be seeing some of that spending beginning to slow down," Ms. Allyn said, "simply because salaries are not keeping pace with needs and desires of consumers."
Ms. Allyn said it was difficult to worry about inflation in light of the wholesale price data, adding that she was expecting a fairly benign report on April consumer prices to be issued today.
 
Municipal Bond Demand
 In the municipal bond market, where investors have not been scared off by this week's swings in prices, demand helped tax-exempt issues outperform Treasury securities.
Issuers sold $760 million in debt, including the week's largest sale, a $400 million offering of revenue bonds by the New Jersey Transportation Trust Fund Authority, which was sold through competitive bidding.
The issue, awarded to First Fidelity Securities Group, was reoffered to the public at a price to yield from 3.75 percent in 1995 to 6.10 percent in 2013 and 2014. And because the bonds are insured, by the Ambac Indemnity Corporation, they are rated triple-A by Moody's, Standard & Poor's and Fitch.
The City of Phoenix sold $96.3 million in airport revenue bonds in a negotiated sale through Smith Barney Shearson. Officials at the underwriting company said the lowering of Denver Airport bonds on Wednesday to junk status by S.& P. did not affect yesterday's sale.
The issue, some of which may be subject to the Federal alternative tax, was tentatively priced to yield a maximum 6.55 percent for a series C bond due in 2012.
Moody's and S.& P. rate the bonds triple-A because they are insured, by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corporation.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Bond Market Rally Fades, Pulling Down the Dollar

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was lower against most leading currencies yesterday after a rally in the bond market faded.
Signs that the Clinton Administration might resume its tough trade stance toward Japan also seemed to weigh on the dollar. 
 Bond prices rose yesterday morning, pulling the dollar up, after the Labor Department reported that the producer prices fell one-tenth of 1 percent in April, suggesting that fears of inflation might be exaggerated.
But bonds retreated from their highs after Robert T. Parry, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, said that the Fed still had "a way to go" before inflation was completely under control.
And Earl Johnson, foreign exchange adviser at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago, asserted: "Producer prices were good, but not good enough to change people's concern that inflation is roaring out of control. With U.S. assets so unstable lately, there's no demand for dollars to buy them."
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 104.32 Japanese yen, down from yesterday's high of 104.80 yen but up slightly from 104.29 yen on Wednesday.
The dollar also slipped to 1.6656 German marks from 1.6680 marks. It had traded as high as 1.6739 marks.
"The dollar is moving in lock step with the bond market," said Tom Hoge, vice president for corporate trading at the Bank of New York. "Capital flows are determining the dollar's direction now."
Uncertainty about the Clinton Administration's trade stance toward Japan helped knock the dollar off its highs, traders said. The dollar fell after Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said the United States had not softened its approach to curbing Japan's trade surplus, as some had read in remarks by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and other Administration officials this week.
Traders bought dollars on Tuesday after Administration officials said they did not want to see the dollar weaken further.
Last week, the Fed and other central banks teamed up to buy dollars for marks and yen in an attempt to end a three-month dollar slump.
Elsewhere, the British pound rose in New York to $1.5001, from $1.4941 on Wednesday. The dollar fell to 5.7186 French francs from 5.7251 francs. It was little changed at 1.4237 Swiss francs. The dollar fell to 1,594 Italian lire from 1,600 lire. The Canadian dollar was steady at 72.43 United States cents.

HEADLINE: Herman Walker, 83, Professor And U.S. Foreign Officer, Dies

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Herman Walker Jr., a former Foreign Service officer and emeritus professor of history, economics and political science at SUNY College at New Paltz, N.Y., died on Sunday at the New Paltz Nursing Home. A resident of New Paltz, he was 83.
He had been ill for a long time, said his wife, Evelyn Acomb Walker, an emiritus professor of history at New Paltz. 
 A native of Nashville, Dr. Walker graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Duke University, where he received his Ph.D. in 1937. He also studied at the University of Paris and received a master's degree from Harvard University.
He worked as an economist and legislative analyst for the Department of Agriculture. In World War II he served in the Army Air Force and the Office of Strategic Services.
 
Negotiated Friendship Treaty
 From 1946 until his retirement from the Federal Government in 1962 he was successively a treaty adviser to the Department of State, First Secretary in the United States Embassy in Paris, vice chairman of the United States delegation to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade conference in Geneva, and chairman of the Trade Agreements Commission.
In those years he helped shape the format for the Friendship, Commerce and Navigation Treaty adopted by the United States after World War II. He also played a role in negotiating political and economic treaties with France and other countries.
After leaving Government service, Dr. Walker taught at Duke and at George Washington University until he moved to New Paltz State College in 1965 as chairman of the division of history and political economy. From 1969 until he reached emeritus status in 1977 he was chairman of the department of economics and political science.
In addition to his wife, Dr. Walker is survived by a son from his previous marriage to the late Betty Friemel Walker, Steven F. Walker of Highland Park, N.J.; and a sister, Martha Summer of Bradenton, Fla.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Oil Prices Rise Above $18 On Concerns About Supply

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices rose above $18 a barrel yesterday for the first time since last October amid growing concerns about reduced supplies.
Oil production has slowed since the Piper Bravo platform in the North Sea was shut on May 1 because of a natural gas leak that forced workers to evacuate. More than two million barrels of crude production has been lost and traders do not know when the platform will start pumping again. 
 In addition, the civil war continues in Yemen, which produces as much as 350,000 barrels of crude a day, while village protests in Nigeria are forcing the Royal Dutch/Shell Group to curtail some operations there.
"These little factors are adding up," said George Ellis, a trader with the GSC Energy Corporation in Atlanta. Some traders said Iran, the second-largest member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, might be producing less than its quota of OPEC's 24.52 million barrels a day, Mr. Ellis said.
Crude oil for June delivery soared 43 cents, to $18.28 a barrel, at the New York Mercantile Exchange. June unleaded gasoline gained 0.79 cent, to 50.53 cents a gallon, while June heating oil rose 0.37 cent, to 48.22 cents a gallon.
 
Drop in Output Seen
 The expiration of the June crude options contracts today also pushed up prices, traders said.
The loss of production at Piper Bravo comes as North Sea output over all is expected to drop as maintenance begins with warmer weather.
"People are viewing that as a little bit of a problem," said Tom Curtis, energy research director with Pegasus Econometric Group in New York, speaking of the lower North Sea output. Even so, "It's adding up to a lot more than it really is," he said.
On other commodity markets, precious metals fell amid signs that a strengthening American economy had not yet caused increasing inflation.
Producer prices declined one-tenth of 1 percent in April, the first drop since last December, the Labor Department said.
"There's no indication of inflation yet," said Daniel Weissman, head trader for MTB Bank in New York. "Companies are very resistant to raising prices."
 
Gold and Silver Fall
 June gold fell to as low as $378.40 an ounce before recovering to settle down $1.90, at $380.80 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange. July silver lost 7.5 cents, to $5.395 an ounce.
July platinum fell $2.60, to $398.50 an ounce, at the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Gold prices follow movements in the bond market, because bonds and gold are both sensitive to inflation. Investors tend to buy gold when inflation threatens the value of stocks and bonds. Yesterday, prices of both bonds and stocks rose, although they ended the day off their highs.
"The gold market has been pretty much a bond market," Mr. Weissman said.

HEADLINE: Profit Up 17% At Grand Met

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: LONDON, May 12

 BODY:
Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. said today that its first-half earnings rose 17 percent amid economic recoveries in the United States and Britain.
Grand Met owns Burger King restaurants, Pillsbury foods, Haagen-Dazs ice cream and Alpo pet foods. 
 It earned 318 million, or $473.8 million, in the six months that ended on March 31, compared with 272 million in the period a year earlier. Revenue slipped 4 percent, to 3.92 billion ($5.84 billion), from 4.09 billion a year earlier.
The company raised its dividends by 6.2 percent, to 5.15 pence (7.7 cents) a share.
Operating profit rose 19 percent at its food business in North America and 16 percent at Burger King, where comparable-store sales rose 5 percent despite the introduction of a value-priced menu in the United States.
In trading today on the New York Stock Exchange, Grand Met's American depository receipts fell $1, to $27.25.

HEADLINE: More Downs Than Ups at Spring Art Auctions

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
Nothing has underscored the art market's fragility better than the auctions of contemporary, Impressionist and modern art over the last two weeks in New York. Six months ago, auction-house experts said they felt confident that the market was making a slow but steady climb up the track. Then came an unexpected derailment.
Several forces worked against both Sotheby's and Christie's. The world economic outlook has worsened in the last few months, meaning that buyers from Latin America and Asia, on whom the auction houses were counting, disappeared; American collectors led the buying. Other buyers, even if their piggy banks were full, apparently didn't feel psychologically confident enough to spend money this spring, always a factor in the auction room. 
 It didn't seem to matter that both houses showed higher-quality art than they have in years. The number of buyers simply had not grown in proportion to the increased number of works up for sale.
Neither auction house performed up to its expectations in either segment of the market: contemporary art, or Impressionist and modern art. Sotheby's sales of Impressionist and modern art on Wednesday night made $66.9 million, compared with the estimate of $90 million to $120 million. Christie's sales in that category brought in $66.62 million, way below the estimate of $104.4 million to $141.7 million.
Last week, in contemporary art, Sotheby's sales fetched $27.5 million, significantly less than its estimate of $41 million to $55 million. Christie's fared worse, with $18.2 million in sales after an estimate of $27.6 million to $37.4 million. Many experts said the houses had been overly optimistic when figuring their estimates.
 
A Demand for Perfection
 "Generalizations about the art market are no longer appropriate," said Christopher Burge, the chairman of Christie's in North America. "What is appropriate is to realize that the art market is the relationship of the sellers to a small handful of buyers. It's different with each work of art."
Diana D. Brooks, who heads Sotheby's auction operations worldwide, added: "We no longer have a marketplace where you can sell anything at any price. We are in an unpredictable but refined art market."
The impulse shoppers of the 1980's have been replaced by a discerning, disciplined breed of collector. Only the best will do. "If you've got something very expensive, it's got to be perfect," Mr. Burge said. "If there's the slightest thing wrong with it, it simply won't sell."
This proved to be true in every sale in the last two weeks. Either bidders fought hard to buy something, or there were no takers at all.
Two collectors competed with a vengeance for Klimt's "Lady With a Fan" (circa 1917-1918), which Sotheby's sold on Wednesday night for $11.6 million, far exceeding its estimate of $7 million to $9 million. There was also a lot of excitement when Sotheby's sold Mondrian's "Composition No. 8" (1939-42), a rare painting in perfect condition, to an unidentified telephone bidder. The $5.6 million price far exceeded Sotheby's estimate of more than $3 million. Several big spenders came forward to bid for Vlaminck's "Landscape of a Parisian Suburb" (1905-06), a brightly colored Fauvist work. It became the highest-price picture at Christie's on Tuesday night, selling to a telephone bidder for $6.8 million, more than double Christie's low estimate of $3 million.
 
Why Some Failed
 But each auction had its share of failures. Works by artists including Cezanne, Renoir, Monet, Matisse, Jasper Johns and Roy Lichtenstein went unsold. In each case, there was a reason. One surprise for Christie's on Tuesday night was Cezanne's "Still Life With Open Drawer" (1879-82): after an estimate of $4 million to $5 million, bidding never rose above $2.6 million. Several dealers said after the sale that the estimate was too high. Mr. Burge said the painting failed to sell because it appealed to a very "specialized collector," and no one that night was willing to step up to the plate.
Modigliani's "Portrait of Annie Bjarne" (1919) also sank that night. The reason, several dealers said, was that the painting is not recorded in the historian Ambrogio Ceroni's book on Modigliani, considered the definitive work on the artist. One telephone bidder was willing to pay $3.5 million, but that wasn't enough for the seller. The estimate had been $5 million to $6 million.
Sotheby's had its share of unsold art, too, and that house's disappointments also held no mystery. Bidding on the sale's cover picture, Monet's "Grand Canal and the Santa Maria Della Salute" (1908), never climbed higher than $5.7 million. The painting carried an estimate of $7 million to $8 million, obviously too high for today's collector. Mrs. Brooks said she thought that as lot 12, it came too early in the sale, "before buyers' confidence had built." Brancusi's "Bird" (1923-47), a blue-gray marble sculpture with an estimate of $8 million to $10 million, also didn't sell; bidding never rose above $6 million. Even before the sale, dealers had predicted the disaster, noting that the sculpture had been shopped around by its owner before the auction.
 
A Time to Hold On
 For several years now, it has appeared that the 1990's buyer is reluctant to spend gigantic sums. "The $300,000-to-$1 million range is stronger than it was six months ago, but the market for $4 million and above is thin," Mrs. Brooks said.
And the market for second-tier works, which fared well when Asian collectors played a bigger role in the market, has fallen flat. "These paintings were overpriced," Thomas Gibson, the London dealer, said of the middle portion of the market. "The true value of them, and the one which has always found a broad audience, is around $300,000, not $800,000."
"In the old days, most people sold when there was a death," Mr. Gibson added. "Today, living collectors subconsciously remember the high prices of the 80's, and since they don't need the money, they don't sell."
Which explains why estate property was the cream of the auctions this spring. Christie's had a small but impressive collection for sale, seven works identified only as coming from "a European estate." Showcased in their own hardbound catalogue were works from the estate of Jacques Koerfer, a German businessman who lived in Switzerland. Sotheby's had the coveted estate property this spring: the modern and contemporary art collected by H. Gates Lloyd, a former Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, who died in November, and his wife, Eleanor, the founder of the Washington Gallery of Modern Art, who died eight years ago. The couple had been serious collectors for 25 years, acquiring many of their contemporary works directly from the artists.
The Lloyd works were the unquestioned highlights of Sotheby's contemporary sale. The highest-priced work, David Smith's "Cubi V," 1 of 28 polished stainless-steel sculptures the artist began creating in 1961, was estimated to bring $2.5 million, but it actually fetched $4 million. Another winner from the Lloyd estate, Gerhard Richter's "Candle," caused a bidding war between four people in the salesroom and two on the telephone. The painting was finally sold to an unidentified telephone bidder for $607,500, more than twice its estimate of $250,000 to $300,000.
 
A Weak Contemporary Front
 But that's not to say Sotheby's contemporary-art sale was a smashing success. Far from it. Jasper Johns's "Highway" (1959), a colorful abstract painting from one of the artist's most desirable periods, failed to sell, undermining confidence for the rest of the evening. Once again, experts said the estimate was too high. One bidder was willing to pay as much as $7.2 million, but the seller, Peter Brant, the newsprint manufacturer who owns Interview magazine, wanted more.
Christie's contemporary-art sale had even bigger problems. Its offerings, for the most part, were weak. There were some exceptions, like Jackson Pollock's "No. 22," a 1949 drip painting that was sold to Thomas H. Lee, the owner of the Snapple beverage company, for $1.7 million, just under its estimate of $2 million to $3 million. Another exception was Tom Wesselmann's "Great American Nude No. 52" (1963), which went to a telephone bidder for $244,500, well above its estimate of $150,000 to $200,000.
In analyzing the contemporary-art market, both auction houses stressed, comparisons shouldn't be made to the market for Impressionist and modern art. "The two have nothing to do with each other," Mr. Burge said. "The contemporary market is more shifting sand, and it always will be. It's driven by different forces and by a different group of people."
Both houses agree that in planning the next round of sales in New York, for November, they will have to start being as selective as their buyers. "The message is clear," Mr. Burge said. "We'll have to look carefully at one picture at a time and think how will it perform, even if it means putting together smaller sales."

GRAPHIC: Photo: One work that exceeded expectations: Mondrian's "Composition No. 8," sold for $5.6 million on Wednesday night at Sotheby's. (Sotheby's)

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Clinton's Honor Saved!

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Somebody once asked Art Buchwald whether it was hard to keep coming up with great ideas for his humor columns. Why, not at all, he said, not in a country that sends a cake to Ayatollah Khomeini.
That's all there is to it. These humor fellows just loll around. Now and then they reach out for a piece of real-life wackiness nobody could possibly make up. No research, no interviews, no nothing. For this they get paid huge amounts of money. 
 So I have to assume Art Buchwald or Russell Baker have already spotted the lead editorial in The Wall Street Journal of May 11. But in case they haven't I offer it to them in gratitude for columns past and favors expected.
The Journal comes up with a really terrific idea for President Clinton. The editorial tells him how to tear up the promises in his own executive order linking continuation of low tariffs to China with some human rights progress by the Communist Government, and still come out looking shiny with honor, a regular hero.
Golf. Just one round of golf.
The Journal wants the President to forget all about that linkage stuff, which it thinks is a lot of nonsense that would hurt trade with China and damage China's "entrepreneurial class." Lots of Americans in the China trade have been putting pressure on the President to walk, run or wiggle out of the official promises he made to Congress and the American and Chinese people last May.
Mr. Clinton has until June 3 to make up his mind. The Journal is happily confident he will not live up to his commitments to use economic pressure as a way of getting the Chinese Communists to go a little easy on torturing prisoners or allow dissidents to speak up a bit.
The Journal reports approvingly and correctly that that is the word out of Washington "notwithstanding China's continuing disdain for minimal human rights norms." But it does seem concerned that changing his mind and breaking his word on China might make the President look bad.
So the editorial says that all the President has to do is to play a round of golf with two Asians not admired by Beijing -- the President of Taiwan, Lee Teng-hui, and a feisty Hong Kong legislator, Martin Lee -- and make sure there are plenty of photographers around.
Flanked by these two, Mr. Clinton can announce that he is renewing China's low-tariff trade privilege for the good of the Chinese people. Their presence will be a "rebuke" to the Beijing Communist leaders that presumably will make tears rise to their pretty eyes as they continue exporting their goods to the U.S -- four dollars' worth for every one they buy from the U.S.
But if he makes a decision to break his word without a gesture toward Asia's democrats, The Journal fears "Mr. Clinton will appear to be capitulating to China's dictators." The golf game will prevent that, it says.
Now, I read The Journal with respect. I think its business coverage is coming along fine and is a potential challenger to that of The New York Times. Generally I have a high rate of approval-nods about its editorials.
So I was struck by the thought that maybe the editorial was some kind of joke, a piece of irony. I called The Journal and was told pleasantly enough that no -- they meant it. A round of golf was indeed their proposal -- a glistening New World Order of appeasement through sport.
But somehow I don't think it will work. My problem may be that after having spent nine years associating with Asians in my reporting days at the early U.N. and then six years living among them as a foreign correspondent I did not find them the intellectual dolts, spineless fools and malleable wood-headed puppets The Journal takes them to be.
How in Heaven can usually intelligent people become so insultingly condescending, so sorrowfully insensitive as even to think that Asians or any other people are so dense and unaware of truth as to take a photo-op golf game as the moral equivalent of standing by a human rights pledge made by the U.S. President?
No, it will not and cannot be seen that way in Asia, all nicey-nicey. If Mr. Clinton breaks this promise he will, of course, be seen as a man who is neither to be honored nor considered of consequence -- all through Asia and nowhere more clearly and contemptuously than in the government chambers of Beijing.

HEADLINE: School Board Will Recognize Other Cultures, but as Inferior

BYLINE: New York Times Regional Newspapers 

DATELINE: TAVARES, Fla., May 12

 BODY:
They said the pledge of Allegiance, heard grade-school children sing "It's a Grand Old Flag," then the school board here voted to teach all students in Lake County that American culture is superior to all others.
The conservative Christian members of the Lake County School Board, who have held a majority here for nearly two years, said that as part of a state-mandated program on teaching about other cultures, the schools should also teach that American values are the best. 
 The policy, written by the board's chairwoman, Pat Hart, says, "This instruction shall also include and instill in our students an appreciation of our American heritage and culture such as: our republican form of government, capitalism, a free-enterprise system, patriotism, strong family values, freedom of religion and other basic values that are superior to other foreign or historic cultures."
While two board members dissented, the teachers' union threatened a suit and the superintendent of schools urged a delay, Mrs. Hart and the two other conservatives on the board Tuesday night passed the measure.
The teachers' union says the policy violates the intent of the state law, passed in 1991, mandating that students learn about other cultures. The state law says students need to appreciate other cultures and "eliminate personal and national ethnocentrism so that they understand that a specific culture is not intrinsically superior or inferior to another."
Tavares, home to the Lake County School Board office, is the county seat of a rural, rolling Central Florida area about 50 miles northwest of Orlando. Since freezes in the 1980's devastated the citrus crops that were the economic staple, Lake County has attracted retirees and those who cannot afford to live on the coasts.
The composition of the school board changed in September 1992, with the election of Judy Pearson and Claudia Ramsey, who joined Mrs. Hart to form a new majority that follows the tenets of Pat Buchanan's Christian Coalition and Citizen's for Excellence in Education.
Since then, the majority has decided to cut Head Start programs and eliminate a sex-education program for mentally handicapped students.
It was unclear whether the new policy would affect all 22,526 students in Lake County's 38 schools, or what grades would be affected, said the school superintendent, Tom Sanders. "There's a lot of unanswered questions about it," he said. "I guess according to the policy it could be one grade."
He said that curriculum committees would look at the policy this summer as they write teaching plans, but he added that the schools have always taught the values that the policy enumerated. "A number of people are calling saying it's great we're going to be teaching Americanism," he said. "That's what we've been teaching."
Since the vote, he said, the superintendent's office has been swamped with calls, with half the callers supporting the policy and half disagreeing.
Those in favor say it will enhance students' pride in America. But critics, including several teachers, complained the policy was vague and opened the door to a lawsuit.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 14, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about a Florida school board's decision to teach children that American culture is superior misidentified the president of the Christian Coalition, which has influenced some board members. He is Pat Robertson. (Pat Buchanan, the conservative newspaper columnist, was not involved in the situation.)

HEADLINE: A Top Executive's Puzzling Death

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
The death of Wardell R. Lazard, chairman of W. R. Lazard & Company, one of Wall Street's top minority-owned firms, contrasted starkly with what his many friends and admirers knew of his life. To them, Mr. Lazard was accomplished, highly regarded, well liked and, seemingly, thriving.
But on Wednesday, less than two weeks before his 45th birthday, Mr. Lazard died, apparently of a drug overdose, naked and alone in a hotel room in Pittsburgh. Next to his bed, the police said they found a vodka bottle and a tray with white powder on it. 
 Although a death certificate will not be issued for six to eight weeks, an autopsy yesterday ruled out most causes of death other than drugs and alcohol. And the Pittsburgh police have virtually ruled out suicide. No note was found in the hotel room.
Mr. Lazard was in Pittsburgh on business and had scheduled a lunch with Dwight White, a former Pittsburgh Steelers football player who is a principal in Mr. Lazard's investment banking firm. Mr. Lazard and his firm were sought after by many local governments that wanted to do business with a minority-run investment firm with a track record.
Marianne Camille Spraggins, a former investment banker with Smith Barney and an old friend of Mr. Lazard, lamented that Mr. Lazard might now be remembered just for the way he died. "There are so few black men on Wall Street," she said. "Most people outside Wall Street do not know him. The idea that this will be in their thoughts overwhelms me."
None of a dozen or so friends and colleagues said they had seen any signs of impending disaster. "Was he under strain?" asked Melvin L. Eubanks, a vice chairman of the firm who was appointed acting chairman on Wednesday night. "Absolutely, yes. The pressure doesn't cease. You're on the road a lot, and as the senior manager of the firm you are always on the line."
"But," he added, "I don't think anything unusual was going on."
And other friends said the notion that Mr. Lazard would die from a drug overdose was almost unbelievable.
"He was a black man trying to make it in a most difficult environment and, in doing so, thriving," Ms. Spraggins said. "He didn't have the time for that kind of thing. He was always in airplanes, always making presentations, always on. Anyway, it was abhorrent to him."
To his friends and associates, Mr. Lazard, 6 feet 6 inches tall, with a baby face, was a gentle giant with considerable vision and unrelenting drive. He worked hard, was good-natured, and became a master of his business.
They said he was completely committed to building an investment firm that would outlive him. He had overcome many obstacles, including overly rapid growth of his firm and a recession in municipal finance, the firm's primary business.
"Business was going well," said Kenneth E. Glover, a former investment banker with Drexel Burnham Lambert who joined Mr. Lazard's firm a year ago. "It seemed like we had the map."
Gedale B. Horowitz, a member of the board of Salomon Brothers, who hired Mr. Lazard fresh out of law school in 1980, said W. R. Lazard's business had started to recover in the last couple of years.
"He really had to take extreme measures to stay in business," Mr. Horowitz said. But recently Mr. Lazard had begun to hire new people and his business had started to turn around.
W. R. Lazard specializes in investment banking, financial advisory services and asset management. One of the first black investment firms, it ranks among the top minority-run firms.
Its headquarters are in New York City, and the firm operates offices in Washington, Atlanta, Pittsburgh, Dallas, Columbus, Ohio, and Los Angeles.
 
A Pledge of Service
 "Wardell's idea was to deliver quality service and that we would be chosen for that and not because of our minority status," said Mr. Eubanks of Lazard.
Yet without Mr. Lazard, who brought in most of the business, the future of the 70-member firm -- which is not related to the much older and larger Lazard Freres -- is very much up in the air. Mr. Lazard's wife, Betty, who now will own more than 90 percent of the firm, has told the principals that she wants the firm to go forward.
The Manhattan District Attorney, Robert Morgenthau, has been investigating Mr. Lazard's firm for several months.
Officials close to Mr. Morgenthau's inquiry said W. R. Lazard was a middleman between investment firms like Morgan Stanley and Sumitomo Bank and the city's job development authority. The firm arranged transactions and collected commissions.
"Mr. Lazard himself wasn't a target of our investigation, but his company and its relationship to some Wall Street investment banks is under inquiry," Mr. Morgenthau said. The investigation had been under way for six or seven months.
 
Feeling 'Very Comfortable'
 "The question that should be asked is why a middleman was needed to broker these deals," said an official in the District Attorney's office.
Mr. Glover said the investigation had not been weighing particularly heavily on Mr. Lazard's mind. "Every investment banking firm spends a lot of time under scrutiny," he said. "We feel very comfortable. Until Wardell's death, our attorneys hadn't talked to anybody for six months."
One thing is certain. To Mr. Lazard, his firm was his greatest achievement, his finest work.
By all accounts, he was a self-made man. An Army brat, he grew up mainly in California. He earned a journalism degree from California State University in Los Angeles. But instead of joining a newspaper, he went to work as a bond trader for California's state pension fund.
Married, with children on the way and eager to get ahead, he slogged his way through law school at night. By 1980, he had earned a degree from the University of the Pacific's McGeorge School of Law.
In the early 1980's, Mr. Lazard did what many hungry young men with good credentials did: He headed for Wall Street. He joined the municipal finance group at Salomon Brothers, which was then hiring, as were its competitors, young black professionals in a race to get business from the growing number of city governments run by mayors who were members of minority groups.
 
'A Very Good Banker'
 Mr. Lazard's mentor at Salomon, Bani Bose, who has since retired, remembered him as "very smart and very eager to learn the business." She added, "He had a chance at Salomon to do more than he could have elsewhere, and he took advantage of it." And Mr. Horowitz, senior managing director of Salomon Brothers and for many years the head of its municipal bond department, said Mr. Lazard was "a very good banker, brought in a lot of business, knew the business."
Mr. Lazard proved to be not only very good at forging relationships, but also at the technical aspects of the business, which enabled him to act as a financial adviser to local governments.
"I thought of Wall Street as another stage of the civil-rights struggle," said Ms. Spraggins, Mr. Lazard's friend. "For him, it was pure business."
Although top investment bankers could earn several hundred thousand dollars, Mr. Lazard had bigger visions than climbing through Salomon's ranks: He wanted to start his own firm. Not only did he wish to take advantage of new opportunities open to minority-owned firms, but he was intent on building a first-rate, minority-owned investment firm that handled a broad range of business.
Maria Day-Marshall, the treasurer for the District of Columbia, described Mr. Lazard as "a pioneer."
"His firm emerged at a time when there were very few minority investment banking firms," she said. "It took a lot of strength and foresight."
Mr. Lazard made his own success look easy, but it was the product of intense dedication. "He worked 7 A.M. to 8 at night," Mr. Eubanks said. "He worked weekends and holidays and called people, did all the homework. It's not all backslapping and conviviality and then the business comes in. The things that seem to be serendipity are the result of intense preparation."
Over time, especially after the firm's crisis in the early 1990's, Mr. Lazard also devoted time to the community. Percy Sutton, the former Manhattan borough president, described Mr. Lazard as "a class act."
"He was constantly involved in community activities," Mr. Sutton said. "You could get money from him for about anything in the community."
Mr. Lazard lived in Battery Park City in lower Manhattan. Besides his wife, who lives in Morristown, N.J., Mr. Lazard is survived by three children, Miandre, Michelle and Marcell.
 Both the article on Friday and the correction yesterday misstated the jurisdiction of the Job Development Authority. It is a New York State agency, not a New York City agency.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 17, 1994, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
(May 16, 1994, Monday) An article in Business Day on Friday about the death of Wardell R. Lazard, chairman of W. R. Lazard & Company, misidentified an investment firm for which that company acted as middleman in dealings with New York City's job development authority. It was J. P. Morgan & Company, not Morgan Stanley & Company.
An article in Business Day on Friday about the death of Wardell R. Lazard, the chairman of W. R. Lazard & Company, included an erroneous reference to Morgan Stanley & Company. Morgan Stanley was not among the firms that used W. R. Lazard as a middleman in dealings with the New York Job Development Authority.
 A correction on that subject in this space yesterday misstated the relationship of J. P. Morgan & Company with the Job Development Authority. Although J. P. Morgan has conducted business with the authority, it says it has not used W. R. Lazard as a middleman in these dealings.

HEADLINE: MAN IN THE NEWS: THE SUPREME COURT;
Scholarly Consensus Builder: Stephen Gerald Breyer

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK 

 BODY:
By nature and personality, Judge Stephen G. Breyer, whom President Clinton named yesterday to the United States Supreme Court, is professorial. But rather than become enmeshed solely in ideas, Judge Breyer has chosen to harness his considerable intelligence to solve problems, to clean up messes.
Rather than stake out fixed positions, he has built coalitions and achieved consensus. As generously endowed with political savvy, pragmatism, personal charm and energy as intelligence -- and unencumbered by any overarching ideology -- he has won a reputation for doing as well as thinking. 
 While serving on the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, where Judge Breyer has been chief judge since 1990, he used the same combination of skills to put together something as complicated as the Federal sentencing guidelines, as three-dimensional as a plan for an environmentally correct Federal courthouse on Boston Harbor and as crucial as coalitions of his fellow judges. He hates dissenting opinions, whether his own or others, and his court produces few of them.
Admirers see for him a moderate, consensus-building role like that of the man for whom he once clerked, Justice Arthur J. Goldberg, reaching out to Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, David H. Souter and Anthony M. Kennedy, the High Court's current middle, as Justice Goldberg once reached out to Justices Tom C. Clark and Potter Stewart.
"There are different kinds of intelligence, and his is the kind that tries to take complicated issues, cut to the core and explain them to people who are not nearly so intelligent," said Prof. Akhil Amar of Yale Law School, one of Judge Breyer's former law clerks. "He's always been smarter than most of those around him, so he's had to learn how to get along with other people."
But for liberals seeking a kindred spirit on the Court after a generation of conservatives and moderate appointees -- and a fitting replacement for Justice Harry A. Blackmun, the current Court's most liberal member -- Judge Breyer could disappoint.
"Breyer's basic social instincts are conservative," said Morton Horwitz, a legal historian and former faculty colleague at Harvard Law School. "His legal culture is more liberal, and his very flexible pragmatism will enable him to give things a gentle spin in a liberal direction. But he's a person without deep roots of any kind. He won't develop a vision."
 
Raw Brain Power
 Judge Breyer is Jewish, but Mr. Horwitz said he had little in common with Louis Brandeis, Benjamin Cardozo, Felix Frankfurter and other Jews who have served on the High Court. "If we still believe there is this social justice strand in the best version of the American judiciary, and that's what all these Jewish Justices stood for, Breyer doesn't stand for that," he said. "The words 'social justice' would somewhat embarrass him."
As intellectually acute and agile as he is energetic, a man who writes his own opinions and selects as his law clerks not those he can most easily lean on but those who are most interesting to talk to, Judge Breyer possesses one trait that Democrats and liberals starved of High Court appointments for a generation still seek: the raw brain power to match Justice Antonin Scalia, commonly acknowledged to be the Rehnquist Court's intellectual leader.
"He's smarter than Scalia, but not nearly as bombastic," said Alan Dershowitz, who has taught with Judge Breyer at Harvard Law School and argued before him. "He will dominate the Court by his quiet intellect, not by brashy, noisy intrusions. He doesn't need to prove he's the smartest person in the courthouse."
But while an intellectual counterweight to Judge Scalia, Judge Breyer is not necessarily a philosophical one. The labels most often used to describe him are "centrist" and "technocrat." His critics consider him brilliant but bloodless, more gamesman than statesman, more clever than humane. They say he lacks passion and compassion, is too centered on economic efficiency and a cost-benefit view of life, and prefers tidying up things, be it the airline industry or sentencing or the way judges choose their clerks, over articulating a sweeping constitutional vision.
 
Satisfying Solutions
 Others maintain, however, that Judge Breyer's moderation stems as much from institutional constraints as from his character. They note the limited role of appellate judges and the pallid, technical caseload of the First Circuit, which encompasses Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Rhode Island, Maine and Puerto Rico and produces few of the nettling constitutional cases from which great law and rhetoric are made.
Freed from those handicaps, they say, a deeply seated libertarian streak could emerge. Moreover, they speculate that a moderate with Judge Breyer's intellectual and personal gifts is better equipped to move the court leftward than a more abrasive activist.
"It's not yet been his assignment to generate a constitutional philosophy, for as a lower Federal judge he takes his marching orders from the Supreme Court," said Professor Amar. "Now, you'll see a guy with fundamentally moderate to liberal instincts, who understands how conservatives think and can talk their talk. He'll come up with solutions that the liberals will like and conservatives will accept and respect."
President Clinton first met Judge Breyer last year, when he was a front-runner for the court seat vacated by Justice Byron White. Judge Breyer hobbled to Washington for a job interview, nursing broken ribs and a punctured lung suffered when struck by a car as he bicycled across Harvard Square. When Mr. Clinton tapped Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg instead, there was speculation the two men had not hit it off.
There are those who find him snippy and snooty, caustic or condescending to those he considers not quite as smart as he, but they are a distinct minority. A good listener and able negotiator, he has won over almost everyone else. He may have won over even President Clinton with his conspicuous chipperness and grace after Judge Ginsburg beat him out. "A great pick," he called her.
 
The Intellect
Mixing Theory And Practice
 From an early age, Judge Breyer blended the theoretical and the practical. At Stanford University -- his mother discouraged him from attending Harvard, for fear that he would bury himself there in books -- he played Secretary General at a model United Nations. At Harvard, where he went on to study law and has taught for nearly 30 years, he planted himself where legal principles and politics merged, specializing in the law of administrative agencies and economic regulation.
By design, he periodically left his Cambridge cocoon for Washington, where he worked as a Watergate prosecutor, played a pivotal role in airline deregulation and became chief counsel to the Senate Judiciary Committee. In the process, he cemented his ties to Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who in 1980, in the waning days of the Carter Administration, shepherded him into his seat on the appellate court.
Judge Breyer remained on the bench despite an offer of the deanship of Harvard Law School, a job that might have been better preparation for the similarly fractious institution he could soon join than the comparatively congenial court where he now sits. He was also a finalist for the presidency of Harvard University.
"He is close to an ideal colleague: bright, intellectually curious and honest, an indefatigable worker, respectful of the views of others," said Judge Bruce M. Selya of Providence, R.I., whom President Ronald Reagan named to the First Circuit Court of Appeals in 1986. "It's a hackneyed phrase, but he has a mind like a steel trap.
"On a couple of occasions I've had to lean over and say, 'Steve, it would be nice if you let the lawyers get a word in edgewise.' Not that what he's saying doesn't make perfect sense, but he does play the teacher."
Joseph L. Tauro, chief judge of the Federal District Court in Massachusetts, said Judge Breyer had allayed all of his original fears. "My impression was that he was a Harvard egghead professor, and then I got to know him, and I found that my impression was 180 degrees wrong," he said. "He's from Harvard and he's an egghead, but he's one of the straightest, nicest guys I've ever met, absolutely devoid of any arrogance or attitude."
 
Relentless Interrogator
 Some of the judges with whom he has sat, however, find his intellectually nimble, facile ways a bit disconcerting. "He's able because of his brilliance to support any position," said one, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "He has to guard against that, and we, his colleagues, have to, too. We, his colleagues, have to count to 10 before we buy what he's selling."
This judge called Judge Breyer "more liberal than conservative," but added, "I can't say whether he's writing out of conviction or not."
Displaying what Senior Judge Hugh Bownes called a "professorial hangover," Judge Breyer is known as a rigorous, even relentless interrogator from the bench, with an ability to cut to the heart of a case. He is extremely industrious, willing to burrow into even the most voluminous record to understand the issue before him. Even losing advocates say they got a good hearing.
"He never rules in my favor, but I find him to be brilliant and a totally decent human being," said Robert Sheketoff, a criminal defense lawyer in Boston. "He's someone who's not stretching to help the defendant, but I've always found him to be intellectually honest."
 
The Decisions
Erudite And Methodical
 Judge Breyer is a man of great range. He served on a Federal judicial study committee contemplating the relationship between law and science, read all of Proust's "Remembrance of Things Past" in French a year ago and studied the Italian architect Borromini to pick up ideas for the new Federal courthouse, on which construction is to start this summer. Judge Breyer's decisions, narrowly tailored and generally deferential to lower courts, are less notable for their content than for their style: methodical, lucid, with no footnotes and little lofty rhetoric -- what Professor Amar called "Hemingwayesque."
They bear the marks of two judges. One is Judge John Minor Wisdom of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, who once advised Judge Breyer that whenever he was tempted to write a purple phrase, he should write it, then read it, then throw it in the waste basket. The other was Justice Goldberg. "I want to extend my congratulations on your recent opinions," the Justice wrote his former clerk in 1983. "However, with all due respect, I still believe that your opinions are too long."
In them are things to please and displease women's groups, civil libertarians, civil rights advocates and criminal defense lawyers. Judge Breyer wrote an opinion upholding the right of Americans to travel to Cuba, a decision later reversed by the Supreme Court (with Justice Blackmun dissenting), but another approving a Boston redistricting plan that civil rights lawyers said diluted minority voting power.
He ruled in favor of an affirmative action plan for the Boston Police Department in 1991, but writing for a divided court two years earlier, he reversed a lower court ruling granting scholars access under the Freedom of Information Act to certain McCarthy-era papers of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. In 1989 he wrote an opinion holding that the State of Massachusetts could regulate parts of the curriculum of a fundamentalist Baptist school in East Longmeadow, Mass., without violating the First Amendment. But in a 1991 decision that he wrote, the court barred the Internal Revenue Service from examining records of the Church of Scientology.
In a 1984 opinion by Judge Breyer, the court struck down on First Amendment grounds an executive order requiring candidates for positions in the World Health Organization to undergo loyalty investigations.
He joined in one opinion striking down prohibitions on abortion counseling at federally financed clinics, and in another upholding a Massachusetts law requiring minors to obtain the consent of both parents before undergoing an abortion. He helped establish the right to a jury trial in discrimination cases brought under Title VII of the 1964 Civil Rights Act, but joined in other decisions increasing the burden civil rights plaintiffs must bear to win. Earlier this year, he wrote an opinion upholding the constitutionality of the Federal law prohibiting the distribution and receipt of child pornography. The Supreme Court has agreed to consider that issue next term.
Judge Breyer has his detractors. "He's very interested in your case, engages you in an intellectually challenging discussion of the points, and then the opinion comes out, and you're history," said Michael Avery, a civil rights lawyer in Boston.
More than any ruling, however, it is Judge Breyer's role in helping to devise the intricate Federal sentencing guidelines, then defending them against accusations that they are rigid, mechanical and unduly harsh, that his critics find alarming. Both as architect and apologist, they contend, Judge Breyer provided liberal legitimacy to a cornerstone of Reagan-era law-and-order forces.
"You scratch the guidelines anywhere, and you get a horror story, and Breyer is as responsible for the mess as anyone else," said Albert Alschuler of the University of Chicago Law School.
His defenders counter that he kept the system from being even worse. Moreover, in a ruling last year, Judge Breyer conceded that the appellate courts, including his own, had enforced them too strictly, and he encouraged trial courts to be more flexible. In the case, a single mother with no prior record received 33 months in prison for carrying a pound of cocaine from New York to Providence in order, she said, to buy Christmas presents for her three small children.
The group that seems most positive about Judge Breyer's record is environmentalists. He has established what Douglas Foy, executive director of Conservation Law Foundation in Boston, called a "terrific" record in environmental cases, involving such issues as offshore oil and gas drilling, the use of dune buggies on the Cape Cod National Seashore, the cleanup of Boston Harbor and the risk to endangered species posed by a proposed oil refinery in Northern Maine.
"I don't think he's a card-carrying member of the Wilderness Society, but he cares about these issues," Mr. Foy said. "You've got to like a judge who gets hit by a car bicycling in Cambridge."
Judge Breyer has earned particular praise from environmentalists and community activists for his work on the new Federal Courthouse in Boston. Though, as a Federal building, the courthouse is technically exempt from state and local legal requirements, Judge Breyer has consulted with local groups and deferred to them. Everyone agrees he has devoted himself to the task prodigiously.
 
The Personality
A Man of Wealth In Frayed Collars
 Judge Breyer is a bit of an Anglophile, with English clothes and what some say is a hint of an English accent. But in other aspects of his personal life, he seems almost determinedly down-to-earth. He bicycles not only around Cambridge, where he lives, but across the Charles River to his chambers each morning, usually in a sweat suit, usually without mishap. The ride helps burn off the Hershey's Kisses and M&M's he filches from the jar his law clerks keep, partly to lure him over and into conversations, partly to slow him down.
He can be quirky, flip, distracted, or simply off-the-wall. At one law school faculty meeting, one unorthodox comment met with complete silence, broken only by Judge Breyer himself. "Well, I have tenure," he said. He can also be absent-minded.
While working for the Senate Judiciary Committee, he once wore the same suit, torn under the armpit, for six weeks running. His sweaters have holes in them and his collars are frayed, even though his net worth is at least $3.6 million. Most of that comes from his wife, Joanna, a clinical psychologist at the Dana Farber Cancer Institute in Boston whose father, Lord John Blankenham, once led Britain's Conservative Party. They have three children.
And Judge Breyer has a self-deprecating wit. It was was very much in evidence last year, as he awaited word from the White House over the first court vacancy. "I know all of you are curious about how I'm holding up," he declared at a meeting with his fellow judges. "It's not affecting me at all except in one small way: I'm hysterical 100 percent of the time." To another judge, he remarked: "There's only two people who aren't convinced I'm going to be on the Supreme Court. One is me and the other is Clinton."
He is a man who loves being loved, who told a friend that because intellect is innate and niceness is not, he would as soon be well-liked as highly respected. At his 50th birthday party, he went around around the table, one person after another, saying something flattering about each of dozens of guests.
Stephen Gerald Breyer was born in San Francisco on Aug. 15, 1938. His father, Irving, was a lawyer and administrator with the school board. He starred debating at Lowell High School -- one of his rivals was Edmund G. Brown Jr., later Governor of California -- and was voted most likely to succeed in the Class of 1955.
"He was always sort of a peacemaker," said Stuart Pollock, a high school and college classmate, and now a Municipal Court judge in San Francisco. "He was not anyone you'd expect to see on the steps of Sproul Hall."
Judge Breyer graduated from Stanford in 1958, then spent two years studying philosophy, politics and economics as a Marshall Scholar at Oxford. He then enrolled at Harvard Law School, where he graduated magna cum laude and was articles editor of the Harvard Law Review. He then clerked for Justice Goldberg.
In 1967 he returned to Harvard Law School, where he taught and wrote on antitrust, administrative law, and economic regulation. Interested in policy matters, he developed ties to the John F. Kennedy School of Government. He started teaching a course on law and economics, which led to his interest in regulatory reform.
He saw Harvard as congenial but a bit remote. "Life there is important but doesn't affect 99.9999 percent of the people who get up, go to work, have to educate their children, and get their health insurance," he said in an interview.
His third and longest foray to Washington came in 1979, as counsel to the Senate Judiciary Committee, then headed by Senator Kennedy. There, he worked on a Federal criminal code, the F.B.I. charter, fair housing law and legislation to deregulate the trucking industry. He also helped select judges and get them confirmed. In addition, he had the politically sensitive task of drafting a policy barring Federal judges them from belonging to private clubs that discriminated.
In 1979, after the Carter Administration balked at naming Archibald Cox, the former Watergate prosecutor, to a newly created seat on the First Circuit, Judge Breyer got the nod. His nomination was pending on Election Day, 1980, and appeared doomed once Ronald Reagan won. With help from, among others, various Republican members of the Committee, his nomination was salvaged, the only Democratic choice to do so. On Dec. 18, 1980, he was sworn in.
 
BIOGRAPHY
 
Stephen Gerald Breyer
BORN Aug. 15, 1938, San Francisco.
EDUCATION Lowell High School, San Francisco; A.B., Stanford University; B.A., Oxford University; LL.B., Harvard University.
CAREER HIGHLIGHTS 1964-65, law clerk, Supreme Court Justice Arthur J. Goldberg; 1965-67, special assistant to Assistant Attorney General; 1967-70, assistant professor, and 1970-80, professor, Harvard Law School; 1981 to present, part-time lecturer, Harvard Law School; 1973, assistant special prosecutor, Watergate Special Prosecution Force; 1974-75, special counsel, Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Administrative Practices; 1979-80, chief counsel, Senate Judiciary Committee; 1980, nominated to the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit; 1990, became Chief Judge.
FAMILY Married to Joanna Hare; two daughters, Chloe and Nell, and a son, Michael.
