HEADLINE: Wall St. Executive's Hidden Drug Problem

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN 

 BODY:
The mystery surrounding the death of Wardell R. Lazard deepened yesterday as some of his closest confidants and co-workers said they were unaware of his drug abuse and financial problems.
The three senior principals of the firm, W. R. Lazard & Company, and the firm's outside lawyer said yesterday that they were unaware before this week that Mr. Lazard had been arrested for drug use or been in treatment. 
 Nearly three years before he was found dead on Wednesday from an apparent drug overdose, Mr. Lazard had been arrested for possession of cocaine and drug paraphernalia. He had completed 11 months of closely monitored treatment as a condition of having the charges dismissed.
But he was apparently able to conceal his problems. He did not disclose his own stint in a drug rehabilitation program last year, even as he helped another executive of the firm who had a drug problem get into a treatment program.
"I didn't know anything about it," Robert Plotkin, the firm's outside counsel, said of Mr. Lazard's arrest in 1991. Melvin L. Eubanks, Kenneth E. Glover and Thomas M. Mead, the three principals of the firm, also said they were in the dark.
Mr. Plotkin also said he was unaware of Mr. Lazard's personal tax problems, including a recent lien by the Internal Revenue Service.
"Just because he was the 90 percent owner of the firm, it doesn't mean the company lawyer gets involved in his personal finances," Mr. Plotkin said.
Mr. Lazard, who was 44, was well known among New York's financial elite as the creator of one of the most successful black-owned investment banks. The firm he founded nine years ago after leaving Salomon Brothers quickly found a niche as more municipalities elected members of minorities to office. W. R. Lazard has since expanded into other lines of business, and now has 70 employees and $2.7 billion of assets under management.
New Jersey law enforcement officials said yesterday that the arrest of Mr. Lazard was made on July 23, 1991, one month and a day after the police were summoned by a family member to the home Mr. Lazard rented at 31 Sheepfield Farms Drive in Harding Township, N.J. The police said Mr. Lazard had overdosed and they called an ambulance to take him to Morristown Memorial Hospital in Morristown, N.J.
"He overdosed, and that led to his arrest," one enforcement official said yesterday, on condition of anonymity.
The episode occurred at the end of a two-year period during which Mr. Lazard's firm had overexpanded and was in a financial crisis that has since been solved.
Mr. Lazard's naked body was discovered on Wednesday in a hotel room in Pittsburgh. Not far away were a bottle of vodka, a tray with a white powdery substance that the coroner said yesterday was powder cocaine, and drug paraphernalia. Though laboratory tests will not be completed for several weeks, the police said they believed his death was accidental.
Law enforcement officials in New Jersey refused to divulge much about Mr. Lazard's arrest in 1991 because they said Mr. Lazard had successfully completed a pretrial intervention program that expunged any trace of the arrest from his record. The New Jersey program, which precludes an indictment and trial, seeks to get first-time offenders who are substance abusers into recovery programs.
As a participant in the program from Sept. 26, 1991, to Aug. 26, 1992, Mr. Lazard was expected to attend a drug rehabilitation center in Morristown weekly as an outpatient and submit to random urine testing and drug counseling. He was also expected to pay $133 in administrative costs for the program and a $1,000 penalty.
 
'Negative' Testing
 Officials said he had abided by all the terms of the program and as a result, all the charges were dismissed by Stephen Smith, the presiding judge of the New Jersey Superior Court in Morris County. "All drug testing during the period of supervision was negative," said Jude Del Preore, chief probationary officer for Morris County.
But as Mr. Lazard wrestled with his drug problem, his legal and financial problems were mounting.
On March 9 of this year, the Federal Government filed a lien against the two-acre property and house at 102 Skyline Drive in Morris Township that Mr. Lazard and his wife, Betty, had purchased in 1985 for $410,000, not far from the rented home in Harding Township where he had overdosed, court documents in Morris County show.
The Government sought the lien because of $68,047.71 it said Mr. Lazard owed in back taxes from 1991.
Mr. Lazard had borrowed heavily against the house for purposes that remain unclear. On the day he bought the house, he recorded a loan of $118,000 from the couple who had sold him the property, Timothy L. Arnold and Jane S. Arnold.
Almost three years later, in May 1988, he got a second mortgage of $75,000 from Midlantic Bank in Bloomfield, N.J. Four months later, a third mortgage for $475,000 was recorded as being issued by the Broadway Management Company, an agent for Fourteen Wall Street Associates. W. R. Lazard's headquarters are at 14 Wall Street.
 
A Personal Guarantee
 The first two mortgages have been canceled, presumably because they have been repaid. But the third, larger one remains open.
Roy R. Bumsted, an outside spokesman for W. R. Lazard, said the large mortgage had resulted from a personal guarantee Mr. Lazard had provided for a loan made to the firm. "It's very common," Mr. Bumsted said.
Mr. Bumsted also confirmed that W. R. Lazard had dismissed one of its senior executives who had a substance-abuse problem to "bring home to him the severity of the problem and the urgency of dealing with it." The company then paid for the employee's rehabilitation and rehired him.
David Shay, the addiction counselor who said he was hired by W. R. Lazard to help the senior executive, praised Mr. Lazard and Mr. Glover, a vice chairman of the firm. "They didn't want to fire the guy," he said. "They were very generous. They really wanted to help. One of the human resources people called to say if the insurance won't pay, the firm will."
Of Mr. Lazard, Mr. Shay added, "He was so concerned, so compassionate." Now, Mr. Shay said, "One of the reasons was that Wardell himself had had this problem."

 
 
'Drugs are Catching Up'
 Robert J. Strang, president of Strang Hayes Consulting, an investigative management firm in New York that advises companies about prevention programs, said, "Some of the incidents we're seeing involve very successful older people who have apparently been using drugs for years. They've been able to function, but the drugs are catching up with them."
In Mr. Lazard's case, Mr. Strang said, it may have been especially difficult to prevent the tragedy that occurred because continuing monitoring is a necessary part of recovery. And as the head of his own firm, Mr. Lazard might have been hard-pressed to submit his private problems to the scrutiny of underlings or outsiders.
When Mr. Lazard died, he was known to have been aware that his firm was being investigated by the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert Morgenthau, in connection with the fees it collected by acting as a middleman in several financings involving the New York State Job Development Authority. People familiar with the investigation said the inquiry had nothing to do with Mr. Lazard's drug use.
Mr. Plotkin, the Washington lawyer representing W. R. Lazard, said he believed the investigation, which started last year, began because of allegations made in a lawsuit brought by a disgruntled employee of the job development authority,
Until Mr. Lazard's puzzling death, "this was not a high priority for Mr. Morgenthau's office and the investigation was not terribly active," he said.

HEADLINE: In a Surprise Gesture, China Releases a Major Dissident

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Saturday, May 14

 BODY:
In an important gesture to the Clinton administration, China today released on medical parole the second of two major figures still serving long prison terms for leading the Tiananmen Square uprising of 1989.
 A brief dispatch this morning on the New China News Agency said that Chen Ziming, 42, "has been released on bail for medical treatment" under an order from "Chinese judicial authorities." 
 Mr. Chen, a social scientist and publisher, is a veteran of China's democracy movement. He was branded along with Wang Juntao as the "black hands" behind the political demonstrations that paralyzed the Chinese capital five years ago. Each man received a 13-year prison term in February 1991.
 
An Unexpected Move
 The release came as a surprise to China's dissidents, many of whom have been predicting that with the April 23 release of Mr. Wang, the Chinese leaders would make no more concessions to Washington in order to win renewal of China's "most favored nation" trade status.
 Today's decision follows a steady trickle of actions in recent days that appeared timed to influence President Clinton's decision on whether to renew the trade privileges.
 On Friday, five religious activists were released from labor camps because of their "good behavior," China said. On Thursday, a 54-year-old woman imprisoned for four years for religious activities was released in southern China's Fujian Province.
 Earlier in the week, China issued a passport after ten refusals to a constitutional scholar, Yu Haocheng, 66, who will leave China for an academic year at Columbia University.
 A longtime associate of Mr. Chen's, reached this morning, said this series of releases demonstrates the determination of the Chinese leadership to avoid a trade confrontation with the Clinton administration.
 "Even if releasing Wang Juntao and Chen Ziming involves a great risk for the Chinese government, today's action shows that the Chinese Government is willing to take this risk in order to win" renewal of its low tariff privileges in the American market, the associate said.
 In fact, he added, the risk of losing these trade privileges on $30 billion in exports to the United States, is greater than the risk of releasing two ardent democracy campaigners. "China's politics and economy cannot bear this loss," said the associate, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
 When Mr. Wang was released he was put on a plane to New York, where he is receiving treatment for hepatitis.
 In an interview a week ago, Mr. Chen's wife, Wang Zhihong, 38, expressed pessimism that she would see her husband released this year. She said one of her hopes has been that they could have a child. "I'm afraid that perhaps I will be too old to have one" by the time he would be released, she said.
 Today, she was reported to have accompanied her husband out of Beijing for medical treatment. The Reuters news agency quoted Mr. Chen's sister, Chen Zihua, as saying Chinese authorities "originally wanted to send them abroad" for treatment but relented when Mr. Chen said he wanted to stay in China.
 Mr. Chen's wife said she had made dozens of petitions to the authorities to release her husband on medical grounds. She said he was suffering from a skin ailment that was spreading all over his body, gastrointestinal problems and a diet so poor that his teeth were loosening.
 "In 1993 for a whole year, he was not able to take a single shower," she said.
 Mr. Chen and Mr. Wang, whose prodemocracy activism began during the 1978-79 Democracy Wall movement in Beijing, founded the Social Economic Research Institute and were publishers of a newspaper called Economics Weekly.

HEADLINE: Prices Rise For Treasury Securities

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities ended moderately higher yesterday after a roller-coaster session that epitomized the trading activity throughout the week.
The market initially rallied after the Labor Department reported that consumer prices rose a tenth of a percent in April. The increase was less than had been expected in many forecasts and was another sign that inflation was still in check. 
 But the market was quickly tripped up by rumors that a leading Wall Street firm was in financial trouble and was selling mortgage-backed securities and Treasury issues to raise capital. Later, the rumor expanded to include at least half a dozen firms or hedge funds. Although these were only rumors, they did affect the market by raising concerns, traders said.
Then Market News Service quoted a Federal Reserve governor, John P. LaWare, as saying that personal consumption, a key ingredient in the economic expansion, remained strong and that consumers were showing a growing willingness to borrow to finance purchases.
For traders and investors, the comments were another indication that there was still reason for the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates again, despite the good news on inflation. But by the afternoon, the positive inflation data appeared to be winning out and giving the market a lift, as prices rose and yields fell.
The 30-year bond rose 20/32 , to 8510/32 , for a yield of 7.49 percent, down from 7.56 percent on Thursday and at the level of Tuesday.
John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said there was no sign yet of any upward trend in price inflation. "In fact, if we look at the trend of the last few months annualized and compare it to the past 12 months, you can see that the latest data remain benign," he said. "This should help ease investor fears about inflation as a near-term risk.
"However, neither should it dissuade the Fed from continuing its tightening policy. Critics who complain that the Fed is responding to inflation now, when everyone else sees none, are missing the point. Fed policy is responding to the continuing strength of economic growth, rather than some ghost of inflation."
The monetary policy-making committee of the Federal Reserve, the Federal Open Market Committee, is scheduled to meet Tuesday, and many analysts expect the central bank to raise its short-term interest rate target by a quarter to a half of a percentage point. The target is now 3.75 percent; it has been raised three times since February by a quarter of a percentage point each time.
"There are substantial reasons for a more aggressive move soon -- for example, 50 basis points," Mr. Lipsky said. "But there are also good arguments in favor of a two-step process."
Some traders and dealers say that an aggressive move by the Fed of more than 25 basis points would be a golden opportunity for the central bank to get out ahead of the market and complete its work sooner.
In other data released yesterday, the Commerce Department reported that inventories fell in March for the first time in three months as sales continued to rise strongly. Total business inventories decreased by two-tenths of a percent, to $869.5 billion -- the first drop since a decline of a tenth of a percent in December.

HEADLINE: California Loses Top Spot In Japanese Tourist Trade

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 13

 BODY:
As California struggles to climb out of its long recession, more bad news has emerged: the state has lost its dominant share of the lucrative Japanese tourist market and may be hard-pressed to recover it.
 As other destinations compete with new attractions and more aggressive marketing, the state's share of the $14 billion Japanese tourist market has shrunk from 44 percent in 1987 to a projected 18 percent this year, California Division of Tourism figures show. The decline has meant a loss of $658 million a year. 
 Despite the declining numbers caused by Japan's continuing recession, Hawaii in recent years has captured the largest share of Japanese visitors, rising to more than 47 percent last year.
 Other destinations, as well as California, have suffered serious declines in Japanese tourism because of the recession, which has cut into travel and made cheaper, nearby Pacific destinations more popular.
 
Decline in New York, Too
 From 1987 to 1993, New York City saw its share of the Japanese tourist market fall from 16.9 percent to 10.2 percent, and New York State's fell from 18.9 percent to 10.6 percent in the same period.
 But California's position has been most seriously shaken.
 Both Japanese and American tour operators say violent crimes and the 1992 riot here, which have been widely publicized in Japan, are factors in California's reduced tourism, although fears of violence tend to generalize to the United States as a whole.
 "Many things have happened, and security is actually very bad compared with other destinations," said Ryo Okura, vice president of Japan Travel Bureau International, a major travel agency based in Los Angeles. "Honeymooners try to avoid this area. It used to be that this destination was very popular among honeymooners."
 He said most now go to Florida, where several foreign tourists have been killed, but no Japanese.
 
More British and Germans
 About 3.7 million Japanese traveled to the United States in 1992, 785,000 of them to California, said Tiffany Urness, a researcher with the California Division of Tourism. Each spent about $116 a day, nearly double that of British or German tourists, whose numbers have been rising as those of the Japanese decline.
 Japan remains the largest overseas tourist market for California, where 8.3 million overseas visitors spent $12 billion in 1992. But Ms. Urness said the loss is more important than its dollar figure would suggest.
 "California's largest market is itself," she said. "The international markets are important because they bring in foreign currency and enhance California's international stature and trade."
 In recent years, Miami, Orlando, Fla., Las Vegas, Nev., and other cities and areas around the country have gone after the Japanese dollar with new attractions and expensive advertising campaigns. As California's share of the Japanese tourist market has declined sharply, these destinations have fared better.
 
Only Hawaii Shows a Gain
 The overall decline in Japanese travel to the United States, and its increasing diversification among destinations, has affected most states and cities. Only Hawaii has seen significant growth among major destinations, from 41 percent of the market share to 47.2 percent in the period from 1987 to 1993.
 Illinois fell from 8.9 percent to 4.8 percent; Washington, D.C., fell from 6.6 percent to 3.6 percent.
 John Poimiroo, director of the California Division of Tourism, said that the problem had been identified here over the last two years or more but that few resources were available to combat it.
 California now spends only $300,000 a year on tourist promotion in Japan, part of overall promotional spending that is 16th among the states and about the same level as Montana's.
 A bill now before the California Legislature would budget $32.5 million for tourism promotion, of which Mr. Poimiroo estimated that about $1 million would be spent in Japan. "This is a great way to balance trade," he said. "Sending 10 Japanese tourists to California is the equivalent of sending one American car to Japan."
 
A 'Worn-Out Destination'
 Addison Schonland, manager of new business development for C.I.C. Research Inc., a travel research company, called parts of California a "worn-out destination" in comparison with places like Las Vegas that are "always reinventing themselves."
 "They have already been to Los Angeles and San Diego five or more times," she said of the Japanese. "They want to go somewhere else. There is only one Golden Gate Bridge, and nobody is building any new ones."
 Anecdotal reports from airlines and tour operators indicate a 28 percent decline in Japanese tourist visits to California in recent years, he said, while visits to Florida are up 40 percent and visits to Hawaii are up 30 percent.
 
Frightened by Violence
 "When you have more products on the shelf, people will buy less of your product," he said.
 Other factors, Mr. Poimiroo said, were the fear of crime and violence and the lack of new destinations "to keep us trendy."
 As with other foreign visitors, the Japanese have been most frightened by reports of violence to their own citizens. The killing of German and British tourists in Florida has had less of an impact in Japan than the recent killing of two Japanese students in a car-jacking incident in the Los Angeles area, Mr. Okura said.
 Robert Fisher, an assistant professor of marketing at the University of Southern California, said: "It's like the Michael Fay incident in Singapore. People get caned all the time in Singapore, but when it is one of your citizens the people tend to look at it and the media tend to exploit it."

HEADLINE: U.S. Hopes To Revive Japan Talks

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
Senior American and Japanese officials agreed today to try to revive their stalled negotiations on opening Japanese markets to more American imports, but privately American officials remained wary about the prospects for a deal.
Foreign Minister Koji Kakizawa of Japan telephoned Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, this morning and they spoke for 30 minutes about the need to have preliminary contacts about resuming their trade talks before the economic summit meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations in July. 
 The previous talks were broken off Feb. 11 by the Clinton Administration after Tokyo refused to accede to American demands for "numerical indicators" that would determine whether Japan really was opening markets in autos, auto parts, telecommunications, medical equipment and insurance.
 
Trade Office Statement
 "Ambassador Kantor agreed with the suggestion of Foreign Minister Kakizawa on the need for preliminary contact between both sides to explore the basis for resumption of the framework talks," a statement by Mr. Kantor's office said. "They both shared the hope that a basis will emerge for a resumption of the framework talks before the July G-7 meeting in Naples."
American officials are cautious about the prospects for several reasons. To begin with, before Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa resigned, he had promised to offer some Japanese steps to open markets and stimulate his sluggish economy. He said he hoped these would go a long way toward satisfying the American side.
The Clinton Administration was dubious about the Japanese proposals, which were scheduled to be delivered in June, but told the Japanese to come ahead. The Hosokawa resignation and subsequent political turmoil, however, overtook that effort and now the two sides are back to trying to resolve their differences through negotiations instead.
American officials also note that the Japanese side has gone out of its way to publicize these latest overtures. Some American officials believe that the fragile new Government of Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata is eager, maybe even desperate, to cut a deal with the Clinton Administration on trade, to prove to the Japanese public and political realm that the Hata Cabinet is serious, can get things done and can manage the most important foreign relationship Japan has today.
But American officials express the fear that while the Hata Government may have the will, it does not have the way. Not only does it carry little weight with the Japanese finance bureaucracy, which has been manning the barricades of opposition to the sort of trade pact the United States has been demanding, but it also does not even have a majority in Parliament.
 
'A There There?'
 The big question with Japan today, as one senior American policy maker put it, is: "Is there a there there?" Is there a real interlocutor with whom the United States can strike a deal that will be delivered by the Japanese side, or is Japan now so politically divided at the top that no serious deal is possible?
American officials do not want to go to the Group of Seven meeting with United States-Japan relations still an open sore, and neither do the Japanese. But the Americans also do not want to resume negotiations with Japan, knowing that in the end they may have to choose between accepting a watered-down deal -- the only deal Japan very likely will be able to strike -- or a second breakdown in the negotiations, which would worsen tensions between the world's two largest economies and further rattle global financial markets.
One reason for the decline in the value of the dollar since February was a feeling in financial markets that in the absence of a trade agreement between the United States and Japan, the Clinton Administration would either actively, or by benign neglect, allow the dollar to depreciate against the Japanese yen. That would make American exports cheaper and easier to penetrate the Japanese market and Japanese exports more expensive and more difficult to sell abroad.
That feeling became so prevalant in recent weeks that the dollar dropped significantly against major currencies, and the Federal Reserve and Treasury had to buy dollars in international markets to prop it up. They also had to declare publicly that the United States did not want to solve its trade problems with Japan through currency manipulation.
This helped to stabilize the dollar, particularly after it was accompanied by reports suggesting that the Clinton Administration might have to change its negotiating policy vis-a-vis Japan -- either to accept a weak deal or to drop the focus on opening particular Japanese markets and emphasize instead the need to get Japan to stimulate its overall economy so that it will import more from abroad.
Consequently, American officials want to be careful that there is no new breakdown with Tokyo. Given the dollar's fragile state, a renewal of trade conflict between Washington and Tokyo would hammer the American currency and add pressures on the Fed to raise American interest rates to keep the dollar's value up. After an initial few months of talking about Japan in very tough language, Clinton Administration officials now choose their words carefully when talking about the relationship with Tokyo, so as not to set off the currency markets inadvertently.
The main stumbling block in the talks is that the United States wants fixed yardsticks to gauge whether Japan's economy is being opened to more foreign goods and services. For instance, they have asked Tokyo to measure each month the number of auto showrooms that are displaying foreign cars. For their part, Japanese officials says such indicators are really just import targets and quotas that will put undue pressure on them and be in violation of world free trade norms.

HEADLINE: Russia Joins the West in a Push to End the Bosnian War

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GENEVA, May 13

 BODY:
Russia formally joined the United States and the European Union today in a reinvigorated international effort to end the two-year-old war in Bosnia, supporting a plan that calls on the Bosnian Serbs to cede nearly a third of the land they control to the Muslim-dominated Bosnian Government.
 Under the plan backed today, that Government, now federated with the Bosnian Croats, would be given control of 51 percent of the country, while the Bosnian Serbs, who now control more than 70 percent, would receive 49 percent. 
 At today's meeting, Secretary of State Warren Christopher and the foreign ministers of Russia, Britain, France, Germany and several other European countries also called on the warring parties to agree to a four-month cease-fire, and urged the Bosnian Government and the Bosnian Serbs to resume peace talks within two weeks.
 
Show of Unity
 The show of unity by the governments with the greatest influence with Bosnia's Muslims, Serbs and Croats seemed likely to increase pressure on the warring parties to accept the peace plan.
 The foreign ministers also supported efforts in the United Nations Security Council that threaten to punish any parties that takes offensive action near Brcko, a Serbian-held town in northern Bosnia where Western diplomats fear an outburst of fighting.
 But otherwise, the meeting produced no new threats or inducements to the Bosnian factions, and it is unclear whether the increased diplomatic pressure will produce a settlement.
 "This is the first time since the beginning of the war," said Foreign Minister Alain Juppe of France, "that the Europeans, Americans and Russians have agreed not on a vague formula, but on numerous details for an overall settlement."
 One senior American official was so optimistic about the unity among the major powers that he predicted a cessation of hostilities in four to six weeks.
 But the ministers acknowledged that after two years of bitter strife that has left an estimated 200,000 people dead, Bosnia's warring parties might not agree to resume negotiations or accept the details of the peace plan.
 "All of this is very fragile, very delicate, and can easily founder," said Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel of Germany.
 
Confidence in Jawboning
 The ministers voiced confidence that through jawboning by the major powers and maintaining the existing array of carrots and sticks -- like continuing economic sanctions against Serbia or renewing old threats to pull out United Nations peacekeepers -- the parties would get down to serious peace talks.
 For example, to pressure the Bosnian Government to get serious about a peace settlement, Mr. Juppe renewed a threat to withdraw France's 6,000 peacekeepers from the Balkans if there was no concrete movement toward peace soon. Mr. Christopher repeated suggestions that the United States might push for lifting the arms embargo on Bosnia if the war continued indefinitely.
 American officials also repeated threats to more strictly enforce the economic embargo against Serbia if the Bosnian Serbs, who are supplied by Serbia, rejected new negotiations.
 The proposed 51-49 division of land would require concessions by both sides. The Bosnian Government and the Bosnian Serbs tentatively endorsed such a division last fall as part of a European-led peace effort, but they have since retreated from that compromise and are demanding far more land for themselves. The Government now insists on 58 pecent, while the Serbs are demanding 60 percent.
 As an inducement to the Bosnian Serbs, the Europeans, who have long called for phasing out sanctions on Serbia if they move toward peace, won United States backing for gradually lifting the sanctions.
 
Russia Urges Lifting Sanctions
 Russia's Parliament voted today in favor of immediate lifting of the sanctions on Serbia, but Russia's Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, endorsed the European proposal to phase out the sanctions once the Serbs began to comply in good faith with a peace plan.
 American officials say the time is ripe for a settlement. Serbia, they say, is being strangled by economic sanctions and is tired of being viewed as an international pariah. The Bosnian Serbs also see that the Bosnian Government, thanks in part to a new federation with Croatia, is in the strongest military position it has held in two years.
 American officials asserted that the Bosnian Government, which now controls less than 30 percent of the country, should look longingly at a plan offering them 51 percent.
A senior American official said today's communique offered the Muslims not just quantity of land, but also quality. The official said it was important that Russia had endorsed a plan saying the final arrangement for Bosnia should provide the country "with viable, realistic and reasonable territory."
 With such a formula and with 51 percent of the land, the official said, the Bosnian Government should be able to regain much of the conquered territory in the east and north that it so eagerly wants back.
 "We have to get the best possible solution for the Bosnian Government," the American official said. But no proposal for actual boundaries was made today.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Iran Said to Violate Embargo
 SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, May 13 (AP) -- Iran has smuggled material for making weapons to the Bosnian Government in violation of a 1991 United Nations arms embargo on all sides in the war, a senior Bosnian Army official confirmed today.
 The Bosnian Army also received a large shipment of antitank rockets delivered to Croatia by a Brazilian ship, said the official, speaking on condition of anonymity. The official could not say whether the rockets had come from Iran or another source. He said further weapons shipments were expected.
 Four convoys carried the rockets and explosives to central Bosnia in the last few days after Bosnian Croats took a one-third cut of the arms, he said.
 He said the Bosnian Army previously lacked good antitank rockets in fighting Bosnian Serb troops, who had received heavy weapons from the Yugoslav Army when the Bosnian war broke out more than two years ago.
 The Washington Post reported today that Iran had delivered about 60 tons of explosives and materials for making ammunition to Croatia's capital, Zagreb, last week.

HEADLINE: THE SUPREME COURT;
Excerpts From Clinton's Remarks Announcing His Selection for Top Court

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's remarks announcing his selection of Judge Stephen G. Breyer for the Supreme Court, as recorded by The New York Times:
 Today I am proud to nominate Judge Stephen Breyer to serve on the United States Supreme Court. 
 I believe a President can best serve our country by nominating a candidate to the Supreme Court whose experience manifests the qualities in a Justice that matter most: Excellence. Excellence in knowledge, excellence in judgment, excellence in devotion to the Constitution, to the country and to the real people.
 It is a duty best exercised wisely and not in haste.
I have reflected on this decision now for the last several weeks, about 37 days. I have been well served by the White House counsel, Lloyd Cutler, and the other members of our legal staff, who have worked very hard; by our chief of staff, Mr. McLarty, who has kept the process going in an orderly way, and by others who worked on it. We have worked hard to achieve the pursuit of excellence.
 In that pursuit, I came again to Judge Breyer, who serves today, as most of you know, as the chief judge for the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. And I will nominate him to be the Supreme Court's 108th Justice.
 Without dispute he is one of the outstanding jurists of our age. He has a clear grasp of the law, a boundless respect for the constitutional and legal rights of the American people, a searching and restless intellect and a remarkable ability to explain complex subjects in understandable terms. He has proven that he can build an effective consensus and get people of diverse views to work together for justice's sake. He's a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Stanford, a graduate of Oxford University, a magna cum laude graduate of Harvard Law School. He served the late Justice Goldberg as a law clerk, spent two years in the antitrust division of the Justice Department and served as chief counsel of the Senate Committee on the Judiciary, where he had the opportunity to work with senators of both parties.
 Judge Breyer has had a private law practice, has written dozens of scholarly articles published in distinguished law reviews and legal texts, and he's been a member of the Federal Sentencing Commission. For more than a decade, he's served with true distinction on the U.S. Court of Appeals in the First Circuit. His writings, in areas ranging from the interpretation of legislation and analysis of the sentencing guidelines to the underpinnings of regulation and the interplay of economics and the law, reveal a keen and vital mind. His record displays a thirst for justice. His career personifies both public service and patriotism.
 As you know, I had a wealth of talent to choose from in making this nomination. In addition to Judge Breyer, whom I considered very seriously for this position the last time I had a Supreme Court appointment, I'd like to take just a moment to comment on two of the gentlemen who made this decision a difficult one for me.
 Secretary Babbitt was Attorney General and Governor of his state, during that time a colleague of mine. He was a candidate for the Presidency in a race which, everyone acknowledged, raised the serious and substantive issues of the day. He has been a very effective Secretary of the Interior for me, one of the most sensitive, complex and difficult posts in this Administration. He would bring to the Court the responsibility and discipline of service in public life. He would bring forth a feel for law at the state level and, most important, perhaps, for life at the grass roots.
 Although I know he would be a good addition -- indeed, a superb addition -- to the Court, frankly I came to the same conclusion I have every time I've thought about him: I couldn't bear to lose him from the Cabinet, from his service at Interior, from his service as an adviser to me and a vital and leading member of our domestic policy team.
 Judge Richard Arnold, the chief judge of the Eighth Circuit, has been a friend of mine for a long time. I have the greatest respect for his intellect, for his role as a jurist and for his extraordinary character. I think a measure of the devotion and the admiration in which he is held is evidenced by the fact that somewhere around 100 judges, one-eighth of the entire Federal bench, wrote me endorsing his candidacy for the Supreme Court.
 But, as has been widely reported in the press, Judge Arnold has cancer and is now undergoing a course of treatment. I have every confidence that that treatment will be successful. And if I am fortunate enough to have other opportunities to make appointments to the Court, I know I will be able to consider Judge Arnold at the top of the list.
 Five decades ago Judge Learned Hand defined the spirit of liberty as the spirit which seeks to understand the mind of other men and women, the spirit which weighs their interests alongside its own bias, the spirit which lies hidden in the aspirations of us all. When our citizens hear about Judge Breyer's nomination and learn about his background and beliefs, I believe they will join me in saying, Here is someone touched by that spirit of liberty, who believes in the Constitution and the Bill of Rights, who is graced with the intellectual capacity and the good judgment a Supreme Court Justice ought to have, and whose background and temperament clearly qualify him to be an outstanding Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court.
 So I will send his nomination to the Senate for confirmation with great pride and high hopes.
 QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 Q. Mr. President, when you had foregone the opportunity to name someone with greater political experience, such as Secretary Babbitt, what makes you think that Judge Breyer will be able to reshape the Court or forge a new consensus?
 A. I think Judge Breyer actually has quite a lot of political savvy, and I would say two things:
 First of all, as you know, in our talks about Senator Mitchell, I would not have offered the position to Senator Mitchell if he were running for re-election and were willing to stay as majority leader of the Senate. And I felt the same way in the end about Secretary Babbitt. I mean, here's a man that is dealing with issues of incredible magnitude, especially in the West, a very important part of our country. And so I just couldn't bear to think about that.
 And then the more I thought about Steve Breyer and the time I spent with him last time I had a vacancy on the Court, the more I realized he had proved that he had the kind of political capacity and judgment we need, because he'd been exposed to the full range of issues working here as the chief of staff of the Senate Judiciary Committee. He obviously has a lot of political skills because of his reputation as a consensus builder on a court where most of the appointees were made by Republican Presidents. And look at the people supporting his nomination. He's got Senator Kennedy and Senator Hatch together. I wish I had that kind of political skill.
 
. . .
 Q. In the end, why do you think that there was so much -- maybe it's our fault as much as it is your aides' fault -- so much confusion in which direction you were leaning? Earlier in the week, we thought Secretary Babbitt had the best choice. Then later it was Judge Arnold. Now, of course, you've made your decision.
 A. Because you all didn't talk to me. When we have these appointments that only I make, especially for something -- with all respect to my aides -- I think I know as much or more about it as they do. And I told you all, they work hard for me, and they do a wonderful job. There's an enormous amount of work to do.
 But one of the best jobs I ever had was teaching the Constitution of the United States to law students. I care a lot about the Supreme Court. I read people's opinions. I read articles. I read letters that people send me about the respective candidates. I think about this a lot, and I care very deeply about it. And I was going to take whatever time I had to take to think this through. In the course of those conversations with my staff, I always tried to take -- when we get down to the finals, where I'm down to three or four finals -- I try to take every strong suit I can about a candidate and work through every weakness. We worked through it.
 But I think -- you know, on these Supreme Court cases, we may never get another appointment -- but if I get another one, you're just going to have to ride along with me, because in the end I'm going to make the decision.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up vs. Yen on Move To Resume Talks on Trade

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen yesterday amid new efforts by the United States and Japan to resume trade talks.
Contributing to the dollar's rise were a modest rally in the bond market and speculation that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates next week. 
 The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, and Foreign Minister Koji Kakizawa of Japan agreed during a phone call to try to resume formal trade talks, which broke off in February. They also agreed that preliminary talks should start before the leaders from the Group of Seven industrial nations met in Naples in July.
Many traders bought dollars after Mr. Kantor's office issued a statement on the developments, betting that the Clinton Administration would no longer favor a policy of allowing the yen to strengthen in currency markets as a way to curb Japanese exports.
 
Up Against Mark, Too
 "Kantor's announcement gave the market a clearer idea of the Clinton Administration's plans for trade with Japan," said Jack Stapleton, senior corporate foreign-exchange dealer at the Standard Chartered Bank. "That really helped the dollar."
In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 104.95 yen, from 104.32 yen late Thursday. The dollar also rose to 1.6700 German marks, from 1.6656 marks.
Mr. Kantor's comments are the latest sign that the United States is done with its tacit strong-yen policy, traders said. A stronger yen would help curb Japan's trade surplus by making the country's exports more expensive.
"Optimism about trade helped the dollar rise against the yen," said Lisa Finstrom, a currency analyst at Smith Barney Shearson, who remains skeptical about the dollar's prospects. She said the dollar would not sustain gains against the yen unless the Japanese economy rebounded, spurring demand for American exports.
The dollar was also buoyed by gains in the bond market. Bond prices rose after the Labor Department said its Consumer Price Index rose only one-tenth of 1 percent in April, suggesting inflation was under control.
The dollar is likely to record further gains if the Federal Reserve, as expected, raises interest rates next week by a large enough margin to assuage some investors' concern about inflation, said Michael Faust, international portfolio manager for Bailard, Biehl & Kaiser in San Mateo, Calif.

HEADLINE: Aging Dept. Privatizes 4 Contracts For Services

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration has given a national for-profit company four contracts to provide city services to elderly people, saying the company can do the work cheaper than the four nonprofit groups that have been offering those services.
The decision has prompted protests from some elderly residents and City Council members, who say the four neighborhood-based organizations will now be forced to lay off dozens of employees and scale back the other services they provide. 
 The $1 million contract was awarded to Personal-Touch, a for-profit company with 23 offices across the country, by the Department of Aging. While the decision affects just four local organizations and involves a relatively small amount of money in the city's $31 billion budget, the controversy illustrates the difficult choices -- and consequences -- of trying to balance the city's budget and scale back government spending by opening up the competition for providing services..
 
Campaign Cornerstone
 The Giuliani administration, facing a projected $2.3 billion deficit in the budget for the next fiscal year, says it has been looking for ways to shave costs in every quarter of municipal spending. Moreover, the concept of widening the competition for functions performed on behalf of government was a cornerstone of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's mayoral campaign last year.
Herbert W. Stupp, the Commissioner of the Department of Aging, said that the decision to award the contract to a corporation operating for profit resulted from an analysis that the company could provide the same services for 12.5 percent less than the four neighborhood nonprofit groups.
But several City Council members and officials of the organizations that are now losing those contracts say the decision will hurt not only their agencies, but also the level of service received by their elderly clients.
The four contracts cover a number of home care services currently provided by four centers for the elderly in Brooklyn and Queens to enable elderly people to remain independent -- from helping with shopping to assisting with chores. The nonprofit groups will continue to provide other services, including operating the centers for the elderly and providing meals there.
Mr. Stupp said that the department had no ideological preference for for-profit companies and that of eight contracts that had been awarded recently, four went to nonprofit organizations. But he said Personal-Touch was selected for its contracts because it could provide equal service at a savings of 12.5 percent.
Cheryl Heiberg, executive director of the Bay Ridge Center for Older Adults, said her agency will lose a $270,000 contract to provide home care services for the elderly. "We have had contracts with the city for 15 years," she said. "This action takes the services out of the community so that seniors can't come to our center and address all their needs."
Ms. Heiberg added that the loss of the contract will mean that her organization will have to lay off 15 of its 42 employees. "And these are older women who are not all that well off and probably won't get rehired because of their ages," she said.
Councilman Sal Albanese of Brooklyn said, "It is outrageous that community-based senior providers with excellent records of service to their communities have been perfunctorily terminated."
Mr. Albanese and several officials of the nonprofit health care organizations said the savings were not worth the inconvenience for elderly people and the pain that would be created for the groups' employees.
David N. Slifkin, chief financial officer of the Personal-Touch Home Care Corporation, said that as a larger company with 12,000 employees and 23 offices in 12 states, Personal-Touch had been able to achieve economies of scale and lower overhead costs.
The company, which has its headquarters in Jamaica, Queens, already has several contracts with New York City, most of them with the Human Resources Administration. The new contracts become effective on July 1.

HEADLINE: Watershed Police Protect What New York City Drinks

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOUNT PLEASANT, N.Y.

 BODY:
The facade of the Mount Pleasant Corporate Center, all silver walls and mirrored windows, was sleek and futuristic, and the lush lawn in front led down to a pretty little pond with heather draped over the stone walls around the water.
But floating on the surface, right under a drainage pipe, was a white sudsy substance that Ronald A. Gatto didn't like the looks of, especially when he considered where it was going: from the pond into Malcolm Brook, then to the Kensico Reservoir, and from there to the taps of nearly nine million people in New York City and Westchester County. 
 Mr. Gatto is the Lieutenant of the New York City Department of Environmental Protection's Watershed Police, a small band of scouts posted by the city to watch a 2,000-square-mile area that collects more than a billion gallons of water a day. The police work cooperatively with a force of civilian inspectors, walking or driving every highway, street, fire road and cow path in the watershed, looking for trouble.
 
Septic Systems and Road Salt
 From the emissions of office buildings, septic systems and industrial plants to such suburban staples as tree cutting and road salting, human activity increasingly threatens water. As warm weather approaches, the worry becomes greater: last summer the city had to tell residents of several neighborhoods to boil their drinking water because of bacteria.
Lieutenant Gatto, the senior uniformed officer of the 29-member force, is at the heart of a systematic inspection program begun last year, part of a sometimes ambivalent struggle by the city to watch what it drinks. The reasons are driven by economics as much as health: if the water is not clean enough, the Federal Government will require the city to build a filtration plant, which would drive up water bills throughout the city.
The force was originally set up in 1906, at twice the size it is now, to protect the dams, gate houses and other property of the water systems. Now its mission also includes protecting the environment, and that, some critics say, is where it is not doing enough.
 
Stepping on Toes
 In its first 84 years, it made no environmental arrests at all, and Lieutenant Gatto testified before city officials three years ago that he was told by superiors in the city's Department of Environmental Protection to go easy on polluters dumping sewage into tributaries of the reservoirs.
In some cases, enforcing the rules can mean stepping on the toes of upstate legislators, whose help in Albany is essential on other city issues. The police also know that some polluters are not venal robber barons, just homeowners, often hard up for cash, whose septic systems need fixing.
But John Melia, a spokesman for the Department of Environmental Protection, said that the city was tough when appropriate. "As a matter of philosophy, we are gung ho on enforcement and will not tolerate criminal activity or civil violations," he said. "That is our hard and fast stand."
Since 1990 there have been 185 "major pollution arrests," said Michael Collins, the Commissioner of the watershed police, all resulting in fines or penalties, even if criminal citations are often knocked down to civil violations.
 
One Person Imprisoned
 Only one person has gone to jail, a Bronx man who was working as a home improvement contractor in Ossining, and was caught early one Sunday in October 1990 by Mr. Gatto, then a detective sergeant, as he was tossing wallboard, tile and plumbing fixtures from his van down an embankment into a reservoir in Cortland.
The man laughed at a judge when told what he was being charged with, Lieutenant Gatto said; he served five days until he came up with $5,000 in bail, and was eventually fined $2,500.
"Gatto probably today has arrested more polluters than any other police officer in the world," said Robert F. Kennedy Jr., an environmental lawyer who specializes in water issues. "He can smell a leaking septic tank from a moving car. He arrests everyone; he's arrested his friends."
This is true.
Mr. Gatto once arrested an old friend of his family, the owner of the Katonah Restaurant, in Katonah, who had rigged his septic holding tanks to flood into the street when it rained -- sending 8,000 to 10,000 gallons of raw sewage each month heading for the Muscoot Reservoir 175 feet away.
The police got complaints of the smell, but the real tip-off was the records supplied by the company that pumped his septic tanks, which showed that the tanks had been pumped four to six times a month for years, at a cost of $300 to $400 each time, but suddenly were being pumped only once or twice a month.
The man pleaded guilty to two misdemeanors and paid $20,000 in fines, Lieutenant Gatto said.
That was a major find, but mostly the battle is gallon by gallon.
For instance, at the corporate center in Mount Pleasant, there were the suds, and the building manager insisted that they were in fact just that: suds, from cars being washed in a parking lot.
Lieutenant Gatto was unconvinced. "We should take a sample; who knows what he dumped in there?" he said.
(The material turned out to be soap suds, but the laboratory also found a coliform bacteria count that was unusually high. Lieutenant Gatto decided to take additional samples in the future.)
 
Help From Fishermen
 The police say that fishermen are their allies, often providing the first reports of pollution.
Tipped off by Trout Unlimited, a fishing group, about a smelly, milky substance intermittently appearing in the Croton River, a tributary to the Croton Reservoir, Lieutenant Gatto eventually found the source, an eight-inch cement pipe. That led to Brewster Honda, where new cars were being washed with a solvent to remove a protective coating.
"What is this chemical?" Lieutenant Gatto asked the manager.
"It's O.K.," was the answer.
"But what's this chemical?" Lieutenant Gatto said.
"It's O.K.," the manager said again.
Sure enough, it was a liquid called It's Okay Solvent, but it was not O.K.
A check with the manufacturer, Ardex Laboratories of Philadelphia, showed that the solvent is an eye and skin irritant, which can cause convulsions and severe nausea in high enough doses. The building owner paid a $5,000 fine.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Water spilling over the Croton Dam, part of New York City's water supply, is protected by the city's Department of Environmental Protection's Watershed Police, who patrol a 2,000-square-mile area. Lieut. Ronald A. Gatto supervises the 29-member force, which, despite 185 arrests since 1990, has seen only one person go to jail. (Susan Harris for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Positive Inflation Report Fails to Inspire Stocks

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The Government further underscored its good economic news of Thursday with another favorable inflation report yesterday, this time involving consumer prices.
But traders reacted as if it was old news, and the leading stock indexes barely budged in trading volume that was below average.
The exception was the over-the-counter market, where high-technology stocks were hurt by a troubled industry outlook for computers. Cisco Systems, a big producer of equipment that allows computers to talk to each other, said its backlog of orders had fallen sharply. Shares of Cisco fell 5 3/4, to 23 1/4, in Nasdaq trading yesterday. 
 Don Hays, an investment strategist for Wheat First Butcher & Singer in Richmond, said the sharp downturn for Cisco and other computer-networking stocks signaled the "beginning of the end" of the down market.
Cisco and others had been among the last of the strong market performers, and their rout meant the market was about to turn. "It could be as soon as next week," Mr. Hays said.
 
Computer Stocks Active
 The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 2.69 points, to 716.92, and the computer-related stocks saw the most active trading. Cisco, Intel, Microsoft and Wellfleet were the top four stocks in terms of trading volume.
The problems began on Thursday when Cisco reported its third-quarter earnings after the markets closed. The profits of the company, while healthy, did not exceed analysts' estimates and its backlog had shrunk, casting a pall on the outlook for much of the industry. About 45 million shares of Cisco -- nearly a fifth of its total shares -- changed hands yesterday.
Traders continued to look ahead to Tuesday, when the Federal Reserve is widely expected to raise interest rates in an effort to slow down an economy that shows some signs of speeding up, but few signs of inflation.
Alan R. Ackerman, stock market strategist with Reich & Company, said the reaction of the market yesterday "was so mild because people are waiting for the Fed to meet."
 
Strong Economic Growth
 The Consumer Price Index yesterday confirmed what the Producer Price Index had indicated a day earlier. The message is that the economy continues to grow strongly, but without inflation, especially in a month without snowstorms, earthquakes or other events to distort the numbers.
The Labor Department reported that April consumer prices rose by one-tenth of 1 percent, while Wall Street economists had expected a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent. The more closely watched core rate, excluding volatile food and energy prices, was two-tenths of 1 percent, compared with the anticipated three-tenths of 1 percent.
Inflation hurts the value of current bonds and raises the borrowing costs for corporations, thus undermining the value of their stocks. Both markets should have rallied strongly with the new data, and the markets did at first, but then sank, and struggled to close at their opening levels.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.84 points, to 3,659.68, and the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 0.39 point, to 444.14.
 
G.E. Stock Rises
 The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.21 point, to 245.76, on volume of 252.1 million shares, about 17 percent less than this year's average volume of 304 million shares. Declining stocks barely outnumbered advancing stocks by 1,091 to 1,033. The American Stock Exchange index fell 0.78 point, to 432.57.
Of the 30 component stocks of the Dow industrials, only 12 rose in price, led by General Electric, which rose 1 5/8, to 95 3/8. There was no big news, although Quaker State agreed to sell its Heritage Insurance Group to G.E. for $85 million.
Of the 500 stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500, 224 rose, led by Philip Morris, which rose 1 5/8, to 52 1/8, on heavy volume of more than 3.7 million shares. Philip Morris was up for the second day, possibly because of traders' speculation that the company's directors may decide to spin off the tobacco business later this month.
Tokyo stocks traded higher yesterday. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 46.51 points, or 0.23 percent, at 20,270.75.11 points.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 37; Column 3; Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1011 words

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
Confirming that inflation remains subdued, consumer prices scarcely budged in April. Nonetheless, the financial world is still bracing for an expected increase in interest rates when the Federal Reserve meets on Tuesday.
"These figures look very good," said Michael L. Penzer, senior economist at the Bank of America, referring to today's Government report showing that consumer prices rose just one-tenth of a percent last month. It is very hard, he added, to find evidence of acceleration. 
 Most analysts said they continued to think the Fed would raise short-term interest rates again next week, but some said that they thought today's price report, combined with Thursday's news of vanished inflation at the producer level and sluggish retail sales, might temper the Fed's action.
"It might now be difficult to push by 50 basis points" -- half a percentage point -- on the overnight private-sector lending rate, said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist for the Norwest Corporation, a banking group based in Minneapolis. "The burden is on those who think inflation will be a problem."
Mr. Penzer, for his part, rated the choice between a half-point rise and another quarter-point increase "a tossup."
Bond prices ended moderately higher today after the inflation report was released, pushing interest rates lower. [Page 47.]
Economists recognize that the Fed is looking forward while the inflation data are history; the services component of the Consumer Price Index, in fact, is an official "lagging" indicator of the state of the economy.
Analysts also noted that the central bank would be evaluating figures on industrial production for last month, a statistical series that the Fed itself compiles and that will be published on Monday.
Some economists worry that the Fed's pre-emptive policy, aimed at preventing a resurgence of inflation many months from now, or perhaps a year in the future, threatens the well-being of the economy.
"At some point the Fed has to take a breather," a senior Congressional economist, a Democrat who insisted that he not be identified, said this evening. "Either right now or after their next increase the Fed should call it off for a while."
Senator Paul S. Sarbanes of Maryland, a senior Democrat on the Joint Economic Committee, was among the liberals who even before this week's batch of favorable figures was forcefully insisting that the Fed should not be raising rates in the absence of a visible threat of rising prices. An attempt to reach him tonight for comment was unsuccessful.
The Clinton Administration welcomed today's Labor Department report, which was more positive than nearly all analysts expected, but did not use it as an argument against further Fed tightening.
"I'm encouraged by what we see in the numbers," said Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen after addressing a meeting of the Business Council in Williamsburg, Va. When asked whether the surge in long-term interest rates had slowed the expansion, Mr. Bentsen said, "At this level, I don't see that."
In a briefing for reporters at the White House, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, head of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, called inflation "well contained" and noted that for the 12 months through April both the core Consumer Price Index and the core Producer Price Index had posted their slimmest advances in 20 years.
Core rates, which exclude the wide-swinging food and energy categories, are considered the best gauges of price trends.
 
No Change in Housing
 The April rise of one-tenth of a percent, which followed increases of three-tenths of a percent in March and February, reflected a downturn in energy prices and no change in the heavily weighted housing sector.
Moreover, grocery-store food prices were unchanged last month and have now declined so far this year by 1.7 percent at an annual rate.
On the other hand, medical costs climbed six-tenths of a percent last month, the biggest increase in almost a year and twice as big as any monthly rise since October. The hefty increase was spread across all major components -- drugs and supplies, services and hospitals -- but analysts said one month's results were not enough to tell whether a long downward trend in medical inflation might be ending.
In transportation, where the overall rise was a modest three-tenths of a percent, the costs of buying a car climbed substantially for a third month. Finance charges were the biggest factor, jumping 2.3 percent, the most in more than five years.
Used-car prices advanced eight-tenths of a percent and new vehicles rose four-tenths of a percent. Additional increases for new cars have been announced and will show up in later Consumer Price Index data.
 
Tyson Sees an 'Uptick'
 Another reason for expecting some rebound for the next index reading is an upward recent march in the price of oil.
Ms. Tyson today predicted a "gradual and small uptick" in the inflation rate as the business expansion continued and further shrank the gap between the economy's actual and potential growth. She estimated that this gap had been cut in half, to 1 percent, over the last year.
The rise in core prices for April was two-tenths of a percent, today's report also showed, with the 12-month rate edging down to 2.8 percent from 2.9 in March.
Services, which account for about 56 percent of the index, rose two-tenths of a percent last month, while commodities, the rest of the index, rose a tenth of a percent.
In a related report, average weekly earnings edged up one-tenth of a percent last month after adjustment for inflation and seasonality, the Labor Department said.
The Commerce Department also reported that business inventories eased two-tenths of a percent in March, as business sales jumped 1.1 percent, a second straight solid gain.
"With stock-to-sales ratios exceedingly low," said Ron Schreibman, vice president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors, "we should see higher production and employment in the coming months, assuming consumers keep reaching for their wallets."

HEADLINE: 3 in Senate Race Bank on Primary Upset

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 12

 BODY:
The June 7 primary election in New Jersey is just a blip on the screen for the two major candidates for United States Senator, but for three lesser-known and less affluent candidates it's the big show.
Frank R. Lautenberg, the Democratic incumbent who made it official Monday that he is seeking a third term, and Chuck Haytaian, the Republican who is Speaker of the State Assembly, are each expected to raise and spend $5 million to $10 million on their campaigns. Meanwhile, the candidates hoping to trip them up next month talk about raising enough to print some handbills and, if things break their way, to produce a radio commercial. 
 All three of those candidates admit they couldn't hope to win their party's nomination in a contest that depended on spending heavily, but they say they are banking on presenting ideas attractive enough to pull votes from the front-runners, whose campaigns thus far have consisted chiefly of ignoring the primary while they try to catch each another in political gaffes.
Mr. Haytaian's opponent for the Republican nomination is Brian T. Kennedy of Sea Girt, a lawyer who spent 10 years in the State Assembly and Senate through 1984. Mr. Lautenberg is being opposed by Bill Campbell of North Plainfield, an engineer, and Lynne A. Speed of Ridgefield Park, a follower of the political extremist and perennial Presidential candidate Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr.
Neither Mr. Campbell nor Mrs. Speed has held public office, although both have waged campaigns in the past. Mr. Campbell ran unsuccessfully for Congress as an independent in the Seventh District in Union County and Mrs. Speed lost a bid for the party's nomination to run for the State Assembly in Essex County. Mrs. Speed works as a coordinator of sales and distribution for Hamilton Distribution Systems Inc. in Ridgefield Park, which circulates two LaRouche publications.
Mr. Kennedy's campaign suffered something of a setback last month when the Republican State Committee endorsed Mr. Haytaian instead of adopting its usual neutral position in a party primary.
"They think he can raise the money he'll need on his own, and that's all they're interested in," Mr. Kennedy said of the state leadership's decision. "My problem is easy to define but difficult to do, get my message out to the 225,000 Republican voters who will pick the nominee."
The message is a call for reversing what Mr. Kennedy says is the deterioration of the quality of life in New Jersey and across the nation, which he attributes to crime, drugs and a loss of family values. "When I was in the Legislature the concern was 'why Johnny can't read or write,' " the 60- year-old former lawmaker said. "Now it's 'why Johnny can't tell right from wrong.' "
 
Industrial Program
 "This is a good time to be running," said Mr. Campbell, who is 39. "Being an incumbent these days is not the advantage it usually is.
"If government leaders had been doing a good job over the last 12 years we'd be in better shape," he said. "The public is tired of seeing people lose their jobs and their homes, and we have to ask, 'Are they getting good representation?' I don't think so."
Mr. Campbell said the Federal Government must reverse the decline in the country's manufacturing sector by assisting private companies without dictating to them. "It's a delicate balance, but we should adopt a team approach, like they have in Japan," Mr. Campbell said.
"When the auto companies had to clean up their exhaust systems because of clean-air standards, they had to do their research independently, and it put American Motors out of business and almost did the same to Chrysler," he said. "If they could have set up a separate corporation and shared the cost, it would have made more sense."
Mrs. Speed says the solution to the country's economic problems is to invest more in industrial technology. She also advocates putting the Federal Reserve System back under the control of Congress. "Then it could be directed to make credit available at low interest rates to small and medium-sized businesses and to finance infrastructure improvements, including highways, energy facilities and port development, which would be important to New Jersey," she said.
Mrs. Speed, who is 40, said she didn't know how much she would be able to spend on her campaign and was hoping that some organizations would set up public debates for the candidates.
 
Getting Attention
 "Today so many candidates are like cereal boxes: they have everything to do with packaging and nothing to do with content," she said. "We have many, many problems, and they exist because of the failure of the American people to look at certain key issues in more depth."
The three challengers to the front-runners plan to spend as much time as they can before June 7 on the streets with their handbills and their requests for support. Mr. Campbell said that if he can get more people interested in voting in the primary, or force public officials to work a little harder, he will consider his campaign a success.
Getting people's attention is the first hurdle. Mr. Kennedy, who believes schools must teach ethics and morals to help stop the rise in teen-age pregnancies and curb violence, and who favors tough prison sentences for habitual offenders, handed out campaign flyers at the Sea Girt Mall on a recent afternoon.
Mary Eichhorn of Sea Girt took the flyer and glanced at it. She said she might vote for Mr. Kennedy. "But I haven't made up my mind," she said. "I'm working more right now on putting a golf ball."

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Low-Cost Ways to Tend Portfolios Over Time

BYLINE: By Francis Flaherty 

 BODY:
NO one much likes the middle of things. Gardeners like to plant and harvest, but who wants to weed midseason? Investors are no different, and now they have a few low-cost aids, offered by mutual funds, to help tend assets as they grow.
The help is needed; neglect can be very risky in investing. Steven Janachowski, a financial adviser in San Francisco, tells of a retired couple, both doctors, with an $800,000 portfolio they need for income. Unmonitored for years, the assets are "about 70 percent in mostly speculative equities," he said. "Hardly an income portfolio." And because equities usually return more than other investments, unwatched portfolios tend to get stock-heavy -- the reverse of what experts advise as retirement or other goal nears. 
 "Inattention can wreak havoc," said Stuart Kessler, an accountant and planner with Goldstein Golub Kessler & Company in New York.
But George Markle, a retired executive for the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company in Dallas, has no such havoc and pays nothing for it. While many investors -- if they can pony up $100,000 or $200,000 -- pay planners, brokers or funds up to 3 percent of assets each year to monitor and help adjust their holdings, Mr. Markle uses the free Stein Roe Counselor program, which has attracted $261 million since it began a year ago. It can be reached at (800) 322-8222.
For a $50,000 minimum, these investors get a personal representative to help apportion their assets among 15 of Stein Roe's no-load mutual funds. The representative will also track the holdings, call investors quarterly or monthly and recommend portfolio adjustments as markets move or as investors' needs change. With a personal "800" number, the adviser is easily reached.
When interest rates began to rise in February, Mr. Markle and his representative, Kelly Dehler, adjusted one of his accounts, a $102,000 holding. Municipal bonds made up 69 percent of the $102,000, but as rates began to climb the two reduced this tax-exempt portion to 55 percent.
For Mr. Markle, such timely adjustments are crucial. "Not to keep tabs on things is dumb," he said. But he finds the job impossible to do alone. Timothy K. Armour, president of Stein Roe Mutual Funds, is not surprised. "We researched our clients," he said. "What they wanted most was useful, ongoing guidance."
In March, the Wells Fargo Bank introduced five Lifepath Funds, which use fund design, not personal counseling, to aid in continuing portfolio adjustment. Each fund has a date -- from 2000 to 2040, in 10-year increments. An investor who must withdraw or begin to withdraw money in, say, 2030, would choose the Lifepath fund with that designation.
Some funds besides Lifepath are also time-limited, like the Benham Target Maturities series and the Scudder Zero Coupon 2000 fund. But most of them are bond-only investments with fixed portfolios.
Lifepath funds invest in stocks, bonds and cash through 14 different indexes. Most importantly, the funds adjust their holdings over time, focusing on growth in the early years and on safety later. (A fund will seek mainly income after its date passes.)
In other words, Lifepath funds, with $60 million so far, relieve investors of a major reason for monitoring investments: the passage of time. If Mr. Janachowski's doctors used Lifepath, the fund would have automatically toned down the risk in their go-go portfolio as they aged. And, like Stein Roe's Counselor, Lifepath has easy-to-meet requirements. The minimum investment is $1,000, and the funds are no-loads with a common expense ratio of 1.2 percent. The number is (800) 222-8222.
"It's financial planning for regular people," said Dudley Nigg, executive vice president of Wells Fargo.
Critics say Lifepath may be too simple. New jobs, marriage, parenthood, inheritances and other changes also affect portfolios, said John Markese of the American Association of Individual Investors. Lifepath can be "dangerous," he said, if it lulls investors into thinking "they can ignore the fund for 20 years."
Software, offered by many mutual funds, is another easy, low-cost way to update portfolios, Mr. Markese added. Investors need only punch in current data, and the computer model will adjust the recommended strategy. Two examples are Fidelity's Thinkware (800) 544-3703 and Vanguard's Retirement Planner (800) 876-1840. Both cost $15 and are available in I.B.M.-compatible form.
The trick, though, is to find a way to insure the software is used every year or two. A tip: Put it on top of your tax records.
Will the funds soon market other low-cost aids for the periodic pruning of assets? If Stein Roe and Wells Fargo succeed, "there'll be dozens," Mr. Janachowski said. "There's a hole in the market."
Indeed, many funds, including Fidelity, Dreyfus and Stein Roe, know investors want more service and already run programs that compete directly with many planners and, to some extent, with the pricier "wrap" programs offered by brokers. For accounts with at least $100,000 to $200,000, and maximum annual fees of 1 percent of assets, the funds actively manage holdings in light of changing markets and investor needs.
Like the new low-cost alternatives, these programs restrict investment choices to the offering family's funds. But, unlike the Stein Roe Counselor, these programs usually give fund managers the power to shift assets without investor approval.
The broader lesson in all this? Investment is not a clock, said Jay Schabacker of Schabacker Investment Management in Rockville, Md. "You can't set it and forget it."

HEADLINE: German Giant Sets Job Cuts

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, May 13

 BODY:
The troubled German conglomerate Metallgesellschaft A.G. will cut 7,500 jobs this year as part of its effort to save more than four billion marks ($2.4 billion) in costs.
The company's chairman, Karl-Josef Neukirchen, outlined the measures in a recent company newsletter. Metallgesellschaft, which has interests in natural resources, trading and engineering, will sell several subsidiaries in a bid to raise one billion marks. 
 Mr. Neukirchen said the payroll reductions should cut yearly labor costs by 550 million marks. As of Sept. 30, Metallgesellschaft, one of Germany's biggest companies, had 43,000 employees.
A financial crisis touched off by huge oil-trading losses at the company's New York-based Metallgesellschaft Corporation unit led to the dismissals in December of the former chairman, Heinz Schimmelbusch, and five executives. Mr. Neukirchen replaced Mr. Schimmelbusch.
In January, creditor banks approved a $2 billion package to keep the company out of bankruptcy.
