HEADLINE: Q & A

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane 

 BODY:

Savings Bond Guarantee
I purchased Series EE Savings Bonds before Nov. 1, 1986, when the minimum guaranteed interest rate was 7.5 percent. If these bonds are kept beyond the 10-year maturity, do they retain the 7.5 percent guarantee? LOUIS MYERSON, Bronx, N.Y.
Since the original maturity of your United States Savings Bonds was 10 years, they are scheduled to enter a 10-year extended maturity period in 1996. During that period, the guaranteed minimum rate on the bonds will be the same as for new issues during that time. The guaranteed rate is now 4 percent. The actual rate on your bonds, however, may be higher than the guaranteed rate. 
 "Bonds held five years or longer receive the minimum rate or the market-based average rate, whichever is higher," said Peter Hollenbach, a spokesman for the Bureau of the Public Debt. "A comparison is made between the market-based average rate and the minimum rates in effect over the life of the bond in determining the yield."
This market-based rate changes every six months, and was reset the first of this month to 4.7 percent.
 
Exercising Stock Options
Will options that are in the money on the expiration date be automatically exercised? SIDNEY KRANE, Colonia, N.J.
A call option is in the money when the strike price -- the price at which the stock may be purchased if the option is exercised -- is less than the market price of the underlying security. A put option is in the money when the strike price -- the price at which the stock may be sold -- is greater than the market price.
"Options are not always exercised automatically at expiration," said Tom Curran, vice president of York Securities. "Equity options that are three-quarters of a point or more in the money will be automatically exercised. So will nonequity options that are one-quarter of a point or more in the money."
 
I.R.A.'s and Estates
Will the value placed on I.R.A. assets for estate tax purposes be reduced to take into account the fact that income taxes will be paid on these assets when distributed to the beneficiaries? EUGENE E. BEYER JR., Manhattan
The full value of an individual retirement account is included in someone's gross estate at the time of death. When the money in an inherited I.R.A. is distributed, it is reported on the beneficiary's income tax return for the year received.
"An itemized deduction is allowed for a portion of the estate tax paid on the I.R.A. account balance," following a complex formula, said Joel S. Isaacson, president of Joel Isaacson & Company, a New York financial planning firm. "The deduction is not subject to the 2 percent limit on miscellaneous itemized deductions."
He added, "If the beneficiary is the decedent's surviving spouse and that spouse rolls over the distribution into another I.R.A., the distribution is not currently income-taxed."

HEADLINE: Construction Below, Opposition Above

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
PERHAPS because land-use battles are tough to fight hundreds of feet underground, New York City's third water tunnel has faced little organized opposition as it has bored through the boroughs.
But an enterprise of such colossal scale was bound to get snagged somewhere. And at the Bulova Corporate Center in Jackson Heights, Queens, the tunnel's second stage has reached its first major impasse. More rough going can be expected in the West Village and lower Manhattan, too. 
 The tunnel's second stage has an 11-mile leg in Queens and Brooklyn and a 5-mile leg in Manhattan. It will cost about $1.5 billion. Tunneling began in 1986 and is to finish in 2002, according to the Department of Environmental Protection, which engineered and oversees the project. The $1.2 billion first stage, which runs 13 miles through the Bronx, Manhattan and Queens, was begun in 1970 and is nearing completion.
It is not the tunnel itself at issue. After all, in some places it is nearly as far below ground as the Woolworth Building is high. Also, since the need is almost universally acknowledged, a "Numby" movement -- not under my backyard -- has yet to coalesce.
Instead, what is at issue are the sites selected for the enormous shafts that rise from the tunnel. Although they leave little evidence behind when finished, the shafts take years to build and require construction staging areas that can spread over acres.
That is what angers the neighbors, tenants and owners of the Bulova center, a successful commercial development in what used to be the headquarters and factory of the Bulova Watch Company. They are protesting plans by the city to situate two shafts on the property, near the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway and across 25th Avenue from the Lexington School for the Deaf.
Opponents have been joined in their fight by Borough President Claire Shulman of Queens and by City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, who represents the district. He would pose a formidable obstacle when the matter comes to the Council for approval, which it will do after the City Planning Commission votes on it next month.
Mr. Vallone said last week that the choice of a site in a neighborhood of small homes was "absurd on the face of it."
Marilyn Gelber, the Commissioner of Environmental Protection, said the agency was "very vigorously" examining other sites. But she will not withdraw the application from review by the planning commission.
"There may be, at the end of the day, no acceptable alternatives," Ms. Gelber said. "I'm hopeful we will find an alternate site. I'm not foreclosing any possibility. But I'm not about to pull the plug unless I understand that we have a good alternative."
Having visited the Bulova center recently, Commissioner Gelber said: "What they're doing out there is critical to the New York City economy and I'm not looking to jeopardize it. But I understand, from a technical basis, why we came to the conclusion that this site would have less impact than others."
"STAGE one went under a whole host of sensitive structures in Manhattan and they didn't know we were under them," said Glen E. Vogel, deputy commissioner of environmental protection and director of environmental engineering.
But residents of El Rosario, a complex of two-family homes in the East Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, definitely knew about Shaft 20B, at Seigel and White Streets. In 1990, a blowout about 500 feet below ground caused minor damage, like cracks in party walls, to several units. "For a couple of months, there was a lot of hysteria" among homeowners, said Kathryn Wylde, president of the New York City Housing Partnership, which helped develop the project. The problems have since been resolved, she said.
"If everything goes perfectly, there will be a minimal amount of disruption," said Shelly S. Friedman of Brown & Wood, a lawyer for the Bulova center. "But this is New York. And things don't go perfectly. And when things go sub-optimal, the price would be paid by corporate tenants, by homeowners and by children at the school."
"We believe their methodology for choosing this site is faulty," Mr. Friedman said, "and that there are other sites."
Alternate sites are being considered for two shafts planned in Manhattan. In one case, the Edison Parking Corporation is fighting the city's proposal to acquire its lot at 13th Street and Ninth Avenue.
There is an even more complicated search for a site for the southernmost Manhattan shaft. For now, the choice is between a development parcel owned by the Milstein family in the South Street Seaport Historic District or a small lot behind One Police Plaza where police vehicles are parked. To complicate matters, this site may encompass part of a venerable Jewish burial ground.
Heated as these fights might grow, disputes seem to be more the exception than the rule in the choice of locations for the 14 shafts along stage two of the water tunnel.
New York's third water tunnel, known officially as City Tunnel No. 3, is designed to supplement two existing tunnels, reduce peak flows and provide a backup source in case of disruption. It would also allow the older tunnels to be drained, examined and rehabilitated for the first time. Tunnel No. 1 has been operating continuously since it was put into service in 1917; Tunnel No. 2 has been in nonstop use since 1937.
The 16 shafts of the first stage have already been built. Five of the 14 shafts in the second stage are under construction, two more have been approved by the City Planning Commission, six are under review and one is still being planned.
(Shafts on the third tunnel carry a "B" designation -- 1B, 2B, 3B and so on -- to distinguish them from the shafts on the first tunnel, which are simply numbered 1, 2, 3, and the shafts on the second tunnel, which are numbered 1A, 2A, 3A.)
"The shaft sites haven't really generated much controversy," said James Merani, the team leader at the City Planning Department for site selection on all city projects. "That means that D.E.P. did a good job finding these locations. And it's not an easy job finding locations of this size."
Even in the dense precincts of Manhattan, the selection process has been "relatively free of complications," said Andrew C. Breslau, press secretary to Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan.
In situating the shafts, geological conditions are "extremely important," Ms. Gelber said. And obviously, the shafts must be near the tunnel route. "Beyond these two key points are the availability, the economics and the size of the site," she said. "Ideally, you like to be in a place where there is the least impact on residences, largely in industrial areas. On the other hand, the construction itself is so far below ground that there is little awareness of what's going on."
Shaft 17B, which is proposed for Jackson Heights, has unique demands because it is to connect the second stage of the tunnel with the fourth stage, scheduled in the next century for eastern areas of Queens and the Bronx. Water from these two legs of the tunnel will travel through enormous manifolds into pipes within a 135-by-40-foot valve chamber some 320 feet below the street.
Besides the 750-foot-deep distribution shaft that is to carry water to the mains, site 17B also requires an access shaft, with stairs and elevator, leading down to the valve chamber.
With two shafts to build, "we need as close to two acres as we can get," Mr. Vogel said. "The more room you have, the more you can keep out of the public's eye -- and hair."
Construction of the shafts and valve chamber is expected to take four and a half years. Construction of distribution and access chambers near the surface would take another two years, if all went according to plan.
Several sites were reviewed by the agency. One of the most promising from a logistical vantage was a triangular plot at 60th Street and 30th Avenue that sits between two rail lines. It is owned by P&F Trucking and is used as a garbage transfer station. Officials rejected it, however, because of the difficulties of soil testing, the possible presence of hazardous and contaminated materials and the need to relocate an existing business.
The search turned toward the Bulova center. Once the home of Bulova watches, the 23-acre parcel was purchased in 1985 by the Blumenfeld Development Group of Syosset, L.I. The next year, Blumenfeld began converting the old headquarters and factory into an attractive 483,000-square-foot office building with an airy, verdant atrium.
Today, the building is 90 percent leased, said Jonathan E. Cohen of the Blumenfeld group. Tenants include British Airways, Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, the Sanus division of New York Life and the Eastern Paralyzed Veterans Association.
A few steps from the existing building is an irregularly shaped open field on which Blumenfeld planned the second phase of the Bulova center. This would include a four-story, 400,000-square-foot office building; a 10-story, 200-room hotel; a shopping arcade and a 10-screen movie theater.
The second phase was "somewhat shelved on a short-term basis" after the real estate market deflated, Mr. Cohen said. At about the same time, two and a half years ago, the developers started hearing rumblings from community leaders about the selection of their property for Shaft 17B.
ENVIRONMENTAL officials were drawn to the open field for many of the things that made it an attractive development parcel: it is large, clear of existing structures, under single ownership and close to the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway.
That was where Shaft 17B was first proposed. But then, Mr. Vogel said, borings indicated that the rock quality was not as good under the open field as it was under the Bulova center parking lot immediately to the east, which is lined with mature pin oak trees. Mr. Vogel said the proposed shaft site was moved eastward, in part to accommodate Blumenfeld's development plans.
But the shift of the shaft did nothing to mollify the owners, tenants or neighbors.
David Blumenfeld, one of the developers of the Bulova center, said the shafts would "severely impact" his project. Some tenants, he said, especially those with sensitive computer centers, had "serious concerns" about prolonged construction nearby.
At a hearing May 4 before city planners, James Weisman, a lawyer with the veterans association, said that about 30 of its 90 employees were in wheelchairs. "This construction will effectively undermine their ability to use this property," he said. "Parking and the ability to travel safely from the car to the building is fundamental."
At the same hearing, an aide to Mr. Vallone, Frances McDonald, said the location was "unacceptable," adding that the "re-arrangement of this site has brought it unnecessarily close to people's homes."
Mr. Vallone himself said: "There are priorities in this town. No. 1 is that you don't dig 500 feet under a home if you have a piece of vacant land or a junkyard available."
Residents are clearly angered by the possibility that while Shaft 17B is being excavated, the B.Q.E. may be under reconstruction, a runway may be extended at La Guardia Airport nearby and a rail link may be built from Kennedy International Airport to La Guardia and mid-Manhattan.
Neighbors who crowded the May 4 hearing unfurled banners reading "B.Q.E.! Monorail! LGA! The shaft too? Why us?" and "Don't shaft Jackson Heights!"
Borough President Shulman said in a report to the planning commission that elimination of on-site parking during construction "will severely affect the viability of existing businesses employing over 2,000 people, as well as future operations" at the center. She added that "this displacement will result in a significant loss of economic development opportunities in the Jackson Heights area."
Mr. Vogel responded that "we are not, in fact, eliminating but relocating parking, which in all probability would be closer to the building than the farthest extremity of the parking lot we'd be taking."
Except for Van Cortlandt Park and Central Park, Mr. Vogel said the Jackson Heights site was "probably the least impacted" in terms of the "congestion of the surrounding community." He contrasted it to Sackett Street and Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn, where there are apartment buildings "right on the edge of the site" of Shaft 22B.
Whatever happens in Jackson Heights, it will not be the end of controversy.
The city has proposed using a parking lot at Ninth Avenue and 13th Street as the site for Shaft 27B. The 180-space lot is owned and operated by Edison Parking of Newark.
"Of course, we don't want to be condemned or lose our site for 10 years or so," said Douglas E. Sarini, Edison's vice president for public affairs. That is particularly true, he said, since there is another lot on 15th Street with an owner who is willing to sell.
Mr. Vogel said no final decision had been made, although city engineers were still leaning toward the Edison site since it is larger and closer to the line of the tunnel.
The borough president's office is also involved in the discussion, as are the community boards on either side of 14th Street.
This is not the first time that Edison Parking has tangled with the water tunnel and it is not surprising, either, since parking lots make tempting sites for shafts.
Edison is also the tenant of a lot owned by the Rudin family at 10th Avenue and 48th Street. The Rudins planned to sell it to St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center until city engineers identified it as the site for Shaft 25B. The planning commission has approved the location and a deal between the city and the Rudins is reportedly close at hand. St. Clare's, meanwhile, picked a site on Eighth Avenue, at 48th Street, for its new hospital.
Another Edison lot, at 10th Avenue and 17th Street, was the first choice for the Manhattan tunneling shaft, No. 26B, from which the horizontal boring is staged and through which the resulting debris and muck are brought to the surface for removal.
However, the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration moved into the former Merchants Refrigerating Company Building on the other side of 17th Street. In deference to the agency's "sensitive equipment," Mr. Vogel said, the shaft site was changed to a city-owned parcel on Murray Street. But that was to have been the location of the New York Exchanges Headquarters, which would have had "greater positive impacts" than a shaft, Mr. Vogel said. So the site was moved again, to part of the John D. Caemmerer rail yard at 10th Avenue and 30th Street, west of Penn Station, a location being leased from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Construction is to begin this summer.
At the end of the line in Manhattan awaits another dilemma. Shaft 30B was tentatively situated on a large vacant lot at Water Street and Peck Slip, in the Seaport historic district.
BUT that lot is owned by the Milstein family, which spent eight years trying to win approval from the Landmarks Preservation Commission for a large-scale development in the small-scale district. An 11-story office project was approved in 1991 and the Milsteins are looking for tenants.
Another possible site is a small triangular plot at Pearl and Madison Streets, behind police headquarters. It is known as James Madison Park, Ms. Gelber said, but is mainly used as a parking lot for police vehicles.
That is not its only potential liability. Borough President Messinger's press secretary, Mr. Breslau, said there "may be an old Jewish burial ground under that park."
There is a remnant some 600 feet to the north, at St. James Place and Oliver Street, of the burial ground used by Congregation Shearith Israel from 1682 to 1831. The cemetery was larger than its present confines. "If, indeed, the Shearith Israel plot extended underneath the park," Mr. Breslau said, "we would strenuously object" to the excavation and placement there of Shaft 30B.
A happy ending, at least for Lincoln Center, can be recorded in the case of Shaft 24B. It was planned at 62d Street and Amsterdam Avenue, near Damrosch Park, where the Big Apple Circus is staged. Lincoln Center executives feared a logistical "nightmare," recalled Jerry A. Hastings, the assistant director of operations. But they were resigned to it and did not openly oppose environmental officials. "We told them it would be a hassle and that we'd rather it wasn't there but that we'd work with them," Mr. Hastings said.
A month later, he said, it was learned that the city had moved the site two blocks south, to 60th Street. "We were tickled pink," Mr. Hastings said, "and closed the file."

HEADLINE: Conversion of Methane Gas To Energy Planned at Landfill

BYLINE: By TOM CALLAHAN 

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE

 BODY:
UNTIL 1984 the Croton Landfill was the dumping site of much of Westchester's garbage and solid waste. But beginning in 1996, what might once have been considered science fiction will become reality. A county program, now in the design stage, will convert the methane gas produced at the landfill into a source of revenue.
The program will use existing technology to capture the methane, a gas that is produced by the decomposition of vegetable matter, purify it and convert it to electricity and compressed natural gas. Methane at the landfill is now burned off and must be eliminated to prevent the possibility of fire. The county is also studying the possibility of taking another landfill gas, carbon dioxide, and capturing it for commercial sale. 
 The electricity generated by the program will be used at the 125-acre Croton Point Park, which is next to the landfill. The county spends $250,000 a year for electricity to light the park and heat buildings. Any excess electricity produced will be sold to Con Edison, which under state law must purchase it. The compressed natural gas will be used in the county's natural-gas-powered vehicles, with any surplus being sold to pipeline operators.
The gas-conversion system, including machinery and a building to house it, will cost the county $6.9 million. This will come from savings in the budget for capping the landfill. Once closed, a landfill must be capped, or covered and ventilated, to prevent buried waste and gases from leaking into the environment. That part of the job will be completed this fall.
 
Other Sites in Operation
 But even after capping, the landfill will continue to produce methane gas until the year 2031, according to preliminary estimates prepared by the county. Once in operation, the gas-conversion plant will pay back its capital costs in 4.3 years. During the 35-year life of the program, the county estimates electricity savings at the park and net earnings of $19.2 million.
"This program will work for everyone," said Anthony P. Trelewicz, Commissioner of the county's Department of Environmental Facilities based here. "The first benefit is to the environment. By creating electricity, methane gas is not released or burned into the atmosphere. The second benefit is to the taxpayers of Westchester. The money saved on electricity will reduce the park budget. The electricity and natural gas sold will be a revenue." In large concentrations, methane is regarded as an environmental pollutant.
Mr. Trelewicz said methane is being converted to electricity at landfills in Macedon and Oceanside, both in New York State, and in New Milford. Methane is being turned into natural gas in Wisconsin Rapids, Wisc., and Cleveland bottles and sells carbon dioxide from its landfill.
"The gas-extraction system already exists underground at the Croton Landfill," the Commissioner added. "The pipes and wells underground are usable and were put there as part of the capping of the landfill. When you cap a landfill, you must put in that underground system to vent the gases or there could be an explosion and fire."
Methane is now burned off at the Railroad 1 Landfill in Croton, an adjacent 20-acre municipal site, which was capped in 1986 and will be included in the gas-extraction program. While burning methane is considered safe for the environment, county officials feel that this program is a better way to eliminate the gas and provide income.
 
Contract to Be Awarded
 Within the next few months, the county will award a consulting contract for a design study, a job that Mr. Trelewicz estimates will take six to nine months. In addition to providing construction specifications, the study will determine how much methane the landfill can produce and how long it will last. When the study is completed, bids will be sought for the project.
As proposed, the gas-collection system will capture 1.5 million cubic feet of gas a day. One-third of the gas will be used to power a 740-kilowatt generator in a sound-deadening building, which will produce power for the park. The remaining gas will be used to create the natural gas equivalent of 700 gallons of gasoline a day. The building will be large enough, though, to allow a switch to total-electric production if desired.
"The compressed-natural-gas conversion is a pilot program that will last for one year," Mr. Trelewicz said. "During this time, we will study the market for compressed natural gas in the county. If we want to sell it, we have to make sure there are customers out there besides us. One possible customer would be the municipalities. But if we can't sell it, there is no use producing it. In that case, we can convert the plant to total generation of electricity."
The county is now operating five natural-gas-powered vehicles in a pilot program to test the economic and environmental benefits. The vehicles travel 150 to 200 miles on two cylinders of natural gas, approximately the equivalent of 16 gallons of gasoline. The county purchases fuel for these cars under a contract with Con Edison, which has a fueling station in Rye.
Mr. Trelewicz expects the gas-conversion plant to be operating by 1996. "This is an exciting project," he said. "We build waste-treatment plants, but this is different. We are using the byproducts of what was once waste to make fuel and energy."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1427 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary, May 8-13

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Inflation? It's Like Prosperity, Just Around the Corner
An old New Yorker cartoon pictured an eager homeowner, rake in hand, rushing to nab the first autumn leaf to invade his lawn. Those who keep crying "inflation" seem equally zealous, for the statistics just keep telling a different story. Look at last week's numbers: consumer prices rose just 0.1 percent in April, while at the producer level inflation vanished altogether, with prices actually falling 0.1 percent. In addition, retail sales were down for the month, and initial jobless claims took an unexpected turn upward. But is all this going to stop the Federal Reserve from raising rates yet again when it meets on Tuesday? The financial markets don't seem to think so, for even though bond rates fell a bit and stocks rose on the price reports, there was no euphoria. The Fed, economists keep saying, is watching for inflation way out on the horizon. Those with a short view probably wouldn't even dig the rake out of the garage until the lawn was covered with leaves. 

Untimely Death of a 'Pioneer'
Here's how friends and colleagues described Wardell R. Lazard: "A class act." "A pioneer" for building a top minority-owned investment firm. A black man "thriving" in a difficult environment. A man who "didn't have the time" for drugs. Yet last week, at the age of 44, Mr. Lazard, head of W. R. Lazard & Company, died in a Pittsburgh hotel, apparently of a drug overdose. The shock left people groping for answers. "Was he under strain?" asked one. "Absolutely" -- but nothing to explain this. The firm was under investigation by the Manhattan District Attorney, but that did not seem to be a factor. But it soon turned out that three years ago Mr. Lazard nearly died, apparently of a drug overdose, and was arrested for cocaine possession.
 
Just Another Littered Highway
If you haven't caught up with the Internet, you've blown a chance to see its "good old days." For a time, innocent tekkies roamed the electronic byways. By unwritten decree, there was nothing ugly. Those days vanished quickly. Among many recent abuses, two lawyers flooded the Internet with blatant ads. Purists rained digital abuse on them, but did they really think a million-lane highway could stay litter-free?
 
Real Lawmakers Don't Do Lunch
Yes, voters supposedly vote their pocketbooks, but when the voters are on the Senate floor (with the world watching) they're likely to do the opposite. Last week the Senate swept the cakes and ale right off their own lunch tables, voting to ban gifts and meals from lobbyists. The House passed a similar bill, so all that remains is for the two sides to thrash out the details in the back room -- buying their own beer and peanuts, of course.

A 'Safer' Cigarette, Unlit
In the early 1960's, documents now show, tobacco companies found ways to make "safer" cigarettes. But they apparently anticipated the obvious question, "Safer than what?" Because they've never admitted smoking's hazards, they couldn't come out and call cigarettes safer without sounding, well, a bit confused. Safer cigarettes never appeared.
 
Cookies for Later? A Bit More
At a corporate bash, the excess might prompt muttered comments like "I'd rather have a bit extra in my paycheck." If Kathleen Tompkins ever muttered this, she didn't mutter for long. Ms. Tompkins, a former party planner at Salomon Brothers, admitted last week that when she submitted bills, she padded things a bit -- to the tune of $1.1 million.
 
COMPANIES
 
G.M. Pays Some Pension Dues
General Motors has one distinction it would just as soon get rid of: of the additional $50 billion or so that American companies need to sock away to pay tomorrow's pensions, a huge chunk -- roughly $20 billion -- has G.M.'s name on it. So last week G.M. said it would chip in $10 billion in cash and stock to cut away at that shortfall. But there's more to this than G.M. simply putting money aside when times are good. Word has it that it wants to sell Electronic Data Systems, which is worth far more than when G.M. bought it a decade ago, and by giving roughly $6 billion worth of E.D.S.-linked stock to its pension plan, it might avoid having to pay some hefty capital-gains taxes.
 
The Inside Track at Time Warner
As a financial adviser to Time Warner, Oded Aboodi has been privy to a lot of inside stuff, and the S.E.C. says he profited handsomely from that information. In 1991, an S.E.C. complaint says, companies controlled by Mr. Aboodi sold $2.3 million worth of Time Warner common stock and bought preferred shares -- on the same day he'd learned of a stock plan that would batter the common and lift the preferred. Mr. Aboodi neither admits nor denies the charges, but last week he agreed to pay close to $1 million to settle the charges. And as of now, he is still a Time Warner adviser -- and a close associate of its chairman, Gerald Levin.
 
All the World's a CD
What next? The works of Shakespeare on the head of a pin? Of course, you doubters -- but who's Shakespeare, anyway? Did he write any software? Did he advance computer technology in any way? But there's no time for that. Onward and inward in the race to make things tinier and tinier and tinier. Here's the latest: I.B.M. unveiled a new technology last week that allows digital disks to hold more than 10 times as much data as they do now. The laser that "reads" a disk, it seems, can be made to read different levels of a multilayered, transparent disk. The result: several movies, or a million pages of text, on a single CD. Tomorrow's unemployed: bookshelf makers.
 
Valdez Skipper Tells His Story
Exxon has said it would never have put Joseph Hazelwood in command of the Exxon Valdez if it had known of his drinking problem. But last week, in his first public testimony since the 1989 Alaska oil spill, Mr. Hazelwood told a different story. He said he'd been treated for alcohol abuse in 1985 and Exxon was well aware of this when it put him squarely between the tanker's oil and the fragile world outside. Not only that, but he said he'd lied to the Coast Guard when he said he'd only had a beer before the spill; it was actually a fair amount of vodka. The stakes are big in deciding who's at fault: fishermen and others are seeking billions in a civil suit.
 
Real War Over 'Plastic' History
Virginia is so lush with real history that the idea of importing a huge load of freeze-dried history seems comparable to bringing sun lamps to a June picnic. Yet that's what Disney wants to do at a 3,000-acre Disney's America theme park, complete with faux Civil War village. For Virginia, the economics are clear: 19,000 jobs and six million big-spending visitors a year. But last week a group of historians and authors lambasted the idea, with David McCullough, of "Truman" fame, calling it "almost sacrilege" to "replace what we have with plastic, contrived history." Clearly, a new civil war is brewing.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
A Saudi Contract for AT&T
President Clinton may draw fire on some foreign-policy fronts, but he's effective in snagging business abroad for American companies. In February his lobbying helped Boeing and McDonnell Douglas get a big Saudi aircraft contract. And last week, again after a barrage of Administration lobbying, the Saudis gave AT&T a $4 billion contract to modernize Saudi Arabia's entire telecommunications system. We're still getting dividends, it seems, for taking on Iraq a few years ago.
 
Bribery at Honda (Updated)
Federal investigators recently charged 13 former American Honda employees with taking $10 million in bribes in return for giving dealers hard-to-get cars. Honda had cooperated, starting in October, but it now turns out that it already knew for some time that things were amiss. A Honda lawyer said last week that the company got on the case back in 1991 and started its own inquiry. More than historical truth is at stake: some dealers have sued Honda, saying the bribes hurt them. This disclosure could color those suits.
 
German Rates Keep Falling
German interest rates are heading steadily downward now that inflation has been tamed. Last week the German central bank sent key rates to five-year lows -- mainly, it seems, out of concern for currency volatility. The cuts could help push Europe out of recession, but there was also the sense that it is now the Fed's turn to raise rates again to strengthen the dollar. Clearly, the gods of global economics can't please all the people all the time.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Readers' Mail: Worries About Bonds

BYLINE: By Carole Gould 

 BODY:
Question: My husband and I are retired schoolteachers in our 70's. We own 15 different California-insured municipal bonds that mature in 10 to 20 years. We bought them for the income and plan to hold them to maturity. You have warned that the value of bonds drops as interest rates rise. Can you tell us about a better investment?
Answer: Because you plan to hold the bonds to term, your principal amount will remain intact in spite of rising rates. But what you have is not the best deal because your income could be improving, said Harold R. Evensky, an investment adviser in Coral Gables, Fla. 
 One solution is to include shorter-term issues in your investments. To stay in munis, you could divide your portfolio, for example, among the Vanguard Short- , Limited- and Intermediate-Term Municipal Bond Funds, which strive, respectively, for average portfolio maturities of 1 to 2 years, 2 to 5 years, and 7 to 12 years. Yields on the shorter-term funds rise more quickly, and their share prices are less volatile. In exchange for the additional safety, however, you get a lower yield than in the Intermediate-Term Fund.
Mr. Evensky also advises that a portion of the portfolio be kept in equities because the value of bond income will be eroded by inflation over time. A simple, low-cost solution, he said, is to invest 20 to 40 percent of your portfolio in the Vanguard Index 500, which owns all the stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Among diversified funds, he likes T. Rowe Price Equity-Income, Federated Stock, and Benham Income and Growth.
Q: On Sundays, The New York Times publishes three-year total return figures for funds. Why? Showcasing this particular period makes no sense because it does not include a substantial downturn in the stock market. Year-to-date or one-year figures would be more helpful.
A: The Times believes that three years is the shortest time period providing a reasonable view of how funds perform in various markets, even though it is true that the stock market has been rising for most of the last three years. Because so many funds are new, using five years as the benchmark would exclude more than half of the 3,800 funds in the data base provided by Morningstar Inc. But The Times does provide five-year figures in its quarterly mutual fund report.
No single figure, however, can provide a total picture. For example, the Vanguard S.& P. 500 fund, a proxy for the stock market, gained 14.5 percent a year, on average, for the decade ended April 30. But for the three years ended then, the fund returned 9.3 percent a year, on average, which is much closer to historical stock market returns.
The Times does publish shorter-term results for all funds, with the one-year return on Wednesdays, three-month on Thursdays and year-to-date on Fridays. But shorter-term results do not provide a complete picture. The average diversified United States stock fund lost 3.4 percent in the first quarter of 1994, but that is not representative of longer-term results.
Q: I own mutual funds in an individual retirement account to which I have contributed since 1982. In the prospectus for a new fund I recently bought for the account, I stumbled onto something called Form 8606 (Nondeductible I.R.A. Contributions), which is supposed to be filed annually with the Internal Revenue Service. Please advise.
A: Form 8606 is a record-keeping form that tracks the portion of your nondeductible I.R.A. contributions. When you start taking money from the account, the percentage of these contributions will be applied to the distribution, and you won't be taxed again on that amount.
A $50 penalty applies for every year in which Form 8606 is not filed. Filing amended returns for the relevant years, however, is probably not necessary, said Fred W. Haas, a tax partner with Coopers & Lybrand in Baltimore. Based on informal talks with the I.R.S., he suggests that the penalty may be waived or overlooked if you file Form 8606 with your next tax return and attach a schedule showing the annual buildup year by year.
Q: In a column on taxes, you advised using the "specific identification" method when shares are sold. To do so, the I.R.S. requires that the fund company identify the specific shares on the sale confirmation, which the Vanguard Group refuses to do.
A: A spokesman for Vanguard confirmed that the account statement issued after a redemption request does not list specific lots of shares sold. The company will only issue an acknowledgment that it has received an investor's written specific-share sale request, and keep a copy of that letter in its files. People who want that acknowledgment should send a detailed letter and keep their own careful records of the sale, although "taking these steps may not assure satisfaction of I.R.S. requirements," the Vanguard spokesman said.
Daniel P. Wiener, who edits the Boston-based Independent Adviser for Vanguard Investors, says he has used the specific-identification method for years. He follows up a sale with a letter to Vanguard detailing the transaction, including the name of the representative to whom he spoke and the transaction number. He hasn't run into trouble. "My advice is to use the method until told otherwise by the I.R.S," Mr. Wiener said.

HEADLINE: A Government-Industry Environmental Partnership

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Michael Silverstein completely missed what is happening in Washington and around the country to promote the environmental industry. A cluster of major policy initiatives to protect the global environment and promote this vital industry is in the final stage of development and many programs are already being implemented by the Clinton-Gore team. 
 In the last 10 months, our organization, the Environmental Business Council of the United States, has worked closely with members of the Administration and Congress to increase Government interest and participation in the environmental industry, including a focus on improved competitiveness in foreign markets. One result of the initiative is, in part, a program announced in November 1993 by the Administration to develop a cooperative export program with the environmental industry.
Beyond this initiative, the Administration has under development a comprehensive strategy to increase exports of environmental products and services and to develop innovative environmental technologies. Other important elements include:
* A new national export policy developed by the Commerce Department, the Environmental Protection Agency, the Energy Department and other agencies as members of the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee announced in September 1993.
* The E.P.A.'s environmental technologies initiative, which will aggressively promote new American technologies in a long-term, well-financed program.
* A program coordinated by the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy to promote development of environmental technologies for sustainable development.
* A reorganization of foreign aid programs, coordinated by the State Department and the United States Agency for International Development, to emphasize environmentally sustainable development.
* Military conversion financing for hazardous-waste site cleanups and for technology development.
* Energy Department financing for technology in areas that include energy efficiency, renewable energy sources and transfer and commercialization of technologies developed in the Energy Department system.
In addition, significant legislative initiatives to implement elements of the strategy and to support the development of environmental technology and business are pending in Congress with the support of the Administration. All these initiatives offer the potential to advance the environmental industry, created by the rigorous United States environmental laws, toward leadership in the global movement for sustainable development.
The environmental industry has been challenged by the Clinton Administration to cooperate and improve its market opportunity. It can either participate or stand by and let the process proceed. A powerful partnership for global environmental protection and job creation is under way.
 
DONALD L. CONNORS
Needham, Mass., April 26
1
The writer is president of the Environmental Business Council of the United States, a private trade group.

HEADLINE: The Lesson: M.B.A.'s and Engineers Need Each Other

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

DATELINE: STANFORD, Calif.

 BODY:
IT was not a major project, just an effort to design new kinds of bicycle lights. But it says a lot about how graduate schools are trying to respond to the needs of American manufacturers.
The lights were designed last fall by teams of graduate students from Stanford University's schools of business and engineering in an innovative joint project. Afterward the students -- two engineers and two business students on each team -- built them in a machine shop on campus. The main goal of the project: to break down the barriers between engineers and business people, barriers that lead engineers to call their opposites "bean counters" and business types to call engineers "propellerheads." 
 "What we hoped to do in the class," said Professor William Lovejoy, who helps teach the class, "was to develop in M.B.A.'s an appreciation for the process of design and manufacture and to develop in engineers an appreciation of the constraints placed on design and manufacture by a competitive economic context."
Across the country, schools of business and engineering at universities like Stanford, Michigan and Carnegie Mellon are devising joint programs to enable their graduates to straddle the fields of business and technology. The hope is that the students will go on to help overcome the divisions between specialties that make American manufacturers less competitive.
Some universities are going further. This fall Carnegie Mellon will begin a master's program involving not only the engineering and business schools but also the schools of computer science and public policy.
One key goal is to train instructors to staff the 100 or so manufacturing assistance centers the Clinton Administration is planning to establish across the country. The centers are an effort to help smaller companies that are falling behind on technology and operating techniques. Small companies are considered important because they make up the supply base for big corporations, and the price and quality of the components they produce are reflected in the cars, appliances and airplanes the bigger companies assemble.
"We want to bring modern management and technical skills to small business," said Robert M. White, head of the electrical and computer engineering department at Carnegie Mellon in Pittsburgh. Professor White, who was Under Secretary of Commerce for technology in the Bush Administration, said that to help manufacturers at a practical level, the centers will need people who understand computer networks and the way the political system works, as well as business and engineering.
"This is a customer-driven program," said Robert Sullivan, dean of Carnegie Mellon's business school. "The area between Pittsburgh and Detroit has the greatest density of small manufacturers of anywhere in the country."
EACH joint program is different, and most are in their infancy. Some, like Carnegie Mellon's, grant just one degree, in this case a master of manufacturing. Others, like Stanford, award two -- an M.B.A. and a master of manufacturing systems.
"We developed the program to respond to the fact that American industry was not competitive in time-to-market, functionality and quality," said Charles A. Holloway, a Stanford business school professor who coordinates joint programs with the engineering school. "We looked at the product development process and found that it was very disjointed in many companies. People really did wrap designs around a rock and toss them over a wall into the next department."
One centerpiece of Stanford's program to break down those walls is the course it calls Integrated Design for Manufacturing and Marketability. The course is open to M.B.A. and engineering-only students, as well as those in the dual-degree program.
Each year a different, fairly simple product is chosen. In addition to bicycle lights, previous groups of students have designed and built can crushers and juicers.
The course simulates real life by having each team do a market survey to determine what product attributes are most valued by customers and what they would be willing to pay. Based on that information, the teams begin to make design decisions. For example, will a more sophisticated device at a higher price be more profitable than a simple, low-priced one that would sell in higher volume?
Later, each team's finished product is displayed to a group of the potential customers originally surveyed, and those customers are then asked which, if any, they would buy. A figure for the sales of each product can then be projected. Subtracting the cost of goods sold produces a bottom line for each product. The final grade is determined largely by that bottom line.
Going into a shop is a new experience for the students, business and engineering alike, Professor Holloway said. "It is difficult to impress them with anything to do with computers because they have grown up with them, but they haven't built stuff."
In addition to teaching students how to work in teams, Professor Holloway said, the course is intended to show them that the product development process is a complete cycle, not a series of unconnected steps. "You show them that the whole cycle has to be managed, from research to design, manufacturing, distribution, service and recycling. When you are thinking about distribution, you should be thinking about design, because design can help with distribution."
Kelli Kowaleski is a joint-degree candidate at Stanford who expects to graduate in June and return to Digital Equipment, where she worked for five years as a manufacturing engineer. She said that because the target market was the Stanford campus itself, her group decided to design the battery-powered light for simple functionality and low cost.
"We did really well in the customer survey and took third place in market share" out of 10 teams, she said. "We did not do as well in the judging on features -- it wasn't the brightest light, for instance -- but we knew that from the start." Higher-priced lights included those with both high and low beams and light-emitting diode displays.
Ms. Kowaleski said she anticipates that the principal value of the joint degree will be that "I can speak both languages," and she added: "You find situations where a manager has great people skills but makes bad decisions because he does not understand the engineering involved. I should be able to talk to him in terms he understands."
TOM LINEBARGER, who graduated from the Stanford program in December, is already busy translating. He works at Cummins Engine in Columbus, Ind., where he is officially on the staff of the group vice president for worldwide operations.
"I'm on loan to advanced manufacturing -- we do prototypes and low-volume manufacturing before products transfer to high-volume manufacturing," he said. "It's partly technical and partly business. I lead teams that try to solve problems and worry about the financial consequence."
He said he anticipates assignments in other areas of the company while he learns the engine business. He said that he had worked before in venture capital and entered the Stanford joint program "because I wanted to know how things actually work."
"That way," he added, "if I wind up as a C.E.O., I'll know how the business works."
Mr. Linebarger said the main value of Stanford's joint program was that it allowed him to straddle the worlds of business and technology. "I still keep some of the B-school materials in my files for reference," he said. "And I use the tech stuff every day."
One problem with the new business-technical programs, educators say, is that the graduates are more broadly trained than those of the past and do not fit well in traditional entry-level jobs in industry. They fear that the benefits of the program will be lost in narrowly defined jobs and the graduates will quickly become frustrated.
"That's absolutely a problem," said Craig Marks, co-director of the University of Michigan's Joint Manufacturing Initiative. "These students need a different career path."
He said the university is forming industry advisory boards and briefing them on the programs in an effort to persuade companies to redesign starting jobs for the graduates of the joint programs. This works well with smaller companies where the chief executive is on the advisory board and can make decisions on how to structure jobs.
Bigger corporations are more difficult, Mr. Marks said. "Typically, the vice president for manufacturing is on the board," he said. "The guy I want to reach is the plant manager, but he is three layers down."
"Some companies are changing to accommodate these graduates," Professor Holloway said. "Digital created a set of slots that allows people to cut across traditional disciplines." Others, he said, still have the narrowly focused jobs but move the more broadly trained executives rapidly into new positions. The Cummins tactic of keeping Mr. Linebarger on staff while he learns line operations is one such approach, he said.

HEADLINE: The World;
Asia's Having One Huge Nicotine Fit

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand

 BODY:
THE Marlboro Man has found greener pastures.
The cigarette-hawking cowboy may be under siege back home in the United States from lawmakers and health advocates determined to put him out of business, but half a world away in Asia he is prospering, his craggy all-American mug slapped up on billboards and flickering across television screens. And Marlboro cigarettes have never been more popular on the continent that is home to 60 percent of the world's population. 
 For the world's cigarette-makers, Asia is the future. And it is probably their savior.
Industry critics who hope that the multinational tobacco companies are headed for extinction owe themselves a stroll down the tobacco-scented streets of almost any city in Asia. Almost everywhere here the air is thick with the swirling gray haze of cigarette smoke, the evidence of a booming Asian growth market that promises vast profits for the tobacco industry and a death toll measured in the tens of millions.
At lunchtime in Seoul, throngs of fashionably dressed young Korean women gather in a fast-food restaurant to enjoy a last cigarette before returning to work, a scene that draws distressed stares from older Koreans who remember a time when it would have been scandalous for women from respectable homes to smoke.
In Hong Kong, shoppers flock into the Salem Attitudes boutique, picking from among the racks of trendy sports clothes stamped with the logo of Salem cigarettes. In Phnom Penh, the war-shattered capital of Cambodia, visitors leaving an audience with King Sihanouk are greeted with a giant billboard planted across the street from his ornate gold-roofed palace. It advertises Lucky Strikes.
According to tobacco industry projections cited by the World Health Organization, the Asian cigarette market should grow by more than a third during the 1990's, with much of the bounty going to multinational tobacco giants eager for an alternative to the shrinking market in the United States.
American cigarette sales are expected to decline by about 15 percent by the end of the decade, a reflection of the move to ban smoking in most public places in the United States. And sales in Western Europe and other industrialized countries are also expected to drop.
But no matter how bad the news is in the West, the tobacco companies can find comfort in Asia and throughout the third world, markets so huge and so promising that they make the once all-important American market seem insignificant. Beyond Asia, cigarette consumption is also expected to grow in Africa, Latin America, Eastern Europe and in the nations of the former Soviet Union.
 
Status
 Smoking is not only tolerated in most of Asia, it is still fashionable. And for millions of smokers here, nothing confers greater status than a pack of American or European-brand cigarettes. No gift is more appreciated in Vietnam than British-made "555" cigarettes. In China, the choice is Marlboro. Among the gentry of Thailand, it is Dunhill.
Status appears to matter far more than taste. "There is not a great deal of evidence to suggest that smokers can taste any difference between the more expensive foreign brands and the indigenous cigarettes," said Simon Chapman, a specialist in community medicine at the University of Sydney, in Australia. "The difference appears to be in the packaging, the advertising."
He said that researchers had been unable to determine whether the foreign tobacco companies had adjusted the levels of tar, nicotine and other chemicals for cigarettes sold in the Asian market. "The tobacco industry fights tooth and nail to keep consumers away from that kind of information," he said.
Most governments in Asia have launched anti-smoking campaigns, but their efforts tend to be overwhelmed by the Madison Avenue glitz unleashed by the cigarette giants. Several Asian nations have banned cigarette advertising on television and radio in recent years, but the tobacco companies often find ways around the bans through indirect promotions that skirt the law -- sports events, glossy advertisements for clothing brands or travel agencies that bear that name and logo of a cigarette brand.
With 1.2 billion people and the world's fastest-growing economy, China is the most coveted target of the multinational tobacco companies. Cigarette consumption, calculated as the number of cigarettes smoked per adult, has increased by 7 percent each year over the last decade in China. There are 300 million smokers in China, more people than the entire population of the United States, and they buy 1.6 trillion cigarettes a year.
Competing in many cases with domestically produced brands, the multinational tobacco companies are moving quickly to get their cigarettes into China and emerging markets in the rest of the developing world. Their campaign has been bolstered by the efforts of American Government trade negotiators to force open tobacco markets overseas. Since the mid-1980's, Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and Thailand have all succumbed to pressure from Washington and allowed the sale of foreign-brand cigarettes. Foreign cigarettes, shut out of Japan in 1980, now make up nearly 20 percent of the market.
Anti-smoking groups in Asia, often critical of the Bush Administration for its aggressive pursuit of the tobacco industry's agenda abroad, say it is too early to judge the Clinton Administration on the issue.
R. J. Reynolds Tobacco has manufactured its Camel and Winston cigarettes in Chinese factories since the late 1980's. Last year the American company also opened plants in Poland and Turkey and took stakes in two state-owned tobacco companies in Ukraine. "Worldwide, hundreds of millions of smokers prefer American-blend cigarettes," James W. Johnston, chairman of Reynolds Tobacco Worldwide, wrote in his company's 1993 annual report. "Today, Reynolds has access to 90 percent of the world's markets; a decade ago, only 40 percent. Opportunities have never been better."
Last year, Philip Morris, the company behind the Marlboro Man, signed an agreement with the government-controlled China National Tobacco Corporation to make Marlboros and other Philip Morris brands in China. The company's foreign markets grew last year by more than 16 percent, with foreign operating profits up nearly 17 percent. Operating profits in the domestic American market fell by nearly half.
Physicians say the health implications of the tobacco boom in Asia are nothing less than terrifying, and there are frequent comparisons here to the Opium War of the mid-19th Century, when the British went to war to force the Chinese to accept imports of a dangerous, addictive drug -- opium, an important cash crop for British merchants.
Richard Peto, an Oxford University epidemiologist, has estimated that because of increasing tobacco consumption in Asia, the annual worldwide death toll from tobacco-related illnesses will more than triple over the next two or three decades, from about 3 million a year to 10 million a year, a fifth of them in China. His calculations suggest that 50 million Chinese children alive today will eventually die from diseases linked to cigarette smoking.
"If you look at the number of deaths, the tobacco problem in Asia is going to dwarf tuberculosis, it's going to dwarf malaria and it's going to dwarf AIDS, yet it's being totally ignored," said Judith Mackay, a British physician who is a consultant to the Chinese Government in developing an anti-smoking program.
The explosion of the Asian tobacco market is a result both of the increasing prosperity of large Asian nations -- suddenly, tens of millions of Asians can afford cigarettes, once a craved luxury -- and a shift in social customs. In many Asian countries, smoking was once taboo for women. Now, it is seen as a sign of their emancipation.
In explaining the boom in tobacco sales here, physicians and researchers also point to the cigarette companies' multimillion-dollar marketing campaigns.
"Just four or five years ago, there wasn't a tobacco advertisement to be seen anywhere in Shanghai," said Dr. Mackay during a recent visit to China's most populous city. "Now, just as soon as you land at the airport, it's a bombardment, an absolute visual disgrace, with signs everywhere for Marlboro, Kent, all of them. On the streets, they've got a huge series of neon signs and billboards. Almost every telephone kiosk has a cigarette advertisement."
 
Targeting Women
 Much of the advertising is aimed at women, who smoke in far smaller numbers than Asian men, and at the young, and the ads often depict young, striking, stylishly dressed Asian models set in scenes of Western-style elegance. Some tobacco companies play up their American roots. Winston is advertised in the Philippines, a former American colony in which American culture still dominates, as "the Taste of the U.S.A."
Rosmarie Erben, Asian regional adviser for health promotion for the World Health Organization, said that "the tobacco industry is addressing women in a very aggressive way. There are still many cultures that do not accept the concept of women smoking, but that is changing."
Dr. Erben said that domestic tobacco companies in Asia have had to step up their own advertising targeted at women to meet the threat from foreign competitors. She said she was startled when she learned earlier this year that a Philippine cigarette maker was distributing free wall calendars decorated with a portrait of the Virgin Mary, an image of conspicuous power in a nation that is devoutly Roman Catholic, set above the logos of the company's cigarette brands. "I had never seen anything like it before," said Dr. Erben, who is based in Manila. "They were trying to link the icon motif to tobacco, to make Philippine women comfortable with the idea of smoking."
The global tobacco companies insist that they are not attempting to recruit new smokers in Asia. They say they are only trying to encourage smokers to switch to foreign brands. "The same number of cigarettes are consumed whether American cigarettes are present or not," said Elizabeth Cho, a spokeswoman for Philip Morris. "Whatever one may feel about the smoking and health controversy, the presence or absence of American cigarettes is not a cigarette consumption factor."
But some of the industry's advertising in Asia would suggest otherwise. Only about 2 percent of women in Hong Kong under the age of 40 smoke, so logic would suggest that a tobacco company interested only in encouraging smokers to switch brands would not introduce a cigarette there marketed specifically for women -- it is just too small a market. Yet that is precisely what Philip Morris did in Hong Kong several years ago by introducing Virginia Slims. As in the United States, the cigarettes were sold in Hong Kong with an advertising slogan that linked smoking to the liberation of women: "You've come a long way, baby."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Russia's New Dictatorship of Crime

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
WITHIN days of the murder of one member of Parliament in a gangland hit, another legislator kills a mobster in a shootout.
Two days later, the deputy head of the Interior Ministry's Criminal Investigation Department, Maj. Gen. Igor Shilov, and his son, a Police Academy cadet, are charged with corruption and possession of a large quantity of weapons. 
 A Mercedes is stopped in St. Petersburg for a towing violation; there are seven bodies inside, neatly wrapped in tarpaulins, the remains of a gang of racketeers.
The collapse of totalitarian order in Russia was bound to foster crime. But few foresaw crime this pervasive and organized, forging strong ties with a weak Government and raising the prospect of a mob-dominated superpower, a Sicily spread over two continents.
James Woolsey, the director of the C.I.A., last month described the potential for a "criminal politburo" that will be "a powerful and resourceful adversary."
Mr. Woolsey's concerns are widely shared. Rampant gangsterism in Russia, untrammeled by a wobbly central Government and poorly paid police, undermines support for economic and democratic reform. Domestically, it risks a political backlash favoring nationalist-populists like Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky. Internationally, connections between the Russian mob and Italian and Colombian drug organizations, and the illegal sale of arms and even nuclear material, are alarming Russia's friends. Helsinki, New York, London, Munich and Tel Aviv already feel the impact of Russian criminal rivalries.
For many Russians living in ungenteel poverty, the sudden, visible wealth of the criminal class is an affront. The mobsters' brazen style could make a Bolshevik blush. Like the evil capitalist manikins of Communist propaganda come to life, the mobsters are seen by many Russians as proof of the pernicious influence of the libertine West.
Combining the corrupt habits of the Communist Party with Hollywood epics like "The Godfather," readily available on pirated, dubbed videos, Russian mobsters and their musclemen swagger through every Russian city like crude parodies of Jimmy Cagney.
While their lady friends have developed their own tarty fashion -- platinum hair, spandex microminis, Lycra leggings and an infinitely bored expression as cigarette smoke curls across the casino or nightclub table -- the mobsters have oddly Germanic predilections. They favor Hugo Boss suits and dark-blue Mercedes sedans, most of them stolen in Germany and driven onto former Soviet army bases, where they are "impounded" and shipped to Russia for a fee. (As Russian troops prepare to leave Germany, however, it may not be accidental that Lincolns are becoming more popular.)
Filled with muscular bodyguards smoking Marlboros, these glossy limousines swerve through the jumble of poky, rusty Zhigulis and Moskviches, often claiming the center lane reserved, in the old days, for the Kremlin elite. It's not uncommon to find two such mobmobiles smashed together in the center lane, a form of justice, many Muscovites feel, more effective than that available from their widely corrupted Government.
 
Crossing the Line
 In the transition to private property and a market economy, the laws have lagged behind the new ways of doing both business and crime. There is no conspiracy law, so mob bosses are hard to prosecute. Meager corporation laws don't yet cover responsibility for frauds, false bankruptcies or the misuse of credits. The line between business and crime is simply fuzzier here, while the inability to get redress through the courts leads to more crime, as businesses hire muscle to enforce deals otherwise unenforceable.
To a large degree, Russian mobsters feed off the corpse of the centralized state, where enormous riches and resources are available to anyone strong or rich enough to claim them. They deal in drugs, prostitutes, oil, minerals, aluminum, titanium, jewels, gold, arms and money-laundering across the former empire's still porous borders.
There are some 5,600 separate gangs, says Gen. Gennadi F. Chebotarev, First Deputy of the Interior Ministry's Organized Crime Department, with about 20 members each. Many are merely protection rackets, but they are consolidating and specializing. Some 160 of them are already large, financially sophisticated organizations with international connections, operating in the United States and most of Europe.
The Interior Ministry estimates that organized crime controlled about a third of all the turnover in goods and services in 1993, most of which was unregulated and untaxed. So crime is not only undermining new institutions, like stock exchanges, it is also raising prices, which include extortion and security costs.
Because crime lives off the market economy, the mafia has become associated in many minds with capitalism and democracy. Given the collapse of the old socialist morality -- steal from the state, but discreetly -- the vulgar mob style has tainted the very idea of private business. Its sheer Westernness feeds the nationalist tone now heard from every politician as it stokes the anger on which the ultranationalist right rides.
Politics aside, this is not just Russia's problem. To try to limit the foreign impact of organized crime, governments are working more closely with the Russian police; the Germans, Italians and Poles have offices here. While the F.B.I. says it will open one soon, its closest officer is still based in Berlin.
Enormous sums of mob money are moving abroad. Guy M. Dunn, a Russia analyst at Control Risks Group Limited in London, which advises Western businesses on security, suggests that most of the 2,000 new commercial banks licensed in Moscow in the last 18 months are fronts to transfer money. General Chebotarev thinks some $40 billion has been transferred abroad since 1992 and continues at $1 billion a month.
The main destinations are banks in Switzerland, Hungary, Belgium, Cyprus and Greece, where there are growing Russian emigre communities. Mr. Dunn said a major part of the luxury property market in the city is being bought by Russians with suitcases of cash for prices up to $3 million.
Last month, at the Moscow airport, customs was stalled for an hour while officials counted out $1 million in cash being taken to London by a passenger. Canadian officials say a popular means of illegal money transfer has been to buy hundreds of Air Canada tickets for cash, take them to Canada in a suitcase and then redeem them.
Organized crime is not merely imitative, but deeply rooted in the past. Stephen Handelman, who is writing a book on Russian crime, noted in the journal "Foreign Affairs" that the traditional Caucasus gang has strict rituals and codes that became a model for the Bolsheviks. Stalin used gangsters to rob banks for the revolution; some later joined the secret police. Under Brezhnev, a widespread black market flourished. The close ties between corrupt bureaucrats and black marketeers provided a model for today's pervasive corruption.
The sudden rise of the market has been an ideal way to launder all that money. "This is organized crime of a quite sophisticated nature," says Mr. Dunn. "The country's up for sale and the people with the most money are the criminals."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1241 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Some Indians See a Gamble With Future In Casinos

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON 

 BODY:
THE rise of gambling halls on Indian reservations from California to Connecticut has added a layer of confusion to what Americans think about the Indians among them, but to the tribes themselves, it has focused attention on a centuries-old question: survival.
Among the clan mothers and other traditional leaders of the Iroquois in Western New York, and among Oglala Sioux elders in the Black Hills of South Dakota, casinos are feared as a threat to the communal way of life they have struggled to preserve. 
 Among once nearly extinct tribes like the Mashantucket Pequots in Connecticut, whose culture has been all but lost, the wealth generated by casinos is seen as the means to retrieve the past, rebuild the nation, and provide for its children's future.
What the casino riches have made clear to Indians of both views is that after 350 years of being demonized or romanticized by newcomers taking their land, Indians are still far from being accepted as who they are, rather than as what others would have them be.
The reaction in many states against Indian gaming, they say, shows how uncomfortable the country is with Indians who have the money and power to exercise their rights as sovereign peoples. A century after the Indian Wars ended at Wounded Knee, they suggest, General Sherman's notorious aphorism has merely been updated: The only good Indians are poor ones. "Some people feel that Indians can do anything they want as long as they're doing Indian stuff," said Suzan Shown Harjo, president of the Morning Star Institute, an Indian-rights group. "When they go beyond that, somehow they're taking something away from the white people."
Some critics question whether many tribes pursuing gaming are even legitimately Indian. A cartoon in Connecticut's largest newspaper, The Hartford Courant, ridiculed the Golden Hill Paugussetts, a tiny tribe that has intermarried with blacks, by portraying them as posers named Chief Lottabull, Chief Running Joke and Chief So Sioux Me.
To many non-Indians, especially in states with small Indian populations, Indian casinos can seem fraught with cultural ambiguity, as commerce collides with their time-capsule images of Indians as spiritual, non-materialistic and very distant beings. At the Pequot casino in Ledyard, Conn., non-Indian waitresses in skimpy costumes carry cocktails past the statue of the Rainmaker, a massive urethane brave who shoots a laser arrow into the heavens. In nearby Montville, the drawings for a casino planned by the Mohegan Tribe show patrons entering through the mouth of a wolf, the tribe's symbol.
Virtually all of the 200-plus tribes that have opened bingo halls or casinos say their aim is to preserve their culture. But Ms. Harjo and others warn that the overwhelming success of the Pequots, a tribe of fewer than 300 members whose casino earns an estimated $600 million a year, is obscuring the reality of Indian tribes and Indian gaming across the country.
At the opposite extreme from the assimilated Pequots, who lost their language long ago, is the 220,000-member Navajo Nation, whose tribal council still conducts meetings in Navajo. In between are hundreds of tribes whose circumstances differ according to their traditions, when they encountered white settlers and the remoteness of their reservations.
Some are divided between Christians and traditionalists who maintain their native religion, between full-bloods and mixed-bloods, between elders who have known no other life and younger Indians who have recently returned to the tribe.
And for nearly all, the pot of gold is much smaller than the Pequots' while their needs are much greater. "For the most part it brings revenue to reservations that by most standards exist in third world poverty," said Paul Morehead, director of government affairs for the National Congress of American Indians. For most tribes, gambling raises the same kinds of questions that states face when they legalize lotteries or casinos: Will the financial benefits outweigh the social costs?
These concerns can be minimal for small tribes like the Shakopee Mdewakanton Dakota outside Minneapolis, whose Mystic Lake casino earns hundreds of millions from non-Indians. They are much greater for large tribes on remote reservations, where the nearest customers are the Indians themselves.
"The real concerns are not cultural," said Duane Beyal, an assistant to Peterson Zah, the president of the Navajo Nation. "Gambling is a part of Navajo culture.
"Our concern is the social impact," he continued. "When you have such a large population with high unemployment, all kinds of poverty and related problems like alcoholism, and you put a casino in the middle of it, what kinds of problems do you have?"
On the Pine Ridge Reservation in South Dakota, where divisions between traditionalist Oglala Sioux and mixed-bloods cooperating with the Bureau of Indian Affairs led to widespread violence in the 1970's, those divisions are evident again in a debate over opening three casinos. Sovereignty is an issue for some Oglalas who oppose the casino proposed for the White Clay District, because the gaming compact with the state gives South Dakota criminal jurisdiction over non-tribe members on the reservation. That, the traditionalists say, surrenders treaty rights Sioux warriors died for.
The Gray Eagle Society, a group of Oglala elders, fears the casino's social impact on isolated Pine Ridge, the poorest reservation in the United States. But they also say gambling is contrary to their way and will corrode their sense of community.
"We are people that live in the creation of God," said Marie Brush Breaker Randall, secretary of the society. "We use everything within the creation, and we have survived this long. When you gamble with something, you don't know what's ahead. We don't gamble with anything, because everything is sacred."
In New York, one of the six Iroquois nations, the Oneidas, have opened a casino under a compact with the state, but last week another, the Senecas, voted by a 2-to-1 ratio against allowing casinos.
"Most of the elders, the clan mothers, those we call the long house people, are opposed to gaming," said Richard Hill, a Tuscarora who teaches American studies at the State University of New York at Buffalo. "It's really a matter of profits versus prophecy."
 
Profit and Prophecy
 The prophecy is that of Handsome Lake, a Seneca who declared in 1799 that gambling would someday destroy the Iroquois Nation. Mr. Hill says he sees evidence of it coming true.
The revenue from gaming has helped some tribes, financing housing, health clinics and education, he acknowledges, but arguments over how to spend that revenue have also divided tribes. He also sees risks in opening reservations to crowds of non-Indians.
"The reservation has made possible a certain life style that doesn't provide the satellite dish and Cadillac and other outward trappings of success, but does give a sense of place that money can't buy," he said.
In Connecticut, the 970-member Mohegans are a traditional tribe, yet a modern one. A casino lies at the heart of their plans to buy land for a reservation, build a studies center and buy back sacred lands they lost years ago. "We have a lot of dreams, and this is the energy to fuel those dreams," said Jayne Fawcett, a member of the tribal council. "People don't expect Indians to change, but we're 20th-century Indians."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Mystic Lake Casino, opened by the Shakopee Sioux tribe in Minnesota two years ago, is the largest casino between Las Vegas and Atlantic City. (Bill Pugliano/Gamma-Liaison)
