HEADLINE: NEW YORK MAY USE INDUSTRIAL ZONES AS SHELTER SITES

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
The chairman of the New York City Planning Commission proposed yesterday that zoning regulations be changed to allow increased placement of social-service centers -- including some kinds of homeless shelters and drug clinics -- in neighborhoods now zoned for light industry.
The official, Joseph B. Rose, said the Giuliani administration was "actively considering" the proposal. It could lead to a major change in the city's approach to equitably locating such services, an issue that has been a political lightning rod in neighborhoods across New York. 
 Some advocates for the homeless welcomed the idea, but others felt it would add a further stigma to poor people in need of social services.
Mr. Giuliani, who appointed Mr. Rose in January, has asked for an analysis of the concept within four weeks, his press secretary, Cristyne Lategano, said yesterday. And Fran Reiter, the Deputy Mayor for Planning, is working with the 13-member Planning Commission to help draft the proposal.
Any change in the zoning would be subject to approval by a majority of the Planning Commission, and then the City Council. "This is something that Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter and I have discussed, and we will be presenting it to the Mayor within a month," Mr. Rose said.
Passage of the zoning changes by the Planning Commission is not assured; Mr. Rose is the only Giuliani appointee on the commission. And because of the way terms are staggered, he would not be able to appoint a majority until the summer of 1997.
Mr. Rose, a 34-year-old Democrat, is a member of a prominent New York real-estate family. Before his appointment to the planning post, he spent four years as executive director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, a nonprofit group devoted to issues of housing, planning and urban development.
Asked about Mr. Rose's proposal, Peter F. Vallone, the majority leader of the City Council, said he had not seen it and knew none of its details but added that the Council's land-use staff experts would examine it.
At a community meeting yesterday afternoon on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, Mr. Rose told about 150 residents, "There are plenty of other social services facilities that would, perhaps, do better in areas that are now zoned light manufacturing."
And in an interview before the meeting, he said that, "obviously, facility-siting decisions are never going to be easy, and there will always be aggrieved parties."
Still, he said, "The record of government decision-making in this area has been poor, and the record of decisions has aggravated the problems and the tensions."
Among the factors adding to the problem, Mr. Rose said, are regulations that prohibit the location of some of the "most problematic kinds of facilities, like a residential facility for homeless, single substance abusers," in areas that would engender the least resistance from residents.
"In particular, there are many areas of the city in each borough currently zoned for light manufacturing which could well accommodate these kinds of facilities," Mr. Rose said. "Current regulations, though, prohibit them from being considered without a lengthy, expensive and uncertain land-use review process."
From 1985 to 1988, Mr. Rose was chairman of Community Board 5 in mid-Manhattan and more recently has headed its land-use committee.
Under the revised City Charter, adopted in 1989, the Planning Commission was required to adopt what is commonly called a fair-share policy to equitably distribute social-service agencies around the city.
Deputy Mayor Reiter said yesterday that the proposal to rezone industrial areas was part of the administration's review of all policies regarding the placement of social services, including the "fair share" concept. "We've got to start developing a rational approach," she said.
Last month, Mayor Giuliani was quoted in The New York Post as saying that the "fair share" program "deteriorates every neighborhood to bring it down to the lowest common denominator."
Yesterday, Mr. Rose said the policy "raised expectations of community protection, but many communities have been frustrated because facilities have continued to be located in the most saturated areas of the city." He particularly cited Harlem, East New York in Brooklyn, the South Bronx and Mott Haven in the Bronx as communities that had been "oversaturated."
Mr. Rose said the Giuliani administration was specifically looking at a revision of the Community Facility Text of the city's zoning regulations to make light-industry sites available. The Planning Department is studying the Community Facility regulations, he said, and plans to discuss them with the city's 59 community boards and the five borough presidents.
George McDonald, president of the Doe Fund, a group that aids the homeless, called the idea "a giant step towards rational siting policies for the delivery of social services."
Mr. McDonald, an author of a report during the Dinkins administration for a mayoral commission on the homeless, said: "The light-manufacturing areas are perfect because they are an under-utilized land resource. We've lost all these manufacturing jobs and the buildings are empty. And you couldn't use them for residential purposes. So this is a great alternative."
 
'Recipe for Failure'
 But Douglas Lasdon, director of the Legal Action Center for the Homeless, a private, nonprofit organization, said: "I don't think it's a good idea to ghettoize programs for poor people. I don't think it works. People don't want to go there and it's harder to resolve their problems. Sticking them in manufacturing zones is a recipe for failure."
"What we need is the funding for programs and the political will," Mr. Lasdon said. "We need the Mayor and Joe Rose to go take a look at some of the good programs, the ones that enhance their neighborhoods, and then act as moral leaders in the city."
 The Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, raised another concern about the proposal. "You have to proceed with caution because many industrial areas are still home to light industry and the small manufacturers that are critical to the city's economy," she said.
Any change in zoning, Ms. Messinger continued, could open the door to incursions by a variety of enterprises, "so, too many changes could lead to driving out those businesses."
Mr. Rose said the commission had not compiled a list of what industrial neighborhoods might best be suited for social-service agencies, or what kinds of services would be appropriate for those neighborhoods. Between 7 and 10 percent of the city's land is zoned for heavy or light manufacturing use, he said, and at least a quarter of that could accommodate social services.
"This is not to say that all social service facilities belong in these kinds of areas," he said, "but the ability to have these options is a big step forward." As examples of services that might appropriately be placed in an industrial area, Mr. Rose cited a residential drug- or alcohol-treatment program that does not require its clients to be drug-free, and a shelter for single, homeless people.
 
State Agencies Exempted
 "Some kinds of programs can and should be absorbed into residential areas, such as transitional housing for homeless families with children," he added. Ultimately, he said, these decisions have to be made case by case.
State agencies that place social services in city neighborhoods, usually under contracts with private organizations, are not subject to the city's "fair share" policies. To deal with that problem, Deputy Mayor Reiter held a meeting three weeks ago with city and state social service agencies.
The state Commissioner of Social Services, Michael J. Dowling, attended that meeting. Yesterday, he said: "It was recognized that we have to coordinate our efforts in a much better way across all city and state agencies so we can assure that we can site facilities and find the balance, being very sensitive to community needs, and especially avoiding saturation." Further meetings on the problem are planned.
Commissioner Dowling said he would not comment on the proposal to use industrial sites until he had had a chance to study it in detail.

HEADLINE: North Koreans Say Nuclear Fuel Rods Are Being Removed

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sunday, May 15

 BODY:
In a direct challenge to the Clinton Administration, North Korea said late Saturday that it has begun extracting nuclear fuel from its largest reactor without international inspectors present, a process that the Defense Department said could provide enough material for four or five nuclear bombs.
The move was announced despite repeated warnings from the Administration that any effort to harvest the fuel would immediately end talks and result in a call for the United Nations to impose economic sanctions. 
 A team from the International Atomic Energy Agency, an arm of the United Nations, is headed to North Korea, primarily to finish an inspection that the North Koreans interrupted in March.
North Korea said on Thursday that the process of removing the fuel rods had not begun. On Friday, a harshly worded telex from Pyongyang told the agency that inspectors would not be permitted to closely sample or track the movement of fuel in the reactor, which is separate from the equipment the team was to inspect.
Mr. Clinton and his advisers are now faced with the decision of whether or not to make good on their threats and begin a more direct, and potentially more dangerous, confrontation. North Korea has repeatedly warned that it would view economic sanctions as the equivalent of a declaration of war.
While the North's warnings are often overblown, Secretary of Defense William J. Perry said here several weeks ago that prudence would require Washington to improve military readiness on the Korean Peninsula before sanctions were imposed. Mr. Perry said again last week that if sanctions are required, "we will have to take seriously the risk of war."
On Friday night, addressing business leaders in Williamsburg, Va., he said that the removal of spent fuel had begun, but as late as Saturday other Administration officials were saying that they had no solid intelligence to back up his comments.
On the other hand, some Administration officials have suggested that the removal of the fuel rods, which take some time to be converted into bomb-grade plutonium, could be a ploy. North Korea could be hoping to win concessions quickly from the United States in return for granting inspectors the right to keep track of the new load of fuel.
 
Just a Pressure Tactic?
 "It may just be a pressure tactic," an Administration official involved in the issue said Saturday in Washington. "But there is no technical reason that they have to unload the reactor now. They are creating a crisis."
The North Korean statement issued Saturday seemed intended to anticipate the arrival of inspectors at the heavily guarded nuclear site in Yongbyon, 60 miles north of the capital in Pyongyang. As soon as the inspectors entered the reactor building, they would have seen that the seals the agency places on critical parts of the equipment had been broken so that fuel could be removed.
The announcement from the Korean Central News Agency, the Government's official mouthpiece, quoted an unnamed Foreign Ministry official as saying that the agency's demand to take samples from the fuel rods, which could reveal how much fuel North Korea has harvested in past years, was unreasonable.
"Under such conditions, we had no other choice but to remove seals and start taking out fuel rods for safety reasons," the spokesman said. He added that once the process begins it cannot be stopped because it "may cause a new danger." The rods were removed, the spokesman said, within view of security cameras that the agency placed around the reactor, so inspectors should be able to review the operation on tape.
 
Rising International Anxiety
 Replacing spent fuel rods is a routine step at every nuclear reactor, and it usually takes several months to reload the reactor core with a fresh fuel supply. But in the case of North Korea, the routine move has become a source of high international anxiety.
While the spent fuel itself cannot be used to make a bomb, it contains plutonium that can be used to make a bomb core. Until now, the Central Intelligence Agency has estimated that North Korea extracted enough plutonium from the plant to make one or two nuclear weapons at most. It is unclear whether North Korea has the technology to build nuclear triggers or the capability of mounting a weapon on a homegrown missile.
Despite the suspicions about the North's weapons capability, the Clinton Administration has justified its continuing long talks by saying that the weapons project was "frozen," -- that is, that Pyongyang was making no progress on additional weapons.
If North Korea's statement on Saturday is true, that assumption is no longer valid. Combined with other activities reported by inspectors, the announcement makes it clear that the North is preparing to turn its spent fuel into plutonium quickly.
During the March trip, inspectors saw that rapid progress had been made on the construction of a second reprocessing line inside the football-field-size building that the North Koreans call their "radiochemical laboratory." That second line seemed intended to double the capability to convert spent fuel into plutonium, in anticipation of the new harvest of fuel that would soon be available.
Satellite imagery also shows that progress is being made on the construction of a new, far bigger nuclear reactor just outside of Yongbyon.
 
The Obstacle of China
 In his speech on Friday night, Mr. Perry said that intense discussions were under way "to insure the world community that the fuel that is taken out of that reactor will not be diverted into more nuclear bombs."
"If we are successful in these discussions," he said, "it will be a major step forward. If we are not successful, and we know that, which we would, then we will have to consider recommending sanctions against North Korea. North Korea has already stated that they would consider sanctions equivalent to a declaration of war."
Getting sanctions through the United Nations would not be easy. China, which has veto power, has repeatedly expressed its opposition to such pressure tactics. But the Administration is betting that the Chinese, after privately warning the North Koreans to back off, will not defend the extraction of the fuel rods.
"I suspect that, if the fuel is really being taken out, they would go along with us," an Administration official said Saturday.

HEADLINE: For East Europe Exiles, Lives in 2 Worlds

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
Theirs is the emigre story with a post-cold war postscript. They came for freedom -- to think and write and speak. Some were visiting, but became stranded when things back home in Eastern Europe turned nasty. Others came for good, assuming they would never look back.
Time passed and they became Americans and New Yorkers. They found work in universities, theaters, journals. They made the leap, painful as it was, to writing in English. Their children grew up here, listening to Pearl Jam. 
 Then the unimaginable happened. Communism stumbled, and democracy began spreading through Eastern Europe. The New Yorkers filtered back, curious, to take a look. Suddenly, they were spending a lot of time on airplanes.
Now many Eastern European intellectuals who have lived in New York City for years are adopting bi-continental lives -- living and working in two worlds and finding unexpected pleasure and pain in belonging to neither and both.
Several professors are helping shape the transition of their home region to capitalism. Others are helping rebuild university departments. Emigre artists are working back home once again. A playwright's plays are again being produced.
For some of them, Eastern Europe after Communism is an antidote to much that is wearying in American life. It is a more intimate universe, familiar, and the place, at least for now, with a sense of possibility.
"Poland is a small country," said Ewa Kuryluk, a Polish-born artist, art historian and novelist living on the Upper West Side of Manhattan who has been in the United States since 1981. "Even after so many years of absence, people remember you. You are famous.
"So every time I go to Poland, I have this sense of being able to do something, of people coming to me with great enthusiasm," she said. Referring to the impact of the American recession on her field, she said, "Here, it is just the opposite."
On a recent visit to Warsaw to start work on a series about democracy and the free market for Polish television, Michael Kott, 40, a Polish-born writer and translator who emigrated with his family when he was 12 and now lives in the East Village, recalls repeatedly bumping into Polish friends from New York.
First came an actress, who was in Warsaw for a part in a production of "Six Degrees of Separation." Then came a jazz musician Mr. Kott knows from New York; both meetings occurred in the lobby of the Hotel Europejski.
"I would say that virtually everyone either has an aging mother or aunt or an article or an exhibit or a girlfriend in Poland," said Mr. Kott, who plans to spent most of the next 12 months there.
One of the largest groups of bi-continental Eastern European intellectuals in New York are the Polish, like Mr. Kott, Ms. Kuryluk and Andrzej Rapaczynski, a professor of law at Columbia University who was driven out of Poland in 1968 and, over the next 20 years, returned only twice.
Now he is constantly in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet republics, working on a massive project on privatization. He is on the faculty of a university in Prague and, at times, has flown back and forth twice a month.
The experience has brought him both great joy and disappointment.
"I rediscovered my past, which was wonderful," Professor Rapaczynski said. "But in the meantime, I had had 20 years of my life. And that life was completely alien to many people who were close to me."
 
Viewing It Differently
 "I thought it was part of me, that I was enriched by it," he said. "But to them, it was simply what took me away from them. Somehow, there was no interest in that. So in some ways, those relationships turned out to be very painful."
Nevertheless, he said, his work in Eastern Europe has become "a huge part of my life now." He added, "Most of the adrenaline in my blood is somehow caused by things that are going on over there."
This generation of emigres, now in middle age, came to New York in waves -- the first group around the time of the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968, the second in 1981, when Poles traveling abroad found themselves marooned by the imposition of martial law at home.
Roman Frydman was in the first group. Now an associate professor of economics at New York University, he left Poland in 1968, driven out by the government's anti-Semitic campaigns. A 20-year-old student, he left with few regrets and no intention to return.
Irena Grudzinska Gross left Poland the following year. A student advocate, she had been arrested and imprisoned. The invasion of Czechoslovakia represented to her the "ideological suicide" of the Socialist system. It was a signal that reform would never happen in her country either.
 
Home by Christmas
 The 1981 group was different. They were not thinking about emigration. Some were traveling, some were on academic fellowships, some were exhibiting their work. They would be home by Christmas, many figured. But martial law intervened. Phone lines were broken, flights were canceled. They got stuck.
"You can't just sit in front of the TV set and wait," said Rafal Olbinski, a Polish-born illustrator and painter. Like everyone else, Mr. Olbinski found work. When martial law was lifted a few years later, he had become too busy to go back. "I got Americanized," he said. "New York-ified."
Some stayed by default; there was no conscious moment of decision. For others, the choice became impossibly draining. Elzbieta Matynia, a Polish-born sociologist now at the New School for Social Research, became ill from the stress: "I came from a country where to make choices was not my business."
One way or another, they worked out their immigration status and settled. Some married Americans, some one another. Fellowships turned into teaching jobs that turned into tenure. Many fell into specialties that had little connection to their past. Some deliberately avoided becoming what Professor Matynia calls "professional Poles."
Professor Frydman became a specialist in what makes market economies work. Professor Rapaczynski taught philosophy at Yale and Princeton, then switched to law. Ms. Kuryluk and Janusz Glowacki, a Polish-born playwright, chose, in their 30's and 40's, to make the hard switch to writing in English.
 
Keeping in Touch
 They kept an eye on one another, as Mr. Kott puts it. They attended one another's birthdays and book parties and openings. They met at dinner parties and lectures and readings. Polish artists designed the posters for Mr. Glowacki's plays. They remained bound, if loosely, by shared history and sensibilities.
To illustrate, Mr. Glowacki tells a story: He was in Florida recently visiting friends when, he says, he heard Vice President Al Gore on the McNeil-Lehrer News Hour predicting that Russia would become the guardian of freedom in Eastern Europe. He immediately got on the phone.
"So I am calling Poles," he explains, "because very few Americans will understand the joke."
To many Eastern European emigres, the collapse of Communism came as a surprise -- if not the collapse itself, at least the speed with which it happened. In the spring of 1989, many Poles in New York headed home to witness what Mr. Glowacki calls the first "sort-of-free elections."
Since that time, many have built whole new additions onto their lives. They fly back and forth regularly, sometimes staying for months. If the new Marriott hotel in Warsaw had a frequent-visitor prize, Professor Rapaczynski believes he would have gotten it. .
 
Making Up Time
 Mr. Kott, the writer and translator, had visited Poland only a few times since leaving in childhood. But he spent two years working there between 1991 and 1993 and is returning later this month.
Professor Frydman, the economist, had never specialized in Eastern Europe before he went back to Poland as a consultant in 1989. But he became fascinated by the process of privatization and he and Professor Rapaczynski ended up spending much of 1990 in Warsaw advising the government.
Professor Frydman then organized an economics program at Central European University in Prague. Now he and Professor Rapaczynski are working in 12 countries in the region, heading a research project aimed at understanding and guiding the transition to capitalism.
Mr. Glowacki's play, "Antigone in New York," is being performed in eight theaters in Poland and is to open in Prague in June and in Leningrad in September. His book about the Solidarity political movement has finally been published in Poland, after being published during the 1980's all over the world.
Even "Hunting Cockroaches," his earlier play about two Polish emigres in New York, was finally performed in Poland. In a delectable example of the absurdity Mr. Glowacki savors, it was censored as anti-Polish in the 1980's -- only to be criticized in the 1990's as anti-American.
 
New School Pivotal
 One focus of trans-Atlantic flux in New York City is the New School for Social Research, which, earlier in the century, rescued 167 endangered scholars from Europe during the Nazi period, and which has been working quietly since the mid-1980's to support the democracy movement in Eastern and Central Europe.
Now scholars travel back and forth between New York and the region, participating in seminars on the transition to democracy. From a handful of clandestine meetings in Warsaw apartments in the mid-1980's, the project has grown to include hundreds of people from all over Eastern and Central Europe.
The head of the New School's East and Central Europe program is Professor Matynia, who arrived from Poland on a one-year fellowship in 1981, got stuck when martial law was declared, fell in love with an American film maker making a documentary about Solidarity and ended up deciding to stay.
In a way, she said recently, she is one of a new breed.
"We don't deny our backgrounds," she said. "We try to use them creatively. We also try to use that sense of the American experience. It's not that we are between cultures, meaning nowhere. I like to think that I'm a very good American when I'm in Poland or abroad."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Polish members of Eastern Europe's intellectual community gathering in the courtyard of the Polish Institute in Manhattan. (Jim Estrin/The New York Times) (pg. 1)

HEADLINE: Short on Soccer, U.S. Gears for Heavy Dose

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MISSION VIEJO, Calif., May 14

 BODY:
In a month, the world's largest sporting event will come to the country with the world's smallest interest in soccer.
The World Cup, soccer's quadrennial international tournament, is expected to attract a cumulative television audience of 32 billion during the monthlong event, which starts June 17. It will lure 1.2 million foreign visitors to the United States and pump $4 billion into the national economy. And the organizers' biggest hope is that it will relieve the United States of its status as soccer's biggest undeveloped outpost. 
 Will Americans sit up and take notice, or will the World Cup pass with the fleeting novelty of a solar eclipse?
Much of the American interest will likely depend on the performance on the young, inexperienced United States team, which as the host automatically qualified for the tournament. The 23 other teams, including players who are among the biggest celebrities in their countries, begin arriving in the United States on Tuesday. Checking in first will be Saudi Arabia at its training site in Rowan College in Glassboro, N.J. Saudi soccer officials, meanwhile, are expected to bivouac at an Atlantic City casino hotel, said a World Cup spokesman, John Griffin.
The United States training site in Mission Viejo is also waiting for overseas arrivals because several of America's important players have been competing in Europe.
Most of the world will watch the World Cup in rapt awareness, and a worldwide television audience of two billion is expected for the final match on July 17. But the tournament will have to compete for American viewers with the National Basketball Association playoffs, baseball's march toward the All-Star Game break and the opening of National Football League training camps. The World Cup fan base in the United States includes 16 million people who play soccer in the country and ethnic groups whose members grew up with the sport.
Of the 52 total games, 35 have already sold out, thanks in part to dream first-round matchups -- including Italy versus Ireland -- and the recently concluded individual ticket sales. Organizers expect all 3.6 million tickets will eventually be sold. But the anticipation of a successful, profitable World Cup is being tempered by concerns about security and the tournament's intended legacy -- the creation of a major domestic soccer league.
The 24 finalists have been divided into 6 groups of 4 teams. After each team plays the others in its group, the top 16 will advance to the second round, in which a single loss means elimination. Play begins on June 17 when the defending champion, Germany, takes on Bolivia, and concludes with the championship game at the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif., on July 17.
 
No England, France or Japan
 Games will be played at nine venues from Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., to the Rose Bowl in Pasadena. The failure of such tourist-intense countries as England, France and Japan to qualify for the World Cup finals, and the grouping of such popular teams as Italy and Ireland in New York, may diminish the expected economic impact at some venues. In Dallas and Chicago, blocks of hotel rooms set aside for the World Cup have gone unclaimed, though all games in Chicago are sold out.
Sales are also lagging in Dallas, which is host to a relatively unglamorous lineup of Spain, Nigeria, Korea and Bulgaria.
"I'm still holding to what I've said for a long time; we're going to sell out every game," said Alan Rothenberg, chairman of World Cup USA '94.
 
The Debate Over Fences
 Of greater concern than attendance at World Cup games is safety. Organizers were rebuffed in their initial request to have alcohol sales banned in and around stadiums on the day of games, as was done in Italy at the 1990 World Cup. Now the request is that beer not be sold in the stands or after halftime. Organizers and officials of FIFA, soccer's governing body, fear the potential of fans being crushed and strongly object to the placement of fences around the fields at the Cotton Bowl, RFK Stadium in Washington, and Stanford Stadium in Palo Alto, Calif.
Authorities at each site determine their security arrangements. World Cup organizers and FIFA officials have accused police officials of panicking in overreaction to the threat of hooliganism.
"FIFA is of the opinion that the only things behind fences are prisoners and animals," Joseph (Sepp) Blatter, general secretary of FIFA, said recently while in New York.
As usual, anticipation of the World Cup elicits wild passion and fevered nuttiness, among participants as well as fans. The Swiss coach, Roy Hodgson, and the Italian coach, Arrigo Sacchi, have restricted their players to sex only after games, not before. Gheorghe Hagi, the tempestuous Romanian midfielder, is serving a two-game suspension for spitting at another player in an exhibition match against Northern Ireland.
 
Kidnapped Father Is Released
 Romario, the creative, Brazilian forward, can concentrate on soccer now that his kidnapped father was released unharmed a week ago. As kidnappers go, those who apprehended Edevair Souza de Faria were clumsy but sympathetic, providing a television for Romario's father to watch his son play a club match in Spain.
Diego Maradona, Argentina's star of past World Cups, fired at Argentine reporters with an air rifle earlier this year and has been barred from tuneup matches in Japan because several years ago he tested positive for cocaine and was arrested for cocaine possession. He has been granted a three-month visa to play in the World Cup in the United States.
All of these international stars, the Michael Jordans of the soccer set, could walk down most American streets with complete invisibility. Opinion polls taken last year showed that fewer than 30 percent of Americans even knew the World Cup was coming to the United States.
Although the evidence is anecdotal -- billboards, advertising on television and in newspapers, news coverage and the appearance of memorabilia in sporting goods stores -- awareness in the United States appears to be increasing. Still, organizers will be satisfied with a relatively modest 4.5 average rating for the 11 games to be broadcast on ABC.
A successful World Cup is being based on three requirements: a profit, advancement by the United States team to the second round and the creation of a major soccer league in the United States. Asked the chance of all three occurring, Rothenberg, realizing he might have to eat his words, said, "I think we're a lead-pipe cinch at all three of those."
 
Surplus Is Expected
 In fact, a surplus of $20 million is expected on a World Cup USA '94 budget of between $300 million and $400 million. As for the United States advancing to the second round, no host team has ever failed to do so in the 64-year history of the tournament. The soccer league is scheduled to begin on April 9, 1995, but as of now it has no players, teams or stadiums, and the asking price for investors has been lowered from $10 million to $5 million in a $100 million capitalization project.
Whether soccer in the United States remains primarily a youth sport or is tugged from ignored backwaters to the sport's mainstream may rest on a single game, the United States versus Switzerland on June 18 at the Pontiac Silverdome outside Detroit. This is the first game for the Americans. It will be played in an unusual setting, indoors, on natural grass that has been trucked in, and it will be broadcast nationally by ABC.
"A lot of people are going to be curious," Rothenberg said. "If we do well, I think we could start to catch lightning in a bottle. If we don't, I think we'll still have a great following and a great tournament, but we won't have the potential miracle that's out there to be performed."

HEADLINE: Hands Off Haiti, Say Dominicans

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 14

 BODY:
With the United States pressing new efforts to isolate Haiti's military junta, the leading candidates in the Dominican presidential elections scheduled for Monday are strongly opposed to any foreign intervention next door.
They are also critical of the international embargo against Haiti. The Dominican President, Joaquin Balaguer, has long been scornful in any case of international efforts to force Haiti's army to abandon power and allow the return from exile of the elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. 
 When a rump group of Haitian lawmakers named a new President this week, a move strongly condemned by most other countries in the region, Mr. Balaguer's Government refused to take a position on the matter. The Dominican Deputy Foreign Minister, Fabio Herrera Cabral, called it "an internal problem of Haiti."
Relations between Mr. Balaguer and Father Aristide have been severely strained since the priest harshly criticized the Dominican Republic for its treatment of migrant workers from Haiti in his presidential campaign in 1990. Diplomats say the Balaguer Government's failure to enforce the embargo on oil sales to Haiti imposed by the United Nations in October has enabled the Haitian military to defy pressures for its removal from power.
 
Rival Silent on Issue
 Since the sanctions were widened to ban all trade and noncommercial air traffic to Haiti, the Dominican Government has continued to allow Haitian charter flights to land here.
Mr. Balaguer's chief rival here, 57-year-old Jose Francisco Pena Gomez, who has narrowly led in most recent opinion polls, has been more supportive of Father Aristide's efforts to return to office. In his final news conference before the election, he said today that he would enforce any international sanctions taken against Haiti.
But aides to Mr. Pena Gomez say that with contraband fuel and other goods sold to Haiti now the biggest source of income for many Dominicans in areas near the border separating the two countries, stopping the trade would be impractical and highly unpopular.
The Clinton Administration has recently stepped up pressure on the Dominican Government to enforce the embargo and has begun to speak of a possible need for military intervention to unseat Haiti's military leaders. But senior aides to Mr. Pena Gomez say they would only support a new diplomatic initiative aimed at starting discussions between Father Aristide and the military that would require a compromise solution from both sides.
"We will have to encourage every sector in Haiti to undertake a dialogue that will require profound concessions from all," said Hugo Tolentino, a close adviser to Mr. Pena Gomez. "Any intervention would hurt Haiti, would hurt the Dominican Republic and would hurt all of Latin America."
Asked what these concessions might be, Mr. Tolentino said Father Aristide might have to remain out of office in exchange for a removal of Haiti's military leadership and for a round of new, internationally monitored elections.
 
A Focus of the Campaign
 The United States intervened in the Dominican Republic in 1965 after the outbreak of civil war. Because of their own experience, Mr. Tolentino said, most Dominicans would strongly oppose any armed intervention in Haiti.
Haiti has been the bitter focus of much of the campaigning between Mr. Pena Gomez and Mr. Balaguer, who is 87 and has served as President for six nonconsecutive terms in a political career that began in the 1930's.
Mr. Balaguer's partisans have frequently focused on Mr. Pena Gomez's black skin to exploit a deep-seated dislike of Haitians among many Dominicans. Through innuendo, they have sought to depict him as a closet Haitian bent on uniting the two countries and destroying the Dominican Republic's national identity.
"Pena Gomez has been pushed thoroughly on the defensive on the issue of Haiti," said a diplomat who was pessimistic about efforts to enlist the Dominican Republic's cooperation in efforts to unseat the Haitian military.

HEADLINE: Unfazed North Leads in Virginia G.O.P.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
Ronald Reagan has criticized him. So have Colin L. Powell, the retired chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Senator John W. Warner, the dean of Virginia Republicans.
But with less than three weeks before the state Republican party picks a nominee to face Senator Charles S. Robb in the fall, Oliver N. North, the former Marine lieutenant colonel and central figure in the Iran-contra scandal, has pushed ahead with his conservative agenda, unfazed by his attackers and, evidently, unharmed. 
 Proclaiming love of God and country and disdain for the left-leaning ways of Congress, he remains the favorite among delegates who will choose the candidate -- even with independent polls suggesting that another candidate might have a better chance against Mr. Robb.
"This is the last lap of the first race in a two-race season," Mr. North said in an interview here this week. "I'm way out in front."
 
Referendum on Character
 Mr. North, who is 50, is being challenged for the nomination by another Reagan Administration alumnus, James C. Miller, a 52-year-old economist and former budget director.
But because their political views are virtually indistinguishable, the race has become something of a referendum on Mr. North's character and celebrity, for his role in the arms-for-hostages scandal, his admission that he lied to Congress and his 1989 conviction on three felony charges that were later overturned.
In a letter made public in March, Mr. Reagan wrote, "I do have to admit that I am getting getting pretty steamed about the statements coming from Oliver North."
Mr. Reagan was referring to assertions by Mr. North that his lies came on orders from the former President. "I never instructed him or anyone in my Administration to mislead," Mr. Reagan said.
Mr. North responded in a letter, telling Mr. Reagan that his comments had been used out of context.
Mr. Warner has called Mr. North "unfit" to serve in the Senate, and General Powell has said he would "not feel confident" with him.
 
Not Stung Badly
 Rebukes from such respected conservatives would seem to spell disaster for a candidate whose values and ardent patriotism otherwise mirror their own. But the private surveys of delegates conducted by each campaign show that Mr. North's past and the verbal attacks have not knocked him out of the lead. Campaign aides for Mr. North say the margin over Mr. Miller remains more than 20 points. Mr. Miller's staff members say their surveys show it is less.
Whatever the spread, the dispute over who said what has appeared to energize many North supporters, who say either that they believe Mr. North was telling the truth before Congress or that his testimony was appropriate because a good soldier is trained to protect his superiors. It also plays well to a conservative audience.
"It doesn't bother me at all," said Sannie Re Blomberg, an elderly housewife from Danville, Va., and a North delegate, referring to the contretemps with Mr. Reagan and the more recent criticism from Mr. Warner and others.
 
Shaking His Head
 It is that kind of loyalty that has Mr. North's hopes soaring and Mr. Miller shaking his head. Yet the loyalty has translated into a serious advantage for Mr. North, who has raised much of his $6 million war chest from sources outside of Virginia. Mr. Miller has struggled, by comparison, trying to convince delegates that his experience and lack of political baggage would make him a more viable candidate in the fall.
By this week, Mr. Miller had raised all of $540,000, most of it, his aides said, from within the state.
Even state party leaders acknowledge that Mr. North has not been damaged by President Reagan or others. "They might be bringing some people over to Miller," Patrick M. McSweeney, the Virginia Republican chairman, said of the critical remarks. "But a like number are going the other way."
 
'High Negatives Can Win'
 Citing other conservative Republican senators who overcame image problems, Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York and Jesse A. Helms of North Carolina, Mr. McSweeney added, "High negatives can win."
Rather than attack Mr. North in conversations with delegates, Mr. Miller emphasizes his own electability, constantly citing the independent polls that show he could defeat Mr. Robb in a two-way race and Mr. North could not.
But Mr. North dismisses such conclusions, not least because he expects that if he wins the Republican nomination other candidates might jump into the general election, splitting the votes against him. Currently, L. Douglas Wilder, Virginia's former Governor and Mr. Robb's biggest Democratic rival, is collecting the 15,000 signatures he would need to get onto the ballot as an independent.
 
'I Am More Qualified'
 Less colorful than Mr. North -- but also with no questions of character to defend -- Mr. Miller plays his former number-crunching job for President Reagan as a trump card.
"I am more qualified to do the job," Mr. Miller stressed to a group of state delegates. Because only delegates vote, not the general electorate, both candidates have been criss-crossing the state, meeting them at small receptions, lunches and other social functions. "Chuck Robb has got to go," Mr. Miller added. "We have two solid conservative candidates, but only one can beat him."
Mr. Miller has, at least, been heartened in recent weeks by his campaign surveys and by anecdotal evidence that delegates are switching. For that reason, his aides say, Mr. Miller has become more animated in meetings with delegates.
Some of his enthusiasm appeared to be rubbing off. Several delegates who identified themselves as North supporters upon arrival said they had been vacillating in recent weeks and after listening to Miller, were ready to abandon Mr. North.
"I have momentum," Mr. Miller said. "As we get closer to when delegates take a harder look at who the candidates are, they might really love Ollie and really want to stick it to Congress. But if they choose Ollie, they can't beat Chuck Robb."
 
Both Men Sought Help
 Mr. Miller's only apparent slip throughout the campaign was an acknowledgement that he sought psychiatric help for a mood disorder after the death of his father several years ago. Mr. Miller volunteered the information last month on the same day he challenged Mr. North to disclose his medical records, presumably to call attention to Mr. North's psychiatric treatment 20 years ago.
But the episode barely caused a blip, largely because Mr. Miller's problem was not perceived as serious and Mr. North had acknowledged his difficulties, in a general way, in an autobiography three years ago.
Mr. Miller readily concedes that to overtake Mr. North by the convention he will have to do a better job, convincing delegates that Mr. North's negative ratings would make him a sure loser to Mr. Robb in the fall, even though many political experts in Virginia cringe at the prospects of a North-Robb showdown for all the mud that could be slung.
 
Robb's Image Problem
 Mr. Robb is considered a strong front-runner in a race that includes State Senator Virgil H. Goode and a Richmond lawyer, Sylvia Clute.
In addition to acknowledging marital indiscretions, including acceptance of a massage from a former beauty queen, Mr. Robb has faced allegations -- which are unproved -- that he socialized with drug users. The charges were raised three years ago in a book, written by a private investigator who claimed Mr. Robb attended parties where cocaine was used. He has denied ever using drugs or being around drug users.
Unlike Virginia Democrats, who will select their candidate through a primary on June 14, the Republicans are staging a two-day convention, over the June 3-4 weekend. While anyone can become a delegate for a small contribution to the party, about $35 in most districts, the ballots of those attending, perhaps up to 14,500, will be compressed into fewer than 9,000 actual votes.
That number is determined by a weighted formula that takes into account the number of delegates, where they live and how their districts voted for George Bush in the 1992 Presidential election and for George F. Allen, the Republican who was elected governor last year.

HEADLINE: W. Graham Claytor, Architect Of Amtrak Growth, Dies at 82

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. LYONS 

 BODY:
W. Graham Claytor Jr., who ended a long career in the railroad industry by guiding Amtrak to a measure of prosperity, died yesterday at the Blake Memorial Hospital in Bradenton, Fla. Mr. Claytor, who lived in Washington and Holmes Beach, Fla., was 82.
The cause was cancer, his family said. 
 Mr. Claytor retired last year as president and chairman of the national passenger railroad, which expanded its ridership and revenues during his 11-year tenure.
He was credited with helping to revive the ailing railroad by many experts, and even some critics of its operations. By the time he retired, fares and other revenues covered 80 percent of Amtrak's expenses, up from 42 percent in 1980.
Before retiring, Mr. Claytor predicted that Amtrak might be able to cover all of its operating costs, something that no national railroad system in the world does now, by the year 2000. Amtrak, formally known as the National Railroad Passenger Corporation, was created by Congress to take over the nation's failing passenger lines.
Mr. Claytor and his managers patched together a network that eventually offered improved service, ticketing and reservations, and cut costs.
 
Turning Railroad Around
 Stephen Moore, an economist with the Heritage Foundation, which has opposed Federal subsidies for Amtrak, complimented Mr. Claytor and his team, saying: "They have really turned that railroad around."
The main hall at Washington's Union Station was named "Claytor Concourse" by Amtrak's board in recognition of Mr. Claytor's efforts to restore the historic station.
He handed over the leadership of Amtrak last year to Thomas Downs, who called it "kind of a miracle" that Mr. Claytor kept Amtrak alive during a decade of hostile Administrations.
Before joining Amtrak, Mr. Claytor had served from 1963 to 1977 as vice president, then president and finally chairman of the Southern Railway. At a time when many railroads were in financial straits, Southern thrived under Mr. Claytor's leadership. In 1982, Southern consolidated with the Norfolk and Western Railway to become Norfolk Southern.
After his retirement from Southern, Mr. Claytor served from 1977 to 1979 as Secretary of the Navy. He also served in the Carter Administration as Acting Secretary of Transportation in 1979, and as Deputy Secretary of Defense from 1979 to 1981.
He also practiced law in Washington with the firm of Covington & Burling from 1938 to 1967, and again from 1981 to 1982.
William Graham Claytor Jr. was born in 1912 in Roanoke, Va. He graduated from the University of Virginia, and in 1936 received a law degree from Harvard University, where he was president of the Harvard Law Review.
He also served as a law clerk to Judge Learned Hand and Justice Louis D. Brandeis. He served in the Pacific as a Navy lieutenant commander during World War II. As commander of the Cecil J. Doyle, he was instrumental in the rescue of almost 100 American sailors from the cruiser Indianapolis after it was torpedoed by a Japanese submarine.
Mr. Claytor is survived by his wife, Frances; a son, W. Graham 3d, of Alameda, Calif.; a daughter, Dr. Murray Claytor of Atlanta; a brother, Richard A., of Bethesda, Md., and two grandchildren. Another brother, Robert, the retired head of the Norfolk Southern railroad, died last year.

HEADLINE: THE SUPREME COURT;
The Nominee, in His Own Words: a 'Mandate of Equal Justice Under Law'

 BODY:
The speeches and writings of Judge Stephen G. Breyer, nominated by President Clinton for the United States Supreme Court on Friday, provide a glimpse into his intellect, passions and personality. His legal opinions for the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit are long on analysis and short on flourishes, reflecting his preference to be understood rather than to dazzle. He tries to use plain language and everyday examples, for instance using the need to fill a car with gas to make an argument of logic. He makes few appeals to emotion, but he is passionate about making the law available to people and cites a need for flexibility from the bench. While his opinions are dry, his personality, and self-deprecating wit, peek through clearly in his speeches and nonjudicial writing. Following are excerpts.
 
On His Motivation
 From his speech when he was sworn in to the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, in Boston on Dec. 18, 1980: 
 Your support suggests that you have confidence that I'll be a good judge, that I'll be honest and capable in seeking to carry out the mandate of equal justice under law. That has been an aim of my life in the law, and I hope that future years will show that your faith in me was justified.
 
On Plain Writing
 From a 1994 speech about education to the Massachusetts Commission on the Common Core of Learning:
Isn't law, after all, simply a body of rules, standards and practices, developed by, and applied to, groups of human beings, as part of their inevitable effort to live together peacefully and productively, justly and with freedom?
As an appellate judge, I set for myself a goal of trying to write my opinions so that a high school student, if willing to take a little time, would understand that, in the circumstances, the law, as revealed in that opinion, makes sense -- both in terms of basic fairness and in terms of helping people live decent, productive lives.
 
On the Public's Ownership
 From a 1991 speech about the new Federal courthouse on Boston's Fan Pier:
This most beautiful site in Boston does not belong to the judges, it does not belong to the lawyers, it does not belong to the Federal Government, it does not belong to the litigants, it belongs to the public. And if the public cannot use that site and see it as theirs, if every man, woman and child in Boston cannot take a walk on that pier, and see it as theirs and use it so that they can look out across the city and enjoy that beautiful site, enjoy that public space, if they cannot do that, then we have failed to achieve an important function of this building.
 
On Religious Scruples
 From a dissent in Alexander v. Boston University, 1985, in which the majority found that students may be disqualified for financial aid for refusing to fill out forms they said conflicted with their religious principles:
I agree that the students have not checked the paper box on the proper form. As a general matter, the government has a strong administrative interest in insisting that applicants fill out forms properly. But are there not stronger reasons for the government simply to overlook so trifling a deviation from the bureaucratic norm, at least where the applicants have a genuine religious or ideological scruple that prohibits their supplying the information on one form but not on another, equally useful one? To deny this, in a nation as diverse as ours, housing so many strongly held but differing points of view, is to exacerbate conflict where it could be muted. It is also to threaten an unnecessary weakening of judicial authority insofar as that authority rests on judicial reluctance to intervene in ideological disputes unless and until they focus upon differences over matters of substance.
 
On Middle Ground
 From U.S. v. Church of Scientology of Boston Inc., 1991:
Therefore, Powell must have meant that an examination of relevant material was a "necessary" examination. Consequently, "to the extent necessary" means "to the extent relevant."
This argument sounds logical, but it is not. In ordinary English there is a "middle" set of circumstances that "necessary" and "unnecessary" do not completely distribute between them. For example, it is necessary that my car have gas if I am going to drive it; it is unnecessary that it have a new paint job; but, it is neither "necessary" nor "unnecessary" that I clean the windshields -- to do so would simply be a wise precaution. Similarly, an investigation of whatever documents "might throw light" on the matter is not an "unnecessary" investigation, but neither can one conclude that it is "necessary." It might, for example, simply be somewhat helpful.
 
On the Courts
 From a 1991 lecture at the University of Southern California Law School on the use of legislative history in statutory interpretation:
First, I assume that appellate courts are in part administrative institutions that aim to help resolve disputes and, while doing so, interpret, and thereby clarify, the law. Second, I assume that law itself is a human institution, serving basic human or societal needs. It is therefore properly subject to praise, or to criticism, in terms of certain pragmatic values, including both formal values, such as coherence and workability, and widely shared substantive values, such as helping to achieve justice by interpreting the law in accordance with the "reasonable expectations" of those to whom it applies.
 
On Sentencing Guidelines
 From U.S. v. Mirna Rivera, June 1993, on the Federal sentencing guidelines, which he had earlier help set:
Ultimately, however, the Guidelines cannot dictate how courts should sentence in such special, unusual or other-than-ordinary circumstances. And, that is as it should be. As we have said, [see pp. 4-5, supra] the very theory of the Guideline system is that when courts, drawing upon experience adn informed judgment in such cases, decide to depart, they will explain their departures. The courts of appeals and the Sentencing Commission, will examine, and learn from, those reasons. And, the resulting knowledge will help the Commission to change, to refine, and to improve, the Guidelines themselves. That is the theory of partnership that the guidelines imply.
 
On Economic Regulation
 From his review of "Private Choices and Public Health: The AIDS Epidemic in an Economic Perspective" by Tomas J. Philipson and Richard A. Posner (Harvard University Press, 1994), in The New York Times Book Review:
There is an important evaluative difference between health and safety policy, in which scientific, medical and practical as well as ethical and emotional factors must play an important role, and more purely economic regulation -- say, of transportation and energy -- in which public policy traditionally has recognized economic theory as telling at least a very large part of the entire story.
It was, for example, fairly easy for economists in the 60's and 70's to bring economic insight to bear on policy conclusions by first announcing that airline or trucking regulation would produce unnecessarily high prices and then skeptically challenging supporters of regulation to come forward with noneconomic arguments powerful enough to justify an economically faulty policy. But the same kind of skeptical challenge in the case of government-supported AIDS policy does not ring true.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Economics alone cannot prescribe how much a society should spend on health and safety. Even if, like the authors, we make the rather extraordinary assumption that choices about sexual behavior are rational (like mountain climbing), we must still recognize that society does provide massive relief for the California earthquake victims who "chose" to live on a fault line; it does help treat and pay for research for lung cancer, whose victims often "chose" to smoke; it has built a Social Security system around the concern that rational individuals may not properly save for old age, and it quite reasonably can and does spend money to rescue mountain climbers in distress. Economics can wisely inform our efforts to attain our goals; but ultimately, if we prefer John Donne to Adam Smith, economists cannot prove us wrong. Nor can the authors.
 
On Human Nature
 From a letter to The Boston Globe, Feb. 26, 1993:
Given the continuous criticism of Boston drivers, how probable is the following? Your car stops in the South Station Tunnel at 5:20 p.m. when you're on the way to give a lecture. Instead of honking and swerving around you, leaving you to create the traffic jam of the week, the driver of the next car in back gives a friendly wave, pushes you out of the tunnel and into Chinatown, leaving you near a phone booth and driving off before you can say "thank you."
Well, that's what happened on Feb. 22 (I gave the lecture on time), and this note is to say, "Faith in human nature is sometime restored. Thank you."
 
STEPHEN BREYER
Cambridge

HEADLINE: WASHINGTON TALK;
Listening to Voters: Proposal in Congress for Polls

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
To help it serve the people, Congress already has barbers and garage attendants and elevator operators on automatic elevators. It has parliamentarians and sergeants-at-arms and even ordinary cops. For advice, it can turn to economists, scientists and accountants.
Even so, its work is widely viewed as imperfect. 
 So here's an idea. To overcome the impression that senators and representatives do not care what the people think, maybe Congress should hire a pollster.
That proposal is embodied in H.R. 4081, a bill introduced not long ago by Representative Ron Klink, Democrat of Pennsylvania, and ardently promoted by Alan Kay, a retired, wealthy businessman who established the Americans Talk Issues Foundation to do polls on issues he thinks are important.
Their arguments, though the bill is getting nowhere, are intriguing. They reflect both an acceptance of the public view of Congress as a trivial institution that serves itself and special interests and a proposed solution for that problem that only underscores the reasons for the public's distrust.
The Ross Perot view of what is wrong with Congress is that it is so caught up in itself that it does not care what the people think, that it won't vote for a constitutional amendment to require a balanced budget, or impose term limits on itself or stop wasting money.
A differing view is that Congress is already too much a weather vane whose careerist tendencies cause too slavish an effort to move every time the public wind shifts.
Mr. Klink's argument seeks to finesse that issue. Whether it is good or bad, he says, members of Congress already rely heavily on all sorts of faulty measures about what the nation thinks, from telephone tallies to deluges of postcards to what they read or hear about real public opinion polls. What troubles him is that they do not know whether their information is any good.
So he wants an office to do scientific public opinion polls on a regular basis to provide the authoritative answers. "If we are going to do it," the freshman Democrat from the Pittsburgh suburbs said recently, "and we are doing it, make sure the polling is for real."
Mr. Kay's argument is grander. At the recent 49th annual convention of the American Association for Public Opinion Research in Danvers, Mass., he maintained, "In every issue area no one is yet adequately researching what people want, majority or consensus, for national policy and legislation."
And the poll gap, he contended, doomed lawmakers to "failing to fulfill a constitutionally assigned responsibility, specifically the responsibility for representing their constituents."
"The public wants its voice heard just as loud as the lobbyist," Mr. Kay said.
He did not have an easy time of it. Other pollsters disagreed. Thad Cantril from Cambridge, Mass. argued from the back of the room that the public's voice was an uncertain beacon for legislators. "We would never have had a Marshall Plan if we had followed public opinion," Mr. Cantril said. "One of the reasons we don't have a serious foreign policy is because we pay too much attention to public opinion."
And Cliff Zukin, director of the Eagleton Institute at Rutgers, agreed and added the argument that "on most issues, there isn't public opinion" in any firm, definite sense. Any effort to denote an authoritative finding of what America thinks on an issue, Mr. Zukin said, "is probably dangerous."
Mr. Klink disagrees. He recently wrote: "I am not proposing government by polling, any more than we have government by polling with the current system of guessing the public will. However, there comes a time when leaders need to know the will of the nation on a given subject."
Mr. Kay offered another argument. He said the public's belief that Congress was unresponsive led it to make all sorts of drastic demands. His polling had found huge majorities for such extreme measures as Congressional pay cuts or term limits or binding national referendums on major issues, he said, and a polling office that would frame issues to find consensus would be a much simpler change.
One alternative he did not pose was raised by the 18th-century statesman Edmund Burke in his Speech to the Electors of Bristol. Even though a vote he cast in Parliament cost him re-election, he told the electors in November 1774, "Your representative owes you, not his industry only, but his judgment; and he betrays instead of serving you if he sacrifices it to your opinion."

HEADLINE: 30 New High Schools Report First-Year Success

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

 BODY:
It is a small triumph of the Coalition School for Social Change, one of 30 experimental high schools begun in New York City last fall, that Shenelle Nolan has been swinging her bookbag under her desk and sitting down for her first-period math class on time in recent weeks.
Last fall, Shenelle was perpetually tardy. But for months, her teachers have been pressing her to rise earlier and spend less time buying candy in a corner bodega on her 10-block walk to school through East Harlem. They got her family's cooperation as well. 
 The attention appears to be paying off. Shenelle, a 15-year-old freshman, is doing better academically than in her eight previous years of school, though sometimes she still stays up so late playing Nintendo at home that she dozes off in class. That draws a quick response.
"Shenelle, are you with us?" said Charlene Jordan, her principal, during a recent social studies class she helps teach. "Pick your head up off your desk. I want you to concentrate."
 
Attendance and Grades Rise
 Shenelle is one of 2,800 students enrolled in the 30 small New York City high schools that opened last fall, aimed at giving teen-agers close personal attention. It was one of the largest school reorganizations anywhere, and as the 1993-94 school year nears an end, parents and educators are evaluating the early results.
Attendance in the small schools is higher than in other city high schools, and students are passing more courses, according to Board of Education statistics.
"The early reports indicate that these schools are doing well," said John Ferrandino, the board's chief executive for high schools. "We don't want to say that smallness is some miracle panacea, but they're showing some nice success."
The small schools' achievements have come despite adversities. They were a project of Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez, and after his ouster last year, planning was often chaotic, officials said.
The board has still not found permanent homes for some; they are squatting in borrowed space in elementary schools and on college campuses. The Coalition School shares a dismal, windowless junior high school building at 127th Street and Madison Avenue in Harlem with three other small new schools.
 
21 More to Open
 Another, the Legacy School for Integrated Studies, has occupied four Manhattan sites since September. Middle College High School at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn is housed in portable classrooms.
Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines has embraced small schools and has approved plans to open an additional 21 in September. Mr. Cortines also announced last month that Deborah Meier, an award-winning principal whose nonprofit group founded 6 of the 30 schools, would join his staff next year, financed by a foundation, as an intermediary between the small schools and the bureaucracy.
In a recent interview Mr. Cortines criticized last year's rush. "We should not have opened many of these schools without more planning," he said. "I think we moved too fast."
Ms. Meier also expressed anguish over the schools' starting difficulties. "Most of our schools are doing well despite all the dislocation, but this has been my most frustrating year," Ms. Meier said. "Instead of spending our time on teaching, we're working on real estate. But if I sound discouraged, it's because of how much we want to get done and how fast we want to do it."
 
Community Groups Help
 Not everyone is enthusiastic. Some educators say small high schools limit the courses and equipment available for their students. Michael J. Petrides, a Board of Education member from Staten Island, voiced such criticisms last year when the board formally created the schools.
Some community groups have taken part in founding schools, as at El Puente Academy in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, where students have helped to vaccinate residents and surveyed neighborhood trees.
But other collaborations have not fared as well. After a new president took over at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, that college's relations soured with the Benjamin Banneker Academy, the high school on Pratt's campus. Banneker students and staff said they had been made to feel unwelcome, and there was a dispute over renovation plans. School officials have been forced to seek new space for Banneker for fall.
Most new schools opened with ninth-grade classes and have about 100 students; they will grow to 500 or 600 students as they add new grades. Many of the city's 125 regular high schools have 4,000 or more students.
For most of this century, most high schools were like factories: schedules were regulated by clanging bells and economies of scale were attainable, school officials thought, by erecting larger buildings and expanding enrollments. But as dropout and violence rates have grown, some educational theorists have advocated a "small is beautiful" approach. The opening of the 30 schools last fall was the most extensive application of the new theory nationwide.
 
More Relevant Learning
 The schools are intended to be permanent and they share in the high school division's budget. They received extra start-up money under the last Fernandez budget, and some, but not all, received additional money from foundations and corporations.
The Fund for New York City Public Education, a private group, oversaw the development of 10, called the New Visions schools. Ms. Meier's organization, the Coalition for Essential Schools, founded six schools, drawing students from what would have been this year's ninth-grade class at Julia Richman High School in Manhattan. Several community school districts founded more than a dozen others.
The new schools aim to make learning more relevant by focusing academic subjects on community projects or vocational specialties. Several schools are participating in efforts to feed the homeless and visit hospital patients. At the School for Social Change in the Bronx, pioneered by Hospital Workers Union Local 1199, students have begun an organizing campaign to relocate a bus stop closer to their school.
Naomi Barber, the fund's New Visions director, said at least 100 delegations visited the schools this year.
Despite the nationwide attention, any evaluation of the small schools' performance was guesswork until the board released figures in late April. The data showed that students in the new schools passed an average of 79 percent of their courses in the fall term, while students in the rest of the city's high schools passed 62 percent. The students in the new schools were not specially selected for their academic performance.
 
'Feeling Cared For'
 The report showed that on an average day, 89 percent of students attended classes at the six new schools that are replacing Julia Richman, which is being phased out, compared with 64 percent of students who attended class at Julia Richman during the last four years.
"These numbers tell us that kids are feeling cared for," said David W. Zuckerman, a doctoral candidate at Columbia Teachers College who is studying the new schools. "Extended personal relationships are developing between students, staff and parents, and that's helping to keep kids in class."
Dragana Stojsic, a freshman at the School District 25 Collaborative School in Whitestone, Queens, said she decided to attend a small school partly because her mother and father separated when she was 2, and since then, her mother has worked two jobs, scrubbing offices and homes.
 
Giving Up Free Periods
 "Teen-agers need to be able to talk with someone, and sometimes our parents aren't there for us," Dragana said during a break in a band practice at the school recently. "It's important to be able to talk to my teachers."
Teachers at several schools said that they felt more motivated to work diligently than they had at larger schools. The seven-teacher staff at the Landmark High School, at 127th Street and Madison Avenue in Harlem, voted unanimously in August to give up their free periods to teach more classes, shrinking class sizes.
Many students have brought poor study habits with them from their junior high schools, teachers said. The School for Public Service in East New York, founded by the East Brooklyn Congregations, an alliance of churches and synagogues, has recruited parents to offer after-school tutoring.
"Kids can't fall through the cracks here, because we won't let them," said Genevieve Richards-Wright, the school's project director.

HEADLINE: A Government-Industry Environmental Partnership

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Michael Silverstein simply is incorrect in his assertions that the Clinton Administration "does not see a vibrant environmental industry as crucial to cleaning up the world or revitalizing our economy" ("Why No Help for the Cleanup Industry," Viewpoints, April 24). Fostering technology businesses, creating high-quality jobs for Americans and protecting the environment all go hand in hand; in fact, sustained economic growth requires a healthy environment. Building this environment-economy link is central to the President's environmental agenda, and in particular is a core mission of Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown. 
 The commercial demand for solutions to environmental problems is large (some estimate a $200 billion to $300 billion worldwide market) and predicted to double by the end of the decade. Much of this growth will come from developing countries, where United States industry has the opportunity to capture most of the growth. This growth supports an industry that consists of close to 60,000 businesses, and exemplifies the sort of civilian technology-based industries that provide good jobs for Americans.
But market size is not the only reason environmental technologies are critical to the United States. While Mr. Silverstein bemoans the recent financial performance of a small number of environmental clean-up businesses, much of the real future promise for environmental technologies is in developing pollution prevention technologies -- processes and products that drastically reduce or eliminate pollution altogether.
Last year in his Earth Day speech, President Clinton directed the Commerce Department, the Environmental Protection Agency and the Energy Department to develop a national strategy to increase exports of environmental technologies. The strategy rests on three legs: supporting and encouraging continuous technology development to provide new solutions for environmental challenges; providing focused export support for United States companies, and forging a strong business-Government partnership to make it happen.
 
JEFFREY A. HUNKER
Washington, May 4
 
The writer is senior policy adviser to the Secretary of Commerce.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Melissa Cates, Roger Claman

 BODY:
Melissa Beth Cates, the daughter of Jane Cates of New York and Gilbert Cates of Los Angeles, is to be married today to Roger Lloyd Claman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Claman of Somers, Conn. Rabbi Judith Lewis is to perform the ceremony at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook, N.Y.
The bride, 35, is the senior lawyer for business affairs at Nickelodeon, the cable channel, in New York. She graduated from the Claremont Colleges and received her law degree from the University of San Diego. Her father, a television and motion picture director and producer, is dean of the School of Film, Theater and Television at the University of California at Los Angeles. He is also the producer of the Academy Awards. 
 The bridegroom, 34, is the vice president of sales at Rosco Laboratories, a manufacturer of television, film and theater supplies, in Port Chester, N.Y. He graduated from Emerson College. His mother, Irma Claman, is a librarian for Somers High School. His father, now retired, was the vice president of Economy Electric Supply in Manchester, Conn.

HEADLINE: Save the Watershed

 BODY:
One of New York City's most precious capital assets is the 2,000-square-mile watershed that stretches northwest of the city for 100 miles on both sides of the Hudson River. For 150 years, the watershed and its reservoir system have supplied New Yorkers with cheap, high-quality drinking water. But decades of careless development and shoddy regulation have put the watershed at risk. If the system is not cleaned up in three years, the Federal Government will require New Yorkers to pay as much as $8 billion to build a filtration plant and $300 million annually to operate it.
This would be a ridiculous price to pay for something that New Yorkers now get virtually free. It is also an avoidable price, but only if city and state politicians are prepared to summon the energy -- through personal visits, town meetings and the like -- to woo upstate residents whose cooperation is crucial to the watershed's salvation. 
 New York City has long had the power to regulate development in the watershed. In 1909, the State Legislature gave the city authority to acquire property around its reservoirs and to regulate economic activity on adjacent lands. Basically, that meant control over sewage -- everything from barnyard manure to the effluents flowing from housing developments and office buildings.
Trouble is, the regulations were rarely enforced. Local residents got the idea that they could do what they liked with their property and development proceeded rapidly, first in Westchester County, later in Putnam County and now in the Catskills -- the three main watershed areas. Faced with the massive costs of filtration, the city has decided to enforce its powers, and upstaters are aggrieved.
Mayor Rudolph Giuliani thus finds himself in a classic environmental struggle, pitting private interests against a larger public good. Like David Dinkins before him, he would be asking upstaters, many of them poor, to accept restrictions on their assumed right to develop their property to help city dwellers many miles away. The numbers are on the Mayor's side. The watershed serves one-half of the state's population -- 8 million in the city and 1 million in the watershed itself. But the watershed issue turns as much on emotion as on logic and Mr. Giuliani will need all powers of cajolery to win it.
The warning flags have been up since 1989, when the Environmental Protection Agency found rising levels of contaminants in the city's water supply and gave the Dinkins administration what seemed a simple choice: develop by December 1993 a plausible plan to protect the watersheds or be prepared to filter. Mr. Dinkins was slow to confront the problem, but last year he and his Environmental Commissioner, Al Appleton, devised new regulations, hired new people to enforce them and committed $439 million to upgrade septic tanks and sewage treatment plants and to purchase 80,000 acres of buffer zones around the reservoirs and the streams that feed them.
The E.P.A. then gave the city a three-year extension to carry out the plan. That sounds like a lot of time, but nothing in New York comes quickly or easily. Upstate residents complain that the new regulations on septic tanks and sewage treatment will soon make it prohibitively expensive to build new businesses and homes. Last month, a group of 45 Putnam County developers filed a $9 billion suit against the city, charging that their property had been prospectively devalued without compensation. But the city's plan to save the watershed is not the bad deal that many watershed residents think it is. Despite complaints about a "land grab," for example, the city will buy land only from willing sellers and will pay taxes on what it does buy -- indeed, New York City is already the largest taxpayer in the Catskills. Moreover, even though new businesses will have to build septic tanks instead of discharging their waste directly into streams, the city plans to spend more than $200 million on municipal waste treatment -- a considerable subsidy to hard-pressed localities.
Questions of fairness aside, what is at stake here is a larger issue of environmental stewardship. To give in to filtration is to concede that New Yorkers cannot strike a sensible compromise between man and nature.
