HEADLINE: Europe's Next Giant Step

 BODY:
In an important vote the other day, the European Parliament opened the way to admitting Austria, Sweden, Finland and Norway to the European Union. Thus what began in 1957 as a six-member common market can by next year grow into a European Union with 16 members and 370 million inhabitants. That would open frontiers for free movement of people and goods from the Adriatic to the Arctic Circle, from the Hebrides to the gates of Russia. Americans are only beginning to catch up with what this epochal change may imply.
It was widely predicted that the vote in the 517-seat parliament in Strasbourg would be close. In fact, it was a blowout: in the first of four votes, Norway was approved with 374 in favor, only 24 against and 58 abstentions; the approval margins were about the same for the other applicants. This bodes well for the next hurdles, four national referendums, beginning in Austria on June 12 and concluding in Norway on Nov. 26. 
 Polls show strong support for Austrian approval, and Finland, worried about its unsteady Russian neighbor, is expected to follow suit. Swedes are undecided, and the prickly Norwegians, who have quarreled with Europe over fishing rights, may again vote down membership, as they did in 1972. But in light of the Strasbourg vote, it is also possible that momentum and enthuasiasm may build, carrying the day for a 16-state Europe.
This would be more than a common market. All citizens in the Union would elect representatives to a parliament with limited but real legislative powers. All would share benefits (and some of the constraints) of an interconnected monetary system. All member states have votes, proportionate to their size, in a Council of Ministers that has final authority on common legislation and that can speak for the Union on foreign policy.
But moves to greater integration, embodied in the 1991 Maastricht treaty, have collided with popular fears of ceding too much power to bureaucrats in Brussels. As important, the unification of Germany increased Germany's population by a third, upsetting the old equilibrium with France and Britain, stirring fears of too much German influence in a too-united Europe.
Notwithstanding these disputes, there are sound reasons why present members would like to broaden the union by admitting Austria and the Nordic trio. The average per capita income of the four countries is 40 percent higher than the European Union average, so the newcomers will be net contributors to compensatory funds for poorer regions and subsidized farmers. More important, enlargement can restore sorely missed vitality to the campaign for European unity and prepare the way for future membership of four new candidates, Poland, Hungary, Slovakia and the Czech Republic.
Europe's self-confidence has skidded as its unpopular governments contend with stagnant economies. And long-buried nightmares were revived by Europe's inability to stop the ethnic slaughter in former Yugoslavia. In this fallow season for Europe, suddenly there is something to cheer about. The overwhelming parliamentary vote is good news for those who believe in open frontiers, free markets and democratic institutions. If for the moment Europe's political union cannot deepen, at least it might continue to widen.

HEADLINE: South Africa Sanctions Didn't Undo Apartheid

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Anthony Lewis notes in "Help From Outside," his May 6 column celebrating the role of sanctions in the victory over apartheid, the important part Sir Robin Renwick, now British Ambassador in Washington, played in encouraging President F. W. de Klerk to release Nelson Mandela and facilitating negotiations. 
 But Mr. Lewis misses the salient point behind Sir Robin's extraordinary effectiveness. He would never have been able to play this role had he not represented a government that steadfastly resisted sanctions. This is what allowed the British to retain the access and influence in Pretoria that United States diplomacy effectively lost the moment Congress overrode Ronald Reagan's sanctions veto in October 1986.
Up to that point, our opposition to sanctions had given us the necessary cover and running room to engage not only the South African Government, but also the South African public on internal and regional issues, much to the annoyance of the truculent P. W. Botha. As he saw it, once Congress had shot its arrow, the American quiver was empty.
Fortunately, the much maligned policy of constructive engagement lived on in Whitehall. Judging by the many expressions of esteem by Nelson Mandela and the African National Congress leadership for the roles played by Margaret Thatcher, John Major and Sir Robin, they understood this diplomatic dynamic.
Symbolism and domestic politics aside, the declared purpose of the Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act was to use economic pressure to force the South Africa Government to negotiate. But by the time Congress acted, the markets had already concluded that South Africa under P. W. Botha was not the place to put -- or keep -- your money.
As we kept warning, these sanctions of the financial market were the ones the South Africa Government had to fear most. It is now generally acknowledged that the 1985 decision of United States and other leading banks not to roll over short-term loans was far more consequential than any of the later legislated sanctions. (South Africa developed alternative markets and continued to run sizable trade surpluses.)
That year also marked the beginning of secret negotiations. With United States encouragement, Justice Minister Kobie Coetsee sought permission from P. W. Botha in 1985 to accept Nelson Mandela's offer to start talking. If anything, these talks were dealt a setback by the 1986 sanctions vote, since P. W. Botha never wanted to be seen to act from weakness and reverted to his repressive, counterrevolutionary mode.
In the end, two unpredictable events dramatically accelerated the timetable for South Africa's negotiated revolution. The first was that in 1989 P. W. Botha suffered a stroke, giving an increasingly restive National Party the chance to rid itself of his oppressive yoke, and to install F. W. de Klerk in his place.
The second was the Soviet empire's sudden implosion. This allowed Mr. de Klerk to remove the National Party's bogyman of the "total onslaught" as an obstacle to legalizing and negotiating with the A.N.C. and its formal ally, the South African Communist Party. Mercifully, it discredited the A.N.C.'s socialist role model.
Understandable as it is for sanctions supporters now to pat themselves on the back, the real credit belongs overwhelmingly to two remarkable leaders, Nelson Mandela and F. W. de Klerk, and to the millions of South Africans of all races who supported their statesmanlike course.
 
HERMAN W. NICKEL
Washington, May 8, 1994
The writer was United States Ambassador to South Africa 1982-86.

HEADLINE: Administrative Costs Make Tuition Soar

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Cost of 4-Year Degree Passes $100,000 Mark" (Education page, May 4) quotes Charles H. Long, Yale deputy provost, complaining of the costs of "scholarly periodicals, library books and scientific equipment, which rise in cost at a rate higher than inflation." 
 Figures from the Association of Research Libraries show that Yale cut its library expenditures 14 percent, from 5.42 percent to 4.65 percent of total educational and general expenditures, in the 1980's.
The growth of bureaucracy that Daniel S. Hamermesh notes in your article is more responsible for increased costs that affect tuition. The Digest of Educational Statistics 1993 states (page 167), "Administrative expenditures (institutional support and academic support, less libraries) have been rising more rapidly than most other types of college expenditures." Table 329 and its predecessors show higher education library funds dropping nearly a percentage point from the 1970's to 2.2 percent in 1992, the lowest since the Depression, a difference of $478 million.
Max Weber observed the nature of "the bureaucracy" to perpetuate itself, using its considerable power to do so. This includes a certain amount of secrecy and doubletalk to protect the bureaucracy from public criticism and control while it devises schemes that result in hiring more deputy provosts. Consider the cost of the busywork involved in the Ivy Overlap Group's annual retreat to standardize scholarship offers to multiple applicants (called "price fixing" by the Justice Department); in sharply rising cost of "compliance" with Government research grant administration; in marketing and orientation parties that didn't exist 30 years ago.
Meanwhile, the library collections essential to the research, education and public service missions of the university have been unfairly downgraded. It's time universities thought, like I.B.M., United Technologies and other large organizations, about downsizing. Cut the fat; build the bone.
 
ALBERT HENDERSON
Bridgeport, Conn., May 4, 1994
The writer is editor of Publishing Research Quarterly.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;
Broadway Business Blues? Well, Cross the Street.

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
For commercial real-estate brokers on the Upper West Side, it is an age-old debate: Is the west side of Broadway north of 72d Street really financially superior to the east side, a mere 80-foot stroll away?
Many say it was ever thus, calling the east side of the street a lonely "frontier" that has yet to be successfully settled, and citing west side commercial rents that are often 30 to 40 percent higher than equivalent space just across the pavement. 
 Others call it a myth. "If a merchant is a good one, he's going to do well no matter what side of the street he's on," said Benjamin Fox, executive vice president of New Spectrum Realty Services.
But for many merchants who have chosen to try the east side, the difference is real indeed and serves as an apt illustration of the often Byzantine difficulties of doing business in the heart of the Upper West Side. It is a neighborhood known for having the savviest of New York's savvy customers, a clientele that, despite its wide diversity, seems to operate as a solid buying bloc. They can be fiercely loyal to certain businesses while closing down others in months.
"I honestly believe that Darwin's theory of survival of the fittest is more actively at work there than any other place in the city," Mr. Fox said.
In the last year, Broadway has entered a renaissance, with the opening of the Barnes & Noble superstore at 83d Street and a Filene's Basement at 79th Street. Several chains, such as Banana Republic, Cosmetics Plus and Lechter's housewares, have also discovered the street in the last decade.
But while many retailers have poured considerable effort into trying to join the street's west-side success stories -- Zabar's, Fairway Fruits and Vegetables, Citarella fish and meats, H & H Bagels and Harry's Shoes -- few have held on for long, especially those who believed that customers drawn to these anchors would bother to cross the street.
The most publicized example was J. Bildner & Sons, an upscale food store, which opened in 1987 on the northeast corner of 74th Street across from Fairway. Although it tried to woo customers with mahogany counters and crisply uniformed attendants, it closed after about nine months.
And just last month, another east-side food store, Adriana's Bazaar, closed after less than three years in business. While its products, exotic spices and herbs and Moroccan pottery, seemed to fit the neighborhood, its owner, Rochelle Zabarkes, said it was simply too difficult to draw enough customers into her store. "I think it's just that people are creatures of habit, and here more so than anywhere else," Ms. Zabarkes said.
Theories abound about why the difference between the two sides exists. One is historical, attributing the west side's dominance to the fact that the neighborhood's more affluent residents have traditionally lived between Riverside Drive and Broadway. However, with the rejuvenation of commerce and housing on Columbus Avenue and, more recently, Amsterdam, that is changing, real estate experts say.
Another theory is that Broadway is simply too broad in the 70's and 80's, with four lanes of traffic and a grass divider with benches in the center, and customers drawn to the anchor stores tend not to cross the street.
Despite the disparity, real-estate brokers and store owners alike are quick to point out that no matter which side a store is on, it must survive the neighborhood's strict scrutiny and win its trust quickly to survive.
Even the best location and name do not guarantee success. For example, a diet food chain, the Muffin Lady, opened next to Zabar's, in what Mr. Fox calls "probably the best retail space in the country" in 1991. It lasted little more than a year. A Kiddie City at 79th Street was also short-lived.
"It might sound like a cliche, but Upper West Siders really try to get good quality for their money," said Bruce A. Rosen, a neighborhood resident and an associate planner with the City Planning Commission. "We are successful, but we are not as rich as the East Side, and so we're careful. If you don't give us something to cross the street for, we're probably not going to cross the street."<? RANDY KENNEDY

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
The Soul-Searching Downtown

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
DOWNTOWN Manhattan just cannot shake that empty feeling. Prozac won't help.
For all the money being made on Wall Street these days, the heart of New York's financial district is remarkably quiescent. Since the peak in 1987, lower Manhattan has lost 100,000 workers in a wave of corporate cutbacks and an exodus to newer and better-equipped offices in midtown, Jersey City and elsewhere in the metropolitan area. Coupled with the overbuilding of the 1980's, that has left a lot of the owners of downtown's office buildings crying the blues. 
 Many of downtown's pre-World War II buildings, proud stone monuments to a bygone era, are more than half vacant. Over all, almost a quarter of the space in older, unrenovated buildings is unoccupied. Lacking the extra height per floor needed for today's high-tech offices, and beset by woes like asbestos contamination that make renovation particularly expensive, perhaps dozens of buildings cannot generate enough rent even to cover their operating costs, let alone generate a profit on investment.
For the owners, as well as city officials, that vast empty space poses a stark quandary: Can those buildings be salvaged, or is their economic future so hopeless that they should be demolished?
Joseph B. Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission, sees the future of downtown Manhattan as perhaps the greatest development question facing New York City. "We're committed to the revitalization of lower Manhattan, no question," he says. "The issues require immediate attention. Downtown has to adapt to a changing economy and a changing market."
But how?
Some real estate owners would love to see a number of older buildings torn down, helping to push up rents on those remaining by reducing the vast overhang of empty space downtown. They say the land can be converted into small parks, to be banked for years, even decades, until demand for new downtown office buildings returns. Many city, state and regional officials appear to be sympathetic to those concerns.
On the other side, preservationists believe that most of the buildings, particularly those with historic significance, are worth saving. They argue that as the recovery catches on, newer, smaller companies will look downtown if affordable space is available.
"Some ways of trying to revive downtown could end up destroying it," said Peg Breen, president of the Landmarks Conservancy. "In the longer run, we'll be better off if we re-use as much as we can."
Meanwhile, foreign investors -- particularly from China, India and elsewhere in Asia -- are seen by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey as a dynamic market to be lured downtown as the city expands its role in the global economy.
Last fall, the City Planning Department proposed bolstering the downtown business community and tourist industry through tax breaks, city financing and zoning changes.
It also recommended a Business Improvement District, similar to those operating in midtown Manhattan. That is now moving much closer to reality. So is a renovation of the plaza in front of the World Trade Center and its underground shopping concourse.
But many of the other plans remain just that. Improvements in mass transit, including the long-discussed Second Avenue subway, are little more than dreams. Talk of luring more people to join the 7,000 people living in Battery Park City and the 7,000 others scattered throuhout the area has not translated into anything concrete.
"I wish I could give you the trigger event that will begin the turnaround downtown," said Barry F. Sullivan, chairman of the New York City Partnership, a business group. "But I can't do that."
 
STEVEN SPINOLA
President of the Real Estate Board of New York
 We're seeing a change in philosophy in City Hall. For years, we've been calling for programs to convert some of the obsolete buildings from office to residential space. We're clearly getting better feedback from the Giuliani administration.
As for demolition, it would be nice to get 3, 4, or 5 million square feet of office space off the market. Beyond that, demolition doesn't make sense. Still, many of the older buildings don't have the floor size or high enough ceilings or the ability to bring up the right amount of electricity for higher-tech tenants. They can't compete anymore.
One of the reasons they are not being torn down is because they have more square footage than the current zoning permits. Under the old zoning, the limit was a million square feet; if a landlord tore down a building and built a new one now, it would be half that. Owners are better off keeping the old buildings up. We should grandfather in old zoning requirements. It is a way to get some space off the market and open up some sites for public space for a number of years and still permit construction of buildings when the market rebounds.
 
ROBERT FITCH
Author of "The Assassination of New York"
 They've been trying to fix up downtown for the last 60 or 70 years. It's a continuing crisis. What's happened is that New York City got the notion that it needed two downtowns, or one comprehensive downtown from 59th to Battery Park. It was an exaggeration of how much downtown can maintain. It's not needed anymore. It can't compete. Transportation is too much of a problem. No one wants to get out at Penn Station and Grand Central and get on the subway and go downtown.
Downtown is the one place no one ever talks about the free market. The only way it has been made viable is through immense subsidy -- the World Trade Center and all its progeny. We should adopt the physician's motto, "do no harm." Fold your cards. Stop throwing more money in the pot. We should envision downtown as part of a comprehensive strategy to achieve economic diversity in New York City. Otherwise, we'll go in the same direction -- giving more subsidies to elite office people and driving out industry.
As for Giuliani, downtown represents his base. I don't see him kicking his base below the waist.
 
 
STANLEY BREZENOFF
Executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey
 Lower Manhattan should be the gateway for New York to reach out to the rest of the world. Our goal is to make the World Trade Center the anchor for an reinvigorated downtown. With more restaurants and shops, if not a 24-hour community, at least we can have more than a 10-hour-a-day community. We're looking to foreign investment. We want to improve transportation, particularly with the greater use of ferries and express buses. Downtown should also be a tremendous tourist mecca, what with the Statue of Liberty, South Street Seaport, the observation deck of the Trade Center already here. But it's underutilized. It's time to get the word out.
Still, you have to be realistic. Some of the older office buildings are not easily adaptable, either to residential use or to current commercial demands. They have very limited futures. You may have to think about razing them and replacing them with mini-parks until it is time to rebuild.
In a pure economic sense, downtown is in a position to rebound. Rents are now competitive with those around the region and with those of most other cities in the country.

HEADLINE: HOME ENTERTAINMENT;
New Off-Ramps On Info Highway For Couch Potatoes

BYLINE: By HANS FANTEL

 BODY:
THE INFORMATION superhighway, charted by the Clinton Administration as a main road to the American future, is likely to cut right through some familiar areas of home entertainment. At present, two different kinds of enterprises collaborate in the field: Content companies, like film studios and other production companies, provide the entertainment. And conduit companies, like television networks and cable broadcasters, distribute the goods.
Relations between the two have been quite cozy in the past. As long as relatively few channels were available, the studios could ration out their product to broadcasters under mutually protective agreements. 
 But with the coming of the communications superhighway, these distribution patterns will be radically undermined. With hundreds of channels available through fiber-optic telephone lines, direct broadcasting satellites and other alternative delivery systems, traditional broadcasting may be replaced by networks of quite a different sort.
Future entertainment networks are likely to resemble the world-spanning links that now connect computers. Moreover, the conventional television set is likely to give way to home computers linked to large screens. This will enable the home screen to serve both as an entertainment center and a display for interactive information services.
These prospects are widely discussed these days among long-range planners in the electronics trade. Some believe that what they call the telefuture will not be shaped by the widely publicized mergers of the electronics industry with film studios -- such as the acquisition of 20th Century Fox by Sony and of Universal Studios by Matsushita, the parent company of Panasonic. Rather, they feel that an onrush of computer technology will alter the face of home entertainment.
The leading exponent of such iconoclastic ideas is George Gilder, who has been called a techno-visionary. This label doesn't quite fit, for Mr. Gilder is firmly enough rooted in the realities of the market to function as a management consultant in the communications industry, and parts of his new book, "Life After Television" -- to be published this month by Norton -- have been serialized in Forbes, a magazine for hard-nosed investors.
"The computer industry is converging with the television industry in the same sense that the automobile converged with the horse," declares Mr. Gilder.
But for all the apparent hyperbole, he musters impressive arguments. He points out that the 33 million personal computers already in place in American homes form a far better and more versatile base for distributing entertainment and information services than existing broadcast channels and conventional TV sets.
Interactivity is the key to the latest forms of entertainment and information services, allowing the viewer to respond to and influence the presentation on the screen. But "interactivity, almost by definition, is a computer function, not a television function," Mr. Gilder claims. "Making the boob tube into an interactive hive of theater, museum, classroom, banking system, shopping center, post office and communicator is contrary to the nature of the box."
Only the personal computer, says Mr. Gilder, holds out hope for realizing these multiple services that have been dangled before the public. And while present technology cannot yet fully answer these needs, chances are that the computer industry -- rather than the television industry -- can rise to the challenge.
In a recent interview at his octagonal home in the Berkshires of Massachusetts, Mr. Gilder expanded on these ideas. His predictions are based on the computer industry's spectacular capabilities. According to Gordon Moore, chairman of the Intel Corporation, the number of transistors that can be placed on a single chip doubles every 18 months. Moreover, cost-effectiveness rises by the square of the number of transistors crammed onto the chip. Cost-effectiveness also rises sharply with the number of computers linked to communications networks. These combined economies point to a future in which computer networks will form the main distribution method for interactive services.
If telephone companies eventually make good their promise to bring fiber-optic lines to everyone's doorstep, they will create nearly unlimited access to entertainment programming and alphabetic and pictorial data bases. And since these new pathways can carry high-quality signals to be displayed on already extant high-resolution screens, high-definition television -- too long waiting in the wings -- will be a moot issue.
One reason Apple and Microsoft are not chasing the studios or networks with merger bids, Mr. Gilder believes, is that the computer companies know they already hold a winning hand.
"It doesn't matter that the studios own the movies," says Mr. Gilder. "With so many channels available on the information highway, the producing companies will not be able to maintain any form of monopolistic control. When the pipe is wide enough to carry everything, they won't be able to restrict their product to a few preferred outlets. The technology will force the market open."
LEGALLY THIS ARGUMENT leaks. After all, copyright remains in force no matter what the technology. But Mr. Gilder emphasizes that throughout economic history, monopolies have yielded to the pressure of broadening demand. This has been true from the royal monopolies on tobacco, sugar and spices in the 17th century to the more recent attempts to control the distribution of oil. Moreover, it often proved more profitable to serve a large open market than a narrowly controlled one. Mr. Gilder believes that in our time, under the prod of the new technology, entertainment and information services will ultimately follow the same historic pattern.
Profound changes are seldom abrupt, and the broadcasting industry will probably do everything in its considerable power to delay or derail any shift to other delivery methods.
The prevailing view at a recent New York conference under the aegis of the Satellite Broadcasting and Communications Association was that traditional television will continue to serve the mass market while the new alternative methods will cultivate niche audiences.
As one participant put it: "We already have a fully operational, fully satisfactory and fully interactive communications medium. The telephone."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 36; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 960 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By Laurel Graeber

 BODY:
THE ROAD TO WELLVILLE
By T. Coraghessan Boyle. Penguin, $10.95.
For the characters in this novel, the road begins in 1907 in Battle Creek, Mich., where they are guests at the sanitarium of Dr. John Harvey Kellogg, the inventor of cornflakes and exponent of rigorous and purgative cures. The author's "prose is a marvel, enjoyable from beginning to end," Jane Smiley said here last year.
LENIN'S TOMB: The Last Days of the Soviet Empire
By David Remnick. Vintage, $14.
Winner of the 1994 Pulitzer Prize for nonfiction and named one of the best books of 1993 by the editors of The Times Book Review, this account captures the period from 1988 to 1991, when the Soviet Union -- and Communism itself -- was collapsing. Mr. Remnick gives detailed portraits of the people involved, from Soviet leaders and party functionaries to ordinary workers. Last year our reviewer, John Lloyd, said, " 'Lenin's Tomb' is an extraordinary confluence of observation, hard work, knowledge and reflection; a better book by a journalist on the withdrawing roar of the Soviet Union is hard to imagine." 

SO FAR FROM GOD
By Ana Castillo. Plume, $9.95.
In a small town in New Mexico, a Chicana woman and her four daughters undergo a series of trials including, but also transcending, death. In this novel of magic realism the mother, Sofi, "loves, she accepts; in the face of loss, she creates," Lisa Sandlin said here last year. "Not much in life is more miraculous." Ms. Castillo's earlier novel SAPOGONIA: An Anti-Romance in 3/8 Meter (Anchor/Doubleday, $9.95) has been reissued as well. Revised since its original publication in 1990, the book concerns a pair of lovers who hail from the mythical country of the title: a place that is the homeland of all mestizos. One reviewer called it "both beautiful and lyrical." There is more of the Latin American experience in TO BURY OUR FATHERS: A Novel of Nicaragua, by Sergio Ramirez, translated by Nick Caistor (Readers International, $11.95). The author, a Sandinista leader and the country's former vice president, frames his nation's political struggles in terms of a friendship between two soldiers that ends in betrayal. Their story "continues today . . . fact and fiction virtually indistinguishable," Shirley Christian said here in 1985. Earlier history is the focus of MEXICAN VILLAGE, by Josephina Niggli (University of New Mexico, $16.95). First published in 1945, this collection of interrelated stories depicts life in postrevolutionary northern Mexico. The author is "a storyteller in the fine tradition," Mildred Adams said in The New York Times.
UNFRAMED ORIGINALS: Recollections
By W. S. Merwin. Owl/Holt, $12.95.
A poet celebrated for his use of words recalls a childhood in which there were few words at all. His father, a Presbyterian minister, presided over a household essentially devoid of books or meaningful conversation. In 1982 our reviewer, Joyce Carol Oates, said Mr. Merwin creates "a haunting and frequently disturbing portrait." The same publisher has also reissued Mr. Merwin's two books of prose poems, HOUSES AND TRAVELLERS and THE MINER'S PALE CHILDREN ($12.95 each). "I like the air of intelligence in the pieces, always ready to meet the unexpected," Robert Bly said of "Houses and Travellers," published in 1978. In 1970 our reviewer of "The Miner's Pale Children," Helen Vendler, said of these works, "Desolation and abandonment shading into terror are more common than any other feeling."
MAKING THE MUMMIES DANCE: Inside the Metropolitan Museum of Art
By Thomas Hoving. Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $13.
Before the author became director of the Met in 1967, the museum's reputation was snobbish and staid. Through Mr. Hoving, the institution gained a gift shop, a glitzy temple, more contemporary art and, as he proudly notes, many more visitors. "His peppery, outspoken, at times gloating narrative . . . is astonishingly candid and unreserved," Arthur C. Danto said here last year.
PAST IMPERFECT: French Intellectuals, 1944-1956
By Tony Judt. University of California, $14.
Jean-Paul Sartre, Simone de Beauvoir and other left-wing philosophers are taken to task for being apologists for Stalinism and for failing to criticize the concrete forms their ideology was taking in postwar Eastern Europe. Last year our reviewer, John Sturrock, said Mr. Judt makes his case "with an admirable clarity, an economy of words and a command of his sources."
RIGHTEOUS DISCONTENT: The Women's Movement in the Black Baptist Church, 1880-1920
By Evelyn Brooks Higginbotham. Harvard University, $14.95.
At the turn of the century the Baptist Church was both the foundation of black American community life and an agent of social change. The author shows how a growing feminist thought helped not only the church's female members fight discrimination, but the entire black population as well. "The result is an important, sophisticated and richly instructive book," Suzanne Lebsock said here last year.
LISTENING TO PROZAC
By Peter D. Kramer. Penguin, $12.95.
The popular antidepressant mentioned in the title is the springboard for a meditation on nature versus nurture and the cultural implications of the use of drugs that may be able to alter personality as well as cure ills. Last year our reviewer, Daniel X. Freedman, said that the author, a psychiatrist, has written a book that is "entertaining, provocative, irritating and often originally insightful." Penguin has also reissued Dr. Kramer's MOMENTS OF ENGAGEMENT: Intimate Psychotherapy in a Technological Age ($10.95), an exploration of the relationship between the therapist and the patient. In 1989 one critic said, "His is a voice of earnest, unashamed speculation and reflection." LAUREL GRAEBER

HEADLINE: Broader Backing for the Buick Classic

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

DATELINE: HARRISON

 BODY:
IT is 8:30 on a bright May morning and several corporate outings are already in full swing at the venerable Westchester Country Club here. The club holds scores of similar golfing events a year, but none as prestigious as the Buick Classic, a premier event on the P.G.A. tour. Taking place at the peak of the golf season, June 6 to 12, it serves as a warmup for the United States Open a week later. The tournament, which has been a fixture at the Westchester Country Club for 27 years, has been sponsored for the last four years by the General Motors Buick Motor Division.
The Classic is also a strong fund-raiser for hospitals. Contributions are raised through the sale of various business-entertainment sponsorship packages like the Pro-Am tournament or corporate hospitality tents. For years, large corporations had an opportunity to dispense corporate hospitality by becoming a sponsor. 
 "That was the pattern," said Lawrence Dwyer, president of the Westchester County Association, a business group. "The Classic, which itself is a showcase for Westchester County, was always identified in people's minds with large corporations. Corporations recognized that there was nothing like the Classic for entertainment, corporate recognition and networking opportunities and for exposure. The event is always telecast and, for example, 50,000 people attend the Classic in one day alone." But society is changing.
Mr. Dwyer said that with the advent of the electronic age smaller businesses are being established and are able to do business with fewer employees. "Currently in Westchester 90 percent of the businesses have fewer than 20 employees and 80 percent have less than 10," Mr. Dwyer said. "They also would like a piece of the action of the Classic, and we felt it was time to find a way they could also participate at a price they could afford."
Now, he continued, for the first time, for the relatively modest sum of $1,500 any company can be associated with the county's No. 1 sporting event by buying a new product: a Classic 5000 corporate package, he said. The package is aimed at the 27,000 businesses in Westchester County that have never been able to afford to participate in the event before.
Frank Boccanfuso, head of F.M.B. Real Estate Services in Purchase and one of the founders of the Classic 5000 and a sponsor, said, "The concept behind the Classic 5000 package is to give smaller companies like mine the same advantages large corporations enjoy from being part of such a prestigious event."
 
The Effort to Broaden the Base
 The effort to broaden the base of participation of small and mid-size businesses -- defined as those generating sales of $2 million to $100 million yearly and employing 20 to 250 workers -- began with a meeting last fall with Mr. Dwyer and Thomas A. Williams, general chairman of the Buick Classic and chairman of United Hospital.
"Larry Dwyer wears two hats," Mr. Boccanfuso said. "In addition to heading the Westchester County Association, he is also an avid golfer, and he has a special interest in the Classic since he has been in charge of the marshals for four years. He and and Tom Williams realize that a new marketing strategy was needed to broaden the base of participation in the event. After Joe Armentano, who owns a mid-size business, Paraco Gas, and I talked to them, we contacted other businessmen and formed a committee to find ways to increase the opportunities for a company like ours to participate.
"We went out, and we literally sold them on the idea of the Classic, and the response was very good. We expect in future years it will even get better."
 
Similar Features
 To date 70 companies have bought the new Classic 5000 packages. Mr. Armentano, said: "These are companies that have never been able to participate in the Classic before. They bought packages that range from $1,500 for the bronze up to $10,000 for the gold.
"Basically, all the packages have the same features. They are just expanded at the higher end. The $1,500 package, for example, includes 10 hospitality tickets to the large air-conditioned Classic 5000 tent that will be especially erected and all food, which is lunch, snacks and an open bar, cocktails, plus 15 grounds admission tickets and two preferred parking passes, an invitation to a cocktail-orientation party, a business profile on a sponsor board listing and a listing in the spectator guide and pairing sheets. It's really a terrific deal."
Bennett Kielson Storch & Company, an accounting firm in White Plains, is one of the new participants. Nicholas DeSantis, a partner in the firm, said: "With the exception of the 'big six' accounting firms, we are the largest accounting firm in the Hudson Valley region. Yet although I personally love golf and we always bought spectator tickets to the Classic, we always felt it was too expensive for our firm to participate as a corporate sponsor, even though we knew how much we would gain by doing it: entertainments and exposure and networking opportunities. The Classic 5000 is a terrific concept. It makes it possible for us to have a piece of the action and make a contribution to the hospitals at the same time. We are really very excited about it."
Another new company is an architectural firm, A. R. Bacon of Purchase. Alex Bacon, head of the firm, said: "We have 12 employees. We do a lot of work, and we have some very prestigious clients, and it's very nice for a company like ours to be able to participate in this major golf event. I have been to the tournament as a guest of the large corporations in the past, and I certainly enjoyed myself and remembered it and the corporation that invited me fondly. Now I'm looking forward to inviting my clients and some of my employees. I think it's a great way to build good will at a price a firm like ours can afford."
 
One of the Top 3 Money Raisers
 Mr. Boccanfuso reported: "We still have space available for about 24 more companies. May 25 is the deadline for participating."
Annabelle Marvin, the Classic tournament director, said: "It is great to see the business community get behind this event. The net proceeds of the money raised through the Classic 5000 packages are an additional source of money for area hospitals."
Raising money for hospitals is more important this year than ever -- to allow hospitals to keep providing quality service, said United Hospital's Mr. Williams, who observed that the Westchester Classic perennially ranks among the top three of the 42 P.G.A. tour events in charitable dollars raised. Since 1967 more than $22 million has been raised by the Classic for United Hospital, 12 other hospitals in Westchester and the American Diabetes Association.
Mr. Armentano added: "In these hard economic times, we are really pleased that we have found a new marketable product in the Classic 5000. We have already raised more than $150,000 in new money and, within the next few years, we expect the Classic 5000 committee to be raising $1 million a year for community hospitals."
Those wishing information about Classic packages or other tournament opportunities should get in touch with Ms. Marvin at 967-5356.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joseph Alonzi of Westchester Country Club checks for frost recovery with Annabelle Marvin, director of the Buick Classic. (Lenore Davis for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Stamford and Norwalk Join to Revive Manufacturing

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
IN a joint project, Stamford and Norwalk will try to revitalize manufacturing in southwestern Connecticut by renovating 240,000 square feet of industrial space.
Backers say the project, which involves one industrial building in each of the two cities, will be undertaken in cooperation with private businesses. And they say it could bring private investors back into the industrial real estate market. 
 The project will be financed by a combination of the state's Economic Diversification Fund, private investment and $200,000 in cash and/or services from each city. The state's $60 million fund was enacted last year as a onetime effort to address problems created by Federal defense cutbacks.
"There is no speculative cycle right now," said James E. Banks, director of marketing and business development for the Norwalk Redevelopment Agency. "The banks got burned and the developers got burned, so unless there's a tenant willing to sign a long-term lease and wait for construction, a project is not going to happen."
Joseph M. Ercolano, vice president of Sacia, The Business Council, said a recent survey by the organization had found 54 percent of the manufacturing companies contacted interested in expanding in the next few years. Sacia stands for the group's former name, Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association.
"When they talked about what was preventing them from staying in southwestern Connecticut, the lack of available space was a major consideration," Mr. Ercolano said.
Christopher L. Bergstrom, the Economic Development Director for Stamford, estimated that there was a demand for 200,000 to 300,000 square feet of industrial space among young companies that had outgrown their first buildings.
"The traditional sources of financing for developers have dried up," Mr. Bergstrom said. "There are niches like this one where there is clear evidence of demand. But the space isn't going to get built, because no one wants to finance these buildings without a firm commitment, and the companies that need the space aren't big enough or patient enough to wait for a speculative building."
The project is even more feasible because both buildings are in Federal Enterprise Zones, making manufacturers eligible for a variety of tax breaks and job-training grants.
"This capital-development project involves only the sites in Stamford and Norwalk, but it has the support of the entire region because of the impact it could have," said Richard C. Carpenter, executive director of the South Western Regional Planning Agency.
Jim Roberts, a spokesman for the state's Department of Economic Development, which will distribute the new state funds, said that while a final decision on the project would not be made until later this month, "I can say this is the kind of project we really want to see happen."
One advantage in the project, he said, is that it involves more than one city. When the Economic Diversification Fund was created last year, the legislature said that the money should be used for regional projects.
Janine Johnson, a spokeswoman for the Business Council, said that the South Western Regional Planning Agency had submitted a grant application to the state for the Stamford-Norwalk project.
"THERE are a lot of people who have become real believers in the regional approach to economic development," Ms. Johnson said.
She said the eight-town group was already looking into other regional projects, such as telecommunications links between the cities.
Stamford is proposing to use $2 million in its state allotment for renovating a 160,000-square-foot industrial building at 17 Amelia Place owned by General Electric Investment Corporation. The corporation will add $2 million for the task.
Mr. Bergstrom said there was a strong market in Stamford for "flex" space -- part office, part research and development laboratory, part manufacturing and part warehouse, usually renting for about $8 a square foot.
"The space we have of that type is virtually 100 percent occupied," he said.
Mr. Bergstrom said that 17 Amelia Place, formerly occupied by an engineering company, could be easily converted for four or five small users, companies that could generate a total of 300 to 350 jobs.
Once that project is rented the owner would get bank financing and the grant funds would be available again. Stamford has identified a 22-acre tract owned by Heyman Properties as a possible second project.
"We envision cycling these funds every one to two years," Mr. Bergstrom said.
Norwalk has proposed renovating an 80,000-square-foot building in the 500,000-square-foot Nash Engineering industrial complex on the waterfront.
Mr. Banks said that Nash, which makes industrial water pumps, had already moved its manufacturing operations to other states and announced recently it would move its corporate offices to Trumbull by the end of the summer. Two decades ago Nash employed about 750 people in the complex.
That will leave 500,000 square feet of vacant industrial space on Norwalk Harbor, which should be viewed as an opportunity, Mr. Banks said.
"I don't imagine we'll be able to create more than 1,000 jobs, but that's a lot better than the 75 there now or the zero we'll have there in August," Mr. Banks said.
Trafalgar Inc., which makes leather goods such as high-fashion Ghurka handbags, will put up $4 million to buy a third of the 21-acre property. A state grant of $2 million would go toward renovating the 80,000-square-foot building. Trafalgar has 250 employees and hopes to grow to 450 by the end of the decade "and we want them to grow here in Norwalk," Mr. Banks said.
DR. EDWARD J. DEAK, a professor at Fairfield University and an economist for the New England Economic Project, said opinion was divided on offering incentives to manufacturers.
"This kind of assistance is going to be available to companies if they move to the Southern states, and if Connecticut is not prepared to offer the same kind of inducement it can't compete," Dr. Deak said. "But it's not without its problems."
For instance, he said, when assistance is given to one manufacturer, other companies will want the same help. Also, with many states wooing manufacturing plants, the cost of the incentives package goes up.
"The bidding war for manufacturing jobs has escalated substantially over the last five years," Dr. Deak said. "But giving up on manufacturing jobs entirely doesn't make sense, either."
Still, despite a perception that manufacturers are abandoning Connecticut -- Dr. Deak said that since 1988 Connecticut's manufacturing jobs had dropped from 417,000 to 300,000 -- southwestern Connecticut continues to have many manufacturers.
Mr. Ercolano of the Business Council said that the Federal Commerce Department estimated that there were 1,700 manufacturers in Fairfield County, with some 100,000 employees.
"Manufacturing is still a pretty good proportion of our economy, about 25 percent of our employment base," Mr. Ercolano said. "And manufacturing means high-skilled, high-paying jobs."

GRAPHIC: Photo: James E. Banks, of Norwalk's Redevelopment Agency, at the Nash Engineering industrial complex. (Janet Durrans for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Island School Districts Bracing to Meet Increases in Expenses

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW 

 BODY:
SCHOOL districts planning for next year are facing rising expenses over which they have no control. Those costs are mainly a result of increasing enrollments, expired union contracts, necessary building repairs and state mandates that districts have to pay for.
For most districts, shrinking revenues from declining property values and lost state aid in recent years have led to rising budgets, translating into tax increases next year of 4 to 7 per cent across much of the Island. 
 Districts are continuing to wait to find out the state-aid package for next year. The aid is part of the budgets, which are now more than a month past their deadline of April 1.
In voting this month voters resisted school budget proposals. In the first week 15 of 41 were rejected, the highest rejection rate recorded since 1989 for the first week of balloting.
The president of the Nassau-Suffolk School Boards Association, Dr. Bruce Brodsky, said although school boards had been sensitive in trying to keep tax increases minimal, they had been burdened by the cost of state mandates without the financing for them.
Districts face, for example, mandates for handicapped students that may be quite costly. Last month the state revised its Least Restrictive Environment policy. According to a spokeswoman for the Education Department, Jennifer Sneed, the "least restrictive environment" means putting handicapped students in special classes or special schools only when the nature or severity of the handicap is such that even with supplementary aids and services education cannot be satisfactorily achieved.
Placing a disabled student in such a situation provides that the special education that the student needs, preferably with students who do not have disabilities, is in a location as close as possible to the student's home.
For districts that formerly placed the handicapped in outside programs or schools, Ms. Sneed said, integration into regular classrooms may add significant expenses in personnel, equipment and services.
"The 'least restrictive environment' mandate," Dr. Brodsky said, "goes hand in hand with the philosophy of inclusion, which has become the new word in the education of the handicapped, to include these students in the regular classroom whenever possible. Aside from concerns that inclusion might cause a great deal of disruption to education and that special-education students might not have their needs best served by being in the regular classroom, a stricter enforcement of least-restrictive environment has the potential for tremendous costs to local districts.
"If special equipment is required for students with communication difficulties or additional personnel is needed to assist the students the burden of the expenses falls on the school district. Although New York State has not yet mandated full inclusion we're moving in that direction."
All districts have special-education committees to place disabled students.
The Federal American With Disabilities Act of 1992 adds to the burdens. That law requires all public buildings to be accessible to handicapped people, with wider doorways, restrooms, telephones, drinking fountains, elevators and full access for wheelchairs.
The Superintendent of Suffolk Boces 3, Dr. Daniel Domenech, said districts had been planning for two years to make the modifications and had acted to comply with the law. Most districts have made the required renovations or have plans for them this summer, he said, adding:
"But money has been a big problem for many districts on the Island. It's difficult to do major capital improvements when voters defeat the school budget. In this situation school districts are caught between a rock and a hard place, between complying with a Federal law and their inability to do it, because they don't have the money."
Many districts have included money in their budgets to comply with the Federal disabilities law. Long Beach allocated $50,000 to renovate the high school auditorium to make it accessible for the handicapped.
One of the biggest expenses can be elevators. South Huntington will install an elevator in one building at a cost of $130,000. The Interim Superintendent, George Jackson, said if handicapped students were unable to go to programs on the second floor, the programs were duplicated on the first floor. "If we couldn't bring the kids to the program," Mr. Jackson said, "we brought the program to the kids."
The Herricks School District in New Hyde Park says financing is not available for elevators in the high school and community center. Until the money is appropriated, a library and science laboratories with stations for handicapped students will be added on the first floor of the high school at a cost of $50,000. That would make all programs accessible to all students, said Superintendent Sidney Freund.
An elevator costing $140,000 will also be added in the Early Childhood Building of the Hewlett-Woodmere schools, with an additional $40,000 in the budget to review and analyze the provisions for the handicapped. Superintendent Bert Nelson said most districts were feeling financial pressures when they made costly changes to comply with laws on the handicapped. "The American Disabilities Act is much like oatmeal," Dr. Nelson said. "It's not always easy, but it's good for you and the right thing to do."
 
Requirement for Fingerprinting
 Aside from special-education mandates, districts face expenses from other state requirements, as well. The president of the Nassau County Council of Superintendents and Superintendent of Rockville Centre Schools, Dr. William Johnson, said although each mandate was not significantly costly individually, "when you take them collectively they impact the school budgets."
He cited a new state requirement to fingerprint and train security workers. "This is an area of tremendous turnover in staff," Dr. Johnson said. "It may cost only $1,000 to $2,000 to train and fingerprint each employee, but when you multiply that by the number of people being hired it becomes a real burden."
Starting next year a breakfast program will be required. Superintendent Elliott Landon of Long Beach said although details had not been finalized many districts would have longer school days and higher costs for personnel, transportation and supervision.
Another mandate, under the Federal Clean Air Act, is to start car pools next year. Dr. Johnson said each district had to develop a plan that would go beyond encouraging employees to car pool. "School districts will be responsible and subject to penalties if their employees don't comply," he said, "which means more administrative costs for monitoring."
Car pooling could also cause other problems. "If teachers car pool together," Superintendent James Ruck of Sachem said, "a teacher who might have stayed late to work with students will have to leave because his ride is leaving. This mandate is a real Catch-22. We're school districts, not private businesses. We have no authority to force our staff to comply. Yet if we don't abide by the regulations we'll get fined, not the employees."
The New Compact for Learning, a state blueprint for education through the 21st century, also has many requirements for programs and staff development that districts have to support financially. The president of the Suffolk County Council of Superintendents and the Superintendent of Westhampton Beach schools, Dr. Ed Broderick, said the state did not back up its mandates with financing.
"If they mandate staff training, new programs or methods," he said, "they've got to keep their pocketbooks open, and they're not giving us enough help. It's especially unfair to districts that can't afford it."
Most districts also face the expense this year of catching up with building repairs and maintenance deferred since 1991, when the state drastically cut aid.
To prevent tax increases, Dr. Brodsky said, some districts used up their reserve funds to maintain buildings and purchase supplies. Dr. Johnson added that many districts were planning repairs that could no longer be ignored. In Rockville Centre, he said, brick work and roof repairs from damage in the winter are estimated to cost $300,000.
In Long Beach a $10 million bond issue has been approved for a 10-year program of repairs and renovations. Dr. Landon said the first phase, to repair roofs and replace windows, ceilings and rotted doors, would begin in the summer. Most districts have no choice but to begin similar repairs, he said.
In many districts, salary negotiations over expired teachers' contracts will also affect expenses next year. Dr. Broderick said that salaries had become a sensitive issue and that strong community reactions had led to stalemates in negotiations.
 
Pressures on School Boards
 In most districts, Dr. Landon said, 80 percent of the expenses are for personnel. Settlements have generally been authorizing salary increases of 3 to 4 percent.
"The public thinks that school boards have more control over salary negotiations than they really do," he said. "The pressure on boards from outside sources is tremendous, and they can't do what the public thinks they are able to."
Increased enrollments next year, particularly on the elementary level, may also require new hiring.
The state dictates that school districts have to provide personnel for students who do not speak English. Dr. Brodsky said the number of students on Long Island who spoke foreign languages and required special instruction had significantly increased in recent years, mostly with students from Central and South America, Asia and the Middle East. Dr. Johnson added that some districts would try to absorb the increased number of students and that others would have to add staff members. "School districts are trying to respond responsibly to tough economic times," he said. "There's a lot of pressure, but the bottom line is that many expenses are rising for reasons that school districts just can't control."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 29; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1157 words

HEADLINE: The Big Divide

BYLINE: By Madeleine M. Kunin; Madeleine M. Kunin's "Living a Political Life" was published this year. She is Deputy Secretary of Education.

 BODY:

BEFORE THE SHOOTING BEGINS
Searching for Democracy
in America's Culture War.
By James Davison Hunter.
310 pp. New York:
The Free Press. $22.95. 
ANY serious effort to expand the common ground between the fissures in the American political landscape is worthy of attention, if for no other reason than that polarization over issues from prayer in the schools to homosexuality and abortion erodes our capacity to govern.
Division is so intense that it not only precludes fair solutions but also diverts us from constructing answers to other pressing concerns, from education to health care. One need only recall the barrage of protest against President Clinton's initial policy for inclusion of homosexuals in the military to be reminded of how divided we stand. The eventual compromise -- a politically acceptable, if not universally satisfactory, resolution -- is only one sign of how desperate we are for new mediating voices and fresh strategies to bring us together. And that is why James Davison Hunter's new book, "Before the Shooting Begins," offers a welcome reprieve from the ideological battleground.
Mr. Hunter, a professor of sociology at the University of Virginia, presents "Before the Shooting Begins" as a "companion and follow-up" to "Culture Wars: The Struggle to Define America" (1991). In "Culture Wars" he described a fault line between "orthodox" and "progressive" visions that is fragmenting American society. In his new book, he uses the issue of abortion as a case study to analyze the sources of our national standoff. And as he says he did in "Culture Wars," he keeps himself at a safe distance from the conflict. The last thing that is needed is "the voice of one more activist," he says. "It is enough to see clearly."
"The deadlock over abortion and the problems it has created for the state in its claim to authority are repeated over and over again within the various issues of the culture war," Mr. Hunter writes. "Some are obviously more intense, enduring and far-reaching than others. In each, no matter what position the Government takes, its authority will be called into question by some. Cumulatively, then, the culture war posits a crisis of legitimacy for the modern state."
Mr. Hunter places his faith in the power of "serious civil reflection and argument" to unearth a new common ground, confident that substantive discussion will lead to deeper democracy. While commendable as sentiment, as strategy this is limited, because it lays too much of our division at the door of public ignorance and relies too much on the power of debate itself.
As is often the case, it is easier for the author to define the problem than to offer a solution. He dismisses as shallow the "pro-life" and "pro-choice" labels, which, he says, express a sentiment, not conviction or even a commitment. One could argue that it is precisely because the labels express a commitment that the divide exists.
"Democracy must be reinvented in every generation and for the circumstances in which each new generation finds itself," Mr. Hunter declares. Accepting the premise that a more thoughtful debate is crucial to that process, his reader is nevertheless prompted to ask: what practical ideas about their circumstances will emerge from his book to make it possible for Americans on either side of the abortion debate to believe that their sense of right and wrong is now protected and that it is time to lay down their arms? While it is admirable for Mr. Hunter not to reveal a thread of bias in his intricate weave of opposing positions, readers on either side may quibble with his interpretation of the facts or balk at the way he weighs every nuance of the arguments on an equal scale.
A section titled "Pro-Choice Tactical Interests" opens this way, for example: "A key tactical advantage of the pro-choice position is economic in nature. Abortion, in a word, is profitable." Yet a few sentences later Mr. Hunter notes that "fewer and fewer doctors are willing to enter the field." And it may be unfair to make the link summarized in this sentence in a section called "What Men Have at Stake": "Thus, when pro-life men refer to women seeking abortions as self-indulgent, they betray a broader discomfort with nontraditional views of sexuality, especially female sexuality."
Relying heavily on well-documented information in a narrative that is weighted with facts and figures, Mr. Hunter includes anecdotal stories about the consequences of abortion on two women in their 30's, both raised in Roman Catholic families. One turned to the church and became "very strongly pro-life in her views," and the other "tries to avoid talking about the abortion issue" and "copes by trying to forget the bad." Both women were deeply troubled, Mr. Hunter relates, as a result of their experience. These are, Mr. Hunter says, "only two of literally millions of stories that could be gathered." One wonders how they were selected at the expense of all the others.
The new common ground that the majority of Americans seek may indeed be emerging, but not where he thought it would, not from the middle of the abortion debate itself but rather from just a bit off center, around the issue of teen-age pregnancy. This is where the two sides have the greatest potential to converge, prompted by the recognition that neither women nor children will be protected if children continue to have children, dooming them equally to a life of poverty.
MR. HUNTER acknowledges these fledgling steps when he refers to the dialogue initiated between the director of Reproductive Health Services in St. Louis and the region's chief anti-abortion lawyer. Among other things, Reproductive Health Services and Missouri Citizens for Life cooperated on legislation to pay for drug treatment for pregnant addicts. Similar programs in Connecticut and Wisconsin are also cited.
Mr. Hunter is doubtful that local initiatives can be carried to the national level, and his skepticism may be justified. But concern over the high rate of teen-age pregnancy is increasingly part of the national debate, especially over changes in the welfare system. The discussion of abstinence, once dismissed as unrealistic by abortion rights advocates like myself, is now being given more serious attention as one option for some young girls.
Mr. Hunter opens "Before the Shooting Begins" with a chilling reminder of the rhetoric and the reality of violence that includes the continued threats of violence at abortion clinics; he closes with a call for "moral education," in schools, universities and the churches, to bring citizens to the point where they can respectfully live with disagreement.
"Alas, success," he writes, "is not measured in political terms but in social terms: in the de-escalation of tensions, in the development of a small measure of mutual understanding and in the outcomes of real people's lives." Would that not be progress?

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1778 words

HEADLINE: Failure of High-Flying Banks Shakes Venezuelan Economy

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela

 BODY:
In Latin America's worst banking crisis of the free-market 1990's, a string of failures since January has left half of Venezuela's banking industry in the hands of the Government.
Venezuelan taxpayers face a $6.1 billion bailout bill, as the Government props up nine banks, including Banco Latino, the nation's second largest. More banks may fail as inspectors unravel a five-year-long banking spree generated by deregulated interest rates and minimal Government supervision. This often resulted in banks offering rates for deposits that were far higher than were justified by loan demand. 
 "Eighty to 90 percent of the banking system is compromised in this catastrophe," said Oscar Garcia Mendoza, president of one of the strongest banks here, Banco Venezolano de Credito. "If you don't have policemen on street corners, bankers will run red lights."
The costly bailout is contributing to political instability. And while fugitive bank directors enjoy comfortable overseas exile, Venezuelans are paying for the bank failures with high inflation, reduced government services and shrinking economic activity.
For Venezuela's economy, today's financial crisis is roughly 10 times as severe as the failure of savings and loans institutions in the early 1990's was to the United States. The $105 billion savings and loans bailout represents 1.6 percent of the United States' gross domestic product and 7 percent of the projected 1995 Federal budget.
By contrast, Venezuela's $6.1 billion bailout represents 11 percent of Venezuela's gross national product and 75 percent of the Government's 1994 national budget. Banco Latino had 1.2 million depositors -- about 10 percent of Venezuela's adult population.
By setting interest rates far higher than sound banks, Banco Latino lured many depositors, then used the funds to build a lavish headquarters, charter jets for each director of the bank, throw lavish parties and make loans to insiders.
"There was absolutely no supervision," one American banker here said, reviewing the collapse. "The regulators weren't trained. They didn't have a budget."
Late last fall, when Banco Latino officials began to realize that their house of cards was collapsing, they started transferring hundreds of million of dollars overseas. In the final frenetic days, one bank director foresaw judicial orders on freezing assets and sold his million-dollar mansion, Another officer, Folco Falchi, the bank's coordinator for international investments, was reportedly seen loading suitcases stuffed with dollars into his corporate jet on the Caribbean island of Curacao.
After the authorities padlocked Banco Latino on Jan. 14, bank officers, operating from offshore refuges, entered the bank's computer elecronically with a modem and erased and altered thousands of records.
At the time, Venezuela's Superintendent of Banks, Roger Urbina, was buying race horses in Argentina. He decided not to come home.
 
Guidelines Ignored
 At the Deposit Guarantee Fund, Venezuela's equivalent of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Esperanza Martino, the president, apparently got the job in 1990 because she was married to the chief bodyguard of President Carlos Andres Perez, who was impeached last year for misuse of Government funds. Despite her training as a lawyer, the director ignored guidelines and concentrated almost half of the money for banking emergencies in only two of Venezuela's 47 banks: Banco Latino and a bank that collapsed in February.
The two regulators resigned on Jan. 21. Without displaying any urgency, Venezuela's Senate waited for three months to ratify their replacements. One legislator, Pablo Medina, charged that Congress's reluctance to investigate Banco Latino stemmed from past generosity by the bank's public relations department. With a $3-million-a-month budget, the department reportedly paid the bills of Banco Latino credit cards furnished free of charge to 36 congressmen.
Venezuela has no tradition of punishing white-collar crime. Three bank failures in the late 1970's resulted in one officer being jailed for one year.
In the Banco Latino case, a criminal court judge issued 83 arrest warrants in early March. The list was apparently prepared by copying names out of the bank's most recent annual report. The following week, the judge excused herself from the case, but left the arrest warrants standing.
Four months later, only 6 of 83 suspects have surrendered. Virtually all the others are believed to be abroad.
Venezuelans, displaying little confidence in their banking, legal or political systems, keep some $50 billion in foreign banks. Deposits in Venezuelan banks total only $12.7 billion. Venezuela's dollar reserves have dropped by 25 percent since the start of this year, a hemorrhaging that was worsened by the Banco Latino crisis.
The gigantic problems in Venezuela's small banking sector have their roots in a free-market change adopted by Mr. Perez when he was president: the freeing of Government-regulated interest rates.
"Free interest rates were adopted in 1989, but banking supervision was not adopted until 1994," Tesalio Cadenas, Venezuela's new Superintendent of Banks, said in an interview here. "That gap was responsible for the Banco Latino crisis."
With a relationship between the Government and the bank, ministries moved their accounts to Latino. The army and the Government-owned oil company put their pension funds in the hands of Latino trust managers.
Flush with money, Latino built a lavish high-rise headquarters here and decorated it with expensive oil paintings and sculpture. Expanding aggressively, the bank became a ubiquitous presence in this country, operating 101 branches, including one in the United States Embassy here. Affiliate banks were opened in Colombia, in Curacao (Banco Latino N.V.) and in Miami (Banco Latino International).
When a Banco Latino representative office was opened in Paris, the bank filled a Concorde with guests for an expense-paid weekend in Paris. The bank also bought a corporate jet for virtually every bank director.
 
Lax Loan Policies
 Struggling to keep up with rocketing deposits, Latino bankers made increasingly poor-quality loans. The same collateral was used for multiple loans. Loans were made to bank officers.
"You cannot apply Swiss standards to Spain," one director, Ricardo Cisneros Rendiles, said from Miami in a telephone interview. "Venezuelans are like some regional banks in the U.S. 15 years ago; there is a lot of community interest, everybody knows each other."
Building a real estate empire, the bank bought 500 office buildings, only to see the market fall. Speculating in the stock market, it invested heavily in Caracas's state electricity company at $10 a share in 1992. Today, the stock sells for $2 a share.
Without informing their Venezuelan depositors, Latino officers transferred millions of dollars in deposits to the Curacao affiliate bank. There, the bank did not have to meet Venezuelan reserve requirements or pay deposit insurance taxes.
Eventually, Banco Latino became a multibillion-dollar Ponzi scheme, a financial operation that could be maintained only by attracting more and more investors. Last year, the bank paid 105 percent interest on one-year certificates of deposit, more than double Venezuela's 1993 inflation rate of 46 percent. Depositors over 60 years of age received interest premiums of 3 percentage points.
But when Mr. Garcia of the Banco Venezolano de Credito publicly urged banking officials to investigate Banco Latino's high interest rates, the only reaction was a threat by the National Banking Council to expel him. (This industry group happens to be housed in Banco Latino's headquarters building.)
 
'Doing Dumb Things'
 "They were doing dumb things, but all the banks were," said Mr. Cisneros, a minority shareholder who said he was only actively involved in Banco Latino affairs when shareholders mounted a last-ditch attempt to save the bank in early January. "If it hadn't been Banco Latino, it would have been any other bank. The proof is that eight other banks are under receivership."
When the collapse came in mid-January, the Government suddenly had more than one million angry depositors on its hands. After one huge street demonstration, several depositors invaded a judge's legal chambers, where they waved toy guillotines.
Seeking to buy political peace, Venezuela's new President, Rafael Caldera, signed into law an emergency banking bill on March 10. This law retroactively raised depositors' insurance from $9,000 to $35,000. With 99.8 percent of savings accounts and 94.3 percent of checking accounts fully covered, Banco Latino reopened uneventfully on April 4 as a Government-run bank.
To placate some 2,000 depositors in Latino's Curacao branch, Government officials announced in early May that the Government would extend the $35,000 coverage to their previously uninsured deposits. The banks in Miami and Colombia are to be sold, and the Government hopes to sell Banco Latino, as well as the other eight other banks now under Government control: Banco de Amazonas, Bancor, Banco Barinas, Banco de la Construccion, Banco La Guaira, Banco Metropolitano, Banco de Maracaibo and Fiveca. To keep these banks afloat, the Government has pumped in $3.3 billion, more than the $2.8 billion in Government aid extended to Banco Latino.
"The idea is to privatize Banco Latino, the sooner the better," Edgar Dao, a member of the Government intervening board, said in an interview at Banco Latino's headquarters.
But many analysts believe that Venezuela's market needs only about 10 banks and that the rest will either have to be liquidated or merged with stronger banks. "They'll put Banco Latino on the block, but I doubt they will get a nibble," said Marco A. Gomez, president of the 78-member Foreign Bankers Association of Venezuela. "I don't know of anyone who wants a bank of that magnitude."
To prevent further bank frauds of Banco Latino's size, the Bank Superintendent's office is quadrupling its budget, is expanding its investigative team by one third and is seeking technical assistance from the United States Government.
As for the perpetrators of the multibillion-dollar collapse, prospects seem to be dim that they will ever be tried and convicted.
"I maintain that the presidents of many banks in Venezuela have signed many more balances with false figures than I ever have," Gustavo Gomez Lopez, Banco Latino's president until three weeks before the fall, wrote in March in a statement defending himself against charges of fraud, criminal conspiracy and undue appropriation.
